reviewText: Now the movie was hailed as a masterpiece BEFORE hardly anybody saw it including most film critics. Is it? Time will tell but I doubt it. Except for some ingenious editing, the movie ain't all that. Inception seems vastly over-hyped and will diminish in stature over the years after the Hollywood propaganda mill and glowing blurbs and buzz promoting ads have faded away. And after YOUR first impression.On this euphoric reception David Edelstein says, "It's as if someone went into their heads while they were sleeping and planted the idea that Inception is a visionary masterpiece and--hold on ... Whoa! I think I get it. The movie is a metaphor for the power of delusional hype--a metaphor for itself". Anyway, great controversy erupted over dissenting reviews, especially Edelstein's.My favorite thing about this movie is the conversation it spawned, or rather the subject it's reception generated interesting commentaries on.Recommended reading: The brilliant Jim Emerson's blog Scanners and his multiple entries on Inception, especially "On Liking and Not Liking". Emerson focuses on actual arguments.ALSO: "Seventeen Ways of Criticizing 'Inception'" right here-->[...]Upon first viewing I enjoyed the visuals but realized I'm (as with many people) less phased by new special effects than I used to be. I recall years ago being in awe of cutting edge effects. No longer. I'm simply expecting incredible effects to be a standard for any decent fantasy/sci-fi flick.I enjoyed the cast and some action sequences were fantastic.I found the logic(?)highly dubious if not incomprehensible, even tho _most of the movie consists of characters supposedly explaining the movie_.I feel the dream worlds are way too literal. WHY are these dream worlds "constructed" the way they are again? Why do....NEVER MIND. Asking why will lead to an infinite regression of whys and no doubt the internet will contain years of analysis explaining Inception.The plot really is absurd--not that absurd is always necessarily 'bad'. But I'll just say I am not fascinated by the epistemological puzzle. It seems we as viewers of the film are supposed to be and to the extent we are then--personally for ME anyway--Inception is a failure. Is he dreaming still? Who's dream is it? (etc.) I don't really care.
summary: first impression and PRE-release lavish reception

reviewText: `Inception' is a hard movie to judge.  Basically, it is a mind-bender, and as such should be judged by two criteria:  How good of a mind-bender is it? And, How much does it create a  realm of its own with phenomena and rules of causality that work consistently?In my mind `Inception,' despite some derivative elements, is an inventive movie that provides mind-enveloping reactions well after the viewing is over.  Much like Lynch's `Inland Empire' before it, the movie coalesces well into one's imagination and lingers in the mind for days to come.Being brief with the story is difficult, and I'm sure by now you've probably digested a great deal of material elsewhere.  Washed up on an Asian seashore, American businessman, Cobb (Di Caprio) meets with an elderly leader to obtain a contract and  defeat his enemies.  To accomplish this, he offers to perform an "extraction," a means of obtaining secrets from a person`s subconscious during one's dream life.  In the midst of their negotiations, an entire village riots and takes over the building where they meet, and Cobb and his sidekick, Arthur, (Gordon-Levitt) fight and flee to save their lives....In this beginning scene the lines are partially drawn between dreams and awakening, but the surrealistic landscape also provides Nolan ample opportunities to provide his trademark action-adventure for his science fiction saga.Cobb later meets an old professor (Caine) who sagely links him to a prodigy student, Ariadne, (Page) who can assist him with his next assignment and help straighten out his perspective and proper use of inceptions, or the use of subliminal persuasion, participating in another's subconscious perceptions and manipulating them during their dreams.  In their first assignment together, he plans to have a rich man's son and heir, Robert Fischer (Murphy) change his mind about his father's will, so he will be able to either obtain or sabotage his inheritance.There are dreams, and there are dreams within dreams, and one of Cobb's plans is to have three levels of dreaming going on at once to have the most persuasive power on Fisher.Intertwined are revelations from Cobb's subconscious, revealed with Ariadne, who joins him on his subliminal journey and witnesses some of his life-changing events with his wife (Cotillard).  In a partial revelation, Cobb admits he included his wife in some of his dream work with complications that has created strife in their relationship.As you might imagine, problems develop that make the operation work less neatly and easily as planned, so discerning what level of dreaming and what level of reality are taking place also becomes blurred.  The exposition and details are laid out more concretely than Lynch's worlds, but the caveats others have placed about paying attention are well founded.Besides the mood of mind-benders like Lynch's `Mulholland Drive,' Nolan has borrowed and alchemized elements from inventive movies like the truly excellent Japanese anime' adventure `Paprika' and movies like 'The Cell,' but the results are truly new and effective.I have to admit my biases.  I love mind-benders, and it's no accident that Christopher Nolan and David Lynch are at the top of my list of favorite directors.  This creates a problem because if you love mind-benders as a rule, it is sometimes difficult to separate effective works from those that don't work as well.I was originally wavering between four and five stars for this film based on the ending.  I'll give no details for that, but, I've decided, like 'Inland Empire' before it, `Inception' may seem abrupt, but its import as a surrealistic experience is nearly as mind-altering.  'Inception' deserves attention, awards, multiple viewings, and the time needed for a truly rewarding film experience.  If you love Lynch's work, you will probably also love 'Inception,' but one could concede this movie isn`t as effective at playing with your noodle. On the other hand, if you find Lynch's films to be frustrating or too abstract, then Nolan's 'Inception' may give you a more satisfying sense of concreteness and closure overall.(Tom Berenger and Ken Watanabe join an outstanding cast for a taut movie experience.)(Some loose ends of `Inception' have been tightened from information from imdb.)
summary: "An Elegant Solution for Keeping Track of Reality"

reviewText: When "Inception" was in the theaters, I chose not to believe the hype and skipped it.  Then I watched it on DVD five months later: WOW!  Yes, it borrows some elements from other movies (especially "The Matrix" and "Dark City"), but the concept is endlessly fascinating and the execution is absolutely perfect: not one dull moment, not one botched line of dialogue, not one clumsy edit!  Christopher Nolan is in the big leagues now ("Memento" and "Batman Begins" bored me to tears, but "The Dark Knight" and "Inception" are amazing).  James Cameron and Peter Jackson replaced two has-beens named Lucas and Spielberg; now they (Jackson maybe, Cameron definitely) are about to be replaced themselves.

reviewText: I regret the decision to watch this online before seeing it at an IMAX theater. The SFX are impressive enough without it but I can just imagine how mind-blowing it would be to experience the film in that format - especially when viewing it for the first time.As many other reviews have stated, this is a mind-bender. I thoroughly enjoy a story that draws you in and demands your full attention to keep up with the details because you don't want to risk getting left behind.You need to be able to think outside the realm of what is typical and tangible, and concentrate on trying to keep track of a series of events that appear to be reality mixed with others that seem impossible. What might at first seem to be a barrage of unrelated, mundane, confusing or abstract elements are critical parts of the final outcome.It may sound like a strange comparison, but I was reminded of movies like Donnie Darko. The story continually makes you question what is real ... what might happen if the characters choose a different decision or course of action ... and what is it all leading to?

reviewText: Ever since he spun the "Batman" franchise on its head half a decade ago, there's been an increasingly significant level of quality expected from writer/director Christopher Nolan. If his latest creation is any indication, Nolan sure knows how to execute a brilliant idea even when under the most intense of pressure. His latest affair, the mind-bending "Inception," stars Leonardo DiCaprio as a thief who extracts thoughts and ideas from people by entering their dreams. When a job goes wrong, he is offered a chance at redemption. This time he has to introduce an idea into the mind of a subject rather than steal it away. It's an easy enough task, right? Wrong. As he soon finds out, plunging into the depths of uncharted waters is especially tricky when carrying your own personal baggage. To quote Arnold Schwarzenegger in "Total Recall": "It's the best mind**** yet!""Inception" boasts an impressive cast. DiCaprio aside, we are treated to some of the finest young talent Hollywood has to offer by way of Ellen Page, Cilian Murphy and Joseph Gordon-Levitt. The actors - while excellent in their roles - are but a pawn in Nolan's game. Fact of the matter is he could have cast a group of no-names and the film would still be as great as it is. The true star of the film is not only the insanely well-crafted script which will have you second-guessing yourself at every turn, but the stunning visuals that accompany it. Watching this movie is like stepping into an alternate universe where anything you could imagine is possible. Nolan asks us to suspend disbelief as we follow the film's characters through layers of dreams. Because the script is water-tight and the visuals so flawless, we are fooled easily enough. Like children, we believe whole-heartedly in what we see unfold before us even if we aren't quite sure of how it all works.While Nolan has had a pretty consistent track-record thus far, it still comes as a shock that "Inception" is as good as it is. The term is thrown around loosely all too often, but the film is a heavy contender for best film of the year. More than that, though, this is Nolan's masterpiece. The director's perfectionist streak shows through in a film that truly has no flaws. It may take a few viewings to completely wrap your head around, but there is not an inch of celluloid wasted. There is not a line uttered without importance and not a special effect that looks artificial. To step into the world of "Inception" is to step into another dimension where films can still be magical and blow the minds of even the most jaded of movie-goers. A dream come true indeed.Oh, and was I the only one expecting to hear Tom Petty's "Free Fallin'" during the scenes where the van falls off the bridge? I hope not.

reviewText: I can try a review.It's full of spoiling, please stop.Inception is a movie made by a guy that apparently took ten years framing his message, that has written other movies that explored consciousness or self in some manner (The Prestige for one). From what I have read in Wiki and on-line since seeing the movie he made a decision later in the creative process to fit the movie to a "heist" format -after considering a "horror" genre. Within that I found some imposition of a form onto an idea that reminded me of how we compromise to bring to form something within an "industry" or sell an idea-but perhaps that is unimportant to this. However it is worth noting that he had the idea and searched out the form-within an American movie set of definitions.The movie tells the story by opening with a scene key to the ending-it will rather repeat with some differences at the end, rather enigmatic, and we are rapidly pulled into something that has to be sorted in our psyche and understood. Again a form from cinema...I got this. There is a person played by Leonardo DiCaprio who "with a team" is capable of entering the dreams of others and taking information. He is hired or coerced or persuaded to take on planting a dream-a different construct-within a corporate person in exchange for his freedom from some charge against him. All of that is rapidly unfolded.The dream capability-of sharing and entering them- is said to come from the "military."It appears -these threads-within great deals of technological structures of danger, chase (so like one  dream state),threat, feats of unbelievable strength, dexterity, so on fit what we see, but generally you are pulled into the story of a guy compromising I think, and using his "skills" as a dream inhabitor-or someone navigating those "realities" that has technologically found ways to enter others dreams and interact there to suit his purposes which on the surface seem high espionage-he now in the movie has a mission that frees him to be able to join his children and be freed of some criminal charge.His children are as shadows in this movie.So on one level you watch a deal be made.I want to say a kind of pact with the devil, but my daughter has reassured me this initial set up is "how all heist movies function." From the "deal." For me early on in the movie I was watching this as a deep moral compromise that seemed to be saying, just one last "job" or wrong, and everything will be right.Inherently a bad thing.At that point I was uncomfortable, and doubted that anything after it would -no matter how it was acted, completed, or done, nothing seemed to flow from such a thing that would not be problematic. Rather like war to attain peace, or someone avenging, or the use of terrorism within a cause. It just seemed to me to enter into a deeply compromised situation.It's funny but at that point, early in the movie, I was aware of just such deep disappointment. Because of that I flashed a thought to the horror genre, and to thoughts I personally have about our culture and its compromises in making technology a god. For what it is worth.Anyway....I'm tempted within this to tell the storyline to you but I don't recall all the names, all the references. I did not go intending to write about it- so I am a poor source for the story-line.  It's available though pretty credibly done on Wiki. I read it coming home and it represents it pretty well.I will however comment on how I took the movie.The character DiCaprio played was evidentally trained in this art of invasion of dreams by a professor played really briefly and gauzily by Michael Caine. Sad his part is limited to almost nothing. It also appears that this is the father of his dead wife-who we will learn lives in his dreams to haunt him-and he goes to Caine to get an "architect" for his new dream invasion last mission having had his architect suffer some incredibly bad something we saw at movie's start....a person that can construct a dream scape so that he can pull the characters into this place-without knowing its secrets himself entirely- to be safe from his wife who functions as a negative-and then to act out his mission. He wants a girl really, a young student, to agree to design for him and in record time this person agrees. That struck me because she remains the character in the movie that is the least compromised, most caring, most intact in terms of an ethic, most idealized-and yet she enters into this deal supposedly intrigued by the fact that she can construct this multi-layered dream context rapidly and with little question.Nothing like a compromised innocent.I suppose a Madonna.She is empowered in that way and the dream world she is sold on as so creatively powerful and entrancing-so that for her merely just being in this world once is not enough. So she "must" do it.From then on she acts as protector to the other characters without question. Totally in.So there are scenes as he sets up his team, dangerous, unbelievable ones, and we learn what they are going to do and why.Basically get into a corporate heir's head and plant the idea he's to break up his father's empire on his death. This a Chinese businessman who has leveraged him by "getting to" DiCaprio, offering him the one thing he wants-to be able to be with his kids again. Movie start scene.That's why Caine "helps" him to gain the girl, and to enter the process of designing a three level dream world. Father of the daughter-in -law.So I really don't have it in me to narrate the entering of the three levels of dreams they design to get this "job" done, all the tricky film-atic stuff, all the things that go so wrong, all the symbols, all the connections, and do it justice. It's quite a tangle. But to get the idea planted the characters have quite a set of rules, levels, dangers that will thrill anyone who is deeply wedded to technological movie wonder. Or to dreams and psychology I suspect.It involves one heck of a lot of shooting.What happened for me was I started following a few themes.The character has lost his wife.She reappears in different ways to stop him, to scuttle him, to pull him further into a dream world. Eventually this gets "explained" as his demon, his guilt, what drives and haunts him.He isn't able to entirely free himself from this projection we are told in his mind of this wife Mal. Incredible name. She's negative, she's difficult, cruel...sexual, needy, shallow, so many things but an adversary...he remains full of guilt associated with her "real" death-tortured by it-she has occupied this dream world with him in "the past" and both undoubtedly are driven crazy from it-but she broke...Broke. So I took from this that she represents what damage comes, the warning, the siren, what can go so" very wrong" from dreams/reality issues.From fooling in this stuff.When your dreams and your reality come up against the limits of the mind perhaps. Or against man as god. She went crazy from an idea he implanted in her, we learn, to bring her back to reality from the dream world. And he's left with his image/projection of her in his mind-that appears in the shared dreaming- from her real suicide caused as she endeavored to take them both through death back to this dream world.Neat huh?Oh well....I still struggle to sort whose dream we are in, whose dream was escaped from, how an open end could be interpreted and I couldn't really present all of it here...and I'm sorry for that.As I watched about 3/4th's through in scenes with archetypal protectors attempting to kill the protagonists in the first of three dreams within dreams (each with very different time space perceptions) I thought of my mother. Yes, my very frail aging mother. For reasons I won't go into at length.It was very strange because it was too real.It was very strange, unconnected, but it took over my concentration for a bit.I had the realist sense of my being unable to face her death, being too weak for that, unwilling to do that-how it would be crushing to my psyche, too final, too sad, just it was a very deep feeling. I guess it was grief, regret, but I was sorry for me in that-I said almost aloud-"I'm too weak for this." Right in the most intensely inappropriate final solution scenes.I sat with that- somewhat like several nights before I sat thinking of the finality of death-mine/my kids, just sat...and only slowly re-entered the logics of the movie.I looked at this movie as a discussion of realities, of what is real.I've studied this through religions, physics, through reading for 40 years...and I'm not sure that I feel that gets enhanced in a heist movie, or against a western backdrop of shooting, archetypes, stereotypes,technological gimmicks....maybe. I'm not sure that you really get to these issues within that context exactly...so for me it pushed in that direction but under constraints and limitations of genre, money, movies...the duress of enduring the genre.The movie poses that we can plant ideas within another's dreams that become real and driving for them. AND This loops me to my mother. Interestingly.It's a movie. It explores notions like this amazing technological thing we are creating, it is looking at the functions of the psyche set within a landscape consistent with American cutting edge movie making-it has gravity free fight scenes and the elements advanced gamers will love-its got the language and feel of this futuristic world ...but somehow I related back into some pretty deep struggling I've had over the years with ideas around someone entering our psyche- profoundly altering and destroying  our safety/security fears.The invasion aspect disturbs me still.I came out of the theater having a lot of that pushing around in my head as well as I tried to hold onto my realities.I'm a dreamer. I often retreat into dreams. One of the things I do know about myself is I often prefer the world asleep.I say this because I thought about it after the movie.Thought about dreams and their function. Thought about "what is real" -thought about illusions.The movie for me was a vehicle for that kind of traveling.But my reactions are so personal I guess I can't step away to really write a decent "review" because I'm not sure anyone else would be that interested.Sorry...this is a sure let down as a review but a fascinating movie. Worth a watch perhaps.--

reviewText: I can not say it is boring, but I had a hard time to finish watching it. Lots of meaningless actions, gun fights packed to the eyeballs, "mind bending" talking about what nobody including actors understands. Comparison to "Matrix" or "Memento" is just laughable.  Plot is ridiculously complicated in a bad way and poorly executed.Center piece dream design is underdeveloped. Heck, it's not even tried! It feels like any freshman from "Mind Bending Academy" is genius enough to do the job somehow. Yeah, there is a silver case with a big button and some sort of tubes to connect to the dreams, yet dream is full of other peoples, which is explained via sub conscience.For some strange reasons beyond me sub conscience is a bitch: always aggressive and ultra violent, military trained and is using firepower without hesitations. No guns? Fear not, it can still tear you apart with bare hands, just like dead men in "Resident evil" or hivers in "I am a Legend". Which is good - if you are dead, you awake.The whole idea to plant the idea is secondary. First things first, ACTION! It's non-stop, it's 24/7 without any reason and regrets. Who cares why? As long as it blasts, shoots, burns, cuts, hits, kills, tears, drives, drowns, climbs, flies - it's goodStupendous action reaches its peak in the best Bond-like tradition when heroes are storming fortress in the remote snow covered mountain region. So they ski, they shoot, they climb, etc. Throw in Aston Martin, shaken martini and famous "my name is Bond, James Bond" and it could be easily disguised.There is no logic anywhere. Events are disconnected. Ex-wife factor is overdone and happy end with kids is unexplainable: why would they jump to unknown alien who says he is the father? Yet there he is with eyes and tears. This movie may work for someone who likes shooting, but why so many emotions then?Movie has a couple of fresh ideas, like recursive dreaming, 12x time stretching factor when you re-enter (although 12x is obviously not enough, it should have been 100-1000 times judging by the length of the movie and time needed for the van to reach the water in the free fall from the bridge). So I stretched too and gave 2 stars, but overall I do not agree with positive reviews here and almost regret my promotional $5 spent towards renting this movie.The good thing I did not spend real money on it. I do not want to watch it second time even for free, never mind buying the disc.

reviewText: Inception  is an intricate film: in its storyline, its sets and its special effects. The film is a psychological heist drama that questions the boundaries of dreams and reality and incorporates all that is generally known and perceived to be occurring in the dream state. This film contains plenty of shoot-them-up and blow-them-up scenes to rival the average blockbuster, but Inception stands out due to a fine script, more than capable cast, and the mind-boggling questions it raises.The film has a traditionally Christopher Nolan feel to it, particularly the very last scene that leaves the viewer to provide the ending that he or she feels inclined. I watched the 6:00 p.m. Monday showing of the film and the AMC theater was quite crowded. At the end of the movie, every single viewer groaned. But the expression was a response to the realization that the film's director wasn't about to provide all the answers.The reason Christopher Nolan's movies -Memento,The Prestige,The Dark Knight (+ BD Live) [Blu-ray], etc. - are fascinating is because Nolan is able to get his audience to invest in his characters and to believe the world he has created, but Nolan never manipulates his viewers or gives the Hollywood version of the happy endings that blockbusters are expected to have these days.Nolan is intrinsically original in his storylines and in his portrayal of those storylines and Inception is no different.I've heard the promotion for this movie asThe Matrixmeets Mememto. Such a comparison would not do Inception justice. To compare this movie toDark City (Director's Cut) [Blu-ray] would be to limit the range that Inception undertakes. Simply put, Nolan's latest film is based on the sci-fi films that precede it but it's original in its scope and execution.As one would expect with a Nolan film, the cast is an ensemble of some of the best actors, each of whom is able to share the screen without a grudge and to hold his or her own. Leonardo DiCaprio is fantastic in his portrayal of a thief who can penetrate the subconsciousness and extract and embed information at will. Both Ellen Page and Joseph Gordon-Levitt are the creme of the crop of those rarest Young Hollywood actors who are not only good-looking and youthful but are also talented. Cillian Murphy displays his naivete and boyish charm, whereas Marion Cotillard is rightfully convincing as the woman who insists of luring DiCaprio's character to spend eternity with her. And last but not least, Michael Caine proves once again that he is able to portray an old sage quite wisely.It goes without saying, but the special effects and stunts are simply stunning. The art direction of this film deserves the highest accolades and it's quite obvious that without convincing effects this film wouldn't be believable at all.In writing a review for the film, I came to the realization that I'm truly unable to the express how unique experience of watching this movie is. AWESOME is the only word that truly describes it, as in awe-aspiring fascination with the art of filmmaking and the way a filmmaker can stir up emotions and intellectual understanding in his viewers. This is the kind of film that needs multiple viewings to allow the viewers true immersion into the storyline and true understanding of the plot.

reviewText: Sorry for that uber-lame title, but INCEPTION could be interchangeable with THE GRAND HEIST easily. I never expected the 10 hour mission to be longer than 30 minutes, let alone much of the movie. In fact, my brain will never be the same again. Just like the pretty Ellen Page said: "It's pure creation."In this movie, Leonardo DiCaprio plays a thief. In fact, a dream thief. He knows the tricks to navigate one's mind. To perform a heist, he prepares an awesome team. He is the EXTRACTOR. Joseph Gordon-Levitt plays the POINT MAN. Ellen Page plays the ARCHITECT. Ken Watanabe is the TOURIST. Marion Cotillard is the SHADE. Cillian Murphy is the MARK. Tom Hardy does a James Bond when playing the FORGER, and Micheal Caine is there for a bit. :)Now that you know the actors, how did they perform. My goodness, they are first-rate. Best ensemble of the year. Leo is simply awesome. The whole movie rests on his shoulders. Joseph is great; he plays a likable guy and is badass in one of the most amazing fights I've seen. Page and Cotillard look great and act really well. Caine is there for a bit and does a great job. Ken i s great, Murphy is solid and Berenger is good.Like BLADE RUNNER, this movie shows us completely new ideas and never bores. The talky parts are vital to the story. In fact, just like BR, people will question where the story lies. There is a story in all that visual glamor, and a beautiful one. I knew what to expect of it and got a huge surprise. The story is powerful and touching.Now to the technical parts. The visuals are beautiful and used well. Not over-the-top at all; realistic as hell. The action sequences are hard-boiled and fast paced. Unlike other movies, you can't count how many there are. It's just so many put together. Since I'm an action-movie fan, the fact that there were so many in one sequence made me cry with happiness. Well, it almost did.There will also be people that will say it is original, but in years, we'll get better movies that use their ideas to full potential. I say:this movie is way ahead of our time, just like BLADE RUNNER was in 1982. To wrap it all up, INCEPTION is BRILLIANT. Christopher Nolan never disappoints. Through his career he has given us a masterpiece after masterpiece. His fans know his true masterpiece will be the one with the intelligent script of MEMENTO and the scale of DARK KNIGHT. INCEPTION is exactly this, but God knows how many times better.WATCH IT NOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! MOVIES LIKE THIS ARE RARE!!!Rating:10/10(WOW)

reviewText: This movie in my opinion was not only one of the best movies that I have ever watched but it is one of the most creative movies as well. Christopher Nolan has had his up and downs as a director but he sure hit home with this movie and I would not be surprised to see this movie win a couple of Oscars. The one thing about this movie is you are going to have to see it more than one time to get it. Even if you follow this movie closely without taking a break or getting distracted you still might miss something. That's how much detail is involved in this movie. I tell you Leonardo Dicaprio has another hit movie as well. I thought him in Shutter Island was amazing but this even topped that. I thought the idea of this movie had so many twists when you thought you had the movie figured out. For example there are times in this movie they are dreaming and wake up but in reality they are still dreaming and it's not easy to figure out. The mazes were designed so well in this movie as well. Near the end of the movie there are three or more different scenes going on because they are all dreaming at the time. The part that you're going to have to follow is the dead wife of Leonardo Dicaprio in this movie because she shows up so many times and is involved in so many angles. The problem is that he can't let her go even though she is dead because how much she loved him and that will play a crucial part in the movie later on. I feel the whole movie is good but the last 45 minutes of this movie will keep you on the edge of your seat. I will not spoil the ending for you but let's just say there are so many questions left to be answered after you see this ending. This movie was a huge hit. I saw it when it came out in theaters the first day and my parents got the DVD for me for Christmas. I am going to give this movie a perfect 5/5 and a strong recommendation to pick this a DVD up.
summary: Inception is a movie with twist, turns, and is breath taking. 5/5 movie and my movie of the year.

reviewText: This movie would be best loved by analytically inclined folks who love to `figure out' movies and talk through exactly what (and why) happened. The conversations generated alone would ensure the movie will stick with its audiences for some time and this criteria - that of `stickiness' long after the movie is over - is what makes a good film very good, if not great. Hence, the 4 stars.Undoubtedly, the dream-worlds the movie brought to the public imagination have been the main focus of discussion. What I'd like to focus on here is how the movie reflects our world itself, starting with a question almost crucial to the entire movie: Why does DiCaprio's totem keep falling in the movie? And how do we understand this in the light of the ending where it (almost) fell but didn't?I hope the following sheds light not only on our understanding of ourselves and the world we live in but also on the movie itself. So again, why does DiCaprio's totem keep falling in the movie?Layer #1 (Objectivity)...Because whenever it falls that's the Really Real World he's living in (and in which it keeps falling). As he explained to his female apprentice, the totem is the only thing which can confirm if he's dreaming or not i.e. in the end DiCaprio was NOT in a dream (Nolan was merely being playful by closing off the scene at approximately the moment when the totem would fall) - this seems the most likely (and least problematic) position.On this view, the totem served as a mark / leftover / reminder of Objective and True reality. We still know that we know something and so we need to hold on.Layer #2 (Construction)...Because, given the fact that we create our dreams (whilst simultaneously experiencing them), the totem falling was DiCaprio's own doing within his dream. Then again, it could've been a result of his continual (self?)-tormenting due to having spent half a century with his wife in a dream only to awake and have his wife kill herself. But after the final 'therapy session' when he 'dealt with' his (quasi-/un-) dead wife, his dreams then reflected his much improved condition. Summing it up: Subconscious/Wife haunting him = Totem keeps falling. Subconscious/Wife exorcised = Totem spins on and on (as when he meets with Watanabe at the start / after many decades in limbo) - the dreams we have both determine yet depend on the state of our hearts.On this view, the very symbol of Reality is our own construction and there's simply no way of knowing if we're dreaming or not. The movie provokes us to re-examine what we consider real or not, how we often lose touch with the actual for the virtual, how the virtual 'plants itself' into our lives and the consequences we face as a result. We now know that we do not know something and so we need to keep searching.Layer #3 (Chaos)...Because the totem, signifying our dreams, have 'taken over' us and has not only blurred our grasp of reality and  dreams but has subverted our very ability to ever find out. Humanity is thus locked in with an intrinsic-yet-external(!!) - a sub-trinsic? - element both inseparable from, yet in full control of, us i.e. our dreams. At least in the previous view, the problem was merely internal in that our ability to decipher reality from dreams has malfunctioned. On this third view, though, our sub-conscious (the deep 'Reality' in our very core) is a malignant force which takes hold of us.On this perspective, the entire movie was, of course, merely a dream but whose? Who's the dream-agent? Whose were the projections? Instead of us spinning the totem, it was really the totem spinning us. This view fits well with the unpredictability and out-of-control-ness which permeated the movie. In Biblical terms, the dream was like the sea with all its terror and splendor, engulfing Man with deadly (and largely unknowable) force.The Dream, then, is More Real than Reality itself and we can never stand far back enough. Inception, here, depicts realms beyond our control. We do not know what exactly it is we do not know, and so we need to adapt and fight a way forward in the unknown.Layer #4 (Obsession)...Most controversially, the answer to the question could be: Because our dreams have taken over us yet this is exactly what we want(!!). Recall DiCaprio's quixotic struggle with his dead-yet-alive wife, how he both truly wants to 'go home' yet at the same time can never get enough of the dreamworld. How, as master architect of the dream landscape, he alone FULLY knows the 'rules' and principles of the dreamworld yet remains 'possessed' somehow by his very own dreams in such a way that he continually (yet willingly and obsessively!) breaks the very boundaries he sets for others.The movie, on this view, brings us to face to face with a 'cut' in our universe, the site of which is our sub-conscious which - far from being 'hidden' - does in fact manifest itself in powerful ways i.e. it is the heart of our hearts about which we know not, yet from which can be loosed the most intense and terrible of desires. It's us in our most central yet also most inaccessible. It's that which drives us on yet which our rational minds reject; its desire in its purest because what it desires is to keep on desiring. This is what the totem represents: A never-ending fixation which in whatever position, whether spinning or stationary, looks exactly the same.Our dreams control and create us all, yet they are of our own planting. We are our own demons and angels, unwillingly yet lustfully embracing our self-created destructive and paradisiacal fates.Inception is not about giving answers (having one's desires fulfilled) nor is it about proposing new questions (having new desires) - it's really about the never-ending act of asking (desiring as an end in itself). Over and over again. At the deepest level of our lives, we do not know what we know and this is precisely what we yearn to keep on (not) knowing.
summary: DiCaprio's Totem : Objectivity, Construction, Chaos or Obsession?

reviewText: I have to start this review by saving if you haven't seen Inception yet -go see it. Seriously, if you haven't seen the movie stop reading this review now, get your butt down to the local theater and see this movie. I'll wait....Okay, seen Inception? Yeah, it's pretty freaking awesome. It's hard to say much beyond "genius," but I'll try. Honestly, Inception is one of the most intelligent movies I've ever seen that still manages to be thrilling, surprising and downright amazing. Most importantly, in an industry flooded with sequels, remakes, reboots and movies based on already-existing properties, Inception is actually original (shock). I know the advertising campaign tried to play it off as a mix between James Bond and The Matrix, which it kind of is (by a stretch), but Inception feels more like a high-budget indie film than anything else.In the world of Inception, the technology exists for individuals to break into others' dreams, create environments so they can "extract" certain information, typically an idea. Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is one of the best Extractors in the business, but after an extraction fails, he and his team are on the run from the powerful entities that hired them. However, an unexpected person offers Cobb a free ticket back home -and back to his children -if he can invade a certain person's mind and, rather than extracting a idea, plant one so deep and convincing that the person believes they thought of it themselves.Inception is as epic as the plot seems. From the beginning writer/director Christopher Nolan (The Dark Knight) throws viewers into an unforgettable and fascinating world where dreams and reality blur. Though the viewer is left clueless for the first 15 minutes or so, the introduction of Architect Ariadne (Ellen Page) offers a much-needed exposition dump and moves the plot into the complex web of a throughly thought-out, intelligent and fairly scientific examination of the human psyche and the shades that torment it.The special effects are pretty awesome too -somewhat reminiscent of The Matrix, but so strange yet familiar that they felt just like dreams should. One thing about the special effects that I really liked is the fact that there was very little CG, a Chris Nolan signature. Rather than being assaulted by very fake-looking CG, everything, especially the weightless scenes where characters are floating through the air, look real.Dare I say there are flaws? Well, maybe a few that some of the dissenters out there cling to -but that's being super picky. For me those flaws are length of the film and the lack of back story for any of the supporting characters. While I admit the length isn't too bad (a swift two and a half hours) I did kind of wish that I could pause the movie and take a few minutes to stretch a bit and well, let me my digest some of the epic awesome that was unfolding on screen. But as for the lack of back story for the characters aside from Cobb -yeah, that's a bigger deal. Since so much time is dedicated to what's going on in Cobb's mind that the other characters were thrown to the wayside somewhat -but I admit, I didn't even notice this until after the movie was over. While, of course, there will always be someone out there who dislikes certain movies, etc., I find it hard to believe that people could downright hate it.Easily one of the top films of the summer, possibly of the year or even the decade, Inception is an amazing piece of original cinema that should set a new standard for innovation in Hollywood.

reviewText: I know a movie critic isn't supposed to summarize at the beginning of his review, but I'll come right out and say it right now: "Inception" is the best film of the year! Now, I know there are at least another five months left in the year, but I've viewed the upcoming releases and, besides Ben Affleck'sThe Town (Extended Cut Blu-ray/DVD Combo + Digital Copy)and/or David Fincher's "The Social Network" having the only chance of disproving my statement, trust me, there aren't any more contenders. So I'm safe in calling this right now. With its movie trailers that recall shades ofThe MatrixandDark City (Director's Cut), "Inception" is brought to us by one of the best filmmakers today, Christopher Nolan (the man behind the successful - finally! - reboot of the Batman franchise). And while "Inception" does have a mind-altering plot like "The Matrix" and "Dark City," that's where the similarities end. The only description I will give besides stating that it's a cool heist noir film that balances drama, action and science fiction with one master stroke, is that the film revolves around a group of dream extractors lead by Dominic "Dom" Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) who rather than extract information from a target's mind, are hired to implant an idea in a new corporate leader's (Cillian Murphy) head, hence the title "Inception."Besides DiCaprio and Murphy, the rest of the cast are also spectacular: Joseph Gordon-Levitt (one of my favorite actors), Marion Cotillard, Ken Watanabe, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Tom Berenger, Dileep Rao, and brief appearances by Michael Caine, Lukas Haas, and Pete Postlethwaite. Nolan has always been blessed with great actors in all of his films (Memento (Widescreen Two-Disc Limited Edition),Insomnia,The Prestige, and the aforementioned Batman movies), so it's really no surprise that he gets the best performances. It also helps that Nolan is one of the best contemporary screenwriters and it is evidenced in all of his works. I heard that he is shepherding the next Superman film and, after first reading up on it, I was a little nervous because I've heard reports of him and screenwriter David Goyer handling it like it's never been done before. However, after viewing Inception, I am completely comfortable with his handling a character for which I have such a strong affection.It's surprising to hear that for many of the film's spellbinding (and mindbending) sequences, rather than using CGI, Nolan insisted on placing the actors on actual rotating sets, making the action look real. And I'm grateful he did; it shows in the film's overall production value. In a day when films are bogged down with CGI and little - or recycled - plot (ahem, "Avatar"), it's something really special when a film not only makes you think on an intellectual level, but also delivers a fresh story with emotional depth. As I said in my review forToy Story 3 (Four-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo + Digital Copy), James Cameron's "Avatar" is visually and technically stunning but its story is extremely predictable just from watching the trailer, it's uninspiring and trite (the story being a recycled product of several films, most notably Dances with Wolves, Pocahontas, and even Cameron's own earlier, better release The Abyss, which focused more on emotion rather than special effects). And that's where most films are headed nowadays. That's why when films like Inception come along, it's important to embrace them ... especially when it's well written and well acted such as this. I know the technical aspects of a film are important as well, but, above all, CGI and special effects should never take precedence or drown out a film's story. Fortunately, Inception perfectly balances the mindblowing special effects and story.Yes, there are plenty of special effects in this film, but the real standout aspect to this film is its story - it's original and captivating with a plot that keeps you biting your nails right until the end. I've heard some reviews and reactions from people saying that this film is confusing and difficult to follow; I couldn't disagree more. The film is involved and you do need to actually think and pay attention to the story, but if you do, there is no confusion. My only advice would be that if you have to use the restroom during this two-and-a-half hour masterpiece, make sure you're either with someone or sitting near someone who can explain to you what you missed because you'll need to know. There are more than two different realities in this film so you'll definitely need to pay attention; this isn't some film you go to with friends and talk to during the entire film and yet still can follow what's happening.Nolan's original work proves that he should be doing more original projects (aside from his debut, "Following," all of his films have either been a remake of a film or based on a novel or comic), and I can only hope that there are more in store in the near future. As I stated earlier, the action is paced very well without overloading the senses and it keeps you on the edge of your seat all the way through the journey with DiCaprio and company until the end. The concept of time in a dream state as well as other aspects of dreaming are intriguingly explored without dumbing down dialogue and explanations to insult the audience's intelligence, but, at the same time, is not so much complex that you need an encyclopedia to view the film."Inception" provides lush visuals, a uniquely stylish story and a range of emotions that should make every great film. After viewing this film, a friend wrote me, telling me to drop anything I was doing and go see "Inception" because there was nothing more important. Well, that's a bit extreme (no offense to him!). However, "Inception" is a must-see and if anyone were to ask me, I'd say without hesitation that it's the best film of 2010.

reviewText: InceptionThousands of reviews have been written about Inception and everyone knows that this movie is a mindteaser that does not give any easy answers. I thought the movie was very good and had excellent acting, music, locations, action and performances. Chris Nolan has served us another mid bender after Memento. I came across an article which said that Inception can be attributed to Quantum Physics which points out that the real world does not actually exist and solids are nothing but an illusion created by energy. I read many articles which have attempted to decipher the movie and the following is a compilation of the best answers to the riddle called Inception. I strongly caution that you do not read the following if you have not seen the movie. These are not my theories but compiled from various blogs and newspapers.Explanation 1 The spinning top is central to the film. Cobb explains that one can distinguish dreams from reality on the basis of the totems motion. If it stops you are in the real world and vice versa.Explanation 2 Cobb's ring appears in dream sequences and disappears when he is in reality. In the last scene the top is still spinning but there is no ring on his finger. His children have not aged and look the same. Was Inception a dream or a reality?Explanation 3 Cobb was just dreaming on the flight from Sydney to Los Angeles.Explantion 4 Adriane ( Ellen Paige) not Cobb was the head shrink who had been hired by Cobb's father played by Michael Caine to cure his son of his guilt complex. According to this theory Cobb was in a mental facility and his room number was 528491- the number that Fisher gives as the password to his father's safe. Adriane plants the Inception in Cobbs head to make him realize that his wife is dead and that he should move on.Some other Theories:Did Cobb and Mal ( Marillion Cotillard) go old together? They did and Cobbs memory of their youth is a fantasy. Why? Because when Cobb tells Adriane the final story of how they escaped the limbo, the clasped hands of Mal and Cobb on the railroad tracks appear old and wrinkled, just as they are when we see them walking towards the city. The youthful version could be a delusion created by Cobb which was visited by Adriane.Too many questions, Inception deserves multiple viewings to be understood. I loved the movie and will give it four stars. 9/10/10
summary: Spoiler Alert.....Read only if you have seen the movie.

reviewText: The movie is about a man named Cobb who enters peoples dreams and extracts secrets from their subconcious. He's hired to do a job called "Inception", implanting an idea in their minds (for a certain outcome) rather than just stealing secrets, to do this job he gets some other helpers who each play an important role in the operation. When they enter the target's mind things don't go as planned and they have to figure out how to get out before they go into limbo.The plot is pretty deep and there's many facets to it so I think you should see it rather than me trying to explain it all in full detail.Considering what I heard from other people, I had high expectations. I also just also watched another "Award Winning Movie" and was not impressed. This movie basically lived up to the expectations. It made you think, had concepts you don't usually see in movies and had good acting. I wish there were more movies like this instead of watching the same old thing over and over.I really don't care for extremely confusing movies but it was confusing in a good way. Some argue the concepts been done before but it hasnt been done before in this way or this well.Is it the best movie in the world? Id say it's not the best but in the top 5. If it has things i've never seen before in a movie and a good story then yea i'd say its near the best ever.People try to compare this to other movies from the past that shared a similar concept- but you can't. This is way better and more realistic than others that have come out in the past.It's better than Memento and 95 percent of all the movies ever made. It's not perfect but it's close. Contains some special features. Highly Recommended.

reviewText: Yes, I said masterpiece.This is going to be difficult, since saying too much here is surely damaging to the movie going experience.  This film has been criticized as much as it has been praised, and all for the same thing, the depth of the script.  Yes, this film can be hard to grasp IF you aren't paying attention, but it really isn't too complicated to follow if you walk in with the right mindset.  My brother hated this film, but he went with a bunch of reckless teenagers who talked throughout the whole movie.  This isn't your typical action film; you have to actually `watch' this one.  I went with my wife.We LOVED it.Simply put, `Inception' is about a man named Cobb who, due to his profession, has been separated from the ones he loves.  His wife is dead and he has been charged with her murder.  If he returns to the states, he will be incarcerated.  So, for the time being, he is not able to see his children.  What it is that Cobb does is someone complicated.  He uses dreams to steal valuable ideas from influential people.  Using technology suited for this task, he enters the mind of the sleeping, builds dreamscapes inside their minds and creates an alternate reality that allows him to extract whatever it is he is paid to find.It's not as hard to follow as it sounds.At the films outset we are shown just how this works.  After a botched job, Cobb and his partner Arthur are given a proposition; to perform inception.  With this job would come the ability to return home and see his children.  There is a small problem though.  Inception is much different and much more complicated a procedure because it involves implanting an idea, not stealing one.  This is harder because it is a much deeper deception; for in order for the idea to take root and grow, Cobb and his team have to make it feel as though the `victim' has come up with this idea all on his own.It has to feel real.Christopher Nolan has a huge following, especially after his brilliant `The Dark Knight', which garnered lots of praise, attention and even an Oscar or two.  While that film continues to grow on me in ways unprecedented (not really, but you get the picture...it is brilliant), there is no denying that Nolan continues to show the goods.  `Inception' is so smart it's scary.  Nolan understands that society in general gravitates towards the action film.  It is the big Hollywood summer blockbuster.  It is a way to make a lot of money.  BUT, Nolan also understands that big explosions and million-dollar effects cannot take the place of a smart and involved script.  He has continued to build a name for himself by marrying the two components beautifully, and `Inception' is no exception.  The film is complex yet free-flowing.  The pacing is exceptional.  The dramatic overtones are all there in spades, especially since the main characters are fleshed out and given life (Cobb becomes three dimensional, and his back-story is just as entrancing as the films actual plot without ever taking away from it).  Some have mentioned that the acting is standard fare, and then some have raved Leonardo DiCaprio and claimed this the best performance of his career.  I don't agree with either statement (best of his career...really?) but I came very close to writing this review as a `best in show' piece and somewhat Oscar FYC for Marion Cotillard, who is just plain OUTSTANDING in this film.Anyways, I decided not to (but a surprise Oscar nomination for her would be AMAZING and totally deserved).That said, this film is very, very good.  I fully expect it to snag a slew of Oscar nominations (including Best Picture and Best Director) and it will be deserved.  No, this film is not the best film ever made (come on fanboys, you are giving the film itself a bad name) but it is a truly impressive feat for the genre and it further cements Nolan's name as one of the most impressive and imaginative directors of his generation.
summary: Implanted affections for a modern masterpiece...

reviewText: Every so often, a science fiction movie introduces an idea or concept so novel that it is forever ingrained in the collective memory of movie-goers everywhere. Star Wars introduced nerds around the world to the idea of the force. The Matrix introduced us to the idea that our world might be a giant simulation. And Inception introduced a whole bunch of horribly modified versions of the noun "inception", all used to describe some version of controlling a dream or having one or more dreams within a dream. After this movie was released, I can't count the Facebook status updates stating how people "incepted" or "inceptioned" or "incept" various dream states. And every time I experience a dream within a dream, perhaps for the rest of my life, I will remember this movie.As a movie, Inception is incredible. I don't want to give the plot away, so I'll just say that it keeps you thinking the whole time, and you'll still be thinking about it from time to time long after you've finished watching the movie. The action is epic and unique, without being unnecessarily gruesome or excessively violent. The visual effects are second to none (you won't find a trace of bad computer-generated effects anywhere in this movie). Hans Zimmer's work on the soundtrack is perhaps his best work ever. Everything about this movie is top notch, and will go down in history as one of the best and most creative movies of all time.
summary: Excellent cast, superb visuals, epic soundtrack, great storyline.

reviewText: I admit it - I wanted this movie to be awesome.  As a whole, I have been unimpressed with movies lately, and I saw this as almost a last-gasp effort to be truly impressed with cinema again.  Then, Inception came along.As a film major in college, this was the type of movie that we all wanted (and still want) to achieve someday - a truly fascinating movie that is as much a feast for the eyes as much as it is a puzzle for the mind.  The story revolves around Cobb (excellently articulated by Leonardo DiCaprio), and his team of unusual characters who make a living by extracting the secrets of high-powered people, which they they are usually tasked to do by a competitor.  Until now, they have focused primarily on extracting secrets.  But then, a client has a tall order - can they actually plant an idea into another's mind?  The story unfolds brilliantly from then on, twisting and turning and throwing in loopholes left and right, forcing you to do mental acrobatics.Any review of Inception would be incomplete if it didn't also mention the visuals of the film.  In short, they are nothing less than breathtaking.  For me, I am often drawn out of the moment of a film by wondering "how did they do that?" or thinking "wow, this CGI is horrible."  There was little to no moments for me like that in this movie - I was completely engrossed the entire time, and the computer graphics (what there is of them) blend seamlessly into the rest of the film.While I know that The Dark Knight made a bigger box office draw (thus far), I believe that this will be known as Christopher Nolan's masterpiece.  He truly creates a different world for the viewer.  Plus, if the last five to ten seconds of the film aren't a conversation starter, then I don't know what is.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: This movie is a perfect example of how easily the mindless viewing public can be duped into thinking they're watching something deep, meaningful and intelligent when if fact, it's nothing more than fluff. reviewText: A sort of blend of the Matrix with Dark City combined with a heist flick and a third act with a big nod to James Bond.People make too much of "What was the ending?!!!"  Or trying to decode everything like it's "Lost."Not only is the cast first-rate and the score amazing, the visuals are truly stunning (even if you saw the ads on TV already) and the elevator scene, when she walks into the dead silent hotel room, makes the hairs on your arms stand up.A movie like this is MADE for viewing on blu-ray and HD TV.  The best combination action/thoughtful film since, well... The Dark Knight.  Upon viewing multiple times, you catch something new with each spin.That said, the blu-ray version of this is just ridiculous to look at.  Almost every seen drops you with its cinematography and the crystal-clear video/audio.  The aerial shots in particular are stunning, and the sound quality is perfect (important in that the score is like a character in itself to this film).The extras are quite satisfying, particularly the "making of" segments, which unlock your "how did they do that?" questions but briefly enough so that it doesn't take all the mystery out of the movie.Just like everybody bought The Matrix when they got their first DVD player because you just had to see it at that quality, this is a must-own for blu-ray enthusiasts.  Having seen it about 10 times now, it certainly has held up since I last saw it in the theatre.
summary: My All-Time Favorite Movie; Just AWESOME on Blu-Ray

reviewText: Christopher Jonathan James Nolan is one of the most intellectual, original, and influential directors of this century.His 8 films are some of the greatest, most influential and iconic films of the decade.Inception is not as good as Memento, but at least as good as The Dark Knight. The stellar cast - Leonardo DiCaprio, Ken Watanabe, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Marion Cotillard, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Tom Berenger, and Michael Caine, boost the film to levels beyond comprehension.Inception is a film that must be watched twice to be comprehended, much less understood.It's original plot and premise will take you by surprise, and really make you think.It's equal parts sci-fi, action, thriller, and heist film.Inception draws on films like The Matrix, and On Her Majesty's Secret Service, yet is totally original - straight for the mind of Christopher Nolan, where it germinated for 10 years.Is Inception overrated? Probably, in fact, YES, it's overrated. The hype has overrated, just as it has overrated The Dark Knight (another equally brilliant film).It's great, but not perfect.However, Inception is  thought-provoking, well-acted, action packed, moving, exciting, MIND- BLOWING sci-fi action heist!I highly recommend watching it for yourself!P.S. If this review was helpful to you, give it a like. Read my other reviews! Thanks!
summary: A Thought-Provoking, Action Packed, Mind-Blowing Thriller.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan has become one of those select few directors who can bring complex and subversive ideas to projects that can be dressed to effectively entertain the movie-going public. He's had a consistent track record and major success with his two Batman films that only at this point in his career (with a script he's worked on for over a decade) could he possibly deliver a movie like this under the cautious eyes of a major studio. And the gamble paid off. Inception was a crowd pleaser and critical hit, not to mention one of the handful of great films in the fog of a dismal summer lineup for 2010. Fortunately for us, the movie inspires if not demands us to return to it repeatedly and the blu-ray edition is the best way to keep returning to it.The presentation of the film is perfect in high-definition. Great detail is on display and colors and contrast are well-balanced. The DTS-HD Master 5.1 audio track is very robust, too. The sound effects and Hans Zimmer's score really stand out here. There's no commentary track from Nolan (I don't think he's done one since Memento) but the Extraction Mode - a collection of specific behind-the-scenes mini-docs you can play during the film or separately - takes care of that, providing more than enough info about the challenges of bringing this film into fruition. All together, you've got under an hour of material here and I prefer watching them separately. And that's on the first disc.The second disc has a fascinating documentary about dream research, a comic-book style prologue to how DiCaprio and Gordon-Levitt acquired the job they perform at the beginning of the movie (it's decent but it doesn't give you anything that'll make you appreciate the film any more), 10 isolated tracks from the film's score (very nice), conceptual art and promotional materials. I haven't bothered with the bd-live content yet.All in all, a great package. The blu-rays are wonderful and they even sweetened the deal with throwing in a movie-only dvd and digital copy code. If you enjoyed the movie during its theatrical run or want it in your collection, this is the best way to obtain it.
summary: The best way to experience Inception on home video

It becomes completely overwhelming when the dream within a dream, within a dream, within a dream, culminates in some sort of "Ice Station Zebra(esque)" nonsense. Gordon-Levitt was miscast(way too young for the part). Ellen Page fares slightly better as the so-called "dream architect."Kudos for the awesome art direction and set design--I would bet my bottom dollar an Oscar or two is definetly in store.I really wanted to like this movie--but in an eggshell--it was just TOO MUCH.

reviewText: I saw this movie on the IMAX theater when it first came out and it was absolutely stunning! How it is that Christopher Nolan was NOT nominated for the Best Director category, and Leonardo DiCaprio NOT nominated for the Best Actor category, I'll never know.  (Well, at least Nolan got nominated for the Best Original Screenplay category.)  What I do know is that this movie works.  Beyond the visual effect, the movie was thought provoking. reviewText: My comments about the film are focused on Hans Zimmer's score, and not the film itself. Many others have discussed the merits and demerits of this movie. I find myself a partisan of it - in conception and execution it is, with one notable exception, an intelligent and entertaining film which I recommend highly, especially in its bluray incarnation. However...As a professional composer who has also had a lifelong interest in "movie music" (Bernard Herrmann was a correspondent and teacher), I often find myself assaulted by what I will call "The Curse of John Williams." Williams is a very gifted composer, both of film music and of concert works as well, but the wall-to-wall music film-score aesthetic which he brought back into fashion beginning with Star Wars in 1977 has long since morphed into the standard method whereby film composers approach their tasks under the fashion that says, in effect, "people are stupid and need aural cues at every possible moment to tell them what to think and how to feel." Thus, especially in the realm of fantasy and science-fiction, we have an endless stream of film scores whose opening title to end title continuity leave me utterly exhausted, aurally fatigued by the incessant blather of overcooked, hyperventilating accompaniments whose minimalist compositional techniques have all but destroyed the effect of music in film.Bernard Herrmann's operating principal was "less is more" - an attitude developed during his pre-Hollywood years as a composer of scores for radio dramas. When he made the transition to film, his overriding sense of economy and brevity made his contributions to the various films he scored all the more effective precisely because they were not constant - because they were present only when the dramaturgical flow of the film required the additional aural element to complete the visual. Herrmann was one of the very first minimalist composers, long before John Adams, Terry Riley, Philip Glass, and all the other minimalists came on the scene, indeed before minimalism was a definable musical technique. As we know, minimalism became an end in and of itself, and not a means to an end. Our current crop of Hollywood composers have largely if not entirely, it seems to me, bought into the utter and total corruption of Herrmann's "less is more" and have turned it into "more less is more."The most recent, and for my money, egregious example of this is Hans Zimmer's score for the Christopher Nolan film "Inception." When I saw the film in its "live" environment, that is, in the movie house, Zimmer's score, never for a minute approaching anything even remotely subtle or understated, was intrusive in a way that seemed to have crossed over into new territories of aural overkill. When I acquired the recently released BluRay version of the film, and then watched it on my home theater system, both my wife and I were overwhelmed by the sheer chutzpah, the noise level, the unceasing repetition, over and over and over again, of the same musical figures absolutely without development, extension or variation. The phenomenal clarity of both the visual and audio elements drove home the point that this score, for all its synthesized and "live" musical elements, was totally inappropriate both in terms of conception and execution. It was often impossible for us to hear dialogue clearly, even though the bluray realization places most all of the dialogue clearly in the center front channels. I cannot fathom Nolan's approval of this kind of overkill. But I am reminded of the story Herrmann told about his adventures with William Friedkin when Friedkin asked him to score The Exorcist. Herrmann was, if nothing else, perhaps the single most original and imaginative film composer - and when he told Friedkin that he would use many French Horns in the score, Friedkin told him that he didn't want anything French in the music! Utter stupidity and ignorance there for a certainty. Zimmer's patented overkill strikes me as director Nolan's equivalent.Now Zimmer is indeed a talented composer even as his scores have their characteristic bloated overstatement. But, with Inception, the score is so exaggerated and the presentation, especially in 7 channel bluray, so intrusive as to destroy what is otherwise a marvelously ingenious and engrossing film. I am not stupid. I don't need the Wagnerian leit-motiv method pushed beyond the outer limits. I do not ever want music in a film to overwhelm absolutely every other element. And, I certainly don't want to walk away from a film annoyed to the point of distraction by a score which shows not a whit of respect for the audience listening to it in the context for which it was composed.I protest!
summary: Inception: On the egregious misuse of music in a motion picture

reviewText: Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is an agent working in the field of data acquisition and extraction. However, rather than follow the traditional routes of industrial espionage, he uses cutting-edge technology to extract this information from his targets' dreams. This can be a dangerous task, with the infiltrators at risk from the target's subconscious, but Cobb is the best in his field.Exiled from the USA for undisclosed reasons, Cobb is desperate to return home and see his children. His latest employer claims that he can make this happen, but only if Cobb can perform the impossible: inception, placing an idea so deeply in the target's subconscious that they believe they came up with it themselves. Cobb has never managed to succeed at this before, but relishes the challenge and the reward. He assembles a team of the very best in their field to mount a reverse-heist into the unconscious of a top businessman, but can he leave his own past behind?Inception was one of the more heavily-acclaimed movies of 2010, a complex SF thriller helmed by director-of-the-moment Christopher Nolan (The Prestige, The Dark Knight). Its cerebral and complex premise was feared to be off-putting to casual audiences, but the film took an impressive $820 million at the box office and demonstrated that a clever film could still be a break-out hit. At least that's the narrative that's been spread around by various critics. Actually Inception's complexity is more about asking the audience to retain information and maintain a keen eye for detail. The film isn't really ambiguous (aside from a slightly cheesy final shot that screams "The End...OR IS IT?!?") and the rules of the dream-hacking and details of the heist are pretty well-laid-out by clearly-related expositionary sequences.Like The Matrix, the film isn't as original as it first appears but melds its ideas with compelling action sequences (a fistfight in a hallway with the exterior gravity switching around is an impressive highlight) and use of CGI (Paris wrapping itself into a giant ball is a staggering visual idea, executed flawlessly). It lacks the confused cod-philosophy of The Matrix's weaker sequels though, instead focusing on the characters of Cobb (a damaged, somewhat arrogant man) and his team-members, particularly Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), Eames (Tom Hardy), Ariadne (Ellen Page), Saito (Ken Watanabe) and their mark, Robert Fisher (Cillian Murphy), well-written characters who stand out alongside the film's impressive visuals and more complex ideas.The film's SF influences are intriguing. Previously Nolan had worked with Christopher Priest on The Prestige and Inception feels very much like a Priest novel reworked to include more explosions and machine guns. The big difference between them is that Priest loves ambiguity whilst Nolan is less interested in leaving open questions, with only the very final shot leaving the story open to further interpretations. The DNA of Philip K. Dick can also be seen in the "What is reality?" question that pops up throughout the film, not to mention the vast and imposing SF city that we encounter in the final act.The film falters occasionally. Like The Dark Knight the film occasionally feels weighed down by maybe one or two too many subplots (though vastly less of a problem than on The Dark Knight, which sometimes loses focus as a result of this). Whilst the film has a strong emotional core with regards to Cobb's relationship with his deceased wife and his desire to be reunited with his children, in other areas the film is less emotionally engaging. In particular, the key relationship between Fisher and his father (the late Pete Postlethwaite) never really grabs hold of the imagination.These are somewhat minor issues, however. Inception (****) features strong performances, a clever premise and mixes entertainment with thought-provoking ideas. The film is available now in the UK (DVD, Blu-Ray) and in the USA (DVD, Blu-Ray).
summary: An unusual but superior heist movie

reviewText: This movie isn't perfect, but it's good enough so that the flaws can be easily forgiven. The science-fiction premise of the story is that it's possible to go into another person's dreams, and manipulate events and perceptions in those dreams, with the intent of extracting information. The supposedly easy task is getting ideas out of a person's head. On the other hand, but putting ideas in, creating thoughts (inception) is infinitely harder. The storytelling structure of the film generally follows a classic caper outline. This being... one man needs to get something secret/difficult/illegal done, so he assembles a team of strange bedfellows, who are often at odds with each other. Along the way the team members exhibit various surprising strengths and weaknesses, and there is at least one twist at the end. Yup, classic. The filmmakers pull it off with style. My only complaint is towards the end of the movie... the film bends a few early-established rules of the dream-universe to make later events fit the story, and the rule bending gets rather flagrant at the very end. But it's a minor irritant that is overwhelmed by the fine production and acting. Leonardo DiCaprio and Ellen Page are electric on screen. This is one of those few films that is fun to watch twice, or three times. I recommend it.

reviewText: This movie is brilliant and outstanding. I watched it this weekend for two consecutive times, and I can't take it off of my mind. I really want to go back to it, and watch it again and again. If you get this Blu-ray edition, you get the digital copy, which is really cool to take with you on your iPhone or iPad, the DVD, and also an extra disc with extras. One of the extras is a selection of Hans Zimmer soundtrack. The selection is 10 out of the total 12 tracks of the soundtrack, so it is like getting almost the whole thing. The movie won 4 Academy awards, and although it missed the best picture and best director, I can assure you will not be disappointed by this movie. Christopher Nolan is a great director, and he did not only directed, but he wrote this movie as well. This is remarkable, because he is the guy who wrote Memento, and if you watched Memento, then this movie kind of makes sense.This movie is about dreams, and how perception of dreams can be so real that we have a really hard time telling the difference from what's real and what's a dream (this is you believe that dreams are not real, which I do believe they are...). Anyhow, philosophic quests aside, the visuals of the movie are unbelievable, with special effects that leave you breathless. The acting is top notch, and I have to admit that I learned to love DiCaprio more and more. He has become one of the best Hollywood actors for the last 5/6 years, and I would not be surprised if he is nominated for an Academy award very soon, because he deserves it. Supporting acting is very good as well, specially Tom Hardy, a great discovery for the film industry.This Blu-ray comes with several extras, among those an 'extraction mode' that allows you to watch the movie with short documentaries in between explaining how the visual effects were created. I already spoke about the Zimmer soundtrack, which is mesmerizing and ver effective in creating the appropriate mood for this movie, and all I can say to finish my review is that I highly and strongly recommend everyone to check this movie out. Thanks for reading!p.s. I forgot to mention ... if you are so confused after watching this movie, like I was after my first time, you can watch it over (again and again), and you can also visit imdb.com where there is a FAQ with at least 60 different questions related to the plot, etc. Needless to say, those FAQs contain spoilers, but you may want to check them out anyway (at your own risk...).

reviewText: This is not quite the inoculate inception you would expect but it holds your attention. This is an action packed thriller with plenty of CGI, blood and guts and a mystery to boot.We already know the formula and this will not be the last movie to use it. Yet it is the execution that is on trial here. Is lots of action and noise the reason to watch the movie or is it actually the distraction. Take away the CGI and the obligatory car chase and what is left?Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) just wants to get on with life and be with his kids once more. He is offered that opportunity in exchange for his skill in changing people's minds while entering their dreams. This is the simple explanation for the movie.  But Cob and his team must go down several levels of dreams in dreams in dreams to accomplish the mission. With each level new problems are revealed as we are also dissecting Cobb's mind at the same time.Will the team complete their mission or like "The Man from the MTA?" be lost forever in limbo.The Thirteenth Floor

reviewText: When you watch this 2010 sci-fi thriller, you need to pay close attention.  You may want to turn on the subtitles to help follow the conversation, or you may get lost in the twists and turns of the plot.  This was what happened to me at my first viewing, but the pieces started to fall into place when I watched the movie for the second time.  The story is about a group of people who steals secrets from corporate leaders by entering into their dreams in operations dubbed "extraction".  They push the boundary further by trying to plant an idea into the subconscious mind of the heir of an industrial magnate.  The operation is called "inception".  I can see why some viewers would throw up their hands on this movie, given the complexity of the plot, but they should give some leeway to the writer-director-producer of this film, Christopher Nolan, who is well known for experimental film making.  This film is not your run-of-the-mill sci-fi and it requires certain amount of effort from the viewers to follow Nolan's thoughts. Lead actor Leonardo DiCaprio is great as usual, but the one to watch is the Japanese actor Ken Watanabe, who is famous as Lord Katsumoto Moritsu in "The Last Samurai".
