reviewText: As soon as I finished watching Inception the first comparison that came to my mind was William Gibson'sNeuromancer.  There's some superficial plot similarities between the two, but what struck me about both was how many really cool images and ideas both had.  It also struck me that despite all of the awesome action, elaborate set pieces and cool moments, both Neuromancer and Inception failed to connect with me on anything other than a purely visceral level.  Inception fails in the same way Neuromancer did.  It's too focused on the various plot machinations and rules that govern it's universe, and it fails to give the character side of the equation as much loving attention.First with the superlatives.  This is a very entertaining and exciting movie.  I was particularly impressed with Christopher Nolan's staging of the action sequences.  I found a lot of the Dark Knight's big set pieces to be too messy.  There was a lot of quick cuts and choppy sequences.  Inception's action sequences didn't seem to have this problem.  I also found a few scenes incredibly imaginative.  The hallway scene in particular was very well staged and thought out.  Most importantly, the action felt much more clear and purposeful than in his Batman films.The ideas in Inception are also very promising.  I enjoy films about dreams because they afford filmmakers the opportunity to get completely lost inside someones head.  Inception doesn't really use the dreams to examine psychology too deeply.  Rather they're used as elaborate staging grounds for mind bending action.  I liked the different take on dreams, and it made for some very good action sequences.Now for some criticisms.  A lot of sci-fi seems to focus to much on the world it's building and not enough on the characters who inhabit the world.  Cobb is given a tortured back story about his wife, but the relationship between the two never moved me in any kind of way.  It's seemed typically Hollywood to me, and it felt out of place among all of the unconventional ideas and set pieces.And what about the rest of the team?  Besides Robert Fischer, who gets quite a bit of back story and motivation, the rest of the team are basically cyphers.  I would have appreciated a bit more characterization of Arthur or Eames to flesh out why I should care about these folks.Inception is an entertaining movie with a lot of great action sequences.  Technically, it's a brilliant piece of film making.  Nolan knows how to entertain and please a crowd.  You should see this if you're at all a fan of action films.  I've avoided any interpretation here, but it's worth checking out online some of the theories and explanation about how the film works.I have one minor quibble about the DVD.  I got the bear bones DVD edition at a gift exchange, and I believe that the dialogue is mixed too quiet while the music and the sound effects are mixed to loud.  I had to turn up the volume to hear the characters talk but turn it down when there was an explosion in an attempt to not piss off my neighbors.
summary: Great Ideas Without Any Real Connection

reviewText: I saw director Christopher Nolan's latest filmmaking masterpiece, Inception (2010), on Opening Day. My one word to summarize this flick is AWESOME. This is truly a stunning piece of cinema in just about every way.  I give it 5 out of 5 stars.  The story is well written, suspenseful, and interesting...the acting is top notch...the music is phenomenal (Hans Zimmer of course)...the cinematography spectacular...and the special effects are incredible.  And it's a big budget summer blockbuster that is sure to make hundreds of millions if not a billion dollars.  While this film won't beat Avatar (2009) at the box office, it's the film that I wish Avatar was.  It's the film that's better than the 10 films nominated for the Best Picture Oscar in 2009.  It's both an action/thriller/suspense juggernaut and a contemplative philosophical/psychological labyrinth.  It's rare now days that a movie can get me just purely excited like a kid on a sugar high, antsy to see a movie on opening day.  But also get my mind and soul intrigued and stimulated as an adult.  Inception is one of those rare movies that does that and got me into the theater on opening day...at 10 AM no less!  The last film I think that did that was Gladiator (2000).  This has got to be an Oscar contender for 2010 considering that The Dark Knight (2008), also directed by Nolan, was nominated for 8 Oscars and won 2, including Heath Ledger's posthumous win for Best Supporting Actor. And this movie far surpasses The Dark Knight in my humble opinion, as much as I enjoyed that picture as well.  My biggest quandary is now how to fit this film into my Top 100 movie list, where it definitely belongs. It's definitely the best film of 2010 so far.  And one of the best in the last decade. It's movies like this that inspire me to be both an Architect and a Filmmaker.  And ironically, this movie is a lot about architecture.  Architecture of both buildings and the mind.  I've known this for awhile, but it's so clear to me now that I became an Architect to become a Filmmaker.  My frustration with architecture in reality is that it isn't as spectacular as the architecture I build in my mind.  And movies are the place where the two meet.If you want a good review of the plot of this movie, read Roger Ebert's review.  I really won't even attempt to summarize this film...it would be too much work, and honestly, you just have to see it...in the theater on the big screen!  That's the power and beauty of great films is that they really defy words alone.  That's why they are on film IMO. You've got to experience them with all of your senses to fully feel them and understand them. Like the title and premise of the movie, this movie has planted ideas in my head that keep building and now I can't stop thinking about this movie, as well as its meaning for my own life.  The best films do that...they seep in to our subconscious and plant themselves there, causing god only knows what.  And there is the idea of Inception, fully realized in film as well as life itself.  Nolan has obviously crafted this story from ideas within his mind and its influences from the world of film and his own life experiences. I can definitely see the influences of his own films like Memento (2000) and Insomnia (2002), both films about the psychology of the mind.  But of course there is also a bit of The Matrix (1999) and The Bourne Identity (2002) within Inception as well.  And while Inception does feel a little familiar at times because of all of its influences, I let that slide.  Film is not a static environment and filmmakers are certainly influenced by other films like any other aspect of our culture. We're really telling the same stories that the Greeks told thousands of years ago.  They've just got a different context and upgraded visuals.I watched Memento this afternoon as well.  I had recorded it earlier in the week on my DVR after being reminded of it from something about Inception/Nolan.  It was only the second time I've seen the movie, the first being 9 or 10 years ago when it came out on DVD.  I remember that I really didn't "get" Memento the first time and didn't really appreciate it.  The way the story was told was complex, being told both backwards and forwards at the same time, in fragments.  I think it was partly due to my young age that I just didn't appreciate Memento as much back then. But I really appreciated it today.  It's not at the same level as Inception, but the ideas at its core go hand in hand with it.  The questions of "reality" that Nolan poses in both Memento and Inception are interesting to say the least.  Memento is a much smaller scale film but I see now how influential it was now to Nolan himself, as well as the rest of the world of film. The film (500) Days of Summer, with its jumbled fragmented timeline, owes a nod to Memento. And apparently Nolan started working on the story and screenplay for Inception while filming Memento.There are many thoughts, ideas, and feelings that I got from Inception today going through me.  And I doubt I will fully realize them all in this blog right now.  I also think that Inception is one of those movies like The Matrix or Memento that needs to be seen a second time to get a better grasp on it. Once you get through it once, you can pay attention to details that are hard to maybe keep up with the first time when you are simply trying to stay with the story. I'm probably going to see this one again in the theater in the next few weeks. I captured a lot of screen stills from the trailers to this film...this simply such a visually stunning movie...enjoy all of them!
summary: Wake me up...but not before the dream ends

reviewText: I really liked this movie.  It's a very involved plot that revolves around manipulating dreams.  DiCaprio, who is always good, runs a small band of dream Extractors.  They use a machine and chemicals to plant themselves into the dreams of others, usually to steal corporate data.  Sounds easy enough, but there are ways to guard against people invading your thoughts while you sleep.  There are ways to train your mind to resist such intrusions.  This manifests itself as the subconscious creating armed guards to fight off the intruders.  So what you get are some very entertaining "Matrix" like battles in the dream.  The name of the movie, "Inception", refers to the act of planting an idea in someone's subconscious and making them believe it's their own idea.  This is considered an almost impossible feat and requires delving very very deep within someone's subconscious.  This means going into dreams within dreams and so forth.  Complicating matters is the fact that DiCaprio's character has some deep problems in his subconscious.  The projections of his wife keep showing up in his dreams trying to unravel all his plans.  It's an amazing movie.  The plot is very complex and can sometimes wrap itself up like a pretzel, so you really have to pay attention.The Blu Ray quality is great.  You get a digital copy as well as the standard DVD included, which is a great deal.  I highly recommend this Blu Ray movie.
summary: Thoroughly happy with the movie and Blu Ray

reviewText: Note: In an ideal world, I would grant this film a 4.5 rating just for its originality, however, I believe that such a high rating would simply mask my objections to parts of this film.Inception marks a return for Christopher Nolan, as he takes a break from the superhero world of DC comics and jumps back into his comfort zone: the human mind. Anyone following Nolan's career will be already familiar with Memento. Memento and Inception, conceptually different, are similar in their approach to filmmaking. Above anything else, both are mind blowing experiences with extraordinary concepts that only someone like Nolan, in this visceral blockbuster era, could conceive. I found his Batman output notable, but, of course, he was attempting to give new life to a franchise that for long seemed doomed for light entertainment. Here, he is back in his comfort zone, creating and developing inventive concepts from sketch.Describing the plot of Inception in such a short space would be both difficult and inadequate. Inception is a journey within the depths of the human mind, via a process named extraction, accessing the most obscure and fascinating concept: dreams. Through the tools at hand, the characters are able to enter the dreams of others and understand the secrets of the subject via their subconscious. However, the subconscious is not only occupied with the subject and the "intruder," as its limitless scope and design allows for countless different and eclectic additional characters and objects. In addition, some people have been trained against such invasions, and have a particularly strong and proficient defense system.The protagonist of the tale is Dominic Cobb, played by Leonardo Di Caprio, who is a successful and intelligent extractor. His personal and professional troubles have for a time forced him to live outside of the United States, away from his children. Accepting the fact that he possibly will never see his children, for he would be arrested and jailed for many years if he were to return to the country, he decides to lay low and eventually get work in another country. However, a wealthy man, Saito, whom he is familiar with due to prior extraction missions, offers him a final job. This job, however, is more challenging than any extraction they have ever performed. On this mission, they must incept the mind of Robert Fischer, heir to a wealthy corporation. Robert Fischer's father is close to death, and Saito wants to make sure that his corporate rival disintegrates the company. As a result, they must incept his mind, and grant him new ideas about his relationship with his father and Godfather, Peter Browning. For the completion of this task, they use sedatives that would grant them to dream within the dreams. They eventually are able to get close enough to Robert to enter his dreams. Unfortunately, even with all their preparation, they experience countless setbacks that endanger the mission and their life outside of the dream world.If inception failed in character and story development, acting, directing, cinematography, and many other aspects of the film it still would be an undeniably original concept. Though it will be compared to The Matrix, and possibly Dark City, this film is more original in its jargon, while something like the Matrix was largely influenced by countless different schools of philosophy. The concept of the dreams is unique and entirely original, and in years to come it will be imitated but never bettered. Many studies have shown that the vocabulary of British films have for long been more widespread than American films. Inception may be an exception. Instead of focusing on the F word, which films of all genres have for long found an affinity for, Inception actually uses some elaborate terms-at least for a Hollywood film. This is not necessarily an intellectual film, as it is entirely fictional. However, Inception's pseudo-intellectuality still makes the viewer think and see if Inception's own rules are logically applied. This is a visceral experience, like Transformers, but our mind is constantly active, trying to interpret all the countless information and new ideas that Nolan throws our way.As you see, I have quite an affinity for this genuinely inventive films, so, why the seemingly derogative heading? This film, possibly due its ingenuity, has been compared to Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. In ways, it is unfair to compare the acclaimed science-fiction film to an exceptional Hollywood blockbuster. Maybe, just as the detractors of 2001 decreased by numbers, Inception's critic may have to eat their words in the foreseeable future. However, there is a place where the comparison is applicable. Kubrick's film is possibly the most implicit film ever created, where nearly every segment has countless interpretations and the film rarely shows us its explicit side. In 2001, Kubrick created an entirely implicit experience, unexpected of the director of Spartacus and Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb. Many years after the first film, Arthur C. Clark released a sequel, 2010: Odyssey Two, which was eventually adapted. As much as the earlier film was implicit, 2010 was explicit and Hollywood entertainment. Of course, the magic was lost, as it tried direly to make the audience, possibly the ones who were bored by the first film, understand the points only hinted by 2001. Inception is 2010, while it could have more elegantly become 2001. This film is undeniably complex, proven by the fact that Nolan explains every single detail of extraction and inception. We need some information about this original concept, but every part of the process is so heavily explained that it leaves nothing to the imagination. Nolan explains everything to such a degree that we truly feel like observers and outsiders to these characters world. If it had been suggestive in some areas, our intellect could have been truly engaged and this film would have been a true cerebral experience. Unfortunately, we gaze at the film with fascination, trying to always comprehend its thread of complexity. We may be confused at moments, but rarely are we bewilderingly lost in the picture. Unfortunately, Nolan is trapped in the blockbuster world, where studios demand clarity from the narrative. In other words, there is a much more implicit and majestic film buried from the view of the still powerful Inception.Inception may be a blockbuster with expected top-notch actors, but it has much more personality, focus, and drive than the average Hollywood product. The fact that Nolan could have created such an original film in such a predictable era is testament to his immense talent as one of the most fascinating directors of recent times, with only Tarantino as his rival. There has been much talk about the final scene and moments of the film, and its implications. On Inception's Wikipedia page, there appears a solid explanation for the ending but that is unfortunate. If Nolan is not aiming for a sequel, which I hope not, the open-ended ending brilliantly matches, and possibly defines this mystifying film and is proof of the audacity of Nolan's vision.
summary: Immensely original, fascinating and satisfactory experience...However; Kubrick had more guts than Nolan!

reviewText: I just watched Inception and right away it reminded me of Dreamscape, where people could enter other people's dreams and help them defeat scarey monsters or kill them off in their sleep.  Inception, though, is on a much higher (albeit "lower" level) going through 4 (5?) consciousness states.  I found I had to consciously keep reminding myself which level of consciousness I was watching so I wouldn't get too lost. I think the trick to watching this movie is to let it carry you away and don't fight it. I found it extremely cerebral, initially, but in the end it's actually quite simple.  That's the genius of the movie - it is both complicated and simple.  The acting is first rate but that's really not as important as how the movie plays out. I gave it 4 stars because it's one of those movies I call "a lot of work".....watched it one time, and it's still with me, but not sure I'd want to go through it all over again.  And I rewatch A LOT of movies but every once in awhile, there's a movie that's "a lot of work"....this one is worth watching, at least one time.....

reviewText: I couldn't finish this. I was overwhelmed by the tedium, the constant shifting back and forth between reality and dream. After awhile, I no longer cared who was dreaming and who wasn't. The script is weak and the acting is nothing special. It's all special effects, and the tale is one you won't want to remember. Skip without fear.

reviewText: There's a lot of mumbo jumbo in 'Inception'-- too much dialog and exposition, too many Hollywood chases and explosions, and an overdose of pseudopsychological pretense, certainly for a film that purports to be about the limits of human imagination.  So, of course, I watched it twice.  Bear with me: I only did it because I hate to see otherwise civilized moviegoers at each others' throats over what's meant to be a couple hours' entertainment.On first viewing, not having read anything but a plot summary about it, I approached 'Inception' (as I think most will) as having a level that serves as a control, that is, 'reality.'  For those with a heightened ability to suspend their disbelief, regardless of how dazzlingly opaque that which is presented to you, you may love the detail, action, plot twists and other conceptual artifice here, and go to bed feeling warm and satisfied. Five stars!  On the other hand, if you're a stick in the mud (like me) and have the type of mind that analyzes-- and accordingly accepts or rejects-- a movie's various premises as you go, you will have all kinds of problems with the logic of 'Inception,' go into a fit, call your lawyer and demand changes to your will that include Christopher Nolan being declared a charlatan somewhere in your epitaph.  One star!To the latter point, inconsistencies and junk 'dream science' make watching 'Inception' almost unbearable after the first hour.  Your brain simply shuts down.  For those who need examples:  Cobb tells Mal 'I don't trust you anymore,' then moments later proceeds to tie himself to her and rappel down the side of a building (I needn't bother getting into the physics of a 100-pound woman supporting the weight of a 150-pound man because-- ta-da!-- it was just a dream); in reality, pain in dreams is caused by conscious pain, not the other way around; the idea of 'inception' has been practiced since the 19th century in the forms of brainwashing and hypnotic suggestion and therefore the notion, posited by Arthur, that 'true inspiration is impossible to fake' would demonstrate a near-total ignorance of his own field of expertise; Cobb operates under the supposition that in dreams the dreamer doesn't 'know it's happening,' but most if not all of us have had dreams where we're fully aware we're in a dream and have control over all aspects of it-- his theories fall apart then; the idea of the totem is fun and an important plot thread but, again, the mind plays tricks on us, and what might be a rabbit's foot in real life could easily turn into a rubber chicken in a dream; Saito's oversimplistic explanation of Fischer's conglomerate becoming a world superpower is laughably weak, even for a MacGuffin, anywhere outside the world of James Bond; a sedative leaving inner-ear functions intact presumably would be useful only if the subject were 'kicked' in reality, not inside his dream; and so on.Now, before you 'believers' get upset, here's the part where I read a bunch of reviews and decide to give 'Inception' a second chance, this time from the perspective that the entire film is Cobb's conceit, several convoluted layers of dream plot and dream characters devised to fool himself in order to 'self-incept,' as it were, to gain safe passage 'home,' i.e., reunite with his family, whether they even actually exist or not.  I have to say the movie is a hell of a lot easier to digest this way, because nothing that is said or done has to make sense, as it all serves Cobb's imagined quest.  It's still overlong and too crammed with generic action-movie fluff for my taste, but at least you can appreciate what director Nolan might have been aiming for, unburdened by the chore of trying to decipher what is essentially undecipherable (OK, OK, let's call it 'subjective') material.  Three stars!I'm sure my fence-straddling will still offend some, but perhaps if fans and critics can find common ground at least on how to approach 'Inception' the armies of our subconscious can lay down their arms and let us dream in peace.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan, being relatively unknown until he rebooted the Batman franchise, has managed to produce the best film of 2010 and possibly one of the best films of the decade. He manages to take fantasy concepts and bring them into the real world, no matter how crazy they may seem. Batman is one of his projects that he wanted to remove from the comic book fantasy and bring it into the real world to the point the viewer would be thinking "so this is really possible". Although it may seem crazy, Inception is one of those movies. Although using technology and ideas that don't yet exist in reality, it uses concepts such as Lucid dreaming and dream incubation and places them in reality. Although it may seem crazy, I think that one day we will develop such an understanding of dreams and the unconscious mind that things such ideas as depicted in the film will be possible.Although being a genius of film making, he's also excellent in confusing the hell out of the viewer, and if you aren't paying attention for the entire runtime, you will find yourself to be absolutely lost. The story centres around dream thieves, Dominick (Leo DiCaprio) and Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt). Well they're not actual dream thieves, more secret thieves. They dream together and break into the unconscious minds of other sleepy people in the hope of discovering some deep and dark secrets about them. They're approached by Saito (Ken Watanabe) who offers Dominick the freedom to return home to the US (where he's wanted for murder of his wife) if he can perform Inception, the act of planting ideas in the mind of another person through their dreams. The victim of said Inception is Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy), the son of a wealthy business man who is about to inherit a massive corporate empire. In order to carry the inception, Dominick and Arthur employ the services of the dream architect, Ariadne (Ellen Page), identity forger, Eames (Tom Hardy) and the sedative guy, Yusuf (Dileep Rao).If the story didn't sound complicated enough, it goes even deeper into the ideas and concepts of dreams that will really knock you if you aren't paying attention from the start. Involving numerous levels of dreams, you become lost in what is exactly the reality. This is a beautifully crafted film that blends stunning special effects with spectacular acting, dialogue and action. Some scenes are just bizarre but wonderfully put together, such as the scene showing Paris being folded on itself. One particular standout moment, however, is the anti-gravity fight sequence involving Joseph Gordon-Levitt, one of those amazing, but criminally underrated actors. This is a visually mind-blowing scene which becomes a centrepiece of the entire film.This is a genius venture by Nolan and seals his legendary status. He is a true cinematic master and this is just an example of the wondrous stories he can bring to the big screen. Everyone must own this film, because without it, you're better off dead.

reviewText: For the most part Inception is original in ideas, but just so you know there are a couple others out there with similar plotlines. The focus is the ability to control anothers mind and make them think they are somewhere they are not so they will leak information. reviewText: Watching this movie was like snorting castor oil up into your sinuses.Just when I couldn't take any more, I checked and there's 1:06 to go!  What punishment!Can I put my finger on what irritated me so much?  Let's give it a try:1.  Premise not believable.2.  Even if you buy the premise, its execution was not believable.  (Would dreams be so grounded in physical laws and realistic settings, and feature such clear-headed thinking?)3.  Watching criminals try to succeed at something evil and nasty for two and half hours was unpleasant.  When is Hollywood gonna learn?  People don't like rooting for the bad guy, even if he is Leonardo Di Caprio.4.  Did anybody really give a toss what was going on between Di Caprio and his wife?5.  The script that's too clever for its own good has certainly been done before:  but this one was utterly predictable.  The final clincher:  "What is real, and what is not?" you could see coming from a mile away.  A lot of the movie's so-called "intelligence" boiled down to making jump cuts without any explanation, something it couldn't have done had it been a book.  In other words, the filmmakers were trying to be confusing.  It's more artsy that way!  It gets people talking!6.  Yeah, one of the most confusing movies I've ever seen, for sure.  I hate confusing movies.  If I'm in the mood for something that convoluted, I'll just read a book.  It's true I only watched this once and a second and third watching might clarify much, but who would bother?  It's too unpleasant to watch.7.  The whole "dream within a dream within a dream" thing might have worked well on paper, but by the time it hits the screen, the any possible poetic magic is lost:  you're just looking at a street scene.  It's like it was the audience's responsiblity to periodically remind themselves how wondrous the situation is, since the movie was unable to relay that visually.8.  The fact that this movie is essentially 2:30 of unrelieved chase scenes gets on your nerves pretty fast.  Remember how Shakespeare would help to break up tension with some low comedy?  Not Nolan.  It's unrelenting, so you check out emotionally before long.

reviewText: This film may strike you as startlingly original overall unless you have spent decades watching films from other countries.  If you have been watching these non-American films, then you know that the exploration of dreams vs. conscious states has been a hallmark of foreign film for decades.  So Christopher Nolan is not striking out onto the bold new frontier as far as his theme for this film.  Yet Christopher Nolan does bring something new to the table that these other filmmakers lacked and that is a physical vision for this dream world.  Thus, for the first time we see rendered in film the physically impossible alterations in the world that cannot take place in our conscious state take place in our dream state instead. This view of our dream world is absolutely breathtaking.  You could watch these sequences without any sound and still be entranced.Like many of the foreign filmmakers he also flirts with the idea that death and dreams are very close.  Thus, the protagonist's seeing of his late wife in his dreams and also his memories or her and his children.  There are questions which repeat throughout the film and you may or not form an answer to these questions by film's end.  It seems Nolan wants you to make up your own mind.  These questions are: 1) Which exact scenes are dreams and which are not? The answer to this is easiest on the scenes where he changes the physical universe so that it defies the law of physics.  2) Which scenes are memories instead of dreams?  This overlaps with the dreams and thus is harder to answer.  3) Does death intervene and end the dreaming process?  The metal top which stops spinning and the all black screen are clues to answering this question.As for the actors, they all do splendid jobs with Leonardo DiCaprio taking the entire movie upon his shoulders and carrying it forward.  We have now grown quite used to his doing this and barely notice how effortless he makes it seem. It is a formidable talent which allows him to do this in film after film after film.

reviewText: Ah, a movie I actually had to think about - what an amazing concept!Would you want to go into someone else's dreams?  Or have them in yours?  Would you want to influence their future actions while you were in there?I, for one, don't want anyone walking around in my dreams, although being in theirs might be enlightening.  In this tech age so much of our lives are out in cyberspace for others to see.  Our thoughts - and dreams - are kind of the last frontier of what only we ourselves can see.  And for how long?  Will the ideas brought forth in "Inception" be viable one day in the not too far future?  Hmmm...I enjoyed this movie - plot, special effects, casting.  It all worked and lived up to the hype I had heard about it.
summary: "...dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before. "

reviewText: It's known that, while dreams are thought to be reflections of the subconscious, they follow no logical pattern and cannot be explained in definite terms. What fascinates me endlessly about Christopher Nolan's "Inception" is that, while he continuously challenges the audience by toying with perceptions of reality, he sets up dreams and dream states under amazingly intricate rules - every action has a name and a function, every image has a label. What the dreamer envisions can be freely manipulated, yet their creations still serve a purpose and follow a definite pattern. Nothing that happens is a random occurrence. It has all been a part of a grand design. It can also be a shared experience. The film is labyrinthine, disorienting, and ceaselessly hypnotic. It weaves through layers of dream and reality (or perhaps it's reality and dream), and rarely if ever is one distinguishable from the other.Despite heavy psychological subtexts and complex structuring, the general story faithfully adheres to the conventions of a heist movie, with a group of uniquely skilled characters convening for the proverbial Last Job. The protagonist is Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio), who hacks into other people's dreams in order to steal their ideas. There are a host of qualifiers for making this happen. First, his clients' backgrounds need to be researched; this is where his associate, Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), comes in. Second, he needs someone to literally construct the dream into recognizable physical dimensions - an architect, in other words. Third, he needs keep a personal item, or a totem, available at all times, for the way it behaves lets Cobb know whether or not he's still dreaming. His totem is a spinning top. Forth, he needs a special machine to induce all the team players into a sleeping state, since it's possible for more than one person to take part in the same dream.Cobb is recruited by a powerful billionaire named Saito (Ken Watanabe) to infiltrate the dreams of a business rival named Robert Fischer, Jr. (Cillian Murphy), who is the heir to his father's fortune. The catch is, Saito doesn't want Cobb to steal any of Fischer's ideas; rather, he wants an entirely new idea planted in Fischer's mind via a process called inception, which is not without risks. Cobb's newly recruited dream architect is college student Aridane (Ellen Page), who shows remarkable talent. He also recruits Eames (Tom Hardy), who, once in a dream state, can shape shift his body and appear to be someone else. Finally, he recruits Yusuf (Dileep Rao), a chemist who has developed a special sleeping agent for this particular mission.One of the film's more interesting plot devices is the ability to go into a dream state even when already in a dream state. Cobb, his team, and Fischer find themselves in not one, but four layers of sleep, each more unstable than the last until at last a raw subconscious limbo is reached. It's also explained that the mind works faster as it goes deeper into dreams, meaning that, with each layer penetrated, time gets progressively slower. What could have been hopelessly confusing is instead an ingenious building of suspense, Nolan successfully keeping tabs on all four dream states as they work towards their own exciting climaxes. None is more exciting than that of the first state, stretched into a nail-biting slow motion shot broken into periodic fragments. This sequence alone is a triumph of film editing.Cobb is not merely the main character. He's also the story's emotional center, his mind plagued with the image of his wife, Mal (Marion Cottillard), and their two children, who, for reasons I won't reveal, he hasn't seen in a long time. Because of the guilt he feels, he finds that their visions are intruding into other people's dreams, which is not only detrimental to his assignments but also to his own mental health, his ability to do his job rapidly deteriorating. The mysterious nature of the plot prevents us from knowing with absolute certainty whether she's a dream participant or merely a memory resurfacing from Cobb's subconscious. Yes, it appears to be one way, but as we all know, appearances can be deceiving. What can be said for sure is that Cotillard is one of the film's best assets - the perfect counterpart to DiCaprio's psychologically fractured character.If the ending doesn't satisfy you ... well, it isn't supposed to be satisfying. It dares the audience to reflect on what may or may not have happened and then come to the best possible conclusion. It's not about closure, nor is it about revealing what's real and what's a dream. It's all about going through a process. Although he has found success with the reinvention of "Batman" (a franchise I persist in believing he's all wrong for), it's movies like "Inception" that show Christopher Nolan in top form. Aside from being an engaging and thrilling work of cerebral science fiction, it's a masterpiece of craftsmanship - the screenplay, the character development, the plot, the visual effects, and the performances all handled with precision and care. Nolan truly believed in his idea; if he hadn't, he wouldn't have bothered to work on it for the last ten years.
summary: Life is a Dream Within a Dream

reviewerName: Chris Swanson "I'm just this guy, you know?"
reviewText: What a strange, fascinating, intelligent film this was. Deep, surreal, interesting and compelling, where perhaps its one fault was that it wasn't surreal enough. It's yet another extraordinary film from Christopher Nolan, who apparently can do no wrong, and it's well worth seeing at least a couple times.Inception tells the tale of a man (Leonardo DiCaprio), and his gang (headed up by Joseph Gordon-Leavitt and Lukas Haas, bringing together three former child stars), in what amounts to a highly interesting caper film. They've been assigned to infiltrate a man's dreams, and bring him new and strange thoughts about what he should do with the corporation he will inherit when his father dies. It sounds simple enough, and follows the basic formula all such works must follow (plenty of charts and diagrams, detailed plans, scenes showing the team being assembled), but as with so many great films, the genius is in the execution.In this case the execution takes us through several levels of a dream world intricately created by an architect (Ellen Page), and designed as a maze. The idea is that as the team goes through each level of the dream world will move closer and closer to the secrets held within the dreamer's brain. To say much more than that would give away too much of the story and the plot, and it's best to go into the film knowing as little about those elements as possible.The film is eye-candy at its finest. You see an entire city created out of a character's mind and watch as that city folds in on itself. You get to watch a fight in a corridor that spins as the characters go at it, and later you see the same character fighting in a zero-g environment so convincing you'll start to wonder if they rented to Vomit Comet for filming, ala Apollo 13.The direction here is also amazing, as Nolan is very much able to create several different stories taking place at several different points in time and space and manages to keep track of all of them. Even in a normal movie that's not easy to do, but in this one it shows some serious skills.Beyond that, it's very hard for me to really review this film without giving away major plot points. But I will say this: even if you go to it and enjoy nothing about the plot, you'll at least see some sights you've never seen before, and any movie that can give you that is worth seeing.On a purely personal side note, this is my 400th review on Amazon! These reviews helped me get into Amazon Vine and have helped me with obtaining screeners from various sources. They're also very fun to write!

reviewText: This is a psychological thriller where reality is challenged on multiple levels with the concept is shared dreaming. When people appear in each other's dreams, they can extract data from the subconscious of another mind. People who know about this can erect defenses in their dreams against data extraction.The main character, Dom Cobb, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, is a bounty hunter for dream extraction. Extraction is relatively well established, but his new employer, Saito, wants him to go further, to plant an idea (inception) into the mind of a business rival. Dom agrees to this and assembles a team of experts to create the dream world and playact with the mark, Fischer.One of the teammates, a young woman named Ariadne figures out that Dom has unresolved issues with his "dead" wife, Mal. He keeps seeing her in a dream. Every dreamer has a token to show them whether they are dreaming or in reality. Mal's is a spinning top that never topples. After a series of dreams within a dream, we are led to believe that Dom and his crew have returned to the real world.But Mal's question to Dom is, "are you sure you're in the real world? or are you in a dream where men are hiring you for all these extractions and chasing you across continents?" She wants him to come with her to where their real kids are. Dom appears to return home. He is welcomed by his father-in-law who was last seen in Paris. The children appear dreamlike, and he steps out to play with them. But before he does, he spins the top. It keeps spinning, wobbles a little, does not topple, and the movie cuts off.So, did Dom return to the real world, or was he still trapped in a dream? That is an open question.

reviewText: There is NO way that Ellen Page's character could have designed such an intricate dream and still have time to visit cute Joseph Gordon Levitt to "discuss" the work - they are adorable in Just the Two of Them scenes.So it must have been a  TEAM who designed the dream i.e. a conspiracy to GET Leo for murdering/violating Mallory, his Teacher's daughter and a BETTER designer than Leo. This movie is filled with snide jibes at Leo usually from Arthur or from Ellen Page but delivered unwittingly by the latter who is ALSO a better designer than Leo as deemed by his former Teacher.  The Hard Candy in Ellen Page is only allowed to peek out a few times in this film with lines like, "is that why you need me to help you steal ideas?" hahahaThat dar candy's pi'son, Leo, SPIT it out.The Main Character is stuck in a dream designed specifically to send him into oblivion whilst he continues to deny any wrongdoing i.e. he KILLED and violated Mallory and told an elaborate lie that she was suicidal because the two of them had returned from a deep dive into dream world.  Leo isn't capable of designing a 50-year worthy dream world.  So I THINK that not only is this world designed by his Teacher BUT that it's an entire team that did what Leo claimed to have done with Mallory and now Leo is refusing to design because of his "grief" but really he no longer has anyone to steal from so he is STUCK.  Totally immobilized and he has no idea how to move forward so the dream designers move him around insteadIt's interesting that Leo's "acting" comes across most authentically when he is raging at Arthur for making a mistake or grabbing Ariadne after designs a dream Paris superior to anything he could imagine.Remember that bubblegum song, "Toy Soldiers" by Martika?Well, you will learn nothing about the science of whatever this is from this film - this is just like Matrix where mental thought is expressed as toy soldiers versus toy soldiers and at the end of it, you should be able to walk away/wake up from it.  If we only think of it as Matrix-like combat in your dreams, then you shouldn't be worrying about just what exactly do the combatants of this dream within a dream represent.  I am not a fan of the Guy Pearce film with all the body tattoos that everyone else on the planet is gaga over so ... I am definitely not a fan of this film ALTHOUGH I did love Cillian Murphy (Scarecrow's on the other FOOT this time - or is it?), pretty Ellen Page ESPECIALLY when she shared the screen with her equally daintily-constructed Joseph Gordon Levitt and JGL is using a recognizable Keanu Reeves drawl in this film which is highly amusing given his later scenes.  HOWEVER, Titanic Boy's drawl is very strange and exacerbates is emotionally vacant line delivery.  I  keep thinking "who is he imitating?" whenever he spoke and I have no idea if he is mimicking Mark Walhberg's stuffed up nose style (too bad he doesn't have Marl Wahlberg or Matt Damon's career!).Just as with Gangs of New York, I was distracted from the storytelling by Leo's performance.  Marion Cotillard's FACE and subtle performance is fantastic in this film.  She seems to be in an entirely different relationship from Leonardo Di Caprio which might explain how their marriage ENDED and how the film ends.Whenever Leonardo Di Caprio explains inception, I get the feeling that he has no idea what he is talking about.  But Ellen Page's character seems to have a far better imagination than he does during her job interview.  THAT must be jarring.One weird thing which may indicate just who is the architect and who is the subject is how hard Leo yanks her arm during her job interview in dream state.But the absolutely best thing about this movie that despite his deep voice talking, Joseph Gordon Levitt ROCKS culminating in his Matrix meets Bruce Lee scene 1.5 hours into this film.  He also is the only one who pronounces Japanese guy's name as if it is Cantonese for Dead/Damned Island i.e. "Say Doe" with the proper Cantonese intonation no less whilst the Mal character's pronunciation of Dom sounds like Dumbf as in Dumbfkopf - Dom Cobb - which is also the name of a character in the director's first film but I like to think of Island of the Damned joined by Dumbfkopf in eternal Limbo which is why Arthur declars Dom lost when Ariadne says that Dom went after Saito instead of staying with Mal.  I like to think that once in a while Mal takes away from her busy life to visit Dompf in the Darkness of his mind.As for the bizarre soap opera romance of the girl who can't take rejection and the brave paramour having the guts to break away from his "guilt" at her demise, I call shenanigans!  This movie has nothing to do with romance (unless you count the tasty and tiny pieces of candy proffered by Joseph Gordon Levitt's Arthur to Ellen Page's Ariadne.  These two delicate boned actors really work in THIS film more so than I can imagine James Franco and Queen of Louisiana Evan Rachel Wood would have in the same roles.I think that aside that Cantonese audiences will also appreciate Dileep Rao's "haHa bloody Ha" and Peter Postlewaite's assessment of the death of his wife as "there really being nothing more to say" as being very dry Cantonese.  Those lines make me laugh and never get old.
summary: Butters is Trapped in the Darkness of His Mind

reviewText: I tried watching this movie twice, the first time I stuck it through hoping it would get better. The second time, I thought I might understand it a bit better but lost interest and shut it off after half an hour. It is worth noting that I like action films and films with twists, I love movies about alternate realities. But in case I didn't make it clear enough, I hated this one.Inception is a science fiction film starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, Cillian Murphy, Tom Berenger and Michael Caine, to name but a few. DiCaprio plays a type of spy who, with his partner Arthur, extract valuable information from the subconscious of their targets while they are asleep and dreaming. Cobb struggles with the circumstances of the death of his wife and not being able to be with his children.Cobb is given an assignment to use his skills to affect the subconscious of his enemy's son, Cillian Murphy, in order to sabotage his empire. In return, Cobb will be able to reunite with his kids, who he hasn't seen since his wife's death.The plot is interesting but the dreams within dreams within dreams were really really confusing to me. Ellen Page is fantastic as is Cillian Murphy but I didn't really care for Di Caprio's acting. I always enjoy watching Michael Caine.So end result: I really really did not like it! My teenage kids disagree though and absolutely loved it.

reviewText: As soon as the film began, a chill went up my spine; a string of goosebumps. This doesn't happen very often and immediately I knew that this was going to be something special. Other than the extraordinary special effects, the most impressive aspect of the film is that every person in the main cast is important to the storyline. Even though this clearly revolves around Cobb, Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), Eames (Tom Hardy), Ariadne (Ellen Page), and Yusuf (Dileep Rao) are all given an appropriate amount of screen time and take full advantage of the time they're given. Every character has at least one moment where they have their time to shine, which is quite an accomplishment given how many people are in the cast. Even Saito (Ken Watanabe) and Robert Fischer, Jr. (Cillian Murphy) have their moments.The film is fabulously complex and there are so many things going on at once in the ladder half of the film that it results in the sci-fi actioner being incredibly difficult to spoil entirely without a longwinded explanation. I could tell you the last scene in the film right now and while it would make sense, things wouldn't fall into place or be entirely appreciated unless you knew everything leading up to that point.The film is superbly written. I'm a huge fan of films that make you think or are able to create something that at least feels like it's completely original and Inception accomplishes both of those things. On one hand, stealing anything you hold valuable from your dreams seems pretty far fetched. On the other, everyone dreams and everybody has secrets or at least something they keep locked away from most people. Imagining that those things are easily accessible to certain people because they've cracked the code on how to maneuver through your mental defenses is pretty intriguing and makes it seem easier to relate to since it's something everyone experiences.While everyone is waiting for the follow-up to The Dark Knight, Inception isn't the type of film that should be swept under the rug in the meantime. It's fantastically original, contains a spectacular cast where everyone involved delivers a strong performance, is wonderfully engrossing, and is definitely up to the high standard Christopher Nolan has set for himself with the other marvelous films on his resume. In typical Chris Nolan fashion, the ending is a huge tease but it's goosebump-worthy, completely fitting, and difficult to imagine the film ending any other way. Inception is Nolan's magnum opus and will be near impossible to beat as the movie of the year for 2010.

reviewText: Director/writer Christopher Nolan has explored dark, obsessive characters in exemplary films like The Dark Knight.  In his most ambitious story yet (one that took ten years to develop), he designs a thoroughly complex story with concurrent narratives (think Godfather Part II or Intolerance) where (like his earliest film, Following, and his classic, Momento,) time and reality are bent and juxtaposed.  This is not light, escapist fare but a deep, convoluted story that engages the mind and heart, and few movies in recent years can be so challenging yet rewarding to its audience.A man named Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) washes ashore and is taken by armed guards to an old man.  From there the film begins to jump in different settings or dream states.  Cobb is an expert at the art of `inception', the ability to enter people's subconscious to steal an idea or plant one.  A fugitive, he longs to be reunited with his two children and is constantly plagued by recurring visions of his wife, Mal (Marion Cotillard), who becomes increasingly dangerous.  A wealthy Asian businessman, Saito (Ken Watanabe), makes a proposition to Cobb: extract a piece of information from a rival businessman (Cillian Murphy), and Cobb gets to return home to his kids.  Vowing this to be his last job, Cobb assembles his team of experts, Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a newbie architect Ariadne (Ellen Page), a forger and impersonator, Earnes (Tom Hardy), and a drug chemist, Yusuf (Dileep Rao).  To infiltrate Fischer's mind, the team designs an elaborate set of dreams within dreams to effect a con game.  This compounds the risks and, as Cobb finds himself being harassed by a more menacing Mal, the team encounters last minute crises that force Cobb to make a desperate choice.  Can they get Fischer to reveal his secrets in time, and what of Cobb's personal obsession?The plot brings to mind the alternative realities of The Matrix, Dreamscape, and Altered States.  Like the magicians in Nolan's The Prestige, it is a slight of hand where much of the film's narrative plays like stream of consciousness.  It's about a lifetime of love that's experienced in mere flashes or an eternity, and despite the film's intricate machinations, its simple themes are the search for validation and love.  The film is also about the need of letting go and taking a leap of faith.  At times you wonder if any given scene is real or a dream, and that is the conceit of the film; for some, the dream IS the reality.The team concept is in keeping with Mission: Impossible and Oceans 11 (any version) as each member's expertise comes into play, and the deeper the team goes into the dreams, the greater the risks.  In one key sequence set in a snow mountain compound, there is an obvious homage to On Her Majesty's Secret Service, and you wonder what wonders Nolan could work on the James Bond franchise!This `dream' cast works together very well and includes Nolan's repertory actors, Murphy and Caine.  DiCaprio (looking astonishingly like Nolan) does an excellent job as the tortured soul with a dark secret.  Cotillard is hauntingly beautiful as Cobb's wife while the younger Page is adorable as the bright architect who also serves as Cobb's moral compass when he begins to falter and have self doubts.The film's technical accomplishments are outstanding, and although the special effects are terrific in depicting the mind bending scenery, the live action sets and stunt work (with Levitt doing some remarkable acrobatics) are even more impressive in depicting mixed gravity where people float or walk on walls and ceilings.  In a masterful blend of film editing, the dream sequences shuttle back and forth, and time is slowed to a crawl in one instance, and given years in another.  Hans Zimmer's relentless, minimalist score is a particularly noteworthy achievement of mood and dramatic pacing.This is not a perfect film, and (at two and one-half hours) there are moments where you think Nolan could have explored more of his subjects.  A director like Steven Spielberg or Ron Howard might have emotionally milked certain scenes for all they are worth, and it is because of that, we expect a bit more connection and feelings.  Like most of Nolan's films, the brooding characters and situations are almost entirely devoid of humor or any lighthearted tone which brings to mind any number of Stanley Kubrick films.  While some may find the ending a bit too neat or perhaps too open ended, it is left to the audience to decide how to interpret the meaning of the finale.  Yet these are minor quibbles for grand, pure cinematic experience.  Nolan has created something so special that it engages the mind. How dare he?With Inception, Christopher Nolan is most certainly one of the best film directors.  His previous masterpiece, The Dark Knight, should have been nominated for the Best Picture Oscar.  Come to think of it, that very film helped change the Oscar rules to expand from five to ten nominees so that gems like Inception are not left out.  It won't be.  Do take this wild ride, and you'll find that you are obsessed with its mystery and beauty and repeating the journey again and again.
summary: INCEPTION Is a Dream Come True

reviewText: I have yet to see a Christopher Nolan film I didn't love. "Inception" is refreshingly original and a welcome film in today's re-boot/re-make plagued film world. Christopher Nolan has crafted a masterpiece thriller with an exceptional cast to back it. The last film I saw that was this original was "District 9". I also love Hans Zimmer, but I felt that his last film with Nolan (The Dark Knight) was lacking. The score felt as though it was always building and your senses never had a rest because there was not resolve to the music, even at the end. That was not the case with "Inception". This score is beautiful and engrossing. It accompanies the film perfectly and resolves at the end. This film forces you to keep up with it. Its fast-paced and will confuse you if you stray for even a second. If you haven't seen this film yet, do yourself a favor and get it.
summary: Brilliant movie that really makes you work hard to keep up

reviewText: Cobb is sort of a spy.  He goes into your dreams and extracts important information.  But now, he and his team have been hired for a different kind of job: placing an idea within a person's head.  Inception.  Can it even be done?  Has Cobb done it before?  And what are the consequences of such a difficult action?It caused quite a stir, as pretty much any Chris Nolan film is bound to do nowadays (you can't direct the best superhero movie of all time and not expect people to riot over your work).  INCEPTION doesn't live up to all of the hype...but it lives up to most of it. (And it's better on the second viewing, too. the first time I saw it in theaters, I was mildly impressed.  The second time, I was awed.)  Leo DiCaprio turns in another rock-solid performance; not his best, but a deep and complex turn for him.  Ellen Page is so-so; she's done better, but her presence alone adds an extra bit of umpf to the film.  Marion Cotillard is truly sexy AND scary (a rare combination for an actress to pull off); Tom Hardy shines; Tom Berenger is just there, but we like him there, so it's okay; Cillian Murphy is great as always.  Joseph Gordon-Levitt is the standout of the cast; he's slick and funny, and one has to wonder how it would've been if he'd been cast as Cobb (not that DiCaprio isn't great).  Nolan's script and directing are top-notch; there are some logical flaws, but surprisingly nothing that brings the movie down too much.  And the special effects are breathtaking; I've rarely seen a movie this beautifully macabre that did so well at the Box Office.INCEPTION isn't quite the masterpiece it's been hailed as; it has its flaws, and some of the acting isn't quite up to snuff.  But that doesn't mean it isn't great; it is truly one of the best science fiction films of recent years.  INCEPTION is a movie that inspires both visual awe and deeper thought.  It won't please everyone, but to those who like their blockbusters with something more than just explosions and one-liners, it's truly a movie to watch again and again.
summary: Is all that we see or seem but a dream within a dream?

reviewText: Every generation has at least one great visionary director whose creative genius transcends their visual craft in a way that defies the conventional norm and is revered by critics and audiences for their originality and brilliance.  Christopher Nolan is, without doubt, this generation's Stanley Kubrick, Alfred Hitchcock, Ingmar Bergman, Akira Kurosawa, or Orson Welles and will long be remembered among that pantheon as one of the greatest film directors of all time.Inception is the movie thatThe Matrixwanted to be but wasn't and only dreams that it could have been while it was more preoccupied making itself look cool with science fiction technology and special effects, it merely stands upon the precipice of the elaborate canvas of storytelling genius that Nolan presents us here with Inception's intricately complex and labyrinthian narrative as he so masterfully demonstrated inMemento(2000) that relies upon virtually no science fiction technology at all, simply the dreams and imagination of its narrative construct.  There is never a dull moment as the viewer's mind is forced to keep up with the expository action racing along like a proverbial freight train.  The special effects are relatively seamless and exist only to support the rich, complicated framework of the story rather than distract from it with gratuitous explosions and an overindulgence of CGI that dominate the morose offerings of modern summer movie blockbusters.  Nolan's visual scope and palette are vast and epic but grounded in a believable and conventional reality, an illusion every bit as effective as the slight-of-hand deception ofThe Prestigethat will leave the viewer questioning what reality really is and which level of reality they are watching long after the film has ended.There are plenty of nods and send-ups to Nolan's favorite films and their influences are evident throughout, the most obvious of which beingBlade Runnerwhich Nolan is quoted as his biggest inspiration and alsoOn Her Majesty's Secret Servicewhich he cited as his favorite James Bond film.  For my money, they should just hand the keys to the Bond franchise over to Nolan right now and let him re-invigorate it with the same sophistication and panache that he brought to the Batman franchise withBatman BeginsandThe Dark Knight.  Tom Hardy already proved his theatrical range as a serious performer with his breakout performance asBronson(2009) and delivers an exceptional supporting performance as Eames mixing sly wit with a focused intensity that would be perfect to see him bringing to the role of future James Bond.Although I've never really cared much for Leonardo DiCaprio as a leading actor and have always regarded him as that "kid" from Titanic but I was completely taken by his emotionally intense performance as Cobb.  Nolan has a knack for casting only the best actors of the highest caliber for his roles and here Leo proves that he is more than a capable leading actor of his generation.  Cillian Murphy, Ken Watanabe, and Michael Caine once again bring an heir of class and benediction to their supporting roles as they had done previously in Batman Begins.Hanz Zimmer's intense score forInceptionis extraordinary delivering a lucid electronic ambiance that is both as ethereal as it is urgent, even darker and more melancholy than his score forThe Dark Knight (2 CD Special Edition).  Zimmer composes an auditory dreamscape that compliments the visual experience of the film by implanting its haunting melody in your mind and staying with you long after you've left the theater.Summer 2010 was looking pretty bleak until Nolan came along and rescued it much like he did in 2008 with The Dark Knight.  All my fears and doubts about how he was going to top that with the third Batman film have easily been subdued.  I have no doubt in my mind that he will deliver a spectacular finale to his chorus of Batman films with the same sophistication as he has demonstrated in Inception.  The Dark Knight is in good hands.  Now, just let him have the keys to the Astin Martin and let him write his own ticket.  Nolan is the real architect of our dreams.
summary: A flawlessly designed construct of cinematic architecture

reviewText: Christopher Nolan once again brings us a movie with special effects to dazzle us and brilliant writing to make us think. This is a movie which bears repeat viewings because some of its ideas and plot devices can be complex. You definitely want to watch it when you're prepared to do at least some thinking - it isn't one of those "turn off your brain" and be entertained action movies (different movies for different moods). There is a lot to like here, with an excellent cast, wonderful cinematography, some interesting twists, and a core that will make you feel for some of the characters.Cobb (DiCaprio) is an expert at getting into people's minds via their dreams and stealing information. Using a special device, he and some other specialists kidnap and drug the target individual, and then draw them into a dream world of their creation. In the dream they interact with the person and get them to reveal their secrets. All the time, the person's subconscious takes the form of people in the dream world who try to attack the invaders. If any of them die in the dream, they wake up. For some assignments, they actually create a dream within the dream in order to more completely disorient the person and have a better chance of stealing the information. There is also the risk of falling into limbo though, a world created by whoever gets trapped there and where time goes on and on. Limbo can be enticing to some because you have complete control over the world around you. The process of knowingly going into these dreams and sometimes seeing familiar places can cause one to question reality. This is where the movie starts to make you think.Although he gets paid to do this and almost certainly enjoys his work to some degree, what Cobb wants most in life is simply to be able to see his children. Wanted for the murder of his wife Mal - of which he is innocent - Cobb is constantly on the run and cannot return to the U.S. to even see his children. During one of his assignments, he is presented with an offer he can't refuse - plant an idea into someone's mind and a call will be made to clear up the warrant for his arrest. Inception - planting an idea into someone's mind - is much more difficult than stealing information from someone's mind so Cobb puts together a team of experts to accomplish this. One member of the team, Ariadne (Ellen Page), notices that Cobb has some guilt issues which interferes with his ability to perform and even think straight at times. Ariadne pursues it to the point where she finds out what really happened to Mal. This is where the movie starts to make you feel for the characters.The movie includes some great effects sequences and action scenes, including some where Joseph Gordon-Levitt's character is tumbling around the walls of a hotel (with stunts performed by Joseph Gordon-Levitt himself). Filmed on location in cities around the world such as Paris and Tangiers, the cinematography looks amazing both in the real world and in the dreams. A couple of structural devices used by the dream designers look like they're straight out of a M.C. Escher painting.I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a gorgeous science fiction movie which will also make you think. The dreams within dreams plot might get confusing at times, but there is an emotional core which doesn't get lost.
summary: Great combination of intelligence, heart, and effects

reviewText: An industrial spy (Leonardo DiCaprio) who can enter dreams to steal ideas leads a team (Joseph Gordon-Leavitt, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe, and Dileep Rao) into the mind of a young billionaire (Cillian Murphy) to introduce one instead.  This involves a mind-bending scheme that involves dreams within dreams and requires the participants to risk spending a subjective eternity in the limbo of the subconscious.I'm looking forward to Christopher Nolan's next Batman movie, but after this film, I kind of wish he wasn't wedded to that franchise and was instead free to create his next movie out of whole cloth.  He is one of the most impressive visionaries working in film today.  Here, he takes the familiar trope of the hardened professional willing to risk everything on one last job that will allow him to begin his life anew, and uses it as the foundation for an innovative story that doesn't spoon-feed the audience.  Some have criticized it for being confusing, and it is certainly complex, but attentive viewers should have little trouble following the action.  It is surprisingly effective on the emotional level as well for a big budget Hollywood spectacle.

reviewText: Inception is so good on so many levels!  Not just dream levels, either. The acting, the characters (especially Eames and Arthur), the visual effects, the storyline, the soundtrack - all are sooo good.  But, for me, what really cements at the "top of the top" movies are the twin themes woven into the movie: reconciliation and redemption. Reconciliation between son and father, reconciliation between wife and husband, and redemption through confession and confrontation.  You will need to watch it more than once to get a basic understanding of what's going on - and then, after that, watch it again  - and again - to allow the power of love and forgiveness go deep into your soul.
summary: So good - on so many levels!

reviewText: One of the things that attracts some people to science fiction (and repels others) is that its stories are usually based on "WHAT IF--?" premises that are NOT parts of our "normal reality." Much early "sci-fi" or "SF" was disparaged as crap because the premises overwhelmed both the story arcs and the characters--and the writing also was often very poor. In recent decades, a better balance has been found by hundreds of authors and dozens film makers, and both the TERMINATOR series and ALIEN series, for instance, are now highly respected classics.INCEPTION, I felt, is better than average but has at least three weaknesses--no, make that four--no, five. For one thing, the story arc is trite and its ending derivative (think Terry Gilliam's BRAZIL, 1985). For another, at its own "inception" we viewers are given material that coyly/pseudo-artfully prefigures some ending scenes but does not logically hold up (Ken Watanabe as an old man in BOTH spots). Thirdly, very often the exposition of the "What If--?" is clunkier than 20 speed bumps in a new housing development--the action grinds to a halt while one "expert" explains some new aspect of Dream Management 101 to another "expert," just so we viewers can eavesdrop and become informed. Fourthly, we really are NOT made to care much either way about the success or failure of the "mission" (a kind of caper involving a sub-category of industrial espionage) NOR about the happiness or misery of the main character, a somewhat charmless widower who wants to live with his young children (played by Leonardo DiCaprio). And the back-stories of the other characters are non-existent, so of course we don't care either way about them. And fifthly, the whole notion of creating the "inception" of an idea in a business rival's head rests on a shakier foundation than trickle-down economics: any kernel of an idea put into anyone's brain can sprout and grow in any of 57-million directions--NOT just the one narrow direction that is desired by the paymaster (played by Ken Watanabe).On the PLUS side--this film has fast-action and good CGI special effects in many places. It IS a decent mind-game with four levels of action that flash round-&-round in kaleidoscopic fashion--and then go to a fifth level. It IS way more mature in its psychology than James Cameron's AVATAR; it makes much more sense than the MATRIX series; and it's far, far, FAR superior in every respect to M. Night Shyamalan's THE LAST AIRBENDER.But I would still sooner rewatch STRANGER THAN FICTION (Will Ferrell, Helen Mirren, Dustin Hoffman). The only reason I put INCEPTION back into my DVD player the next day and sped past scene after scene to the end again--was to satisfy my curiosity--as to how LONG it ran. SPOILER ALERT: the version I watched ran 2:20:47--which is more than I'd have cared to sit in a theater, especially if I had bought a large cola.
summary: A THREE-CARD MONTE MIND-GAME--NO, MAKE THAT FOUR-CARD MONTE--NO, FIVE

reviewText: I finally saw the movie after renting it first from a Blockbuster kiosk. I have had so many people tell me how good it is and always worried about watching a movie with so much hype.However, it fully delivers, without a question. The actors are phenomenal, the script is fresh and creative, and the visuals and action sequences are exciting, unique, and original. I was not disappointed at all. Actually, I felt like the hype still didn't live up to the enormity or greatness of the movie.I am honestly shocked that I have seen that so many people did not like it. I don't know if it is because it feels high budget or because of the intense action sequences. But the acting is stellar and the story is original and compelling. I was under the impression that this is all that is necessary to make a good movie. This movie simply has great additional action and visuals-and added suspense.I absolutely loved it and I would highly recommend it to anyone who has enjoyed or appreciated The Matrix, The Dark Knight, or other movies similar to these.
summary: Still Unbelievable . . . . . despite the hype and naysayers
Title: N/A

reviewText: I like Nolan okay. I watch Memento fairly often and I enjoy it. I also like most of the cast of Inception. DiCaprio keeps turning out good performances even with weak material. But most of all, I like the epistemological/ontological subject matter of the film - The Cartesian Dream Problem, Plato's Allegory of the Cave, etc. It is a rich and worthwhile topic of discussion, and if done correctly it can make for an excellent film.Unfortunately, Inception didn't live up to its potential. It was over-weighted by special effects and forced drama, and far too light on actual substance or insight. And believe me, it's not that it went over my head. It went under my head. Maybe it received so many rave reviews because the number of morons who are impressed by zero-gravity fight scenes and collapsing cities is growing by the minute. Recommendation: only see Inception if you get free tickets and have an evening to kill. Better yet, just read Descartes' First Meditation and then watch Brazil (1985).
summary: Rehashed Descartes with Overdone Special Effects = Poor Film

reviewText: After the innovative ideas presented in the original Matrix movie, the subsequent films failed in a disappointing manner to add any real intellectual content.  They were good as SCI-FI, but not ground-breaking like the original.  This film takes off where the Matrix left off, raising strong issues and ideas with respect to the nature of reality and dream-states.  It gets into the "dream within a dream" experience (a real experience) with authenticity and depth.  The experience of multiple personalities within dreams gets substantial treatment.  Even the physics of dreams, and Einstein's General Relativity (equivalence of gravity and acceleration, as detected by the inner ear) gets a wonderfully creative treatment.  I have a very good strip sound system, and the audio was great on this.  This is a film that will keep you thinking for a long time, with tremendous special effects, and very fine acting by a strong cast of major characters.  With three disks and a digital copy, this is quite a value.
summary: This is where The Matrix left off

reviewText: I've always loved the "Alien" series  for their suspense and intense action. Inception is now in my collection right beside them. It should be a favorite of science fiction fans. Many of the concepts of the movie incorporate the experiences of everyday dreams that people have such as a sensation of falling will wake a dreamer up or that pain can be experienced in dreams. If you can surrender to the concept that a machine can be built to gain entrance to another persons dreams for the purpose of manipulation and industrial espionage then "Inception"  becomes all to real. A nail biter and edge of the seat movie that I'll watch over and over. I was pleased with Leonardo Dicaprio's performance. Since "Titanic" he has become a very mature and superb actor. He turned in a stunning performance. Way to go Leonardo. The $9.00 I paid for the DVD was well spent.

reviewText: I'm sure there will be as many admirers and detractors of this film but without a doubt, this imaginative thriller and "The Social Network" rank as two of the best of 2010--and of course the huge box office receipts for both these films can attest to that. Christopher Nolan has outdone himself in creating a visual universe that rivals that of the classic "Blade Runner" and has assembled a fine cast including Leonardo DiCaprio, Ken Watanabe, Marion Cotillard, Ellen Page, Michael Caine,Joseph Gordon-Leavitt and Ellen Page to create a near-classic. The question I ask is--will there be a sequel because of the huge box office returns that this film accrue? Nevertheless, savor this film and also if you have it in Hi-Def, use it as a demo so as to utilize the best aspects of your HDTV and Blu-ray player.
