reviewText: This movie was touted to be a thinking man's movie, that dreams are a perturbation of a higher reality. It's suppose make you question and beg the fabric of the world we live in, that we perceive, and to question if your current life is a dream. Plaster Inception with many special effects and explosions, this flick is bound to win many awards. It has that blockbuster type of production and feel to it.But these factors failed for the following reasons: 1) The storyline is too confusion, the "who, what, where, and when" is not obvious; 2) Too many dream sequences and levels down; 3) Suffers from poor character development (reminds me of Italian Job); 4) That portable dream machine device and wiring is a joke; and 5) The unconventional running length of 2  hrs is overwhelmingly a dragging work still in progress of editing.A movie's storyline should contain all the elements/points needed for a smooth understanding. Only later when I read about the synopsis did I connect the dots. But any movie should not require "homework" but should appeal to "average Joe" movie goers. A great movie is one that leaves you still thinking days later. I was lost here after 20 min.This movie could easily be 5 star by doing the following: 1) Don't hide the concepts, but make the driving force the story itself, and adventurous, for example classics like Star Wars, or Wizard of Oz. 2) Make dreams something we can ALL relate to (more realistic) by dumping the multi-layering aspect.  One level down is good enough.  3) Cut out some useless scenes, make it 1  hrs, but keep the special effects.As far as the product, 3 discs are encased in a standard sized blu ray case to save space. On the cover slip (a 3D hologram, though this is not a 3D movie) says, "digital copy." This product should NOT advertise "digital copy" (misleading), since it's actually "digital download." Like many other reviewers here, I was disappointed to find a digital copy missing from my purchase. Likewise, anyone would be disappointed too, if the blu ray disc were missing inside the case, but instead, a paper containing instructions on how to download the movie itself online. Worse yet, there's an expiration date (May 6, 2011) on the download.Inception had too much hype and expectations leading to letdown. Concept is nothing new here. Better thinking man's movie in the dream/reality genre I recommend are The Matrix, Truman Show, and Vanilla Sky.ADDENDUM UPDATE 02/10/11I watched Inception a second time and, whala!  The pieces of the puzzle fell into place.  I went from totally confused to totally the light bulb duh effect.If Inception left you with blanks, I STONGLY URGE you to watch Inception once more.  Confusing details will be clarified.  I think the movie was purposely made to mystify you at first, only to let the wow factor discharge with subsequent viewings.  I'm sure writer/director Christopher Nolan craftily planned this, intentionally placing scenes in the beginning left unexplained, knowing that inquisitive diehards will take a revelation the next time around.PLOT & CONCEPT OF THE MOVIEThe storyline is actually pretty simple.  Don't let that confuse you.  I will not inundate you with the plot details, as you'll read it elsewhere for easy explanation.  Actually, I'll place the plain framework synopsis in the comment entry section.  The what, who, why, when, how will be clarified.  Otherwise, let me go into the meat of this movie.Depending on how you view it, the concept of the movie as intended by the author C. Nolan is a bit more challenging, which my review here will address.  The premise of the movie is not that obvious, but when understood in the context of psychology, is quite deep.  And the significance of this movie's meaning is philosophical and the psyche blowing implications are staggeringly mind boggling as the concept are a mouthful to take in.  Hopefully I'll bridge some gap here.ONLY IN HOLLYWOOD, WITH AN INGENIOUS THINKER, WRITER, AND DIRECTOR.Though unique and original in its own way, Inception does follow suit with the other analogous mind-boggling concept movies that my further review is in allusion to encompass et al., not limiting to Inception.  That is to say my references to these mind twisting ambition are likewise, deduced aspiration similar in genre to movies/TV of such, The Matrix, Vanilla Sky, Truman Show, Tru Calling (TV), and The Adjustment Bureau (TBA, March 4th release).You can see there's a multitude of mind twisting movies.  They're nothing new.  They are to show what could be beyond, outside the box, which you never notice on your daily life's routine basis.  Like nothing can substitute the thrill of a coaster ride, it does take the creation by means of Hollywood movies and a distinctive writer/director to visually portray that outer (or inner) world beyond your perception, and likewise important, an audience who's equally open to interpret such ideas with the current methodology understanding process of science, philosophy, and existentialism.The following concepts or conclusion can be ascertained from the information provided by the story line and that the writer Nolan would like to audience to establish.  That dreams are as authentic as reality to the point for you to question, like Cobb & Mal did, if your current awaken reality state is actually a dream state?  And, as I will also describe how Inception is precisely and surprisingly consistent with the way we humans dream.  In addition, the concepts in Inception are shocking consistent w/ physics, philosophy, ideology, and theology.  (Don't assume Nolan didn't do his homework.  He warps all the bases for your mind). By consistent, I mean the following:METAPHYSICAL IMPLICATIONSIt is readily taken for granted; your thinking process is independent.  But if there's an external controller, how would you ever know it right?INCEPTOR / INCEPTEEHence, the first and principal foremost, insight is that the inceptee (the one being incepted, in this case Robert Fischer, the corporate heir and the target of Leonardo DiCaprio's dreamscape heist, played by Cillian Murphy), never realizes it.  By the same token, like Fischer, we are probably subjected to inception without a clue.  Nolan is showing that in the real world, the inceptee could be anyone, including you.In Vanilla Sky, David Aames (Tom Cruise) was trapped in a simulation unaware, and evidently tries vehemently to break away.  Matrix ccomputer programmer Thomas A. Anderson (Keanu Reeves) character is encased in the Matrix.  Tru calling TV where we never perceive the outer framework of our normal day to day perception, but Tru Davies (Eliza Dushku) could in that other dimension.  Likewise, Truman Burbank (Jim Carrey) never realized he was being watched by thousands.  In addition, Truman Show's architect designed the set and entire city and sky, stars, was framed, and what is believed by Truman, the heavens as well.  The Adjustment Bureau, {taken from the trailer, "Life is a series of events.  This man (Matt Damon).  This glance.  The moments all happen according to plan.  This plan, monitored by the bureau who run the world, behind the curtain you never knew existed."}Now the inception schemes in the movies Inception and Vanilla Sky may not be as quickly revealed compared to as in Matrix or Truman Show, or as obvious as in Tru Calling.  That's what leaves the art, mystery, attention focus span, and suspense more daunting in Inception.  See, you have to figure it out yourself before the answer to the puzzle is revealed, or before you're confused, or have to re-watch it again.CONTROLLERS / CONTROLEE-The external controllers are as follows:-Inception: Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his dream team, including Ariadne (Ellen Page), a young student architect tasked with designing the labyrinth of the dream landscapes.-Truman Show: the entire cast (except Truman), including Christof (Ed Harris), the creator AKA "god."-Matrix: it's Morpheus (Laurence Fishburne) and the Matrix itself.-Vanilla Sky, it's an unnamed man (Noah Taylor), and the court psychologist Dr. Curtis McCabe (Kurt Russell).-Tru Calling: it's Tru Davies (Eliza Dushku), and an unknown force (who gave Tru her calling ability).  Also, her father Richard Davies (Cotter Smith), and Jack Harper (Jason Priestley) as the counterintuitive force.-The Adjustment Bureau: the adjustment bureau team.The controllee are as follows:-Inception: it's Robert Fischer.-Truman Show: it's Truman Burbank.-Matrix: it's Keanu Reeves.-Vanilla Sky: it's Tom Cruise.-Tru Calling: it's those saying, "Help me!"  And in your life, well, you!-The Adjustment Bureau: David (Matt Damon).Lets look at some scientific data on how this may be true this moment, how inception and movies like these are in fact very consistent w/ pure science.Please check back.  I'm finishing / editing the rest of this review to publish soon.
summary: A very simple plot made way more complicated than it should be.

reviewText: To begin, I have been waiting for this film since Christopher Nolan announced it. All films I have seen from him are amazing and I usually have high expectations for him. AfterThe Dark Knight, I expected a great deal from this film. The previews only helped to flame the fire. It is also a common thing for me that when people talk about how wonderful a film is, I walk into the theaters overly-hyped and usually walk out disappointed. Case-in-point:Avatar. I was beginning to get over-hyped with this film since people couldn't stop talking about it and everyone loved it.Now, isn't it wonderful when you can get over-hyped and walk into a movie with sky-rocketing expectations and still come out completely satisfied?Yes, it's wonderful! And yes, that happened with this movie!The movie follows a team of mind-navigators that specialize in stealing secrets. They find that they may be well in over their heads when they accept the job of performing an inception,  a task where they must plant an idea so deep in someone's mind that the person must believe that it is their own idea.This movie was amazing! The story was original and thought-provoking, the graphics were incredible, the acting was very good, the music was awesome, and the ending was perfect! I know a lot of people were upset with the ending, but I loved it! The end! This movie was awesome! My favorite movie of all time, and that is a hard bar to reach! Thank the heavens we have Christopher Nolan around to create astounding movies and never leave us disappointed! And just a hint for Hollywood, he didn't have to do it with all the sex and the cussing and the gore that you think is oh-so-necessary!Okay, this is the end for reals.But the movie was awesome. Okay I'm done.It rocks. Last thing I'm gonna say.Awesome.[...]

reviewText: Dreams have always been abstract, interesting and hard to explain. The intrigue of dreams vs reality. When does one cross the line? In Inception, Leonard di Caprio leads an all-star ensemble (including Ellen Page, Marion Collard, Ken Watanabe, Jospeh Gordon-Levitt, Michael Caine etc.), to explore the realms of the dream state, delve into deep subconsciousness, reconcile with differences and issues and come to terms with reality. 148 minutes of suspense and CGI action that's really a thought-provoking and introspective look at life. Profound while entertaining, this is Chris Nolan's shot at critical and commercial success. Leonardo Di Caprio continues to shine in his tormented role (after Shutter Island) and you would think the Oscar will be his next year.  A+

reviewText: After the spectacular "The Dark Knight", Christopher Nolan introduces us into a new masterpiece. When I saw the trailers for Inception, I didn't know what to expect but when I saw it the day it premiered I was completely blown away. So blown away that I watch it again in theaters. 2010 was a year full of dissapointments (especially in the summer) and Inception was the only live-action film that truly delivered. It presents a completely original complex idea of how dreams work that in other less talented hands would have been a mess but in Nolan's hands is a masterpiece. Add amazing special effects, a talented cast and a fantastic score provided by Hans Zimmer and you have one of the best movies ever. I've seen some good movies this year like The Social Network, Black Swan and others and while they are really good, Inception is the best and by far is my year's favorite (alongside Toy Story 3).Inception in Blu-Ray looks fantastic. There is really good detail with no grain, artifacts or any other bad thing that could plague the picture. Even more impressive is the sound, with a dts-hd 5.1, Inception really rocks the house.You have a handful of bonus material like some deleted scenes, trailers and most exciting the Extraction-Mode viewing experience which dissects many scenes of the film and the crew discusses how they achieved this amazing scenes.A DVD/Digital Copy disc is also offered.Inception is a clever, well-constructed film that deserves every praise that it got. I know The Social Network is the favorite to win the top prizes but I really hope Inception wins because is fantastic. Completlety Recommended.
summary: Excellent film and my favorite of 2010!!

reviewText: Inception is a great thriller that is original, intelligent, and worth the price of admittance.  It is a movie that demands participation of the viewer.  This is the case of any real "think of the possibilities" film.  Anyone who expects the film to unfold in simple terms will not only be disappointed, but will not understand the content.  This is the reason the film is getting some bad reviews on Amazon.  There are those who are unable to get involved in film and would rather have some monster running around gutting a cast of guest victims (the lowest common denominator).Inception deals with dreams and the layered dream world affect on space and time.  The special effects are well rendered, but the real thrust of the film is the storyline.  If the viewer enters the world of Inception with a mind to follow its complexities, the film will not only prove itself worthy of a top rating, it will open the neurotransmitters of the mind and send the intelligent on a trip they will not soon forget.  In other words, this is not a film for the common dullard who will not understand what the heck is happening.  For more in the dullard perspective, read the one star reviews.The blue ray disk has excellent extras, including a great 50 minute documentary on dream states. Beyond the talking heads, the visuals are akin to an acid trip.  The whole package is well worth the ride.

reviewText: Frankly, I don't get it.Inception was one of the most acclaimed movies of 2010. I was anticipating great things.Didn't see, hear or feel them.The plot was very hard to follow, but, once I'd watched a while, I didn't much care anymore, and the whole thing became incomprehensible.Right from the start, the film had no context; the people on the screen seemed connected to no one and nothing. They were just there for no appreciable reason. They hardly seemed connected to each other.The dialogue was jejune - what there was of it - mostly there were declamations. The acting was either bad or missing - I was especially sorry to see the talents of Joseph Gordon-Leavitt and Marion Cotillard utterly wasted.Leonardo DeCaprio is in a league of his own. It's not that he can't act - though his skills are rudimentary - he just doesn't. He seems to have one facial expression for most of the movie, although sometimes he squints. Since his is the only character dealt with at length and since he is opaque, the film lacks any emotional touchstone.There is a lot of action, although it doesn't add up to much, perhaps because it is so random; causality is missing. Credibility is stretched until it twangs in your face - if what they all are doing is so delicate, why are they actually in a van careening around a city instead of in some quiet apartment? (Silly - quiet apartments don't plunge off of bridges.)The vaunted special effects - I had seen virtually all of them in the trailers for the film, and, since there seemed to be no point to any of them and since they passed by rather quickly, I found them unimpressive.The ending is supposed to be enigmatic - it is, but it is also predictable.Moral of this story: Watch things like this on DVD - it's easier to turn them off than to struggle through a row of rapt people to escape.

reviewText: Not since the publication ofThe Interpretation of Dreamshave dreams seemed so alien as they do in this film.  The story plays-off of ideas of lucid / shared dreaming that are found in earlier films such asDreamscapeandThe Serpent and the Rainbow.  However, in the present movie, the objective is not to kill the dreamer (DREAMSCAPE) or to scare / harrass the dreamer (SERPENT / RAINBOW) but, rather, the goal is to manipulate the dreamer & make the individual reveal their secrets.The mechanism for being able to get into other people's dreams is left ambiguous & is largely beside the point.  This is much more of a "What if?" sort of movie rather that one that tries to have a plausible explanation for something that is far-fetched.So, if you're looking for a story that Freud & Jung would have gone bonkers over, this film might just be for you.  Whether you like it or dislike it (and I'm sure there are many who will not care for this movie as it is rather bizarre), one thing you cannot accuse the film of being is a predictable formula movie the likes of which Hollywood churns out by the dozens.  It may also be useful to remember the adage of the poet Edgar Allen Poe:  "All that we see or seem is but a dream within a dream."

reviewText: Christopher Nolan's winding, twisting dream epic is just as revelatory today as it was in the theater a few years ago. Nolan clearly took his time with this script, a full eight years in the making, and it bears gorgeous fruit in the form of a rich, bright analysis of lucid dreams, shared consciousness and the very roots of influence in an individual psyche. Those are some pretty heavy concepts to just toss around in a Hollywood blockbuster, but through careful elaboration and a few very stylish test cases, it manages to efficiently explain the ground rules and get on to telling the story without bucking the casuals or alienating the intellectuals. With all sorts of hidden truths, cleverly-masked winks and subtle hints at all sorts of deeper meanings, there's also much more here than can be absorbed in a single viewing. Although the run time falls well north of two hours, the groundwork is so enveloping - and the plot so fast-paced - that the minutes just rip by without any regard for the clock on your wall. It's a fantastic effort, and a great indication that large-scale, big-budget American filmmaking is still capable of bringing the goods from time to time.
summary: Crafty, Intelligent, Deep and Emotive; It's Among Nolan's Best

reviewText: Inception is by far one of the most original films in recent years. A great action film, it also provides a strong metaphor for film making. What makes the film great are the strong performances by Leo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy,Marion Cotillard  Ellen Page, Dileep Rao and Ken Watanabe and the spectacular visuals. DiCaprio plays Dom Cobb, a master extractor - a specialist in stealing information from target's dreams. Cobb assembles a team in order to perform inception - influenced inspiration on a subconscious level - so that he can have criminal charges placed against him lifted and return home to his family. While the plot requires a large amount or suspension of disbelief, it is handled in a brilliantly realistic manner. The Bluray includes a number of entertaining extras for people who like learning more about the behind the scenes process. This movie should be considered one of the new "classics" and is definitely worth the purchase.

reviewText: Inception is an interesting movie but might not be everyone's cup of tea.  Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a man who specializes in dream extractions (think corporate espionage) - going into a shared dream state using a military derived technique with a team and a subject to extract a piece of information from that subject's subconscious mind.  This can sometimes involve going into a dream within a dream (or more).Much was made of the complexities of this movie and indeed it is complex but for a generation growing up watching Matrix movies (especially the latter two) this is positively straight forward - and that's not a bad thing.  This is helped by Cobb's new dream architect (played by Ellen Page) who is also new to this world and to whom he explains the rules of the dream world (and thereby us - something not as well done in the Matrix flicks).  In addition to these dream rules there are the complexities of Cobb himself and the guilt he feels over the tragedy of his wife and kids and how this affects his missions.  And the complexities of the new job - to plant an idea into the mind (this process is called inception) of a young business tycoon who has a strained relationship with his dying father.  So yes it is complex but at no time did I feel lost either and this is a major plus for the movie.Some other plusses are extremely cool effects in the dream worlds, likable and believable characters whose interactions are fun to watch, effective action scenes, light comedic moments that pop up rarely but never fall flat and a satisfying emotional arc for our main character.  Truly there are many positive aspects to this movie.Some minuses are that it's a bit too long with a few dragging dialog sequences that could probably have been edited down.  This leads to the fact that it does slow down in parts such that you begin to get antsy (not that I have a short attention span but in a world where anything can happen?).  Despite the preceding two sentences I have to admit that all the dialog added to the movie in one way or another.I was a bit distracted by the fact that the dream rules - although meticulously laid out (which is appreciated) - did not always feel like the movie followed to the letter as laid forth.  (possible minor spoilers) For example the rules of time of a dream within a dream, etc. are laid forth but at times things seem to happen way too fast a layer or two in compared with what we know the rules are.  I also understand that the filmmakers wanted a realistic representation but I felt that dreams were - on the whole - rather boring.  I get that these particular dreams were tailor made but they were so orderly it was a bit disconcerting.  No chaos, no random events, unless provoked by the outside world (or only the next layer up),  just cities and buildings and people in suits.  Speaking for myself (but I'm insane) my dreams are a bit more chaotic.  Then again there were a few surprises in there and a few very cool dream fight sequences.Overall, yes, I do recommend this movie.  It's not as complicated as you may initially think but carries its own for sure.  The characters are well developed and the action carried out quite well within a well defined universe.  It is long and you may struggle with some of the rules but overall the movie is rewarding in visuals, story, overall action and emotional depts.  A solid four stars.

reviewText: This is an excellent film. It's a daring film too. Like another film, The Usual Suspects, it starts in the present with a scene between an old man and a young one. The old man asks him what he wants and the young man struggles to recall what he wants from the old man. It leads to the start of the story in the past and an extraction job on the train to Kyoto, Saito's offer to Cobb, the assembly of the team, putting together their game plan for putting an idea into a financial rival's mind, the dream shared aboard the jet, onto the opening scene again when the young man why he's here then onto the final scene. The plot is superb. One man, Cobb, wants to find his way home to his family while another one, Saito, is willing to pay a fortune to change the outcome of events with a rival business firm through the inception of an idea into his rival's mind. The cast is also superb. It took more than Leonard DiCaprio to pull this story off. In this case there was some strong writing. Something closer to six or seven characters were needed for the development of the plot. Is it too complicated or just too intriguing? I really enjoy watching a good film again and again and have truly enjoyed Inception. Dreaming by itself was no basis for a story but to the credit of Inception it introduced dream-sharing by way of a new technology. In view of the developments over the past 60 years viewers will find it quite easy enough to suspend their disbelief. Cobb and his wife, Mal, put the learning to use by way of extracting ideas by people. Once they began building dreams within dreams extraction was easier but time moves at a different and slower pace at various levels of a dream. It can also become difficult to distinguish a dream from reality and they finally lose their way into the sub-conscious. After fifty years down there Cobb tries inception on Mal and plants an idea in her mind which leads to their return but Mal suspects that she's still dreaming and wants Cobb to return to reality. One night she tries to blackmail Cobb by informing the police that she suspects her husband will kill her. Dreams can be usually brought to an end when the dreamer runs out of time on the machine or is killed. After she kills herself Cobb leaves the country to avoid arrest but he's still deeply filled with regret and guilt about Mal who is constantly trying to keep him with her. It's interesting how one storyline is affecting the other one and the characterization which results from it.Ken Watanabe plays Mr. Saito. He's heard about extraction and rumours about conception. He's convinced that he will be financially ruined by his rival, Mr. Fischer. Now he's heard rumors about Cobb's skill but before he asks Cobb he wants to make sure that he's talking to the right mind. So he arranges an audition for Cobb's crew under tough conditions with himself as the target. Cobb extracts the information but he realizes that Saito has known all along about the job from start and asks why? Saito was never interested in the extraction but the level of Cobb's skill. While Cobb extracted the information, Saito wasn't impressed with the level of skill that Cobb showed. His opinion of Cobb quickly rises when he realizes that he's still dreaming. Cobb placed him in a dream inside a dream. In the following scene Saito makes an offer to Cobb of financial reward and a safe return to America if he can succeed in planting an idea in his rival's mind. Money is no problem with Saito. So Cobb finds a top-notch crew who will work for him and his partner, Arthur. DiCaprio clearly dominates the first crew but when Saito tells him to put together a better team he becomes part of the team. Michael Caine puts in a strong appareanance as Cobb's father-in-law who finds him another architect in dream-sharing, Ariadne played by Ellen Page. Then it's onto Africa for an interview with an old friend, Eames played by Tom Hardy, who's a skillful thief and forger and introduces Cobb to Yusuf, the Chemist played by Dileep Rao. Fischer, played by Cillian Murphy, puts in another good performance as Saito's rival. What's really interesting are all the contributions everybody makes towards the development of the story. It is a well written story and well performed one. You'll also appreciate the quick pace.While the dream starts on the jet. The levels of the dream can always be identified. The first level of the dream can always be identified by the rain in a city downtown. The primary development is the appearance of projections from Fischer's mind into dream who will defend him against any attempt at extraction. On this level Saito is shot and dying but on the lower levels it will take longer for him to die. Eames attempts to kill him and end the dream but the sedative taken demands their return to consciousness in a particular fashion. If they die they are lost in a sub-consciousness of the dreamer. So they must go onto the next level of the dream inside a van that Yusuf is driving. The second level of the dream is found in an expensive hotel where Cobb plays a figure on this level known as Mr. Charles and poses as one of the projections sent to guard Fischer. Mr. Charles gains Fischer's trust and convinces him that a corporate figure in his father's company is betraying him and the only way to learn the truth is entering a third level of the dream. The third level takes place in winter and the mountains where Fischer fights to learn the truth and the team plants an idea in him.In the meantime Saito dies during the assault. The scenes in the sub-conscicous take place in beautiful weather on the seaside. The final beach scene leads you to an earlier scene from the start of the film: an old man asks Cobb what he wants. The old man is Saito who was killed and has been lost for years. Cobb now remembers the audition for Saito, the inception and his confrontation with Mal. He urges Saito, now an old man filled with his regrets and guilt to come back with him and be young again. Well, the next scene tells you what happen he finds himself waking aboard the jet with Fischer, Saito and his crew. Saito places a call to set things in motion which will clear the way for Cobb's return home.I've seen this film on numerous occasions over the past few years. It just keeps getting better. It only proves the importance of good writing and acting to one another as well as editing and directing. Suspense simply is not a factor. Yet the story constantly grips you. You simply don't realize the length of the film by its quick pace of the story.
summary: Science fiction, fantasy, drama, mystery or adventure?
Title: N/A

reviewText: For months, just like everyone else on Earth, I've been hearing and seeing the buzz surrounding Christopher Nolan's newest film, Inception. However, due to time constraints caused by college and other personal matters, seeing the movie wasn't high on my list of priorities. Since I just got a mini vacation from college this week, I found some time to finally watch it, and I must tell you, the movie left me scratching my head. Now don't let that past sentence fool you. I wasn't scratching my head over how "complex" the movie was, but rather over why so many people are hailing this as one of the greatest movies ever made. Sure, this movie is a deep and complex brain twister if you're only familiar with the cookie-cutter Hollywood swill like Smokin' Aces or the Twilight franchise, but go read a Philip K. Dick book or watch a film by Satoshi Kon or Andrei Tarkovski, then come back and tell me how "genius" Inception is.STORY"Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is the best there is at extraction: stealing valuable secrets inside the subconscious during the mind's vulnerable dream state. His skill has made him a coveted player in industrial espionage but also has made him a fugitive and cost him dearly. Now he may get a second chance if he can do the impossible: inception, planting an idea rather than stealing one. If they succeed, Cobb and his team could pull off the perfect crime. But no planning or expertise can prepare them for a dangerous enemy that seems to predict their every move. An enemy only Cobb could have seen coming."-Taken from product description (too lazy to summarize plot myself).CHARACTERSWhat's a movie, regardless of how thought-out the plotting is without any interesting or properly fleshed-out characters? Unfortunately, Nolan overlooked properly developing characters or even giving them anything interesting or charming to their personalities so that we could latch on to them as the movie went along. With the exception of Cobb, the characters are either mere plot devices or exposition magnets. The biggest exposition magnet by far is Ariadne played by the miscast Ellen Page. She spoon feeds every little detail to the audience, not letting us think for ourselves. Some of the worst offenses are with the scenes with Ariadne telling Cobb after a flashback or dream "You have some dark stuff buried in you." You really think so? Whatever happened to "show, don't tell?" Cobb's inner demons revolving around his dead wife, Mal, had some potential, but I wasn't emotionally moved at any point in the film since Nolan was too focused on the architecture of the dreamworld and the little "ticks" going on with it rather than actual character development. Supporting characters like Saito and Arthur were very dull since like everyone else, were just plot devices.EXPOSITION, EXPOSITION! RUSH IT OUT A-S-A-P!For a movie acting like it's intelligent, it sure talks down to the audience. As stated before, nothing is left to the imagination. Much superior dream-related films like Total Recall (1990) and Paprika (2006) establish their own rules about dreams and create dreamworlds that require one or two little bits of exposition and after that, you fully understand their workings and can enjoy the rest of the films without further explanation. However, the dreamworld in Inception was way over-developed since there's too much to the structure as to where it requires constant explanation. This is a clear case of too much complexity killing a potentially good idea. Some might defend the heavy dialogue, stating that the explanations give people a full understanding of the universe Nolan created. However, it doesn't work with me because when I watch a movie, I care about character development and exploration of certain ideas, I could care less about every tiny detail in a certain universe since I only want enough information as to where I can follow it.LACK OF ORIGINALITYLots of people are hailing this as very creative and original. I can't disagree more with this notion because this feels like a stale copy of Paprika. Paprika focused on psychotherapists diving into the dreams of their patients to understand the subconscious better and to get information important to them (such as the theft of their technological breakthrough, the DC Mini). Inception focuses on people diving into peoples' dreams so they can steal or plant ideas. While Paprika had better visuals and characters to go with its dreamworlds, Inception opts for very conventional imagery and bland characters, thinking that the "amazing" multi-layered dreamworld is enough to hold the movie together.TOO MUCH CONVENTIONALITYFor a movie focusing on dreams, Nolan's take on dreams was terribly vanilla. I don't know about the rest of you, but while my dreams can relate to parts of me that are entirely personal, they're largely nonsensical, unpredictable, and depending on who you talk to, disturbing. The lack of predictability in someone's mind renders the idea of a "dream architect" successfully creating a dreamworld in someone's head as a pretty silly one. Having Paris fold in on itself and having rotating mirrors on the streets wasn't too imaginative, and that's the only "surreal" imagery you get in this dream-themed film, everything else looks very conventional.PRETENDING TO BE "SMART"It looks like Nolan made some quick searches on Wikipedia to shoe-horn in some "smart" ideas into the film. The best example of this would be when Arthur explains to Ariadne the concept of the Penrose Stairs and explains how it's an infinite loop, and how it's that concept that's used to confuse inception victims, then the camera moves down to show that it's a regular staircase. Wow, wasn't that genius?!! The other part that pretends to be "smart" is the plotting. Again, Total Recall and Paprika successfully merged fantasy and reality and really twisted the audience's minds questioning what's happening is real or not. With Inception, however, it's quite easy to follow the dreams within dreams within dreams within dreams because they're neatly separated from each other, you just have to keep track of them (I guess Nolan thinks we're too stupid to do that). The last quarter or so of the movie gets extra convoluted with quick cuts between the multi-layered dreams and Cobb facing Mal in others. I guess this was supposed to make the movie puzzle-like and give the audience something to solve.SOUNDTRACKNolan depends on Hans Zimmer to deliver an overblown score for an overblown movie. Since Nolan forgot to properly develop characters and give them any legitimate tension, he depends on Zimmer to fill nearly ever second of the movie with music to drive home how we're supposed to feel in certain scenes. Look, music can be a great element in enhancing the emotion in certain scenes, but when you're depending entirely on it to drive home certain scenes, that's just unprofessional.FINAL WORDAt the end of the day, Inception is just another "style over substance" over-priced summer cash-in (much like Nolan's previous movie, The Dark Knight), but unlike most others of its ilk, it really hurts itself by pretending to look like a thinking-man's film. At least the recent Transformers movies are honest with being loud special effects vehicles and the fans will agree with that notion. I'll give Inception some more points than that blue abomination Avatar since it felt a little more ambitious than that blue liberal propaganda piece, but it's still quite a wretched picture. If you want some great and truly thought-provoking sci-fi, go read the Selected Stories of Philip K. Dick and go watch Paprika (2006), Total Recall (1990), Solaris (1972), and Stalker (1979).The day that people stop looking at Nolan's movies through rose-colored glasses can't come sooner.
summary: A stupid movie pretending to be smart.  25%

reviewText: How does a director follow up one of the biggest films of all time? By doing a film with more action and explosions? Or by directing a film that is even more ambitious and thought-provoking? Christopher Nolan seems to have found the answer with Inception: you do both.After The Dark Knight's massive success, it's no wonder that Warner Bros. gave Nolan carte blanche to do whatever he wanted with his next movie. And boy, does he. A creation spawned from his own mind (a rarity that a film this big isn't a sequel or an adaptation of a comic book or children's novel these days), Nolan delves into the realm of dreams and the subconscious with Inception.Describing what Inception is about in a mere paragraph is nearly impossible, as you'll notice the back of the Blu-ray/DVD combo package lacks the customary brief synopsis. But I'll do my best to describe the film here: Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his team (populated by Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Tom Hardy, and Ellen Paige) specialize in "extraction" - stealing secrets from a person's mind through their dreams. Cobb, a fugitive of the law, takes one last job with the hope of being able to go home to his children. But this job may be the most difficult of all - inception, or the act of planting an idea in a subject's mind. Problem is, the human mind can't be fooled into adopting outside ideas very easily. So Cobb and his team must delve into the deepest recesses of a man's subconscious, by infiltrating a dream within a dream withing a dream, to plant the idea in the most subtle way possible. But Cobb has a secret in his own subconscious that could jeopardize the entire operation. And failing the mission might land Cobb in prison for the rest of his life, either in reality or in his own mind.Inception is one of those films that is so complex (there are literally four plot threads simultaneously occuring at the same time during the film's climax), that attempting to pick up the film halfway through and understanding it all is impossible (which means good luck to anyone who ever watches this for the first time once it is inevitably aired on television). It may frustrate those viewers who still like to check their brains at the door when they watch their action films, as plot explanation and plot details come so fast that even a quick bathroom break might leave you scrambling to make sense of the next scene. Even the film's character's get a little confounded, as Ellen Paige's Ariadne asks at one point, "Whose subconscious are we going into, exactly?" It's one of those film's that is "spoiler-proof" since knowing how the film ends means nothing if you didn't know how the film got there.And that is truly a wonderful thing in an age where films are so predictable that we know exactly what a movie is about and how it is going to end just from watching the previews and commercials. Nolan loves the element of surprise and keenly knows that it desire to find out will fill even more theater seats, as even the pre-release trailers for Inception gave no clue as to what it was about. It also doesn't hurt that long-time collaborators like cinematographer Wally Pfister and composer Hans Zimmer bring their stellar work to Nolan's world of dream thievery. And the best films keep people talking long after the credits roll, and the film's brilliantly ambiguous end is truly up to the viewer to decide and postulate their own theories as to what really happened.Inception is one of the best mindbending science fiction films of our time, taking its rightful place among greats like The Matrix, Dark City, and Blade Runner. It's a film that begs to be watched more than once. Now you can buy this Blu-ray/DVD combo pack of Inception to watch, rewatch, and watch yet again. But whether that spinning top falls down or not is up to you.
summary: One of those truly great "mindf&@%" movies

reviewText: Christopher Nolan may be the most brilliant, unconventional mainstream director working in Hollywood today, crafting intricate stories where narrative forms are stretched and twisted.Nowhere is this more obvious than "Inception," which turns into a multi-level Möbius strip -- worlds within worlds, dreams within dreams. Nolan delights in being able to conjure strange worlds that could never exist in real life, but he crafts a very heartfelt, powerful story for those visuals -- a story of love and loss, ambition and power, and a broken man haunted by guilt that constantly chases him through every dream.In the not-too-distant future (next Sunday A.D.), the military has created a technology that allows artificial shared dreaming. Within multi-leveled dreams, architects can create elaborate worlds, and special "extractors" can get information from a sleeping subject's brain. Oh, and there are several layers of dreaming, each with a different period of time passing.The movie opens with Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his partner Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) trying to extract some information from tycoon Saito (Ken Watanabe). It turns out that this was actually an elaborate audition by Saito, who wants to hire them for an "inception" -- to plant a new idea in someone's head. Cobb isn't interested until Saito offers to clear him of the murder of his wife, which would allow him to return to his young children.Their target: Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy), who has just inherited a massive energy conglomerate from his cold, callous father. Saito wants the company dissolved before it can become too powerful, so he wants the idea incepted into Robert's head.So Cobb gets together a gang of the best: clever forger Eames (Tom Hardy), dream-chemist Yusuf (Dileep Rao), and the new architect Ariadne (Ellen Page). But only Ariadne sees how troubled Cobb is, and that the memory of his dead wife Mal (Marion Cotillard) is deliberately sabotaging every mission he undertakes. As the team weaves their elaborate web of deception and dreams around Robert, Cobb finds that his demons are threatening their mission.You have to give it to Christopher Nolan: he doesn't dumb down his movies for the masses. "Inception" is a hard movie to even summarize because it's constantly growing more complicated -- the team is spread out over different dream levels, with different time periods passing and different perils attacking them simultaneously. It's half heist caper and half sci-fi meta-thriller... if that even makes sense.And while Nolan sculpts a strange Escheresque dream-world of labyrinths and never-ending stairs, he also crafts some powerful subplots about love and loss. As the plot unwinds, he intertwines Cobb and Fischer's personal issues with the main story of inception. Suddenly the constant firefights, explosions and free-falling elevators/vans aren't the only reason we're invested -- the audience is truly left wanting to see both men work out their issues and find some measure of inner peace.It also has spectacularly good special effects, particularly Arthur's battle in the hotel -- he scampers across the walls and ceilings, grappling with projections as he floats through empty halls. Not to mention the scene where Ariadne turns a whole city upside-down... literally.Honestly, the biggest problem with the movie is that the dreams sometimes make too much sense. Why do Fischer's projections have to actually TRAVEL to attack the team instead of... I don't know, materializing inside the building?Nolan also populates "Inception" with a lot of actors that he's cast in other projects, especially "The Dark Knight Rises." In fact, I can't help but wonder if DiCaprio's role was originally offered to Christian Bale, because we've also got Cotillard, Hardy, Watanabe, Murphy, Gordon-Levitt and Michael Caine. There are actually only a couple major actors who haven't worked with Nolan elsewhere.But this is one of DiCaprio's best roles, even if he's not very convincing as a father -- his Cobb is riddled with guilt and numb sorrow, and it's only prodding from Ariadne that finally gets him to confront his issues. All the other actors give lovely performances as well -- Cotillard is particularly wrenching as a strange shallow shade of a madwoman, as is Murphy as the downtrodden son of a powerful man."Inception" is the kind of movie that we desperately need more of -- a wild Möbius strip of complex ideas, brilliant direction and powerful acting. This is truly a one-of-a-kind film, and not one to be missed.

reviewText: I've loved every Christopher Nolan movie I've ever seen from Memento to The Dark Knight but Inception left me a bit unsatisfied. My main issue is the same issue that many people had with the Matrix movies in that there are no well defined rules under which the movie operates. I will attempt as best I can to avoid any spoilers but it's hard when talking about the mechanics of the movie.As one might tell from the previews and articles on Inception it's about delving into dreams. Using technology and drugs Leonardo DiCaprio and his crew are able to inject themselves into peoples dreams in order to extract information for things like industrial espionage. In order to accomplish this they use an architect to construct the logistics of the dream in a way to best accomplish their task. Death in a dream wakes the dreamer. Also, there is a severe time dilation since a dream moves as fast as the human mind rather than as fast as the real world so minutes of sleep can produce hours of dreams. The plot centers around DiCaprio attempting to produce an inception. An inception is the implantation of an idea into a subject's brain while convincing them that it is their own idea. Apparently this is a very difficult task and requires a three level dream within a dream within a dream as well as the use of heavy sedatives. Having a three layer dream will produce an even greater level of time dilation and I as best as I can remember DiCaprio said that as far as the dreamers were concerned this process would take what appears to them to be ten years despite sleeping only around ten hours. This time dilation was apparently important enough that Ellen Page repeated it for emphasis and the thought of this being a ten year operation was pretty intriguing. So where are the problems?Again, I'm trying to avoid spoiler but I will reveal some smaller plot points to make my argument. The target of the inception will be a wealthy heir played by Cillian Murphy who played The Scarecrow in the Batman movies. Things immediately go wonky when it becomes obvious that Murphy's character has been trained to resist invasions into his mind and he immediately launches a counter attack by his sub conscious represented by armed assailants. The next problem is that DiCaprio's group used a sedative that's so powerful that if someone is killed in the dream rather than wake they will descend into a severely time dilated abyss where their mind will be trapped for decades likely driving them insane. I would assume the movie is taking place in Murphy's dream which I guess would give him an edge. Murphy seemed only capable of fighting them subconsciously and didn't even recognize the armed assailants as representatives of his own psyche. What I couldn't figure out was since the attackers were his subconscious everything must be representational rather than real. What did a bullet through the chest represent? Was it a successful domination of will? If someone is shot but lingers does that mean that the two are locked in some kind of mental battle of wills. From my experience if I'm shot in dream I could be perfectly fine in a moment but in this movie wounds seem to be as permanent as an injury in the real world. In fact, besides the occasional tilting of the world and loss of gravity at one point there didn't seem to be much difference between the dream world and the real world. I have no idea whether Cillian Murphy's sub conscious guards were horrible shots or if this was part of a dream. It seems hard to believe that several people opening up with heavy automatic weapons on a stationary van could miss with every bullet. The last big issue was that this so called time dilation seemed only to occur at times where it was convenient to the plot. Not only did the operation not take a purported ten years I would estimate that start to finish it took maybe two to four hours a most which means it was actually less time than the ten hours that they had Cillian Murphy available. Yet at one particular important plot point an event that would have taken only a few seconds allowed them I would estimate 45 minutes or so of apparent time. There was no consistency. Last but not least was how relentless the action was once things kicked up and there was this ever present heavy musical score.Christopher Nolan has had such a consistent track record of great movies that even a good movie like Inception felt disappointing. The acting and casting are fantastic, the special effects are brilliant and there are tons of plot threads with powerful emotional impacts but I just couldn't get past the fact that the general plot felt lazy.
summary: A Film Without Rules (and not in a good way)

reviewText: Empathy turns out to be the biggest challenge that filmmaker Christopher Nolan faces in his audaciously intricate, sometimes confounding 2010 sci-fi action thriller. It's a 148-minute somersault of a ride viscerally engaging in its vivid elaboration of lucid dreaming. Ironically, there is little time to feel for the characters involved when the whole point of the movie is that nothing is meant to feel real. This dramatic dilemma is almost completely shouldered by the main protagonist Dom Cobb, a professional thief specializing in corporate espionage whose sharpened gifts as an "extractor" allows him to enter the dreams of others to obtain information that is otherwise inaccessible. Heading up aMission Impossible-type task force, Cobb has become aShane-like solitary figure whose talents have cost him his family. He wants nothing more than to see the faces of his two young children.The movie wastes no time in giving Cobb a final mission, his one last shot at redemption which will allow him to reunite with his family back in the states. A Japanese tycoon named Saito wants Cobb to perform an act of "inception" in which he would plant an idea in the subconscious of Robert Fischer Jr., the son of a corporate rival who is about to inherit his father's energy conglomerate. Saito wants Fischer to dissolve the company to prevent the corporation's inevitable takeover of global energy resources, but Cobb's participation represents a risky maneuver that conjures up memories of his dead wife Mal. She figures in the dream episodes in unexpected ways that invariably cloud Cobb's judgment in executing upon the mission for Saito. A crack team has been assembled to aid Cobb - Arthur, the point man who researches the targets whose dreams will be infiltrated; Eames, a cocky forger who has the ability to change identities inside dreams; Yusuf, a chemist who has developed the powerful sedatives that take Cobb and crew into the dream state; and Ariadne, a preternaturally talented graduate student whom Cobb and Arthur train as their new architect.As both writer and director, Nolan methodically bends the storyline into a labyrinth that turns out to be circular in structure and contains at least  four layers of dreams in which the task force must tag team in order to wake up to the next higher level until they each face reality. This is easier said than done since he attempts to show the unconscious as a supremely unruly place where nothing ultimately makes sense, and that's the film's major conundrum since it demands that the narrative must make some amount of sense to make the viewer feel engaged with the story being told. Leonardo DiCaprio brings his trademark intensity to Cobb and manages a gravitas that helps ground the story at a human level, even when the plot convolutions get more and more elaborate and far-fetched. There are some impressive CGI set-pieces like the street of Paris folding over like an omelet, a train careening down a busy downtown street, and the eerie sight of a vacant city in a virtual limbo. Other scenes border on the silly like Arthur's fight scene amid a rotating hotel that make him look like he's doing a2001riff on Fred Astaire's classic dance routine inRoyal Wedding, or the way Ariadne precociously diagnoses the solutions to fatalistic dreams like an worldly scholar.By no means does the approach translate into ineffectual performances by the rest of the eclectic cast. It's just that the actors reflect the generally poker-faced manner expected within the sci-fi genre. Joseph Gordon-Levitt ((500) Days of Summer) plays Arthur just that way as does Ken Watanabe (The Last Samurai) appropriately inscrutable as Saito. Ellen Page (Juno) neutralizes her naturally sardonic manner to play up Ariadne's nave curiosity, but to her defense, she has some of the clunkiest dialogue to deliver. Tom Hardy and Dileep Rao fare better as Eames and Yusuf, respectively simply because they play plot devices more than people. Cillian Murphy (Breakfast on Pluto) channels his usually intimidating intensity into Fischer's deceptively becalming manner, while an almost unrecognizable Tom Berenger manages to play his father's loyal associate with welcome gusto. As Mal, Marion Cotillard (La Vie en Rose) has by far the film's most challenging role, maintaining a careful balance between a spectral figure of longing for Cobb and a manipulative femme fatale.As one would expect from a Nolan film, all the production details are exquisite. Wally Pfister's astonishing cinematography contributes immeasurably to the film's overall hypnotic effect, and Hans Zimmer's foreboding, percussive score thrusts the drama forward with momentum. This movie is too startling a work to ignore, but it would be disingenuous to say that this venture reflects a grand vision since the story is basically an elaborate heist movie. Everything is so well thought out that Nolan may have inadvertently prevented his audience from feeling the full emotional impact of the ending despite the superb editing job by Lee Smith that juggles all the concurrent dreams together. This is still masterful filmmaking from someone who could have focused a tad less on technique and a tad more on the untamed heart that really alters the order within our dreams.
summary: Artfully Stunning, Ambitiously Complex Sci-Fi Thriller Shows Nolan's Reach May Just Exceed His Grasp

reviewText: Inception is a highly complex film because it entails following a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream.  That's 4 levels of dreams to keep track of.  All the levels are necessary, though, for a successful inception to take place.This film asks you to believe in a world where it's possible to enter other people's dreams and either extract or plant ideas.  Apparently this isn't top secret, though, because the targets have all protected themselves against intruders by planting militant Perceptions to ward them off.  Therefore, a plan can quickly go awry unless you have a very skilled and cunning person who can outmaneuver these Perceptions.The person hired for the job is Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) with the help of his crew members (Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ken Watanabe, Dileep Rao, Tom Hardy and Ellen Page).  The target for inception is energy magnate Fischer (Cillian Murphy).  The team devise an eloborate scheme requiring 3 levels of a dreamstate, but at the last minute, end up requiring a 4th dreamstate to rescue two casualties.To complicate matters further (as if this story wasn't complicated enough), we also discover that Cobb has played this game before with his wife.  He had good intentions for doing so, but his intentions nonetheless came with deadly consequences.  As Cobb explains, when you plant an idea into someone's mind, that idea can either cure you or destroy you.  With his wife, it destroyed her.As the story progresses, we witness just how much it's destroyed her.  And nearly destroys Cobb, too.  Not only does he feel tremendous guilt over his past decisions (reminding me of his role in Shutter Island), but also because she seriously complicates his already complicated plans.This movie tests your mental acuity and plays with your perceptions of reality.  The world created here came with rules I didn't fully understand.For example, I didn't fully understand why the dreams needed to be realistic or how someone can be so defensive while in a dream state.  I thought the whole point of entering a dream is that this person's defenses are down and they'll accept whatever reality you show them.I also wasn't sure if all Perceptions are automatic or if you plant them there, since Cobb had them, too.Nonetheless, I still enjoyed this film, although at times, I felt it moved too slowly.  I thought director Christopher Nolan was the perfect choice to organize this complicated film since he so carefully organized two other complicated films of his, Memento and Following.  I also liked the musical score chosen with it's deep trombone sound adding drama at key points.Inception is about planting ideas.  With the mindbender ending, I was left wondering who had been planting these ideas all along.  I was left thinking about a question that had been asked in this movie -- if you don't know which reality you're in, why not choose the one you like best?I could go back and think about how and when this idea got planted....but I think my head would explode.
summary: Who's really behind the wheel here?

reviewText: Definitively among the best films of 2010. An original script and quite a master work of creativity by the film writer and director Christopher Nolan. At the beginning you might find some resemblance withThe Matrixregarding what the perception of the real world is, or withTotal Recallregarding implanting memories, but Mr. Nolan manages to develop a one of a kind original and interesting story, with full action, spectacular SFX, you name it. No need to go into details, there are plenty in the other reviews, but do not let them spoil it, just watch it.Without any doubt this movie is a delight for fans of hard core science fiction, you might mistakenly think Philip K. Dick wrote the story. Because the plot unfolds like a flawless chess game played by two masters, following up the plot and digesting all the information is difficult, so this is a movie you might need to watch two o three times to fully grasp all the details.Amazon discounted launch price is quite a bargain, for just $17.99 you get the Blu-ray disc, the DVD and a digital copy you can play on your favorite mobile device. Nevertheless, watching the Blue-ray on a flat screen is quite an experience, so it is not worthy to save a couple of bucks for the DVD only version. Highly recommended and let's hope there is a sequel of the same quality (the ending leaves the door wide open!), just like the Matrix trilogy
summary: Outstanding, a brilliant piece of creativity, A+

reviewText: I saw this movie three times in theaters and have since watched my DVD of it as well. The movie is brilliant, through-and-through, masterfully written, masterfully filmed. Every time I watch it, I catch something new, and that's something that you can't say about a whole lot of movies. Between "Inception" andShutter Island, DiCaprio had a stellar year at the box office.I think part of what makes this movie so genius is the shake-up in the use of the "it was a dream" function. While other movies have used "it was a dream" as a twist (which, when used carefully, can work), "Inception" tells us from the start that what we will be seeing is a dream, and yet, it still matters.

reviewText: 4.5 / 5 StarsFascinating !  Captivating story, thought provoking, great visuals !  ... too much shooting and hunting ...In reply to the review entitled "Rating Depends On How Much Foreign Film You've Watched" I say:  I do not see much ***correlation*** between "Inception" and "L'Année dernière à Marienbad" or "Hiroshima mon amour", to the point that one might say these two Alain Resnais French films of 1961 and 1959, respectively are ... more original ... or deeper.  I have watched these two films without subtitles."Inception" is interesting, quite original, an attempt to explore the world of dreams.  The exploration is a combination of known things about dreams (e.g. outside stimuli influence dreams), and lesser known things (questions), such as "What happens when we die in a dream ?", "How is a dream within a dream ?", "What happens if two or more people could share a dream ?"  The answers Chris Nolan (both British and American by birth) offers, may be viewed as speculations, of course, but, nonetheless are interesting.  Not seldom he gets the Physics right - Gravity (= acceleration, as Einstein points out):  loss of it; creation of temporal artificial gravity.  Chris Nolan suggest that Gravity effects propagate to dreams - true or not, but interesting.  He even suggests that in a dream world, Gravitation my pull in multiple directions !  Why not ?!I have my own questions:- Will understanding dreams help us further uncover the mysteries of the mind ?- Will we ever be able to design dreams - ours and others ?- Will we ever be able to share dreams ?  Will this be useful ?- Will we be able to visualize dreams, say on a TV scream dreams ? - ours and others ?- Will this help treat currently incurable and most destructive mind (brain) diseases such as Schizophrenia, Bipolar Syndrome, Alzheimer, Parkinson ?- Will we ever be able to do "Extraction" and "Inception" ? - for non-harmful, maybe good purposes ...So, while we may not fully agree with the story proposed to us, the film is thought provoking, but, because of the nested layered dreams (dreams within a dream within a dream ...), hard to follow for many viewers.  That is where the DVD/Blu-ray comes to the rescue - Rewind (many times) !  Not possible in the theater, but easily done at home.Next, please, pay attention:  at the end of the film, the top ("toupie" in French, right ?) is still spinning, which allows us, the viewer, to formulate two possible interpretations:  1) It is, finally reality;  2) It is (still) a dream - maybe, everything was a dream from the very beginning ...  A fantasy ?  A good work of art (visual or written) should be susceptible to multiple interpretations, right ?  Hamlet:  he is tormented  - maybe he really saw (the ghost of) his father, maybe not, maybe his uncle murdered his father, maybe not ... should I take punitive action or not (" ... to be or not to be ... ").  The Penrose Steps (nice drawings by Max Escher !) - an optical illusion:  are we going up or down ?  Maybe both at the same time.I like Leonardo di Caprio and Marion Cotillard a lot.  The personal story of the characters they play (story which causes trouble to all) brings humanity and depth to this film, and the two actors are very convincing in their roles.  By the way, "Mal" means "bad" in French.My only real criticism is this (therefore 4.5/5 stars):  too much shooting, too many people chasing each other, and too often (a diversion/distraction)- it makes it more attractive to some viewers, but ***lowers*** the overall value of the film !  It makes it look "less deep" than Chris Nolan would have liked.  Notice this:  The Academy nominated this film in several categories, among others:  "Best Film" (which refers to the producers, one being Chris Nolan), "Best Original Story" (Chris Nolan), but not "Best Director" (who is also Chris Nolan).  Maybe this is due exactly to the fact others noticed the same thing:  long and frequent chases, lots of shooting ...The thrilling should come more from the tension between characters, from the collision between their minds and souls, their problems, worries, and less from fast paced and sustained action sequences.Last but not least, I like the use of one of my longtime favorite songs:  "Non, je ne regrette rien" sung by Edith Piaf.  It is used in the film as a signal to wake-up the dreamers in a synchronized fashion (it even propagates from one dream level to the next), but, perhaps it also means this:  no matter what happens, or happened, whether this is reality or it is just a dream, I do not take anything back (I regret nothing).Good quality with extra features Blue-ray.  I do not regret having watched.

reviewText: Inception is an exploration of dream science set in the future. There a person's knowledge can be extracted against their will using techniques developed by Dominick (Leonardo DiCaprio). Basically he takes a team of trained dream thieves into a person's dream, then convinces the person in the dream to reveal their secret(s). Sometimes in the dream the person is put to sleep; this sets up a second dreamscape to operate within (hence the need for a dream team). Problem is, when one of the team dies in a multi-layered dream, he or she might never wake up. If all goes well, a big thump ("kick") will either awaken everyone or alert them to start wrapping things up. The ultimate inception is five-layers deep and highly charged with action and drama. Will Dominick succeed, thereby being reunited with his children? Or will he fail and drift into Limbo forever while dreaming he's free? We gotta pay to find out!
summary: I Dreamed a Dream That I Was Dreaming.

reviewText: If you're reading this, chances are you've been exposed to the hype surrounding this film and might be misled to believe that there is something extraordinary about "Inception".Let me straighten things out - this is not "The Dark Knight" of modern science fiction.In its essence, "Inception" is the regular summer blockbuster Hollywood produces annually; The movie is no more than the typical shoots, explosions and CGI action flick - carried out in the context of a plot that has been marketed as more mature and complicated than usual - but there is nothing really groundbreaking under the sun.The story revolves around the efforts of a team of thieves that specialize in stealing ideas and secrets from the minds of people during their dreams.The team leader, portrayed by Leonardo DiCaprio, accepts the revolutionary task of planting  an idea inside the mind of a person (this is the "inception").This endeavor is supposed to influence this individual to transform the planted idea to action in real life.The main memorable concept "Inception" purposes is that the brain thinks faster during a dream state. This might explain why some dreams give us the impression that they have lasted for many hours when in fact we have been dreaming for only a few hours in total.I'm not sure about the scientific base behind this, but it proves crucial for the viability of the main action sequence of the film.In all, the focus of "Inception" is not on the acting, so expect a lot of action, confusion and alternate-fictional-realities, but don't expect any serious Oscar nominations coming January.

reviewText: I've seen Christopher Nolan's Inception seven times now. And each time, it's left me exhilarated, mentally stimulated, and wanting more. The big-budget execution of its intricate concept -- which circles the idea of accessing and manipulating our dreams, memories, and psyches -- comes together in a thrilling reality-bending experience, one that's only hampered by a one-dimensional focus on its supporting characters and a necessity to quickly force-feed the rules the film must abide by. The only thing more gripping than the actual experience of watching Nolan's penmanship play out on-screen is the ambiguity that follows when the credits roll, which transforms everything you've seen into an intricate, wholly fascinating puzzle of a film. To say the least, it's far from the typical fare seen at the cinemas during bright-'n-sunny summer days, instead planting itself in the fray of 2010's best films.

reviewText: Director Christopher Nolan ("Memento," "The Prestige," "The Dark Knight") continues his outstanding streak in "Inception," his finest work to date and the best film of this young decade. What sets Nolan apart from a majority of other directors and screenwriters is his ability to dream big and follow through on his innovative ideas. He takes you to places you've never been, and in many ways, they are places you would've never imagined yourself visiting.Unlike most summer blockbusters, "Inception" actually requires you to think and demands that you pay close attention at all times. Understanding everything in this film is impossible in one viewing, but I am more than happy to take a look at it again.At the heart of it all is Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio), a thief who specializes in entering a person's dream and extracting beneficial information from deep within their subconscious. But Dom's skill at his trade has also come at a price - he's a wanted man and his crime has something to do with him being separated from his late wife, Mal (Marion Cotillard), and their two children.Dom makes a living traveling the world doing extraction jobs with his longtime assistant Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt). However, he is forced to put everything on hold when he gets an offer from Saito, a wealthy industrialist played by Ken Watanabe: enter someone's mind and insert an idea instead of removing one.The target is Robert Fischer Jr. (Cillian Murphy), the son of Saito's most fearful competitor. Saito would like to see Robert voluntarily dissolve his father's empire, so it's up to Dom and his talented dream team - Arthur, Ariadne (Ellen Page), Eames (Tom Hardy) and Yusuf (Dileep Roa) - to pry their way into his noggin, plant the seed and leave without ever being detected. In return they will all be richly compensated, especially Dom, who's promised a clean slate so he can return home and reunite with his two precious offspring. But pulling off their mission will not come easy, especially when a conflicted companion from Dom's past returns and threatens their lives and the whole operation.Often, it is unclear if what we are seeing is a dream or reality or a dream within a dream or even something else. One may think this would be a weakness. It is not; eventually, we realize what we are seeing, and up to that point, it's a lot of fun trying to figure it out.The film has jaw-dropping visuals, not unlike 1999's "The Matrix." The two movies are very similar in that they largely take place in an alternate reality where the rules of time and space are altered, and just like the Wachowski Brothers, Nolan has taken full advantage of all the possibilities this concept has to offer.In this summer (or any summer for that matter) that primarily consists of sequels, remakes and adaptations, it's extremely refreshing to be treated to an original film that genuinely challenges you to use your brain while also giving your eyeballs a stimulating canvas to feast upon.5 stars (out of 5)

reviewText: Last night we traveled to Aventura to see Inception at the IMAX theatre. Aventura provides the benefit of a nice dinner before the show because of the many wonderful restaurants available to the public.We selected Rosalia, an Italian restaurant accessible both from inside the mall as well as from the courtyard where AMC theatres are located.From the start, this movie captured our imagination and as we did our morning walk today, we could talk of nothing else. The premise is people that learn to tap into their minds, utilizing the subconscious to recreate reality at different levels.What is new about this? We all dream, we are all capable of escaping reality by focusing on memories of the past, or returning to places we liked, where we felt safe. But in this movie, the experience is shared with others and learning about another person's mind and how they think, sometimes planting an idea that turns the other person's life into the reality of our choosing is new.We are able to experience these shared dreams through the power of film, but we come to understand that these people simply go into a trance of sorts, into a powerful recreation of a certain reality that they are able to share as a team.An architect is required, a person that builds a certain reality, shares it with the team for understanding and they go off, together, to experience highly emotional and philosophical escapes.Arthur played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Dom Cobb masterfully played by Leonardo DiCaprio join to steal ideas for clients from the minds of their competitors.But as with all things, times are hard and Mr. Cobb becomes estranged from his family. Saito, played by Ken Watanabe, hires Cobb to get to Fischer, played by Cillian Murphy. The purpose is to plant an idea in the mind of this powerful businessman.Without giving the plot away, it gets so complicated that Cobb requires fresh talent and they hire an architecture student played by Ellen Page, a chemist, played by Dileep Rao and a forger played by Tom Hardy who designs the most incredible of experiences.To be perfectly honest, we could not hear everything that was said because the sound track overpowers voices but plan to acquire the DVD and with the tool of subtitles see this movie again to fully grasp the dialogue.Our minds are our greatest asset and few if any have tapped into its full potential. So, as we watched the movie we concluded that there are endless possibilities of what we can do if we focus on the development of our minds.In the end, we rated this movie with a simple word: Awesome!

reviewText: If you're captivated by debating which parts were dreams, dreams squared, or dreams cubed, then the comic book store still holds sway over your disposable income.If you believe Inception's time fictions and twists are ingenious, then you've never seen La Jetee.If you think Dom and Mal are searingly complex, then you haven't watched In The Mood For Love or 2046.If you think there's anything happening underneath the surface of Inception, anything at all that required dreamscapes, memory, projection, or self-deception, then you either haven't caught or didn't understand Waking Life, Heavenly Creatures, Mulholland Drive, and Billy Liar.And if you think all the aforementioned films are indie, international and hifalutin, go see The Limey and learn what flashbacks are for in an action film.Because Inception spends all its time on one ludicrous goal (in reality, at the highest levels of management, multinationals consider divesting assets all the time, no first-world government is going to allow for "an energy monopoly," and we're expected to believe the "second place" company is willing to engage in sabotage for moral reasons and/or market advantage, and their best shot is to get Company Number One to sell off assets...let's just move on).And that's before we get to the whopping screenplay problem: once we know Leo misses the kids, the film has to resolve there...dream or no dream, the end is spelled out in the first ten minutes, and the rest is pyrotechnics, explanations, and waiting for the inevitable.So what are we left with? A possibly imagined billionaire believes an intuition planted in a dream, and Leo remains trapped in a dream, possibly willingly. Because dreams are, like, this double-edged sword, dude.Inception gets two stars for looking great, but it can't get more, not when it's a meaningless, unimaginative film, wholly taken with its own logistics.

reviewText: There is a small, militant camp of malcontents who despise everything Christopher Nolan has ever committed to film, and their numbers only seem to grow as countless critics and the movie-going masses at large declare him to be one of modern cinema's greatest visionaries. They see Memento as pretentious, arthouse drivel; Batman Begins as a serviceable but unspectacular foray into comicbook adaptations; Insomnia as bland and uneventful; The Prestige as an over-scripted mess with three twists too many; and The Dark Knight as an overblown, over-hyped cash-in that doesn't deserve the accolades it's received. To them, Nolan's latest buzz-earner, Inception, is either a dull, confounding, over-plotted misfire or a convoluted, self-important, superficial brain-bender. My apologies if you're one of these disgruntled few... I can't come out and play today. I've long been one of the masses, willingly drinking more and more of Nolan's Kool Aid with each passing film. As far as I'm concerned, Inception not only stands as the pinnacle of a master filmmaker's canon, but as a cerebral masterpiece in its own right; one that's far and away my favorite film of 2010, and a strong contender for my favorite film of all time. And believe me, that isn't the sort of statement I ever make lightly.
