reviewText: As dreamers ourselves, we, as human beings, have always been unequivocally fascinated by dreams.  People have made a fortune on interpreting dreams and analyzing dreams or even publishing self help books that put dreams into a more tangible, legible, and easy-to-understand format.  Dreams can be powerful, enough so that if we wake up from them we are sometimes convinced, if only for a little while, that what happened in the dream actually happened in reality.  So, what happens when we can use that to the benefit or detriment of others?  Enter the movie Inception.Inception is a concept where a team of professionals can access your dreams, your subconscious, and alter it.  Mainly, they focus on extracting information, but Inception is when those professionals place information.  Not as easy as it sounds since, like fighting a disease, the subconscious will defend itself (oftentimes with training on how to do this) to keep Inception from happening.  On top of this, levels of subconscious are involved (a dream within a dream within a dream), a place called Limbo, and the threat of your own subconscious getting in the way.Leonardo DiCaprio's character, Cobb, leads a team to place information into the mind of a man whose father recently dies and leaves his larger than life company to him.  The son must disband the empire.  What with the above stated complications, the team must complete the task in a given amount of time and to do so without endangering themselves.The movie is extremely complex, and at 148 minutes, it doesn't seem long enough to explain all the subtle nuances of what is happening.  This is a definite "pay attention to everything" film and I would recommend not only watching it once but several times.  Thankfully, it's very good and the rewatching of the film is quite the joy ride.  However, don't be fooled.  When one thinks of dreams one might think of the odd dreams that someone has when they believe they are captured by alien space monkeys and delivered to the Queen of Bananas.  This is not that type of dream.  In fact, they argue it away by mentioning that the more reality shifts and bends, the more the subconscious is aware that it is dreaming.  At that point, the Inception or even extraction can't take place.  Words aside, all of it is explained in the film, if you have the attention span to pay attention.A great film, well put together, and an original concept that is very often not seen in any kind of entertainment.  It is not based off of an original work other than itself and it is, therefore, even more genius.  With powerhouse actors like DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, Cillian Murphy, and Ken Watanabe it's hard not to be immediately engaged.  The ending, too, is a rather perfect finale that sums up the entire piece with perfect ease.  Is it recommended?  Absolutely.  Several times over: absolutely.

reviewText: INCEPTIONThere was a lot of hype surrounding this movie when it was released and all I would hear from people was "you have see this flick". I skipped going to see it in theaters because most of the time I am let down when something is overly hyped. So like I do with a lot I waited until the DVD release to finally catch this film. I must say that I am glad I waited and let the hype factor die down because I did enjoy this movie. I also will say that if I had been paying attention and realized Cillian Murphy was in this I may have went and seen it on the big screen.If you have yet to see this I can assure you that what you have heard is true, you do have to follow what is going on the whole time [kinda]. Well at least at first but once you know the rules the film is playing by it becomes easier to guess what is coming. The film starts out with our Dream robbers inside the mind of a man who will become one of the center parts of this story. When we learn that you can be in a dream inside a dream things start to heat up. But once out the question is asked "can you plant an idea in some one's mind like you can steal info from them". This question is pressed by the man they just tried to steal from and he offers the thieves a job. So the plan starts to be laid out as a team is assembled to do what most think is impossible.Written and directed wonderfully by Christopher Nolan this movie combines elements of other films and styles to create a very intriguing world. The effects and twists of the story keep you interested the entire time, and it is a long film. Take for example the building of the dream, when you see what "the human mind" can come up with and all the things it can add to these worlds are amazing. Visually this film is near flawless but there are other factors that bring it down. Such as when you figure out the film, you figure it out, sure the twists are there but you can kinda guess what is coming.And while the film takes a while it does and some great actors keeping things going, one of my favorites Cillian Murphy is the mark in this movie. Of course lead Leonardo DiCaprio does a good job here as does Ken Watanabe who is actually a favorite in the film as he did a great job. Joseph Gordon-Levitt as well was great as Leo's number one guy, Marion Cotillard was excellent as Leo's wife in this movie, Ellen Page as the dream weaver, Tom Hardy was another wonderful addition to the film, Tom Berenger, Michael Caine, Dileep Rao all did great jobs as well. Add in a wonderful soundtrack and you a very good film.This was a really good film and worthy of the praise it got but I feel like it fell just short of classic status. Maybe because the characters were not as developed as much as the plot was or something but it felt kinda incomplete. I don't know maybe I am crazy, you tell me. However feel about the film I am sure everyone can agree that it is at the very least worth a rental right.

reviewText: Unless you are prone to fall asleep during movies (I usually have the same problem, especially with shallow plots), ignore the reviews that imply that Inception is "confusing".  It's true that the movie presents some mysteries to be resolved (which Nolan does quite well) in addition to some of the most thrilling action scenes in recent cinema, but Nolan takes great pains to make the plot easy to follow.  The elaborate plans made by the team are simplified for the audience through the characters' strategy sessions, and when simultaneous actions are taking place on different levels, the use of entirely different settings for each level make it extremely easy to follow the abrupt shifts.  Why anyone would find this puzzling is...well, quite puzzling.Go see this movie...you'll be glad you did.  I'm not a big Leo fan, but he (along with the rest of the cast) did an outstanding job. Each member of the 'team' gets his/her own moments to shine, which is extremely gratifying for the viewer.  Memorable characters, unpredictable plot twists (and dialogue!), and outstanding special effects make this one a keeper.Can't wait for the blu-ray!

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***Inception (2010) is a brilliant film - intelligent, exciting and dazzling. When the award season comes, and it is not nominated for editing, screenplay, music, cinematography, set decoration, art direction, and directing by Nolan, I'll be very surprised. Nolan is highly talented as both director and writer and should be recognized for the amazing achievement which his new film is. By the words of writer/director, "the key to completing the script was wondering what would happen if several people shared the same dream... Once you remove the privacy, you've created an infinite number of alternative universes in which people can meaningfully interact, with validity, with weight, with dramatic consequences." Inception feels like The Matrix on steroids with the impossible structures of M.C Escher coming to life, with some ideas shared with Solaris and the short stories by Jorge Luis Borges such as The Circular Ruins and The Secret Miracle, and with the script that would do honor to Charlie Kaufman. In my dream world, I want Nolan and Kaufman work together and I would love to stay in the alternative reality they'd create. I would not mind the totem top spinning endlessly advising me that I am in the dream world of Nolan's and Kaufman's imagination. As it is, the film is a great entertainment, the real feast for brains, senses and feelings. There are so many references to the studies of the most mysterious stage of human brain, dream state, specifically, lucid dream. There are the nods everywhere to the previous films, mythology archetypes, literature and art works. I found particularly touching the use of the Edith Piaf's song, Non, je ne regrette rien and casting as one of the main characters of the film Marion Cottilard, the 2008 Oscar winner for playing Edith Piaf. Acting in the film is pleasure all around, starting with Leonardo Di Caprio (Hey, someone give him an Oscar already) as an expert in stealing the ideas out of the human brains in the lucid dream state, who has to perform the opposite task of inception the idea in someone's brain. Everyone was memorable and well-cast including Joseph Gordon-Levitt whom I like in every film I've seen him, Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe, Cillian Murphy, Michael Caine, and already mentioned Cottilard. My favorite performance is by Ellen Page as Ariadne - what a fitting and appropriate name for the Architect of the dream world's sets and mazes and the guide inside the labyrinth just like her mythological namesake princess on the island of Crete. With all its complexity, reality within dreams, many layers of subconscious, projection and manifestation of the dreams, three or even more states of dreams all played off each other and communicating with each other and the wake state, the film in its core tells a very simple story about one man's burning desire to go home to these whom he loved the most but couldn't be with. It is about love, guilt, creating and living the dream, and finally letting it go. It is an action thriller sc-fi heist that simultaneously plays in four or even more different level of subconscious but with the real feelings and emotions. It is spectacular. It is the best Christopher Nolan's film I've seen and in the very end of his film he wants us to acknowledge that everything we saw has been designed by him. He is the architect of all layers of dream. We are in his dream and that's why the totem keeps spinning and never stops as the screen turns black.

reviewText: My bargain rack movie for last night was the "Inception" DVD. The movie was complicated and required a lot of close attention and concentration. The story was dreaming and dreams within dreams. I ended up confused early on and it didn't get much better. The movie was interestingly done, however.I had trouble with the sound. It was one of these movies which relies strongly on surround sound and I don't have a surround-sound system. My sound system is stereo and it's quite good. I'd guess that most people's TV is only stereo, either as a system or as the sound of the TV set. Well, in this particular case a lot of the film's conversation was meant to come through the side speakers and it would probably be highly effective in a large theater. But I don't have side speakers and I get all my sound out of the front speakers. The engineering of this sound track was not suited with my sound system and the majority of people would probably have the same difficulty. I've run into this problem with several other DVDs but this one was particularly difficult. Another thing is that this movie has a highly-praised musical score, and I can understand. It's quite good. The problem is that the music doesn't enhance the movie. It interferes with the movie, in my opinion."Inception" is loaded with a lot of interesting special effects including spectacular explosions which are probably meant to coincide with the dream theme. Some are very dramatic and are tied in with a major burst of sound for the sound system. Every once in a while, I'd have to decrease the sound in order not to disturb the neighbors.In any case, I had a lot of difficulties in watching this film. I feel that I would have to watch it over again, perhaps several times, to give it a proper evaluation. The problem is, I didn't find the film interesting enough to watch over again. I have others that I would far prefer to watch a second time. My patience on this film became somewhat exhausted. One final note. "Inception" is a 2010 movie and I'm not used to finding movies this new on the bargain rack and in such abundance. That's probably trying to say something.Gary Peterson

reviewText: The more I watch this movie the more it unravels the complexity of our dream worlds. This film delves into those worlds showing how fragile the mind can be. To believe or not in our own reality. Are we dreaming? If not, how can we tell. The story line is incredible and the acting is superb, especially DiCaprio who is searching for his way home. Along with the script Hans Zimmer interweaves a "dream-like" soundtrack throughout the film to truly capture the moods, whether dreaming or awake. And that is just the point. Awake? Dreaming? Watch the film and answer for yourself. A definite five star movie.

reviewText: This movie has got it where is counts, here are the things that I like about this movie:[1] Mind-Bending Plot[2] Great acting[3] Superb Special Effects[4] Plenty of Action[5] Suspenseful MusicUnlike most movies, this film has a high degree re-playability; meaning that you don't get everything in one sitting. I would say that by the third time you will be able to fully understand the plot, and appreciate its full depth.Initially, you are not sure what's happening. But as a new dream architect is enlisted, you learn along with her.At the height of the movie, the action unfolds on 5 levels, each with its own perspective on the speed of time, as follows:- Real World- First level dream- Second level dream (inside of first dream)- Third level dream (inside of second dream)- Limbo (where you go, if you die inside of a nested dream)This film is a must-see as far as I am concerned. It is a real Thriller to the very end.

reviewText: Inception is perhaps 2010's most astonishing film, designed on a big budget, the product of 10 years writing work,  a success at the box office. I'm not going to bother describing the story. Any short description wouldn't do justice to how well put together and nuanced the story is, any long discussion would spoil moments without need.Suffice it to say, the themes of the movie (on my rendering, at least) are how humans influence each other, and an exploration of the hazy epistemic boundaries between dreams and experience. Leonardo Dicaprio has come a long way since Titanic.  Here, he's a true star in every sense of the word: he holds this multi-hundred-million dollar movie together through his emoting, and his struggles are who the audience follows throughout the movie.  Ironically, however, I found myself more drawn to the unknown-to-me Joeseph Gordon-Levitt, who is perhaps given the film's best role in the point man who has to navigate a dream where the rules of physics have gone completely awry. After Inception, I watched 500 days of Summer, and with the experience of both of these films in my mind, I declared Levitt my favorite actor recently. The stunts he pulls in Inception are quite simply amazing, and even the Blu-Ray's breakdown of how they were composed does nothing to fade my admiration. These two are pretty much headliners of a cast of incredibly talented people, including Michael Caine and the beautiful Marion Cotillard.Behind the scenes, however, we always sense the hand of Christopher Nolan, whose themes existential anxiety continue from the Dark Knight and Memento. Some of the shots in this movie are second to none, and that is effort not owed to actors or setup crew, this is brilliance at the writing and production stage.  Even the first scene, of Leonardo Dicaprio lying on a beach, soaking wet as waves crash, is absolutely gorgeous. It's realistic, gritty, but at the same time, it's more gorgeous to me than anything seen in say, Avatar or The Matrix. Delve deeper into the lore of the movie and you'll realize that musically it's brilliant too, the sound of Edith Piaf slowed down and altered into a leitmotif that sounds deep and imposing.Such a collaboration of exceptional actors, filmmakers, and writers truly deserves to be seen.  If you enjoy it a quarter of how much I have, you're in for a pretty good ride.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan has already created a niche in cinematic history with the few in number but huge in impact films he has made. What Nolan manages to do with his storytelling is request, no, insist that his audience thinks - and that is such a change from the usual fare on the screens these days.  His 'MEMENTO' is as intellectually dynamic as his more traditional in content 'THE DARK KNIGHT', 'BATMAN BEGINS', 'INSOMNIA' and 'PRESTIGE' are in spectacular use of the cinema as an art form.  He takes all that one step further with 'INCEPTION', a strangely very personal inquiry into the world of our dreams, aided by a story that challenges us to stay with him through 148 minutes of tension and special effects used as no other director to date has dared.The plot is so thick and seemingly fragmented at times that even Nolan has been said that he didn't always know where the ideas were born. Essentially it is about dream invasion, a futuristic concept that by entering the dreams of competitors or opponents, possibilities/ideas/truths can be found in one of the most startling permutations of  identity theft yet described: if dreams can be entered and examined and altered then many things can be changed by the 'dream thief'.  The cast is absolutely remarkable - actors who can take an idea so strange and pull the audience with them through an experience that can be at times challenging to follow.  Leonardo DiCaprio, growing with each film he makes, is joined by his troops Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ken Watanabe, Dileep Rao, Ellen Page, and Tom Hardy to explore the minds/alterable dreams of Cillian Murphy, Tom Berenger, and Pete Pete Postlethwaite.  Along the way of this venture DiCaprio must cope with his encounters with his wife of the past, Marion Cotillard.  Oh, and throw in Michael Caine as DiCaprio's father to flesh out a truly stellar cast.It is a fascinating ride, and though there are portions that seems to go on too long (the episodes in the snow, the loss of gravity in the elevator shaft, etc), the film is truly unique.  it would probably be well to see it twice: the first time for the astonishing affect it has on the viewer, the second time to better appreciate all the little clues dropped along the way that would make the story more accessible. Grady Harp, August 10
summary: Inside the Creative Mind of Christopher Nolan

reviewText: The power of an idea. Just as Christopher Nolan's latest epic centers around this concept, so too does this review. Inception is a completely new and original idea - no small feat in a Hollywood overflowing with sequels, reboots, and retreads. Over the past fifteen years, Nolan has proven himself to be a fine director blessed with the ability to craft epic thrillers with no shortage of intelligence, style, and technical virtuosity. Much was made over 2008's The Dark Knight and rightly so, but with Inception, Nolan has upped the ante in nearly every regard. This review will be extremely light on plot details as I firmly believe one should go into the theater with as little knowledge as possible - the experience of discovery is so great, that to take that away, even just a small amount, would be a cinematic travesty. I, for one, won't be the reviewer to do it. So if you must know all about the events that fill Inception's 2.5 hour run time, look elsewhere.There is so much that I could mention here that it's difficult to know where to start: the technical wizardry on display in nearly every frame, Hans Zimmer's bombastic score, and the murderer's row of acting talent all merit their own discussion. However, I must start by describing, in broad strokes only, the concept of Inception and how this complicated film springs forth from such a universal act - the act of dreaming. This is one of Nolan's many masterstrokes throughout the film. By creating a world in which perhaps 80% of what we see takes place in various dreamworlds, Nolan has captured the imagination of everyone. This is not The Matrix or eXistenZ, there is no computer knowledge or enthusiasm required; everyone dreams, and therefore every single member of the audience is able to live out various scenes of the film, because we know many of these rules. Do you ever remember the beginning of a dream? No. All of a sudden you are right in the middle of it. And how often do you wake up right as the killer is closing in or the bullets begin to tear through your chest? These are basic concepts ripped from the dreams of all the people in the world and then woven into a narrative so deep and complex that it makes The Prestige (Nolan's other masterpiece) seem as complicated as a Care Bears episode.So yes, Inception is a complex film, but that doesn't mean that's it's inaccessible or overly complicated. Far from it, in fact. Those who simply wish to see a glossy heist movie will not be disappointed, just as those in search of something far deeper will leave the theater happily shaking their heads at the sheer enormity and ambition of Christopher Nolan's vision. This is the ultimate thinking man's blockbuster. It is filled to the brim with magnificent action set-pieces including a zero-gravity fight in a hallway and an assault on a snow-covered hospital fortress, both of which must be seen to be believed. The academy might as well send the best special effects and art direction statues right over to the Warner Brothers lot, as both categories should be a lock after the insane display put on by Nolan and his talented crew. It's an enormous task to translate dreams to the big screen, but Inception passes every test with flying colors. This is a beautiful movie, just as The Prestige and both Batman films before it.I also must mention Hans Zimmer's score. Rumor has it that Nolan would not permit Zimmer to see the film as he wrote the score, and this only enhances the impact of Zimmer's deep and booming music. Not since Up and The Dark Knight, have I been this impacted by a film score. The music adds the perfect amount of grandiosity and emotion to the proceedings. Nowhere is this more apparent than the film's climax, a gut-wrenching finale that assaults the senses on every conceivable level.Finally, I must mention the terrific ensemble cast of Inception. Utilizing many actors he has worked with before, Christopher Nolan has brought together what is arguable the greatest cast in years and there is not a dud in the bunch. Leonardo Dicaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Tom Hardy, Ellen Page, Ken Watanabe, Marion Cotillard, Cillian Murphy, Michael Caine, and the list goes on. It's an astonishing collection of talent, each of whom is utilized perfectly. There is no filler here; no characters written simply to take up space. Everyone has a part to play and the actors fill these roles perfectly. Dicaprio once again proves that there is no one better working in Hollywood today. He has come a long way since his Titanic days, and just as in Shutter Island, he commands the screen with such vigor and intelligence that it's impossible not to identify with the guy.Watanabe and Murphy, both villains in Nolan's Batman Begins again prove that they can absolutely command the screen whenever they want. Watanabe is an absolute marvel here, the guy's gaze could back down a pack of hungry wolves, I swear. Ellen Page continues to move away from her Juno persona and into young-Jodie Foster-territory and Marion Cotillard nails one of the most difficult roles in the film, portraying a figure both sympathetic and terrifying without seeming to break a sweat. Caine's role is not much more than a cameo, but damn he's good. I really don't know what else to say about Michael Caine, he just adds such gravitas to any film he lends his name to.That being said, in my mind this movie really belongs to two actors: Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Tom Hardy. Both are young up-and-comers in the film world, and I'll be damned if this movie doesn't launch both to stardom. JGL has come a long way since his 3rd Rock from the Sun days, exhibiting the confidence and charm of a young Brad Pitt with the range to match. His zero-g hallway fight is a sight to behold and throughout the film, Gordon-Levitt exhibits a cool factor that would be unmatched ... if it weren't for Tom Hardy. Previously confined largely to British cinema and thus unseen and unappreciated in the states, Hardy exploded onto the scene with last year's Bronson and continues his ascent with a wise-cracking bad-ass role which he tears into with unabashed enthusiasm. Hardy was a crowd favorite at the screening I attended and I dare you to feel any different. The man simply oozes charisma and he possesses the physicality necessary for any role. Indeed, he will next be seen in the remake of The Road Warrior, and as much as I detest remakes, this one will be on my radar for one simple reason: Tom Hardy.If you haven't figured it out by now, let me spell it out for you. I love this movie. As I left the theater I was struck by a sensation very rare for the jaded would-be film critic: pure and genuine excitement. I couldn't get Inception out of my head all night long and when I woke up the next morning, it was the first thing to enter my mind. I simply can not give any greater recommendation than that. Christopher Nolan has truly outdone himself this time around. Inception is a masterpiece, plain and simple. What an idea. 5 out of 5 stars.
summary: The power of an idea ... quite the concept in today's Hollywood.

reviewText: what is this movie about?  mind bending action drama?  exploration of dreams and how ideas can be "extracted" and "incepted"?  matrix wannabe?  it's all three... or is it?  i'm going to go along with the logic of the movie and write this review.-->  SPOILERS ARE IN THIS REVIEW - do not read further if you care.there is a kernel of an interesting idea in this movie.  how can dreams be explored and formed.  how are you able to use dreams and the dreamscape as a metaphor to steal the innermost ideas of someone.  in this case, the idea is that you can put a high level executive into a dream state, create a dreamscape for him, and then convince him to reveal his secrets.  frankly, i found that to be a DULL scenario.  here is an idea for getting the most intimate secrets from someone, and it's going to be on the secret formula for coca-cola, the 13 secret spices of KFC's or something like that.  so already, the plot is suffering from a lack of excitement.  in order to make up for that dullness, Nolan interjects some action through security forces, rioters, a staged kidnapping and car chases (gotta love a car chase for no apparent reason), and James Bondian assaults on a secret snow covered base.  you see, what happens in reality can affect the dream so if you play music for someone, they can hear it in the dream.  if the car goes into freefall, people are gravity-free in the dream.  the latter leads into an interesting fight scene (that lasts too long) reminiscent of Fred Astaire in the Royal Wedding.  if you hit water, you are in a flood in the dream...  you get it?  it's pretty straightforward. and b/c time is exponential in each layer, a few seconds in one layer are minutes in another, years if you go deep enough.  so, the concluding part of the movie is intercut by each layer, b/c Nolan thinks you NEED to be reminded of this simple idea over and over again.  oh, the van is falling so... sloooooowly... while, guys are fighting in freefall... while the snow assault is exploding... while Cobb leads the token Juno through his dreamland.the idea is to extract a secret.  but, then it is asked if we can put in an idea - inception.  oooooooh! no way! oh, wait, sure, no problem.  seems like that it has been done before by Cobb (DiCaprio) to his wife.  it is a mystery though...  what exactly happened to his wife?so, the idea is to have the heir of a giant corporation, and rival to Saito, to break his company apart.  how exciting is that?  i've never yawned so much before.  wouldn't it be easier to just take over the company? or just kill him?  it's a movie, right?  Saito is a mysterious and super powerful business figure that can erase a criminal record and fix it so Cobb can return to the US with just a phone call.  and he's got a helicopter. and he can kill people with impunity.  but, he can't break up a rival company except through this convoluted scheme?  you can almost hear the Mission Impossible music.so the setup is that it is highly dangerous and almost impossible... but, there it is a second later.  it is that kind of smooth glossy logic that makes Inception kind of corny.  the idea that a dream can happen within a dream is a marvel!  Saito says, "Impressive."  then, Cobb wants to do a 3 layer dream.  oooooh!  no way!  oh, wait, no problem.  seems like the Yusuf, the chemist that creates the drug to put people in a dream, has been doing it for a while.  all the protests of the dangers and complications of a 3 layer dream are washed away.  but, wait, it gets better!  by the end of the film, you are in a 5 layer dream!  that's impossible, you say???  nah, it's no problem.  so, the sense of danger of doing any multilayer dream is really just glossed over.  and any profound complexity is just adding another layer of dreams.how is it like matrix?  well, how do you know when you're in a dream?  this is the Brain-in-a-vat question.  turns out Cobb and his wife had created their "perfect" world for fifty years (Cobb the architect and his wife, the oracle... ha! it's a stretch but, i went there.)  there's even a "training session" of Juno much like Morpheus taking Neo thru training simulations of the real matrix.  the sub-conscious is represented by the people in the dreams and they act much like agents when they sense something foreign in the dream.all throughout the movie, Nolan wants to put in that cliche personal layer.  what about Cobb's wife and his kids?  well, turns out Cobb's wife got lost in the dreams, so he "put in" the idea that she was in a dream.  she escapes by killing herself in the dream - thus waking up in the real world. (unlike the matrix, if you die in the dream, you don't die in real life.)  problem is, the idea is still there so she still thinks she's in another layer of dreams.  she can't recognize reality any longer... or is it reality???  ah, the ending is ambiguous and cliche.  Nolan wants to leave you spinning on that question.at this point, if you've kept up, you either really cared deeply or like me, you've just wasted two hours (+ half an hour writing this review).  i didn't find any likable characters, just a series of annoying ones (Juno is the worst by the way).  found most of the ideas derivative and not really developed - hey, Nolan, if you're going to challenge us with all the hype, please deliver.  and the action could have been pulled from any other generic action movie.i've read some of the other reviews that give this movie 5 stars, but, i think it's safe to say that i am in disagreement.btw, i really like Matrix.  if you couch a simple idea with coolness and martial arts, i'll go along for the ride.  just do it well... do it well, Nolan.
summary: a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Christopher Nolan directs one of the most mind bending films I have ever seen, literally. It follows a skilled extractor Cobb(Leonardo DiCaprio) who infiltrates a wealthy, incipient heir's dreams to complete what is thought to be an impossible task. A harrowing ordeal, running around people's dreams,but he must do so to regain his ability to reenter the U.S. to get his old life back. The storyline of the movie is extremely complex and if I spoiled the ending it would have no meaning unless someone knew how the cast ended up there.  Nolan keeps the audience guessing by skewing what we understand to be a dream, reality, dreams without reality, and the perception of a dream and real time. He does so by using the idea that we never really know when or where a dream begins. Roger Ebert gave a great quote in his review for this film, explaining how the audience can relate to this film stating that "We are always in the Now. We have made some notes while getting here, but we are not quite sure where here is." I have never seen anything like this film it is wholesomely original and those looking for something new will enjoy it. If the movie itself in theaters was not enough, now on DVD there is a load of interesting Special Features. The Extraction Mode: which goes through how Nolan, DiCaprio and, the crew designed the films setting and key moments. The feature I enjoyed the most was the one that everyone can relate to, Dreams: Cinema of the Subconscious. Everyone dreams, and the idea that our dreams can be a functioning parallel reality is extremely interesting. I give this film 4/5 stars. Looking for more information on the film? Find it at [...]Graydon Frenzel

reviewText: Set for a November 2010 release, Terrence Malick's long gestating The Tree of Life, starring Brad Pitt and Sean Penn, is our pick for the year's big Oscar film. The details of the production have been kept as secret as any major production ever, word slipping here and there that the film is the product of nearly three decades of writing by Malick. The production is said to be huge and the post-production as labored-over as any. All that said, we at ScreenTime refuse to believe that Tree's production will match that of the just released new Christopher Nolan film, Inception, surely another big Oscar film.Where to begin? Inception, Nolan's seventh proper feature, is the British-American auteur's biggest, strangest, most promoted, most anticipated and most memorable work yet. Opening this past weekend at No. 1 with over $60 million in US sales, I left the theater wondering three things about the dreamy heist flick: 1) how many people in the theater with me were able to follow not just the bombastic action, but the delicate storyline?; 2)  How the f%#@ do you write something like that?; and 3) which of ScreenTime's favorite directors saw this film? Malick? Tarantino? Scorcese? Spielberg?! What did they think of it? This, I'd love to know.I wasn't alive when Stanley Kubrick's 1968 sci-fi epic 2001: A Space Odyssey was released, but I can still watch it today and feel its power and originality, every time wondering how it made Kubrick's contemporaries feel. My guess is that it made them all realize that they needed to think harder and work harder. Even if your name is Spielberg and you made an epic production called Saving Private Ryan, Inception likely has a similar 2001 effect on you. More than Star Wars in 1977 or Avatar just last year, Inception just feels bigger, grander, more labored over and "next level" than anything of recent memory. Films likes Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, Tarantino's original Kill Bill cut, Nolan's own The Dark Knight and even Malick's own The Thin Red Line are humbled by the mastery and creativity of Inception.That said, Inception is not the best film of 2010. Not in our book. It may be the best made film of 2010, but a better film, Jacques Audiard's Un Prophete, has already been released and there are a couple coming yet (Tree, mostly), that stand to be better. After such a rant about the brilliance of Inception, how can I already say such a thing? Well, many reasons. For starters, Inception is an often tedious film. Using a chopped-up non-linear storytelling device, Nolan has made an extraordinarily cerebral caper film that's dressed up as a big summer blockbuster. There's enough action to make Sly Stallone blush, which is cool, but there's also an awful lot of important dialogue. You have to hear every word in the film so much so that, in fact, if you simply sneeze at the wrong parts of the film, you'll miss something that could maybe spoil your complete understanding of what's going on. (Tedious is the word I keep coming back to, even if I'm uncomfortable using such a negative word to describe such a masterful work.) If you've not yet seen the movie, imagine sitting in a theater for 150 minutes, paying close attention to every word and movement, never more than a 10 second break for a joke or two. Plan to walk out of the theater with a fried brain, dropped jaw and crossed eyes.But hey, let's not knock an artist for being wildly ambitious. We're cool with Inception frying our brain. And, aside from that, we have very few issues with the movie. Sure, the setup (basically, these dudes gotta crack into this younger dude's dreams and plant an idea in this his mind before he turns his dad's company into a Wal-Mart-like monster) is incredibly underbaked compared to what follows, but that's no big deal. And the casting, aside from Marion Cotillard (who is perfect), seems a bit off, Leonardo DiCaprio's Dom Cobb seeming a bit too similarly played to his recent Shutter Island character, Teddy Daniels. The still-very-young-feeling Joseph Gordon-Levitt as the mature daddy of the operation? And Ellen Page as the big brain who makes things happen? Ummm.Now let's focus on the good things. First and foremost is the writing, which is brilliant. People who write as well as Nolan usually write long, details novels - and Inception could've easily been a mini-series. But Nolan thinks equally in movement and vision, and we're the luckier for it. His writing, especially in Memento, The Prestige and The Dark Knight, has always been impressive, but here he makes his mark. The amount of detail and thought put into this puzzle of a story is mind-blowing. Look for Nolan to grab an Oscar nomination - and maybe statue - for his original screenplay. No. 2 on the list of things Inception does impossibly well is editing. You have to see it twice to believe it. Telling a story like this on paper is hard enough, but taking moving pictures of it, adding sound and music and CGI, then cutting it all up non-linear-style and making sense of it is the hardest part of the process.  Editor Lee Smith, known mostly for his work with Peter Weir, will win 2010's Oscar for Best Editing. He should've won it in 2008 for The Dark Knight, in 2006 for The Prestige and maybe even in 2005 for Batman Begins, but he will win it in 2010.There's much more to say about the tedious but brilliant, visually inventive yet action-packed new Christopher Nolan movie, but let's not get carried away. It's just a movie. It's just the movie that deserves all of the attention Avatar received last year but won't (this because it makes you think too hard). It's just the movie that (fingers crossed) might change the way Hollywood studios treat big brain artists with big ideas. For a while, anyhow. And we have Christopher Nolan and his brilliant new sci-fi mindbender to thank.

reviewText: If you've heard the ending sucks, you've talked to people who weren't paying attention.  Ignore them.  The movie asks you to pay attention, and to think, and the ending is of the sort you have to give some thought to--unless, unlike most people you were right on top of everything, all the way through, and you read the credits at the end...At its essence, "Inception" is a heist film, with DiCaprio and gang entering people's dreams to get the secrets that will allow them to steal stuff.  Then, a client asks them to implant an idea in someone else's dream.  In theory that can't be done, but DiCaprio has had some experience both ways, as it turns out, and it has been creating problems for him all through the film... which means there's a story within the story, about a dream within a dream.  The film is visually stunning to begin with, and I should have seen it on the big screen.  As you probably already know, the film then takes its setting and folds it in on itself, so Paris is not just Paris, but Paris facing our way, with another part of Paris upside down above us, and cars driving right up the streets that now rise like walls.  And, things fall apart, whole cities, rooms, everything, as the dreams collapse when they get unstable.  It's like Matrix action meets James Bond scenery, so now it's not only the characters who are flitting about mindless of gravity, so is the landscape.  And then, when the subconscious begins to feel that you're messing with the dream, they--the projections of the dreamer's subconscious, come after you, and that really cheapens the film.When the movie gets to its main focus, the Inception--inserting the idea into the Industrialist's dream--they have to go down into three levels of his dreaming, each one occupying exponentially more time than the one above.  What do they find?  That he's been trained for this moment, and that his subconscious is fully armed and ready to fight back.  Yawn.  You'd think in a grand cinematic adventure of the mind like this one, when you get that far into someone's head you'd find an old fling, some deep secrets;  a lost fantasy world?  Something really interesting?  No.  All we get is a mainline Hollywood big budget shoot 'em up.  Oh well.  It's a hole in the film, but the film doesn't fall apart because of it.My first viewing went by like a fast trip on a train in a driving rain--I had to guess what was going on most of the time, so I offer the following tips:Pay Attention to:1) The Rules--they come early, and are simple and clear and don't change.2) Notice who is actually doing the dreaming for any sequence--they have to stay awake in the dream, when everyone else goes to the next level--this can get confusing.3) The Rules about the time spans of each level of the dream within a dream.4) The spinning top, and where it stops spinning.If you can manage that, you'll come to the end much more prepared.I very much enjoyed the film and look forward to watching it again, and probably more times after that.
summary: They Went Down Down Down And Found An Action Film

reviewText: Inception is a Science Fiction film in the purest sense of the word. It does have some amazing special effects but the Inception has a unique way of sticking in your head due to the clever way it handles its subject matter.Instead of dealing with the exploration of outer space, this film tackles the subject of the inner workings of the human mind. In the future, people have developed a way to tap into peoples dreams as a means of corporate espionage. That is the main character's, played by Leonardo Dicaprio, means of making a living. His special talent goes a step further by creating/controlling dreams within dreams to extract secrets from the dreamer. The movie is alot like a hiest film where the vault is someone's mind.Leaonardo's character takes on "one last job" in order to free himself from the imposed exile from his home and family. The job is extremely dangerous since it involves creating one dream world inside another, inside another. The danger is that his emotional baggage could trap him in the dreamworld forever.Inception is a very engrossing film that forces the viewer to pay close attention to what is happening on the screen; rewarding him/her to a great movie-going experience. This DVD is a "must have" for any fan of director Christopher Nolan and a "must see" for anyone else.

reviewText: I love Christopher Nolan!!! Truly . I own all of his films but the first Batman film (which is very good) . Perhaps i'm too old ? My wife and i really anticipated watching this film on Blu-ray . The Mrs. wanted to stream it but i felt i'd need the subtitles to keep up with the many characters (great cast) and twists . We made it about 70 minutes into the picture when we turned toward each other for the last time (my wife and i) and laughed . Out-of-there . We had lost interest in everything about the film (particularly the characters) who were not developed at all (in our opinion) . I've seen over four decades of pretension on film . Save it for someone who cares . Even the favorable critics on R.T's have only faint praise for it . If you're really smart and you "got it" , bully for you . We're stunned this is being considered for so many awards ? To each their own .
summary: Enough exposition for 20 films , enough cleverness for 8

reviewText: When Inception came to the theaters, I was interested, but had not yet gotten to watching the movie. As soon as the credits rolled, I was on the phone with him talking about Nolan's amazing cinema skills.  When I got home, the first thing I said to my girlfriend was "We need to see Inception", and the very next day I was back in the theater.Inception's plot has been tossed around on the internet, parodied, praised, and punished since its release.  Yet you cannot avoid a sense of wonder in the scope of the movie.  Dream landscapes, mental quandaries, and a beautiful score will haunt your imagination.Please pick up a copy of Inception and enjoy this film.I would just like to add to those who have already watched Inception (SPOILER), have you noticed Cobb only wears his wedding ring when he is dreaming?

reviewText: Chris Nolan is -step by step- the most innovator, defying and risky of the actual generation of North American filmmakers. This audacious project seems to confirm it .Sleep is unquestionably a "dangerous" condition, from the biological perspective; it's to say a Box of Pandora who suddenly may be waken up, switching off the array of defense mechanisms, exposing it with all its fragile vulnerability in order to be shaped or forged.Dom Cobb (Leonardo Di Caprio in lifetime role until this date) is a specialist in what concerns to permeate the frontiers of the subconscious and so, being capable to steal ideas of other people during the dream state; he seems to be a perfect target to undertake a most hazardous mission. To plaint an idea rather than steal it. This bold plan will allow him to recover part of his missing existence. But at the meantime he will have to face other big challenges of the enemy in this puzzling game of interests and strategies all the way through.The film carves in relief and brings us back the old romantic notion of the imagination and two worlds, night world and day world. And so, the psyche is the basic pillar of the whole drama. The psyche is far to be what supposedly we mean by unconscious. The psyche -in its perpetual evolution- makes intelligible statements being able to erect new hidden connections, unthinkable projects, dreams, moods, desirable worlds or unbearable environments. I cannot stop to think in the famous short tale of Jorge Luis Borges titled "The memory of Shakespeare" in which the owner of this gift has a crown of thorns in his head and only can be saved when other people asks him why he has this arrange crown. Once you have asked this question, the crown goes to your head and you will have to wait for weeks, months or centuries for other who asks you the same and finally it releases you from this torment.When Napoleon defined the death as a dream without dream, he was conscious or unconsciously, pointing to the core of the question. The different layers of reality in what we move, the levels of relative sanity or insanity in what we live, the powerful contradictions of  terms such passion, caprice, firm determination or relentless attitude in pursuit of something or someone, depend in last instance, of every one of us; this implies a subjective matter, obscured by the jungle of the prefixed concepts that have nothing to do with our surrounding reality. The more intelligent you are, the more you are near of leave behind what many people may regard as impossible at a first sight. When Balzac stated the bravery was just an habile calculus about the fear that struggled our adversary, one can infer the will as the main vector of our live may surmount obstacles of any sort, and so, for many this defying and even irreverent attitude may be associated with a state of dementia.Nolan takes advantage of this script and exposes several lines of behavior around the chaser and victim and shows us they are not so distant like it seemed at fist sight.It would be convenient not forget that this fascinating issue had previously explored by Rene Clair in The beauties of the night, Buñuel in the Exterminator Angel,  La Jete by Chris Maker, Dodes-Kaden by Kurosawa, Gilliam in Brazil and Twelve monkeys, David Lynch in Mulholland Drive.Complex, dynamical, imaginative and fascinating film that I wouldn't hesitate as the best script in years.A must-see.
summary: The most imaginative script of the year!

reviewText: This is definitely one piece of sci-fi candy to be enjoyed over and over again.  I will not bore you with the plot and special effects.  Suffice it to say that you have to pay attention and additional viewings will be rewarding. It appears to be inspired from an older movie, The 13th Floor, staring Gretchen Mol. That movie explored the realm of tapping into a computer simulation program (a very real appearing program in which participants believe they are real people).  Inception actually gives the movie a bit of a nod by naming one of its central characters Mal (pronounced "Mol" in the film). But that's where the similarities end. I suspect that those who gave the movie a negative review were expecting a traditional and very linear feature.  You have to re-adjust your expectations, take a deep breath and keep awake for this little gem. And that's the "kick."

reviewText: There has been movies that deal with layers of reality before and even dreams-within-dreams. Remember the endings of Men in Black i & 2? Or even Tron and Tron Legacy? And then there was The 13th Floor, where the reality had a boundary, and the characters could see it.Inception brought the concept to another level and made each reality affect the other like a domino. If you believe in karma, then you can see the direct results of cause and effect, layer upon layer. The director makes you think, makes you pay attention and dares you to blink - because, if you do, you probably will lose it all and get totally confused. De Caprio, as usual, does a good job out of fleshing out his character, but what the heck I'm a de Caprio fan anyway. But I suspect, when he was peddling his skills about subconscious extraction, he was trying very hard to keep a straight face...The great intercuts and fast editing keep the audience on its toes; the glass-shattering soundtrack (listen to those giant French horns!) is only matched by that in Tron Legacy, but where storyline goes, Inception comes up tops. You need a really solid sound system with great bass to really enjoy this!One beef: I got the BD, DVD, Digital Copy combo, and I suspect the engineers deliberately produced a DVD of lesser quality just to show off the quality of the Blue Ray. When playing the DVD, the banding on my tv was totally unacceptable. Technology has produced audio and video to the limits of human sight and hearing, and I'm afraid those clever people producing tvs, players and recorders are going to produce more and more sub-standard DVDs just to make us switch to the pricier medium. I hope there are people out there who keep an eye on such things...That said, I am watching Inception over and over again, like Mal trying to return to her dream. Maybe my reality is elsewhere too?This is the first time that I am giving 5 stars to any movie; it's going to be a long time before I will rate a movie like that again.Go watch it.

reviewerName: I'd rather be at the Beach
reviewText: Finally!  A really unique, interesting idea for a movie!  After seeing so many remakes, Inception is one you have NEVER seen before.  It is the idea of hacking into someone's dream to either extract one of their ideas or a piece of knowledge or to implant one.  There are layers of dreams, and it is a trick to get back out of them.  A team of specialists lead by Leonardo Dicaprio tries to enter the dreams of a corporate executive to implant an idea, but there is nothing easy about it.  This is a multi-layered story with subplots and even multi-layered dreams!There are movies whose plots can be written on a cocktail napkin.  This is not one of them.  It took my seeing it twice before I really grasped everything going on.  I love movies that really make you think and don't hand you all the answers on a silver platter.  The acting was solid, the special effects were AMAZING, the directing & pacing fantastic and even a good soundtrack.  I recommend this movie.
summary: WOW!  Unique Idea for a Movie!

reviewText: I realize that this movie has generally received very good reviews, so I'm in the minority in saying that it didn't do much for me.At a micro level, the visuals are effective and there's enough action to make the movie reasonably entertaining.  The acting is also generally good enough.However, on the macro level, the nested dreams concept just seemed complicated for the sake of being complicated, and it wasn't done in a way that generated much intrigue for me.  In fact, I found it almost boringly tedious.  And even more broadly, this movie doesn't seem to have any point, any serious reflections on the human condition.  Yes, it does obviously raise the question of how we can distinguish dreams from reality, but there's nothing new there, and other movies have done a much better job with this theme.  Moreover, the notion that people would go to all this trouble for the sake of business espionage strikes me as being silly and bordering on cartoonish.In the end, I find this movie to be something of a pretender - somewhat entertaining, but a pretender nonetheless.

reviewText: This is a science fiction film that, as its director says, "explores the potential of the human mind." It is based on the idea that people using the proper equipment and skills can enter other people's mind while the people are asleep and implant ideas into their head that the people thinks are their own ideas. A very rich man who owns a huge business is dying. He left his estate to his son. A competitor wants Leonardo Dicaprio and his team to kidnap the son and implant the idea that he wants to divide the large business into smaller parts. The competitor explains that as long as the business is large, he has no chance of competing and making money. But if it is divided into small businesses, he can, with a larger business, beat them all. Dicaprio and his team accept the challenge, but the system requires that they also enter the victims mind when they are asleep, when their own subconscious may sabotage their plans. Dicaprio has many unresolved psychological problems that interfere with his plans in this fast-moving film.

reviewText: .....Or at least in My Humble Opinion.So, at first when I heard of this movie I was suspicious not a little but a LOT. I mean, this film basically has every element that will make it a "mess" for me :-(A) It has a complicated plot that will probably make no sense at all.(B) It's gonna be totally unbelievable and totally ridicules.(C) It's A Sci/Fi DUH ! I hate Sci/Fi.And what even made me more suspicious is that one of my friends have seen it and "hated" it. I quote "couldn't even finish the movie" due to the unclear completely confusing story line.I have to admit that all of the above made me put this movie off for a while, even If I've already bought the DVD but another friend of mine was urging me on watching it because as yet I quote again "It's SOOOO Good and a must see" that I had to satisfy my curiosity and given in........and I'm glad I did !This movie wasn't just "good" it was brilliant ! Fantastic and totally Awesome ! Seriously, probably the best Sci/Fi movie I've ever seen and the most fun film I've enjoyed like really enjoyed in a long time and that's coming from someone who doesn't normally watch Sci/Fi.Usually when I watch a movie, I either skip some parts, let the movie play on my DVD while I do other things like doing a project, assignment or read an article or whatever. Sometimes I would leave the movie playing while I do other things and sometimes I would "Pause" the movie and return to seeing it at other times.  This movie However had a gratifying effect on me, it just made me totally glued to the chair, there were parts in it where I was wondering How did they do that ? Especially the part when they were floating in the air was pretty cool and I haven't been wondering about this kind of stuff since I was in primary school.I think the major problem for this movie is that some people may not understand the plot line and I don't blame them, I mean the plot is kinda complicated and hard to get into unless you're paying a close attention you'll probably get that facial expression on your face that says "Whaaaaat ????" or "Ehhhh, I don't get this".That's why for the sake of understanding the movie, I'd recommend you do as I did. Turn the lights off, remove any element of distracting, don't get busy doing anything else or you won't understand the movie. Stay in a quite nice corner and just relax and watch the film. See if you won't understand it, never "pause" unless you have to.The filmography was amazing ! The directing was cool, the scenes beautifully made all the virtual stuff are awesome too. The acting fantastic and the premise is Original and creative and completely interesting.I would recommend this film to every Sci/Fi lover, and if you don't like Sci/Fi I would recommend you give this movie a try you might like it. Oh, and chicks it's not just a guy's movie I'm a chick and I loved it so maybe you would wanna watch it sometimes ;)

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: You will recognize at once the various matrices that have produced this film. The first matrix is of course that of all sorts of king fu and other action films that deal with real and virtual worlds intertwined into a more or less loose fabric. This one is simple to identify and follow, if follow we want to or can.The second matrix is naturally "Matrix", the film or rather trilogy of films. In Matrix though the three levels of reality are the underground warriors who fight against the conquest of the world by machines, the real world and the world of machines. A fourth level exist which is the result of the matrix itself: the real world of the surface is little by little conquered by a mental world "controlled" or "invaded" by a certain Mr. Smith. This mental world is the creation of some engineer behind who invented the mathematical matrix that enables his mind to take over the real world.None of this here. In fact we have a real team of people who are exploiting a certain capability of some human beings, themselves among others, their ability to dream and to be able to live (virtually of course) in that dreamed world. That dreaming can be controlled by some machine and is like hypnosis. The complication comes from the fact that anyone in any world can dream a deeper world that then superimposes itself onto the original world. We thus can come to five, six or seven levels of depth. This is done so fast that, and since we are constantly jumping from one level to the next, the film becomes chaotic.The human mind is afraid and abhors chaos. So in front of this situation we are confronted to we try to sort out the various levels and to remember which one is the first true dream, hence which one is the real world, and hence which ones are the other and deeper worlds. Don't believe in miracles. You would have to be autistic to be able to really follow every shift from one world to the next and identify them in their depth and successiveness. And that's the charm of the film. A certain balance and equilibrium is then re-established at the end when finally - but I won't say - though we have absolutely no real element to make sure that last scene is the real world.At another level of meaning this film, as opposed to "Matrix", has no reference or metaphor connected to any Christian myth, or as for that any mythology at all. The film then has no ethical meaning, no spiritual signification, no mental and moral depth. We are thus and henceforth floating and roaming into a vast universe of many strata with no milestone, guideline or compass to find a way out. This world is absolutely psychotic and after a period of living in that universe the characters would find it a relief to finally die. But is it that simple?If you died in the first level of dreaming that would wake you up in the real world. But if you died in any deeper world you will never be able to wake up in the real world, hence you would die really. The fact that suffering at any level accumulates in the real person whose personae or avatars are suffering at any dreamed level makes the experience really painful for the real persons. The psychosis would easily then induce this person to just accept to die, to commit suicide.The last characteristics of this film is that the main character has the capability to bring into any of his dreamed world the recollection of his wife who is really dead, or so he says, and she can play a direct role against him including enticing him to commit suicide in order to stay with her. Here the psychosis can reach a certain level of schizophrenia.This film then is a pure strong disorienting drug that aims at getting you out of any kind of stable vision of reality. That's what the title means and that's what the objective of the real people in the real world is: to implant ideas in the brains of other people to control them and to make them do what they want them to do, in other words to manipulate them. IN-ception is nothing but a manipulation of words like RE-ception, PER-ception, DE-ception, and many others: CON-ception, EX-ception, .... In a way it is a denunciation of the virtual universe or universes of electronic games now game-designers have been able to introduce us into their virtual reality just as if we were really in that universe made real in the process. All that is false and fake but quite a few people find it comfortable to live in such a psychotic reality, and for some of them to die there.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 8 Saint Denis, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID

reviewText: it might help to think of dreams as virtual realities - cept that they occur in another human - rather than in a computer - then you'll see this story as analogous to the virtual reality films you might have seencharacters in a dream can also dream - call it a "nested" dreamjust as there are laws of nature for our reality - there are laws of nature for dreams - their presentation come fast and furious - and it can be tricky for viewers to keep them in mind - writer/director Chris Nolan had 8 years to work them out - but they are often arbitrary - generated to aid the plota prime example of that is the law that the outsider provides the "architecture" or environment - which gives the invading team some control over the course of events - while the dreamer provides the characters - especially his ownanother arbitrary - and very counterintuitive law is that even in their dreams - dreamers will hide information they want to keep secret - and obtaining those secrets is the typical mission of this rogue team - altho "inception" - or planting an idea in the dreamer - seems possibleit is not always easy in a dream to tell who the dreamer is - and who is the outsider - altho - at times - outsiders will be sensed by the dreamer - and the dreamers populace will stalk themin the film - the actual techniques of invading another's dream is left unexplained - this omission keeps the story flowingi hope that is helpful - plus - i hope you enjoy the movie more than i did - if you surf on top of the story and not try to analyze things too carefully - you might enjoy it - it has more surface than depthpeople who already have been intellectually stimulated by virtual reality concepts will find this familiar territory - the same questions are stirred up - a similar topography exploredi found the main plot - the "inception" plan - was so trivial that it culd have been turned over to a low rent Mission Impossible team rather than a Dream team - i found the subplot about the man's wife more interestingand another gripe - whereas a computer-based virtual world should seem like the real world - that's the intention - but dreams - at least MY dreams - look very different from reality - even tho i find them convincing at the time - my dreams are more vague and surreal - constantly morphing from one scene to another - that sensation wasn't captured by this movie - not even close - Chris Nolan must have incredibly detailed and realistic dreams

reviewText: A film like Inception only comes along once a decade, and it's no surprise it took Writer/Director Christopher Nolan over ten years to polish the screenplay into its final form. The loud and frenetic visuals in the trailer all fall into place when you see the film, which represents a masterful blend of genres and ideas, some of which have been attempted before but never in this combination. Unlike so many Jerry Bruckheimer visual onslaughts or the recycled franchises that use continuous split-second cuts to replace plot, the major set pieces in the film leave the audience literally on the edge of their seats, and it's one of the few blockbusters in memory that can be enjoyed as both a top-notch action movie and a deeply cerebral experience.In fact, Inception is a perfect film on so many levels that it's breathtaking to watch. Apart from the technical wizardry of bringing some of the mind-bending visuals to the screen, the real triumph is in conveying its complex, layered concepts and plot lines in a way that never lectures or loses the audience and never takes a break from the action to lay down exposition. Unlike the sequels to the Matrix, where the attempt to develop the alternate reality of the first film became convoluted and ludicrous in the second and third installments, Inception has enough fresh ideas to feel like an entire trilogy perfectly woven into one coherent and gripping movie. And with a running time of 2.5 hours, it's remarkable that it never once drags or lingers on unnecessary scenes to reach the conclusion.For fans of Memento, it will seem like that film was just Nolan was warming up to getting Inception just right. Roger Ebert made an interesting observation when he said it's a film that defies spoilers, in that even if you know the ending, it's meaningless without knowing how you got there. For film-buffs and screenplay enthusiasts, the richness of the dream-within-a-dream reality and the effortless jumping between different timelines and dreamers' worlds will be studied for years. And even though the film happens primarily in dreams, Nolan avoids the temptation to use the weirdness of the the dream world just to show us something different that ultimately doesn't make sense.And yet despite the tight plotting, fastidious direction and pitch-perfect score from Hans Zimmer, it's the performances of a flawless cast that pulls the whole thing together. Leonardo DiCaprio once again shows us he's one of the finest actors working today, and any one of the supporting cast creates an Oscar-worthy performance. Amongst a remarkable cast, the real star is Marion Cotillard who, in playing the subconscious projection of Leonardo's deceased wife, is both warm and completely terrifying, and grounds the challenges of the hero to chilling effect. She provides the darkness of the theme in the same convincing way that Heath Ledger epitomized the black undertones of The Dark Knight.With Inception, Christopher Nolan underscores himself as one of the best Writer/Directors in Hollywood, and continues to develop not only his own storytelling but the capabilities of his crew, many of whom we've seen in previous films. I don't think you'll see a better film this year, and seeing this was the first time in a long time I walked out of the movie theater thoroughly entertained, intrigued and inspired.
summary: An instant classic that demands multiple viewings

reviewText: I'll admit I'm very mixed when it comes to Christopher Nolan's films. I loved his first film 'Following' as well as 'Batman Begins' and consider them both favorites. I liked the ideas behind 'Dark Knight' and 'Prestige' but felt Nolan was sacrificing the fun in the ideas of his films for cleverness. Inception is kind of in the middle: a science fiction thriller with great direction and fun ideas but a bit artificial in the story-telling department.The plot of Inception follows a bunch of 'mission impossible'-like thieves who have the technology to invade people's dreams and steal information. The team is led by the charismatic Cobb who has a tortured past and is hired/strung-along by shady businessman Saito to implant an idea into a rival's dreams. I loved how the people in Cobb's team are recruited, each having his or her ability in the 'dream' world (i.e. one's an architect who creates the dream world, one's a forger who can assume other identities). As the movie goes on we are introduced to more and more rules of the 'dream' world our thieves are infiltrating (how time works in different 'layers' or dream within dreams) at the same time getting more and more about Cobb's past. Unfortunately the film starts breaking it's own "rules" after a while and the pay-as-you-go dialogue gets so ridiculous that the experience falls apart and feels more like a blueprint than an actual movie.The cast in Inception (as with the rest of Nolan's films) is perfect. Leonardo Decaprio (in my opinion) gives his best performance to date as the lead-thief Cobb. Joseph Gordon-Levitt is reason enough to see any film and (in my opinion) steals every scene he's in. Ellen Paige is a good choice as the every-person for whom we see most things from and get alot about how the dream technology works. Ken Watanabe is great as Saito and Tom Hardy is given a fun character who can assume other people's identities in dreams.Another great thing about Inception is the visuals. While Christopher Nolan's screenplay is filled with too much exposition, the sheer imagination put into the set designs and action scenes is breathtaking. Buildings fold, characters walk on a never-ending staircase, and the gunfights (particularly the one in zero gravity) and chase scenes are slick as can be. You really have to see it to get how neat it is.I obviously wouldn't call 'Inception' best film I've ever seen. As usual I like Christopher Nolan's stories but I don't like the way he tells them. I did find 'Inception' worth watching, though if only for it's originality. With so many other movies adding up to absolute garbage it's nice that there's a director who's still thinking outside the box. I just wish he would leave some sense of wonder and imagination left to the audience.

reviewText: What are you thinking about?  Elephants, right?  You've just taken the first step into understanding the mind-influencing and reality-bending genius of Inception.Imagine you're dreaming an M.C. Escher painting.  You don't know up from down, don't know real from fake.  Now imagine someone else can control your dream, implant thoughts, influence your behavior, manipulate your beliefs.  First explored competently inDreamscapewith a young Dennis Quaid, the thought of dream control - followed closely by the real life physical, emotional, and psychological consequences of dreams - is compounded upon in level s so numerous I had to take off my shoes and socks to keep count.The basic concept: Cobb (DiCaprio) and Arthur (Gordon-Levitt) have the extraordinary ability to enter others' dreams - Sleeping Toms, if you will.  After an intensely realistic trial run, a rich businessman named Saito (Watanabe) enlists their abilities to accomplish the dangerous practice of "inception:"  planting thoughts into another's mind through dreams.  The target is a competing businessman, Robert Fischer, Jr. (Cillian Murphy).  What Saito doesn't know, however, is Cobb's dangerous history with time and mortality slipping away in his dreams.  Dying in dreams.  Getting stuck in dreams.  To explain all the details or dangers of their mission would be futile, but they assemble a team of various malcontents (i.e. Tom Hardy as Eames and Dileep Rao as Yusuf) and a wunderkind (i.e. Ellen Page as Ariadne - the architect) to share a perilous multi-dimensional mission into the unpredictable nether regions of the psyche, where a person's subconscious can and will attack foreign intruders like white blood cells battle disease.Director Christopher Nolan, who previously fried synapses with Memento and The Prestige, provides yet another wholly enjoyable, spell-binding, challenging film.  The plot and the script are fabulously complex.  There's no doubt that the Deus ex machina is heavy handed at times, but a movie intending to challenge viewers to interpret reality from dream - particularly the unknowns being explored - should be given wide latitude for explanation without ruining a viewer's exposition experiences.  In and of itself, the plot is amazing.  Paired with an outstanding cast - powered by DiCaprio, probably the best actor of his generation - that receives ample, individual screen time to strut, (great supporting roles from Tom Berenger, Michael Caine, and Marion Cotillard) and we're talking Oscar territory.  Combine all that with multiple action and special effects sequences (especially a weightless frenzy of punches, kicks, and elbows that puts a few Matrix fight scenes knee-deep in molasses) that have to be seen to be believed, and the layers form quickly (except the eye-popping slo-mo scenes) into what I'll tout as film of the year, and a round-table discussion topic for Freudian psychologists for decades to come.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan never disappoints. In a time when Hollywood seems to have run out of ideas and only feels safe betting on reboots and sequels, it's extraordinary to see someone with the guts to make something original and successful.Inception is an entreating film. It is smart enough to make you think and wonder (without trying too hard) somewhere amongst the adventure which is quite a ride.I'd also like to make a special mention of the soundtrack. Hans Zimmer always rules, but he outdid himself here.One of Nolan's best, right there with Memento and the Dark Knight.The Blu-Ray has amazing picture quality and sound. Some people might complain about the special features, but they're fine as long as you don't let Lord of the Rings spoil you and expect every movie release to include more time of special features than the length of most miniseries.This movie is on par with precious few like Matrix and Dark City. It is smart sci-fi that makes you wonder and keeps you at the edge of your sit.

reviewText: I will be labeled a bad guy for this review as almost everyone I know say they love Inception. I did not and I will try to explain why.Inception is a joyless movie that is far more interested in the complexity of its plot than the boundless imagination it could have with its subject matter. Dreams are where anything is possible, where people can fly do things they could not do in real life. It's an experience that frees us or traps us in a new world created and only restrained by our imaginations. Inception does it's best to keep all that at bay, as it needs to to fulfill the requirements of its plot. But in being so subservient to its plot Inception also drastically under develops it's characters to the point that I really didn't care a whole lot about any of them.There is a small segment in Inception in which it glosses over its main character's backstory. That brief five minute synopsis should have been the movie.  It was a love story and a heartbreaking one at that. It would have been all emotion and all character driven. It could have played with the backdrop of dreams and been a great visual treat while staying true to the characters. Heck, it seems like a perfect Jim Cameron movie really.But that is not the kind of movie Nolan makes. Even the Dark Knight would have been bogged down by it's own complexities without the marvelous performance by Heath Ledger. The Joker  brought a character that was profoundly having fun creating as much mayhem as he could. It injected fun and intrigue to a group of rather dry characters. Inception didn't have a character like the Joker. Not one character looked like they were interested in being there. In fact early in the scheme, one snag, and all of them wanted out, but none of them seemed too upset or concerned about going forward either. The characters just obeyed what was necessary for the plot to continue on and virtually ignored most natural human reaction or emotion. This also undercut to a large degree the danger these characters were in. They seemed rather unaffected by it for the most part.So while I will give Nolan credit for creating a very complex and interesting concept, he needs to populate those type of stories with characters too. I think for a movie to really work for me I need to be invested in the Characters of a movie and Inception made a feeble attempt at that so I just couldn't get too excited about the movie as a whole.Now let the sniping commence as I know that this is a minority opinion to say the least!
summary: Why Inception did not work for me

reviewText: In spite of some good acting and an interesting and weird premise, this film fails utterly in terms of plot. There seems to be so much set up early in the film that is then never delivered on. For example, Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) asks Ariadne (Ellen Page) very early on in the movie to design a labyrinth, as part of her job interview. Later in the movie she's spending a lot of time designing the labyrinth needed for their plans to manipulate Robert (Cillian Murphy)... and then at the height of the story, we never see the labyrinth, and then they're blowing it up for reasons I couldn't begin to grasp. There are many things set up in the film that simply "disappear" later on.In any case, it's a story that could have been a lot better. The film is visually stunning, at least early on  -- there are some cool scenes later in the film ("How did they do that???"), but seem very self-conscious. In other words they were included because they are cool. But it feels to me like one of those movies that somehow ended up in screen-writing hell and they finally just gave up.All that said, Leonardo DiCaprio was really super. He was the only "real" character in the film, everyone else is nothing much more than part of the set. Ellen Page did as good a job as anyone could have hoped, given the miserable material she was given to work with.
