reviewText: Inception is a ridiculously detailed movie, that is helmed by as much of a star (Christopher Nolan) than perhaps even his own all-star cast. You travel to the depths of the mind as far as no movie ever traveled before, and the concept is so mind boggling that you leave with doubts about your own existance. The array of effects does not overwhelm the complexity of this film, nor does the intrusive, symphonic music of this film distract the viewer from the brainy events that take notice regardless of what is swarming.It is a considerable task to determine all the symbols and reasons before the events actually occur, and they occur at different rates of time, and also, reality is warped and at times out of reach. Without spoilers, I will say that the places you travel are disturbing, and epic.Inception requires a heavy dose of story build up, and the multi-dimensional climax is something to behold. And it takes some will of the viewer to follow along, but that is also one of Inceptions rewards: Is that it is challenging and worth the brain power you put into it.Yes, Inception travels along at its own pace, and yes it can be overwhelming at a point, but the scenes are so masterfully put together, that it works. This movie is a lavish, unforgettable puzzle. At some point, you don't care about why they are there, only about how it will come to fruition. After all, it isn't the characters you decidely care about, it is the ultimate climax of this deeply concieved movie.The ending is full of questions, but not frustratingly so. I say this with full regard of its effect, that the ending is appropriate, and should never be tampered with again. I do not ever want to see some directors cut out there that has a more "Hollywood" ending. Unbelievable.
summary: A deep story with unfathomable dimensions

reviewText: First off, I have to say that this movie is visually stunning.  I only watched it on my laptop, so I can't even imagine how awesome it would look on my flat screen.  That being said, I found the whole movie to be confusing, and at times, completely unrealistic and ludicrous.  Before anyone rips my head off, let me explain.  The plot was so complicated, and all over the place, that I found it hard to understand exactly what was going on.  And I can understand that this is a sci-fi movie at heart, and I love sci-fi movies, but the entire premise is so far out there (i'm talking thousands and thousands of years to even come close to what these characters are doing), that I had a hard time getting into the movie.  It is just downright impossible for someone to insert themselves into someone else's brain, and I dare say it always will be impossible.  And if it is possible one day, I doubt all it will take is to pop some ambien and connect to each other with an electrode.Even though the plot was basically ridiculous, I can see why the movie was such a hit.  Visually it is incredible.  And I think a lot of the plot was introduced solely for the purpose of "look what I can do!"  The characters float around, walk up walls, fall from high-rises, you name it.  You could say that this is what "The Matrix" would have been if you switch computers for dreams.I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy it.  And if you haven't seen it, it is definitely worth a look.  I would also advise you to watch it alone, or at least with someone who doesn't talk during movies, at a time when you won't be interrupted.  This might have been my problem with the complexity of the plot, I was watching it at work, and had to pause it frequently to help customers.  I will definitely watch it again at a better time.
summary: Cool movie, if you are good at suspending disbelief...

reviewText: I enjoyed "Inception" immensely in the movie theater and was looking forward to reviewing it in detail when I got the DVD.Even though I like the movie a great deal -- I have deducted two stars because the DVD comes up painfully short in the extras department.Yes, there are a few extras, but THEY'RE painfully short -- probably twenty minutes in total -- and there's NO director's commentary.  I think that the previews run longer than the extras.Shame on WB.  Such a highly regarded film deserves a much better DVD release -- and reserving some of the extra content for the BR package is NO excuse.The studios would love us all to move up to BR, but many of us still have SD CRTs -- and given the dearth of quality programming on TV these days, that isn't likely to change until our trustworthy old tubes die out.So I'm sorry to report that this is far from the dream DVD I was hoping for...

reviewText: Lets get the good points over with 1st: Good acting,creative, good scoreI am very fussy with action movies today. After seeing this film, I am very much in a hurry to see 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' in the theaters. Why, because I am afraid I will never see an ordinary, traditional, digestible action film on the big screen anymore! I am afraid that 'The Matrix' started this mess! The batmobile/cycle chase in Dark Knight (same Director) is a good action sequence that you can find in a new film nowadays. But 'Inception' is just a mess! "Oh No! The subconscience people are attacking!!"It's just thrown at your face too fast and too close to digest or appreciate it!! Why cant I understand it while its happening instead of finding out later?? Do I have to watch it again or go on Wicipedia to find out the plot that I cant swallow but keep spitting out? Well, I dont know If I want to see it again...too bad I bought it!! A few iconic tweaks may have helped this tremendously: Like a different music theme for a different dream layer. The editing and layout of the movie just didnt work!...I guess I'm old fashioned!The story is a problem with this movie! Maybe the story looks better on the page! There was something really wrong with the translation of the material to the screen. Years ago this would have been unacceptable. But I guess people were saying things like me here when seeing Hitchcock's Vertigo in 1958.
summary: If 'Inception' is our style today, what will be our style in 5 or 10 years?

reviewText: "Inception" has elements of both "Memento," which launched the whiz kid Christopher Nolan's film career, and "The Prestige," which is Nolan's most complex and subtle, interesting and entertaining, cerebral and provocative achievement to date.Like "Memento," "Inception" is concerned with how the mind works, how it chooses to gain or lose control over itself.  "Memento" was about memories, those crucial building blocks of our identity, and "Inception" is about dreams, which the movie argues is fundamental to how we think and behave.  (Extraction is about looking for locked-away memories, and inception is about implanting a small idea that then grows until like a virus it subsumes everything.)Like "The Prestige," "Inception" is a complicated maze.  In fact, it is like the dreamworld in which it inhabits, a multi-layered maze, with no start, no exit, and no direction.  Its precious complexity, a Nolan trademark, is ultimately the film's undoing, as while the film clearly entrances it does not hold and capture, and ultimately its idea fails to implant itself:  Nolan's inception has failed.  Both "The Machinist" and "Mulholland Drive" are far more fascinating (and, I believe from a neuroscientist's point of view, accurate) meditations on dreams, dreaming, and dreamers.Why the film fails is that Nolan does not establish anything concrete in the film, meaning that the entire film feels like a concocted dream.  There is a section which is meant to be "reality" but the acting is so bad, the editing so fast, the plot so incredible (everything so conveniently falls into place) that it fails to anchor us, and so we just float away.  There are many contradictions (or in Nolan parlance "paradoxes) in the film, and that's how Nolan likes it.  I think Nolan was going after the effect of having questioned everything about the film the audience now begins to question everything about their reality.But, uh, what's the point of that?There is no doubt that Nolan is one of the most talented and definitely the most cerebral of our directors today.  But there's nothing substantive or particularly intellectual about his films:  they're all just intricate and intriguing puzzles, meant to entertain and challenge the mind -- but there's just no greater meaning under the surface.  So "The Inception" team dig deeper and deeper into our minds, and all they see is either a vast blanket of snow or a great expansive empty ocean.The best thing about Nolan as a director is that he knows how to use good actors.  Both Christian Bale and Hugh Jackman were terrific in "The Prestige," and Leonardo DiCaprio shines more under Nolan than under Scorcese.  DiCaprio can be juvenile and irritating under Scorcese (which is probably how Scorcese wants it) but DiCaprio is captivating and sympathetic in this movie."Inception" is a fundamentally flawed concept and plot, but given the mediocrity that is Hollywood nowdadays it's better than most things out there.

reviewText: This movie is destined to be a CLASSIC.  At the Oscars it seemed to be largely overlooked and was nominated only for special effects and the like.  I can only assume that the movie was too cerebral for the Academy, and that they just plain didn't understand it.  Too bad.  It has an excellent script, but you can't afford to not pay constant attention.  Special effects, cinematography, set designs and the like were excellent, but so were the acting and directing. This is one of those rare movies where all violence and special effects were an integral part of the story; they weren't just "thrown in".  I saw the movie three times in the theater; buying the DVD was a must. A must buy.

reviewText: I am contemplating my review. I really don't know where to begin except to say this movie is a work of art. Christopher Nolan is the artist and Inception is his masterpiece. I really don't see where he can go from here.I won't go into detail about the plot because it will give to much away. Essentially a man named Dom Cobb(Leonardo DiCaprio) takes one last job to plant a idea inside Robert Fischer Jr's(Cillian Murphy) mind. So he can be able to go back to the United States and be with his children. I won't tell you why he can't go back it's a big part of the plot. The story is a dark tale about dreams and reality. None of these characters are good guys after all they break into peoples minds. Still you end up liking these flawed characters and root for them. That sometimes the dream becomes our reality and you can't tell the difference. That sometimes we prefer our dreams to the real world. The ending will leave you questioning what happened and what was real and what was the dream. If you don't pay attention this movie can be hard to follow. At one point near the climax there are four different plots going at the same time.The cast and acting was superb. Besides Leo who we should all know. There's Cillian Murphy(28 days Later/Sunshine), Ken Watanabe(The Last Samurai/Batman Begins), Joseph Gordon-Levitt(3rd Rock From The Sun/The Lookout), Ellen Page(Juno/Whip It), and Tom Hardy(Layer Cake/Bronson) round out the staring cast. All of which do a great job. Though I think Watanabe, Gordon-Levitt, and Hardy were the best. Rounding out the supporting cast were Marion Cortillard(Public Enemies) and such veterans as Tom Berenger(Platoon/Sniper), Pete Postlethwaite(The Usual Suspects/Alien 3), and Michael Caine(The Quiet American/The Dark Knight). The Michael Caine only had about three minutes of work in this film if that. Tom Berenger did a wonderful job with what he had to work with.With this complex story that is hard to follow some people might think there isn't any action or suspense. They would be wrong. From the opening scene the suspense builds until the stunning climax that I think will leave you speechless.Then there's the music by Hans Zimmer(Backdraft/Crimson Tide/The Dark Knight). Virtually every score he composes for a film ends up being a great.Finally there is the the directing by Christopher Nolan. A directer who has far as I know hasn't made a bad film yet. Hell he hasn't made a average film yet. All his films are good if not great and he just keeps on getting better. From Memento to Insomnia to Batman Begins and The Prestige to finally The Dark Knight. As if he was honing his craft for this film. The film he's been working on for years. Like I said his masterpiece. He is without the doubt the best director of this past decade and it looks like he will be in this decade. Is he one of the best directors of all time. With the likes of Eastwood, Spielberg, or Kurosawa. No he's not but he's well on his way.Overall for me this is the best movie of the summer. The best movie I've seen since The Dark Knight and one of the best Films I've ever seen. This is how films should be made with great writing, amazing acting and music and wonderful directing. It's hard to find in Hollywood now a days with endless sequels, remakes, and unimaginative or original stories. It's not the first to delve into this territory. Films like Dark City and The Matix(Before the ruined it with the crappy sequels) all went in this direction but only Nolan brought it to reality. If there is truly one movie to see this summer Inception is it. I am going to see it multiple times.

reviewText: "Inception" stars Leonardo DiCaprio, Tom Berenger, Marion Cotillard, Ellen Page, Pete Postlethwaite, Michael Caine and other top-notch cast members on a mission to enter the dream world of others, and not only interact there to the extent of extracting secrets, but to implant an idea that changes the course of the target sleeper's life by making them think they came up with the idea themselves.  This movie is a really good Sci-Fi / Fantasy genre offering, and it makes you pay attention.The movie was left at PG-13, and it needed to go farther.  But with censorship what it is, to get profitability in marketing where producers want it, they throttle back what might have been one of the greatest movies of all time.  As it is, since they kept it at the milque-toast level, this movie comes off as simply being snippet copies of other films that were quilted together to make a fast buck.  Too bad.  Could have been fantastic.  The idea of the freight train in the downtown business district without a railroad track is this movie's only redemption FX, and not much else was pioneer work effort.  I'm guessing this movie needed to be about half an hour to an hour longer, but even as abbreviated as it seems to be, the movie still takes 2 hrs and 28 minutes to view.Could have been better, but still pretty good IMHO.
summary: Sci-Fi / Fantasy flick keeps entertainment quality great . . .

reviewText: I'm an open-minded cinephile; but this film is a re-hash of movies and Tv shows that have already covered the same ground.  Dream-space, Existenz, Paprika, Star Trek's The Menagerie, Total Recall, Alias, Doctor Who, etc.  Right now people are on a Nolan kick so that means anything he does is automatically gold, but this film will be the reverse of Blade Runner -- it will enjoy immense popular acclaim and then be reviled fifty years from now.  I've heard all the popular defenses of this movie:  "You didn't get it," "it was too complex for you," for people who actually didn't like this film.  The fact is this movie aspires to be an artsy, thinking man's sci-fi film, but in the end it offers no new philosophy that better writers and directors haven't offered before.  The structure is derivative; the themes are derivative; the obligatory faux-ambiguous ending is derivative.  When you are working in the genre of sci-fi, and you are trying to craft an artsy sci-fi film, you had better be aware of all the other products out there, and offer some type of philosophy of your own, or yours won't stand the test of time.There is nothing here that Clarke, Bradbury, Ballard, Ellison, Chris Carter, DC Fontana and many others haven't explored before.  To suggest the world is all a dream is a theme as old as time itself, and to suggest that parts of one's consciousness might be lost in separate realities or dreams within dreams is derivative as well.  Even the visual language of this film has been capitalized on in other films, everything from the moving buildings, to the presence of an infinite regression -- Nolan has managed to lift his iconography and pastiche these from other movies, without offering any conclusion of his own.  It's the difference between a teacher who can explain Kant's "Critique of Pure Reason" versus a philosopher who calls into question the validity of Kant's argument.  Nolan is so content being a teacher that he doesn't even care about whether or not he agrees with observations he is reciting.I read one article where the film critic justified the movie as a comment on the dream nature of cinema itself (duh!) and argued that Nolan's blatant plagiarism was to be excused on the grounds that dreams themselves are the products of blatant plagiarism (or pilfering from reality).  While I admire the immense thought that went into his defense, I disagree with the idea that self-reflexivity makes or somehow elevates a film.  "Rear Window" is a masterpiece of suspense despite its allusions to the act of film-going.  It's a deeper movie when you consider how Hitchcock is implicating us in the voyeuristic process, but that alone doesn't make it a masterpiece.  Furthermore, any filmmaker who were to make a movie with the same implications would be seen as re-hashing an observation already made by Hitchcock.  "Inception" is not the first to address the nature of dreaming, and the manner in which it addresses it is ultimately derivative and conservative in nature.In the end, "Inception" is a tepid, conservative, safe, and derivative movie about dreams, made for American audiences who are not tough on their filmmakers (there is a reason Inception has suffered with foreign audiences who have seen much more creative fair), to make them feel all tingly all over.  Eventually time will show that Nolan was asleep on the job.
summary: A movie taken from other movies...

reviewText: If you can figure out the plot of "Inception" and follow through its excruciating steps, you deserve a tee shirt prize. People are put in various dream states and strata or levels of dream conditions. One is Limbo, and in one dream state you can never get out and can be trapped there forever. One person's subconscious directs another person who may be the architect of the dream world or the inceptor. Sound like a lot of gobbledegook? Well, it may well be.Leonardo Di Caprio is the lead inceptor, but he is a poor one, because he's too wrapped up in his wife's death, a death he may have caused by putting her in a dream state in which she killed herself. An elevator in a dream takes him down to a beach site, and his reality dreaming conflicts with the mission he is supposed to be conducting. He keeps seeing his dead wife over and over. Get it?There's a lot of action, a great deal of destruction of buildings and street scenes created by computer enhanced technology, something we're getting way too much of in movies these days.Michael Caine has a cameo role in the film. Di Caprio assembles a team to go with him on his dream missions. It reminds me of other team movies like Munich or Mission Impossible or Topkapi. A leading member of the teams is Eames, a very athletic guy, actor Tom Hardy, who is able to defy gravity and walk up walls and on ceilings. Di Caprio is this sci-fi action thriller is a crook who doesn't steal objects; he steals ideas from people's minds and dreams.It's an interesting premise, but the producers should practice the principle of KISS which is Keep it Simple, Stupid, so moviegoers can more readily follow this type of dream creation. Di Caprio is very earnest in it, but I'm not sure he has figured out the plot either.There are interesting visuals, some good special effects, some unique dream sequences, and good cinematography. It's a tricky subject but one which can be conveyed better through movies than in any other medium.

reviewText: "What's the most resilient parasite? An Idea. A single idea from the human mind can build cities. An idea can transform the world and rewrite all the rules."And with that premise comes Inception- the latest slice of psychological brilliance from director Christopher Nolan to hit the theaters.  It's a well-layered, dynamically intriguing landscape of a story that absolutely seizes your attention. In this near-future vision of the world Dream Share Technology is a high-end field of both private enterprise and corporate espionage, so much so that CEO's and the like are often trained to resist it.The movie opens with Cobb (DiCaprio), an Extractor- who makes his living stealing people's secrets from their minds while they're dreaming.  He and his team had been hired to enter the mind of Saito (Ken Watanabe), but the job is disrupted by Mal (Marion Cotillard), the ghost of Cobb's late wife who haunts his own psyche, forcing them to hide from their employer.  But unbeknownst to them Saito was also auditioning them for his own purposes: he wants them to perform not an extraction but an 'inception'- planting an idea within someone's mind- on a business rival, Fischer (Cillian Murphy).  The trick of an inception is in making the subject believe they conceived it themselves, otherwise their subconscious will reject it.  The concept of an inception is extremely radical and considered only a theory, but Cobb knows it can be done... because he's done it before.  Once.Time is also a factor as a subconscious mind will eventually perceive the intruders and attack them relentlessly.  Success demands extreme skills and delicate navigation of the subject's psyche.  Cobb and Arthur (Gordon-Levitt) the Point Man, who researches their targets, recruit associates old and new- Eames (Tom Hardy) is the Forger, who can assume a specific identity within the dream; Ariadne (Page) is the Architect, who constructs the dreamscape to fit the team's needs; Yusuf (Dileep Rao) is the Chemist, who supplies the drugs needed to keep them all in the dream state.  Saito also accompanies them into the dream as they all have specific roles to fill once within Fischer's mind.  It's very much a Matrix version of Mission Impossible with some Dark City thrown in.To both complete the mission and escape successfully they must create a dream within the dream- a very unstable platform- taking them even deeper within Fischer's mind to manipulate him.  But the sins of the past continue to haunt Cobb as Mal reappears yet again to sabotage their plan and steals Fischer for her own purposes.The sub-plot and character arcs are equally compelling: Cobb's relationship with Mal is critical to the story, driving him to extremes that put everyone at risk, as well as giving Saito the leverage he needs to push Cobb into accepting the assignment.  The genius of Nolan's script is the fact that the opening quote lies at the core of the entire film.Characterizations were brilliant as well: having never been a fan of Dicaprio I am after seeing this movie.  Page did good work as DiCaprio's character foil- both providing the audience's viewpoint and juxtaposing his dilemma.  Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Tom Hardy played off each other well as men with opposing personalities.  The special effects were amazing; the visuals wholly appropriate to a dream reality.  Even the soundtrack was effective; Zimmer's synth, horn and percussion arrangements complimented the on-screen action perfectly.  If there's one- and only one- real complaint here is that it's too long; clocking in at 2  hours, there were several places where cuts could have been made and trimmed a good twenty minutes off without missing a trick.  Other than that this is a helluva mind scramble, and reminds you of just how good movies can be.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ***This review may contain spoilers.  What it doesn't contain is a rehash of the plot.  Sorry. You'll have to look elsewhere for that.***Everyone and his Yorkshire Terrier is commenting on "Inception". I'll chip in my two-cent criticism as well.I viewed this movie with my friends Mark and Ron at the AMC Theater in Framingham on Flutie Pass (yes, named after Doug). All of us came out stunned. Ron thought it was the stupidest movie he had seen. Mark colorfully opined that it was some really (expletive deleted) weird (expletive deleted). I tried to be more thoughtfully diplomatic by describing what I thought the movie was trying to do. Basically, I thought "Inception" tried to take the ancient themes of "What is reality, what is dream?" and "Is it all a dream" into convoluted, tiered, and entertaining directions.I disagree with Mr. Ebert's assessment in his review that "Inception" is "wholly original". "Inception" will remind you of many other movies; for example, it obviously evoked "Dreamscape", "The Matrix", and any Bond thriller you've ever seen. But did I "like" it? Well, in past blogs I alluded to the concept of "cinematic dissonance" (which I believe should be included in Mr. Ebert's movie glossary, by the way), a simultaneous experience where your intellect regards a film as garbage while your emotions regard the film as great fun. With "Inception" I somewhat experienced the converse; my intellect appreciated the straight/convoluted logic of the plot while my emotions simultaneously and eventually surrendered to impatience and boredom, in spite of the phantasmagoric special effects and intense action. Well, it was late, and I am more of a morning person.Like other movies in the "dreams/reality" genre, "Inception" sucks you into deciding which exciting, involved scenario is a dream or not, even when we are apparently "told" which one. This "trees at the expense of the forest" view is, I think, meant to be beside the point. Like all good movies in this genre, "Inception" is saying that the basic ideas to retain are "It's really all a dream" and "Reality is a subjectively chosen point on a circular continuum". Three scenes illustrate this: 1) Ariadne shows Cobb the old "infinite mirror" phenomenon in the Paris construct, 2) Cobb points out Ariadne's circular maze is the proper architectural dream construct, and 3) the entire film's circular, "this is where I came in" structure."Inception" cleverly distracts us from this unsettling overall view with its noisy plot spinnings, the deceptive "3-dimensional chess" structure (recall Ariadnee's choice of a bronze pawn as her "reality marker") of the putative idea-planting plot, and the more emotionally involving dilemmas of Fischer's and Cobb's family issues. Nolan also realizes that these distractions also make the potentially alienating and disquieting notion that nothing is truly real more entertainingly palatable. In other words, we arbitrarily choose Cobb's and Fischer's situations as the reality to which we want to cling because they are at least understandable, reasonably entertaining, and diverting from the bleak "non-reality". Michael Caine's character underscores that with his exhortation to Cobb, "Come back to reality", making him, and not Cobb's top, the actual arbitrary "reality marker".Inception asks, "At what point does the circle (of life) begin?" Even though the movie gives you an "answer", the real answer is "Any point you choose." Some would say "Inception" demands repeated concentration. If you want to go on a metaphor and symbol scavenger hunt (and there's nothing wrong with that), go right ahead. I don't think it's strictly necessary. One viewing is enough to tell you that life is but a dream.P.S.: I think Nolan wants you to be lulled into happy closure with Cobb's "apparent reunion" with his children. The muted, static way that reunion scene is shot suggests otherwise. The Dream Never Dies.  Hey, what a great title for the inevitable sequel.  Also a great title for another Bond flick.
summary: It All Boils Down To "The Dream Shall Never Die"

reviewText: I wanted to like this film but I just couldn't.  Interesting premise, I'll admit.  But not a very good movie.  Nolan has made some movies with interesting premises but he's not terribly skilled at the craft of movie-making or storytelling.  Others, including some established film critics, have summed up this movie's numerous failings (and Nolan's shortcomings) far more eloquently than I will here.  I have listed a few of them below, and some of them make for quite entertaining reading, especially the ones by Edelstein and Wachtel.Had another filmmaker without Nolan's current/recent standing made this film, I believe it would have been more universally dismissed as the flawed film it is.  But Nolan seems to be getting a free pass lately, and it is not deserved.  Is the love for this film based on the film itself, or is it based on the excitement of simply getting to see another Chris Nolan film?  Think carefully before you answer.  Be honest with yourself.There's really not that much to invest in emotionally.  Leo's Dom Cobb has his motivations for barreling through all this mess, but largely I didn't care.  The special effects sure were nifty, and the concept was somewhat interesting, but I felt like the whole thing was "forced" and the effects and the conceit WERE the story rather than being there to serve it.  The story seems reverse-engineered, as if he had certain action setpieces and spiffy sequences he wanted to put on film and he constructed a storyline around them as padding just to have a vehicle to carry them.The primary goal of the movie's merry band of brain hackers is to implant an idea into a corporate executive's head that, if acted on, will benefit his competitor.  Thrilling, no?  Problem is, the target of the "inception" is a thinly-developed character who from all appearances is a decent enough fellow, so why is the audience supposed to root for the hackers to succeed against a nice guy for whom we harbor no real animosity?  There's no clear villain here, no one to root against. The only sense of urgency is a race against the clock.  It might as well be a game show.  Yep, those are the stakes in this film -- all this trouble and expense and danger just to give a Japanese businessman a competitive advantage.  Not very compelling.  The stakes are not much different than your boss telling you to "have the report on my desk by five o'clock!"I don't dislike Nolan or his films just on principle.  I think we can all agree that "Memento" was a very, very good film.  But I think many of his films suffer from poor editing and poorly executed story points.  More to the point, however, I think many of Nolan's films, "Inception" included, aspire to the grandiose at the expense of coherence and sensible narrative flow.  Again, it is the craft of good storytelling that is the hallmark of a great director.  Nolan has shown he is capable of it, but he doesn't demonstrate it here.Is "Inception" multi-layered and occasionally complex?  Sure.  But layering and complexity do not make a film great.  Is it complicated and challenging in spots?  Yes, but so what?  I think it is also lazily-written in many places.  The script wiggles around and maneuvers to meet the needs of the ingredients Nolan wished to show off in the film, and it often comes at the expense of narrative sense.The immense amount of praise showered on Nolan after "The Dark Knight", a movie that was elevated to "event" status in no small part due to the untimely death and riveting performance of Heath Ledger and not necessarily because of any genius on Nolan's part, has almost made it a sacrilege to say anything less than overwhelmingly flattering about him and to almost completely insulate him from criticism, lest the critic be reviled.  Saying anything derogatory about a Nolan film is now considered "bad manners".  Think about that for a minute.  Are we all meant to toss objectivity out the window?  Even Roger Ebert, who liked the film, wonders if we are even allowed to dislike it in today's "we love Nolan" environment.I encourage you to read the following reviews of the film:David Edelstein's review for "New York Magazine" called "Dream a Little Dream -- Awakening to the leaden reality of Christopher Nolan's INCEPTION".  (*** MY FAVORITE ***)Charlie Wachtel of FilmCrusade.com  (***** MY SECOND FAVORITE *****)Stephanie Zacherek's review for MovieLine called "Is INCEPTION This Year's Masterpiece?  Dream On."Nick Shager's review for "Slant Magazine".Vadim Rizov's pre-release thoughts entitled "God help whoever gives INCEPTION a negative review" for IFC (website of the Independent Film Channel).Or reviews by Rex Reed of the "New York Observer", Harvey S. Karten, or Steven Rae of "The Philadelphia Inquirer".I'm not dissing this film just to fly in the face of popular opinion.  Truth is, I just didn't care for this film, and I suspect that a lot of love for this film stems from the public's recent showering of praise on Nolan for his previous films, which have NOTHING to do with this film.  Thanks to Nolan's recent successes, this film had a built-in audience predisposed to liking anything with Nolan's name on it, and for that reason perhaps they lost a bit of objectivity.  You must admit, though -- the advance trailers for the film were very well done and probably got a lot of people stoked for it.  But I don't think the film lived up to the promise.  It is layered and complex but not well-executed.I mean no disrespect to those who liked or loved the film.  If you liked it and will buy the DVD to watch over and over, then god bless ya.  Enjoy it.  I can attest that my love of certain films sometimes mystifies others.  I'm not here to tell you that you are wrong for liking this film.  I did, however, buy three other Christopher Nolan films in years past and I enjoy watching them regularly, despite the major flaws in two of those films.I'm not a "Nolan hater".  I just don't care for THIS Nolan film, and the reviewers I listed above managed to articulate my thoughts about this film far better than I could, so I encourage you to read those reviews -- especially the first two -- so I don't violate copyright laws by posting snippets of them here.This home video release includes both the Blu-ray AND the regular DVD.
summary: I wanted to like it.  I really did.

reviewText: A gleaming, machine-tooled puzzle box of a movie which has justifiably spawned a plethora of theories about what's "real" in its narrative (and justifiable complaints that it didn't snag Christopher Nolan a Best Picture or Best Director nod).One's assessment of what's real hinges on one's assessment of the film's somewhat Byzantine explanation of how dreams work. Do you take at face value the "infinite subconscious" and the accelerated time of the dreams or don't you? Are the emblematic names of a couple of characters coincidental, aimed only at the viewer, or aimed at the "realness" of the dreamscape itself?Nolan's tale of a group of dream thiefs hired to implant an idea in the head of the new head of a multinational conglomerate falls down only, I suppose, in the realm of emotional depth and richness of characterization. But the actors are all so good at combining competence with a sort of post-James-Bond bitchiness that the whole affair goes down smoothly, though the James Bondian third level of the dream world bogs down a bit in pyrotechnics and too much gun-toting action.South Park accurately skewered the gobbledygook of the dream-world dynamics (Ellen Page has an occasionally thankless role as a sort of reverse-Basil Exposition, repeatedly getting DiCaprio's Cobb to explain how things work, sometimes at credibility-stretching moments). Nonetheless, the movie is a serious fun machine, and DiCaprio has really started to grow on me as an occasionally dewy eyed action hero.

reviewText: Inception is a deeply moving piece of Science Fiction with action that is more like a video game and virtual reality.  I rented this video recenty and even though I had seen the trailers I was pleasantly surprised at the story line and the overall action and even the intrigue involved.Although the concept is a dream within a dream and so on, there are a couple of stories within the overall story of what we find Leonardo Dicaprio's team is able to do.  Fascinating concept of dreaming with others, not sure if there is some overall message they are attempting to get across, but it is a rather cool concept of group dreams to manipulate the thoughts or to share the ideas of others.When thinking of the concept, I thought of the Matrix in reverse, you place yourself in an unreal world of your making, but you need others to help you build and interact with it.  I would imagine there are virtual reality sites already taking advantage of this in the world of Web 3.0.Besides the overall exciting story and time line and the action in getting the mission accomplished, the special effects are enjoyable and the methodology thought up for the dream state and getting in and out of it seemed well thought out and seemingly also without holes.  Some times there are obvious holes in a story that you find something was left unaddressed creating an inconsistency.  At first pass, there seemed to be no inconsistency in the film, making it even better.The flick takes you to Mombassa Kenya of all places, along with Europe and Asia.  The virtual worlds are really cool, and it is really and imagination fest.Inception is a fun movie and a nice distraction for a rainy or snowy day.  It is longer than many movies, so if you are viewing on a week night, leave enough time to watch it.
summary: I Like Dreamin' - How Many Levels Can You Go?

reviewText: Inception is one of those movies that you not only love to watch again and again (especially if you are a movie lover), but one of those films that is necessary to watch again to fully understand the concept and the detail. Christopher Nolan is my favorite director for a reason; movies like Inception hit home all the way and keep you interested and spell bound throughout the entire movie. The excellent supporting cast consists of: Ellen Page, Joseph Gordon Levitt, Ken Watanabe, Tom Hardy, Marion Cotillard, and Irish actor and frequent collaborator of Nolan, Cillian Murphy. Spectacular is the word used to describe each and every performance in Inception. Story line is Great and I promise that there is never a dull moment in Inception. Leonardo Dicaprio was fabulous and convincing in his performance as Cobb. Inception not only sparks the imagination to the fullest, but it leaves you in amazement and wonder even when the credits begin to roll. Inception will make you pay closer attention to detail, use your imagination, and is a sort of Asset to the "what is real and what isnt" or "what you see others may not can see" and with these examples, Inception stays on track and never loses its focus. There are those who criticize Nolan for making "extremely long movies" or "movies that are too difficult to understand". But to be quite honest that criticism is entirely unjust. Nolan has a brilliant mind and vision, and he uses it well each time he makes a movie. So with no second thoughts, I gladly give Inception:5 Stars

reviewText: If any film defies a simple synopsis, it's Christopher Nolan's Inception. Few films released by major film studios are this layered, this complicated, and this well-rendered. I must admit that it took me three viewings to accept it for what a masterwork it is. Upon first seeing Inception, I questioned how it would hold up on subsequent viewings due to how much time the film spends explaining the process of inception. Turns out it holds up rather splendidly even on a third viewing.To give a synopsis in the simplest terms possible, Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is an extractor, a thief who steals secrets from people's minds while they're dreaming. Being the most skilled extractor, he's hired by a billionaire named Saito (Ken Watanabe) to try a different approach; inception. Saito wants Dom and his team not to steal an idea, but to plant one in the mind of Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy). While Dom and his team are skeptical, Saito gives Dom an offer he can't refuse.If there were any doubts about Nolan's brilliance as a screenwriter, this film should silence those doubts. Few screenplays are this complex, this exciting, this original, and this accessible. Nolan is a master architect of storytelling and not a scene or line of dialogue is wasted with everything absolutely essential to telling his story. While certain science-fiction elements may be recycled from other films and Cobb's relationship with his dead wife Mal (Cotillard) is similar to DiCaprio's other 2010 role in Shutter Island, it's one of the most stunningly original films of 2010. While it does spend an ample amount of time explaining the concept of both extraction and inception, once we enter Fischer's dream-world just about an hour in, the film becomes a heist movie unlikely any I've seen before.Not that anyone will find this to be unique news, but Nolan is a director of great vision who has made a film that is unlike anything I've seen before. Slow-motion is nothing new, but Nolan uses it frequently for Inception and in the most elegant ways. Nolan and his collaborators, specifically cinematographer Wally Pfister, production designer Guy Hendrix Dyas, film editor Lee Smith, and the various art directors, set designers, and special effects experts involved have crafted this film perfectly. I'm not saying it's a perfect film (only time will tell), but Nolan and co. have achieved perfection with the overall look of the film. Look at each dream level as the characters pass through it; the rainy street, the beautifully-designed hotel, and the snow-covered fortress. The film was budgeted at $150 million and no expense was spared to put the vision in Nolan's head on-screen. Even the special-effects are mind-blowing, unique, and beautiful and the score by Hans Zimmer is marvelous; emotional, ominous, and highly memorable. I've always respected Nolan as a director, but there was one scene in this film that really convinced me what a visionary he is. The gravity-defying fight sequence between Arthur (Gordon-Levitt) and some dream henchmen is one of the great sequences of 2010, magnificently filmed and eloquently choreographed. It's a sequence that would make Stanley Kubrick proud and it does recall Kubrick in sheer elegance and scope.The star-studded cast also includes Ellen Page (as architect Ariadne), Tom Hardy (as identity forger Eames), Michael Caine (as Cobb's father-in-law), Dileep Rao (as Yusuf, a chemist), and the late Pete Postlethwaite (as Maurice Fischer, Robert's late father). Despite Inception falling more into the science-fiction/action genre, Nolan has said that he wanted the character's emotions to drive the film. Nolan's film may be a $150 million action extravaganza, but the emotional depth he sought was achieved through the use of a marvelous cast. The dynamic between DiCaprio and Cotillard has it's similarities to Shutter Island, but it's the driving force of the film and it works. Cotillard does a magnificent job portraying a character that exists entirely in Cobb's subconscious and DiCaprio shows that he's one of the few actors that can express emotion through the use of subtle facial features so effectively. Since Cobb spends significant time in the film experiencing a certain emotion that he's not expressing out-loud, it's up to DiCaprio to convey that emotion to both the characters around him and the audience. DiCaprio is an actor that some people don't take to very easily, but he's one of the most acclaimed living actors for a reason. Gordon-Levitt plays Arthur totally straight, but is charming none-the-less. Murphy finally gets a significant amount of screen-time in a Nolan film and shows the range that must attract Nolan to squeeze him into a film whenever he gets the chance. Finally, Nolan makes a star out of the immensely talented Tom Hardy, an actor of tremendous range who elevated a small film called Bronson into something highly memorable. Hardy plays Eames, the identity forger of Cobb's team, with smarmy, humorous wit that makes him one of the film's most memorable characters. Nolan obviously recognized this as he promptly cast Hardy in his next Batman film.The scope and magnitude of this project, whether you love it or hate it, is something to marvel over. What other director has or could make a film this complicated with intense action sequences that will excite even the most unmotivated viewer? Inception is an incredible film that only grows richer with more viewings. While it took three viewings for me to fully appreciate and come to terms with this; it's one of the best films of 2010. Intellectually-stimulating entertainment with one hell of an ending, that people will be debating and discussing for years. While a film that becomes this acclaimed and this popular so quickly will attract nay-sayers out in droves (which is fine as some people truly do not like the film), few can argue what an innovative, brilliant piece of filmmaking this is.GRADE: A
summary: An Innovative, Highly Original Film That Grows Richer with Subsequent Viewings

reviewText: Ok, I'm not going to lie, I've seen Inception before, but decide to pass on writing a review of it because I felt that I'd not quit understood the film, and now here we are 2 years later, and fresh from re-watching it, I feel like I should finally review it. Now 'Inception' is not your everyday kind of movie. It requires you to really think, or you'd just be lost throughout the whole movie. Usually, I'm not into films that are so complicated you can't watch it; it's as if you blink and you miss something. You have to really pay close attention to every word said, as it gives you information on what's going on. Anyway onto my review of 'Inception'.'Inception' follows Dominick 'Dom' Cobb (Played by Leonardo Decaprio) who is a professional thief committing corporate espionage by entering the mind of his target and taking their secrets. He is offered a chance of redemption as payment for one last job, doing the impossible, by entering the mind and implanting of an idea into a target's mind.The script's plot is by far one of the most complexing, and intriguing ideas I'd ever heard. Now, when we talk about originality, it means making an idea that is new, but not only that it makes sense, and isn't completely ridicules. That's the kind of original 'Inception' is.When I watched this movie, I never knew what was going to happen, everything led to something new, and then something new, and so on and so forth. This plot was beyond good that has something to-do with the script, provided by 'Christopher Nolan' who completely blew my mind at how good he is with script writing. This is one of the most beautiful scripts I've ever seen, and it's so original, maybe the idea isn't but just the way everything happens is. 'Christopher Nolan' wrote a wonderful script. Even if some of it is quit questionable, but what's a movie without plot holes right?A good script is nothing without a spot-on cast to broadcast the whole thing. And 'Inception' has quit an ensemble. 'Leonardo Decaprio' brings the heart and soul as the lead with an emotional past. Every moment he's on screen (Which is actually the whole thing) he really gets into character and provides a great leader role to the group. His journey through the film, both emotional and realistically, is compelling and sad. 'Ellen Page' is our sole female of the group, and man does she get into her role. She brings the fear that the others don't have quit she was just lovely. Plus, she came in handy, asking the questions us viewers have, and helping us along the way on this complex ride. 'Joseph Gordon-Levitt' always gives off a great performance and this movie is no different, he's charming and witty in a few scenes, and suits his role pretty well. Other solid performances come from 'Cillian Murphy', 'Ken Watanbe', and 'Marion Cotillard' playing the films targeted guy, the business man, and Dom's Wife, respectively. With Marion you never know whether her character is good, evil, crazy, or just needy. She fits into her role as if it was a snug blanket, she just gets comfy cozy in it.The editing is perfect, everything comes together perfectly and never glitches if you will. When the street starts to turn inward, not one bit of it comes off choppy. The sounds fit in where they should, and it just makes for great editing.The Visual Effects are beyond amazing, they're spectacular. Every single thing about it comes off well detailed, and thought through, it's just so beautiful. When the streets start to turn over, the details on it are amazing; the people walk on it, and the cars driving in all directions. It is just spectacular.This film features some great cinematography. I loved the camera work for inside the hotel when the gravity was turned off, it had just 'Joseph Gordon-Levitt' jumping across walls and fighting two men, I loved the different angles used for that scene, as well as during the scene with the van falling off the bridge, beautiful.The music is just what the film needed something fast paced, energetic, and smooth. 'Hans Zimmer' really gave us a wonderful score, to complement the film itself giving us something to hold onto, and excite us even more, even complex us.The set designs for the buildings, like the Chinese house, during the first act, which was a beautiful looking set. The house was beautiful and ghostly but I won't tell you why, you'll just have to wait and see for yourself.All is good, except that the film features a poor blending of pacing, switching often from fast to slow, and back again and it comes off, abit distracting. When we watch scenes between 'Marlon Cotillard' and 'Leonardo Decaprio' which are usually in-between sequences inside someone's mind, the pace is slow, and it somewhat disorientates you, as your going so fast, and then you stop for a short conversation and you're like 'Is the ride over yet'? But it's only a miner issue.All and All, 'Inception' is breathtaking feet of visuals, an original script, and some solid performances turning this into an excellent tent pole-blockbuster-popcorn film with a brain and I loved every minute of it! A 1/7/14
summary: Smart, beautifully filmed, and visually splendid.

reviewText: Is this movie original?.. yes.  Does it keep your attention?... yes.  Is it one of the best movies ever made?... not by a long shot.  The acting was pretty good, the story original, but for several reasons I think this is a glorified over-rated movie.  Whenever a movie seems hard to follow, which this movie is meant to be, people automatically think it is deep and complex, which classifies it as a stimulating movie.  Not the case here.  I found it rather annoying and far-fetched.  For one thing, hooking yourself up to what looks like a futuristic cappuccino machine, does not allow you to enter another person's dream.  This device is so under explained and so ridiculous, it forms a huge hole in the movie plot.  Of course if you want to turn off your brain, which 98% of people do while watching big Hollywood movies do, then you will blindly ignore this and go on believing this BS.I really thought this movie had a refreshing vibe to it in the way it explored dreams, the concept of time being warped while dreaming, the ability to control a dream environment, and the consequences of dying while dreaming.  But due to the excessive gunfights and explosions, the story became generic to me. The story also seemed to contradict itself.  First you go to a never-ending abyss by dying in a dream while being heavily sedated, but the only way you can escape the abyss is by ending your life.  This idea is vague and contradicting.  At least `The Matrix' had a much more solid concept that if you die in the Matrix, you die in reality, which was by far a much better movie.The movie's ending is cheesy and under dramatic.  Leo gets to see his children's faces.. so what? To me "Shutter Island" was a much better movie, which also starred Leo and also explores alternative planes of reality and has a fantastic surprising ending.  This movie's ending is predictable and obvious, leaving no twists or having the audience thinking "Oh, now it all comes together".

reviewText: While the movie is entertaining and the picture quality is very well done, where this shines is in the sound! I don't have a high end surround sound system, it's good, not Bose quality or anything, but the sound transfer is so well done on the bluray I often have to turn down the volume because the bass will literally shake the walls. The sound is booming on this bluray and if you're an audiophile this is a good movie to put in to test your sound system. It's that well done!Additionally, though this is listed as a two disc set, it really has 3 discs: bluray; DVD; Special Features. The special features disc has some great extras on it including a motion-comic that details Cobb's mission for Cobol and why they're after his head which is completely unexplained in the movie. The first time I watched the movie I had no idea why Cobol was after Cobb since they never said what his job for them was to begin with. It just starts mid-stream. The prelude stop-motion explains all of that. Well worth the watch and it's only a short half hour or so.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had a strange experience while watching this film.  It reminded me of other films I did not like much, and made me wish I was watching them instead.  I had disliked "The Matrix", but this film reminded me how much more lively and involving it was.  I had disliked "Shutter Island", but was reminded how much more colorful and atmospheric it was, with more likable characters, and how it seemed to have a more genuine dreamlike quality.Its fans praise it for its intelligence, but I can sense nothing of the sort in it.  It does carry with it, however, a stench of nihilism and solipsism, and the human mind engaging in self-worship.  There was little to engage the mind, though I did note the symbolism of the Escher staircase, which seemed to suggest that those who try to descend or ascend to higher or deeper levels of dreaming - or who try to wake up to "reality" - are in fact merely going around in circles.  Like the ouroboros, it also seems to suggest the mind turning in on itself; though I get a vague sense that Chris Nolan approves of the horrible process.

reviewText: OMG!  What if . . . you and I were business competitors, and what if YOU were the only one standing in my way of being Numero Uno?  What if, I could somehow get into your mind --- into your dreams --- and convince you to sell off or split up your company?  WOW!  Holy Schmidt!This is an awesome movie.  It really keeps your mind tuned in.  It's weird, but very, very interesting.  It is also futuristic in concept.DiCaprio is Cobb, working with the "inception" of dream concepts into someone's mind.  To do this, there is a network of people involved.  Someone is a architect of the actual dream, and there are several team members who also participate, beside the person being manipulated.  This is quite an operation and the variables are quite interesting and many can be unexpected.  To do the ultimate Inception, you have to go "3 layers deep" into the dream world - most dangerous- a dream within a dream within a dream.  Also, COBB is quite obsessed with his dead wife and constantly seeing projections of her.  He can't quite let her go emotionally, which makes it a little tough for him to stay focused. He also can't go back home to see his children because the police think he killed her.There is lots of action, car chases, and excitement.  Cool movie.  I think you will likely want to watch it more than once.  You'll also notice Michael Kane in a small supporting role.

reviewText: "Take, if you must, this little bag of dreams, Unloose the cord, and they will wrap you round." William Butler Yates"Ha, bloody ha!" Viewing this movie left me with wobbly legs, barely able to walk the first few steps towards the door. My hands were shaking and my head ached. What a rush! I haven't had this reaction since "Black Hawk Down". Christopher Nolan has artfully taken the images of our subconscious nocturnal ruminations and used them as priceless fodder for his "Inception." Not only was I completely drawn in within the first few minutes, I felt involved.The notion of dreaming 'in conference", as well as in layers is interesting and intelligent, but there are myriads of such ideas bouncing around in the heads of creative sorts all over the place. The fact the Nolan was able to gather the group of actors that he did and then pull it off is extremely impressive.DiCaprio as Cobb the retired 'architect' was, as usual, solid and dependable. Even more, his haunted affect in respect to his relationship with his wife, was chilling. Ellen Page, Ariadne, becomes to Cobb a sort of 'good angel' on one shoulder to his wife's (Marion Cotillard) bad angel on the other. The insinuations of ambiguity between reality and dream become a frightening proposition for Cobb, and for those of us who witness. As supporting cast, Tom Hardy, Ken Watenabe and Joseph Gordon-Levitt were icing on the cake, powerful and proficient in their parts. What a surprise to see Gordon-Levitt used as muscle! Cillian Murphy's muted performance as the passive victim was underplayed in the very best of ways.  He is certainly one brilliantly versatile actor (see 'Peacock').CGI was mind-bendingly claustrophobic in some scenes and eye candy for the ADHD advantaged in others! I'm far too ignorant about such things to comment beyond that.There have been some criticisms regarding character development and confusion regarding the role of Kobel Engineering in the dream sequences. As far as character development in concerned, when chaos abounds, there is not much time to exchange personal information or go fishing, however much you wish. This was an intense experience that I believe would have suffered from too much exposition. As to Kobel Engineering, it is important to keep track of what is in Cobb's surreality and and what isn't."Inception" was the movie of 2010 for me. Furthermore, I plan to watch it at least a couple of more times in order to cull the marvelous minutia right out of it.
summary: "I'll let you be in my dreams, if I can be in yours." Bob Dylan

reviewText: Admittedly, I went into this movie with very high expectations. Everyone I spoke with raved that it was a fantastic film. I was expecting to be blown away like everyone else. Unfortunately, I wasn't. The concept of this film is brilliant and fascinating. The manner in which they chose to execute it, less so. I didn't feel invested in the movie at all or connected to the characters in any way. From the beginning, the story is muddled and bogged down with the angst and personal drama of DiCaprio's character Cobb. I understand that he's the main character and that his motivations are the driving force behind the entire story. Unfortunately, therein lies my problem with this film. We are not offered any opportunity to emotionally connect with anyone other than Cobb. All of the other characters are nothing more than paper cutouts, not even quirky enough to offer the illusion of some development. We are meant to rely entirely on DiCaprio to make us care about the story. And in my case, DiCaprio is unable to garner my interest or sympathy. I've always felt that DiCaprio is overrated as an actor and this film did nothing to change my opinion of his skills. I honestly couldn't bring myself to care whether or not Cobb made it home. Also, the source of his personal trauma was fairly predictable from an early stage in the movie. Which wouldn't have been a big deal necessarily but it's unveiling is dragged out unbearably an din such a heavy handed manner that by the time it was fully 'revealed' what little interest I had in it was gone.Ellen Page's character served as the catalyst for Cobb's personal expositions...and little else. And it's not because she connected to Cobb on an emotional level or had any more depth than the other characters. It's simply because as an outsider, she offers the simplest method for exposition. She professes concern for the safety of everyone on the mission and says that she's going along in case Cobb's subconscious gets out of control. However, there is no indication whatsoever that she would be able to do anything for anyone if that happened and in fact, she never does anything more than stand around and whisper earnestly at Cobb- which has no effect whatsoever. If she had truly been concerned for everyone's safety she should've told them upfront that Cobb was a basketcase unfit to share his dreams with anyone. I suppose we're meant to assume that she's come to care about Cobb but I just don't get that from Page's performance. I feel no connection between these two characters and Page's delivery is consistently flat throughout the whole film. She has no solid character traits or motivations of her own. Joseph Gordon-Levitt's character would've been a better choice to help Cobb- having known him longer and already being aware of his personal tragedy and motivations. And his acting was much better, although they certainly didn't 'waste' time developing his character at all. And what last thing about Page's character...her name. Ariadne? That's almost as bad as Bella Swann. I guess they thought they were being clever but to me it came off as ridiculous and heavy handed, especially in comparison to everyone else's mundane names. They may as well have called her Maze Guide Girl.In conclusion, this film relies far too much on one character to carry it, especially considering it's an ensemble cast. Obviously, there are many people who were able to glean more from DiCaprio and Page than I was. I imagine that would make this movie far more enjoyable. As for me, I simply waited for it to be over.

reviewText: Think back to your early youth. The most exciting trip was to the local amusement park. The candy, the people in costumes and of course the rides. But we learned quickly that the best rides required an "E" ticket and of course, there were never enough "E" tickets for the day.As adults we look to more intellectual pursuits. We read books, travel to distant lands, and on occasion we endeavor to find something new and exciting at the movies. But more often than not, we find that films from Hollywood utterly disappoint us with plots that have been rehashed from hundreds of other films or insult us with vulgar comedies that are churned out on a regular basis."Inception," a new film from Christopher Nolan, the director of "The Dark Knight," is one rare instance when Hollywood has gotten it right. The film has a tightly woven script (also penned by Nolan) that allows the viewer to enter a world of espionage with a clever twist. "Inception," has been advertised as a film similar to "The Matrix," and here to set the record straight: it is not. It is a much better movie than any of the Matrix films, which tend to be too convoluted for any true enjoyment. "Inception," remains unique without reaching too far beyond the boundary of imagination.Starring Leonardo DiCaprio and "Juno's" Ellen Page, the film depicts a world in which even your deepest secrets are not save. The new criminal of this world enters into your mind during dream-state in order to steal from you or even implant an idea that could change the world. But how safe is this new form of theft? DiCaprio's character finds that his new world of dreams and reality often are difficult to tell apart. And that like all new technology, a simpler way of life must be abandoned to fully embrace the new one.Christopher Nolan's job as director and writer are spot on. His world of reality intermixed with dreams have stunning visual effects that even out weigh those in "The Dark Knight." Out of the supporting cast, most impressive are Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Ken Watanabe. The only disappointing part of the film is the bad casting of Marion Cotillard and the annoying insertion of the song "La vie en rose."Overall, "Inception," is the best film of the year so far. Being released among the summer it would be shameful if it is not remember for award season. So at last film lovers, it's time to rejoice! It appears that there may still be one more "E" ticket left in our book.For more reviews and film industry news see Kay's articles at: [...]-Kay Shackleton is a film historian with special focus on the Silent Film Era, see her work at [...]
summary: ."Inception" is the best film of year, so far...

His totem was unreliable due to the fact that he had sabotaged and taken it from his wife. The voices of his children on the phone were older than the images of his children at the end of the movie, so I believe at some point in the film he got trapped. Particularly before the introdution of the Ariadne character because that is an uncommon name and she coincidentally was creating mazes for the dreams.Its an entertaining film. reviewText: Inception is full-scale intrigue, weaving meta narratives in an agonizingly impeccable jumble. The leads are likable, despite at least one character being used almost exclusively to ask expository questions. The action sequences are brilliantly shot and constantly enrapturing, with the exception of a late winter shoot-out which resembles a level of Call of Duty more than it does a brainy summer blockbuster. Nevertheless, there is no real reason not to call this film the work of an auteur: one of the best minds of his generation. Prepare to ponder the twirling totem at the center of your dreamscape.

reviewText: Leonardo Dicaprio plays the role of a dream architect and hacker who has the tools to enter people's dreams in order to extract important information from their brains. Not only that, he can also enter their dreams to incept information and make this new information part of the reality of the dreamer. He makes a deal with a powerful Asian business man to incept the idea of dissolving the company of his largest competitor. In exchange for that, Dicaprio would be able to return to the US and see his children, after the Asian man uses his power and connections to waive all the charges against Dicaprio, including the murder of his own wife!Great Story and Great Plot! It was wonderful to watch a movie that taps a very myserious part of our lives, which is the world of dreaming.If you watch the movie carefully, it could answer many of your questions about dreaming, such as why do dreams feel longer when we actually sleep for very short period!Totally loved this movie! Could be one of Dicaprio's best works.
summary: The Movie Is "The Matrix" Of The Dream World!

reviewText: "Inception" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: Dom Cobb is a skilled thief, the absolute best in the dangerous art of extraction, stealing valuable secrets from deep within the subconscious during the dream state when the mind is at its most vulnerable. Cobb's rare ability has made him a coveted player in this treacherous new world of corporate espionage, but it has also made him an international fugitive and cost him everything he has ever loved. Now Cobb is being offered a chance at redemption. One last job could give him his life back but only if he can accomplish the impossible -- inception. Instead of the perfect heist, Cobb and his team of specialists have to pull off the reverse: their task is not to steal an idea but to plant one. If they succeed, it could be the perfect crime. But no amount of careful planning or expertise can prepare the team for the dangerous enemy that seems to predict their every move. An enemy that only Cobb could have seen coming.The cast led by Leonardo DiCaprio (in an impressive performance as Cobb), Ken Watanabe (as Saito), Joseph Gordon-Levitt (as Arthur), Marion Cotillard (as Mal), Ellen Page (as Ariadne), Tom Hardy (as Eames), Cillian Murphy (as Robert Fischer, Jr.), Tom Berenger (as Browning) & Michael Caine (as Miles) is brilliant! The directing and screenplay and story by Christopher Nolan (also produced) (who also directed "Memento" (2000, also wrote the screenplay), "Insomnia" (2002), "Batman Begins" (2005, also wrote the screenplay and ironically, co-starred Watanabe, Murphy & Caine), "The Prestige" (2006, also wrote the screenplay & produced and also starred Caine) & "The Dark Knight" (2008, also wrote the story & screenplay & produced and also starred Caine and a brief appearance from Murphy), he is also doing the upcoming "Batman 3" (2012, also writing the story and producing and is also starring Caine) is brilliant!The music by Hans Zimmer (who also did the music to "Batman Begins" & "The Dark Knight", he also did the music to "Angels & Demons" (2009), "It's Complicated" (2009) & "Sherlock Holmes" (2009, for which he received his 7th Oscar nomination) is brilliant! The Oscar-winning cinematography by Wally Pfister (who has been working with Nolan since "Memento" and is doing the upcoming "Batman 3", he also has received 3 Oscar nominations, ironically, on the films he worked with Nolan on "Batman Begins", "The Prestige" & "The Dark Knight", he also did the cinematography to "The Italian Job" (2003) is brilliant! The film editing by Lee Smith (who also did the film editing to "The Truman Show" (1998) & "Master And Commander: The Far Side Of The World" (2003, both which were directed by Peter Weir), he also did the film editing to Nolan's "Batman Begins", "The Prestige" & "The Dark Knight") is brilliant! The casting by John Papsidera (who also did the casting to "Drag Me To Hell" (2009), "Zombieland" (2009), "The Crazies" (2010), & the upcoming "Life As We Know It" (2010) & "House At The End Of The Street" (2012), he also did the casting to Nolan's "Memento", "Batman Begins", "The Prestige" & "The Dark Knight") is brilliant! The production design by Guy Dyas (who also did the production design to "X2" (2003), "The Brothers Grimm" (2005), "Superman Returns" (2006) & "Indiana Jones And The Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull" (2008) is brilliant! The art direction by Luke Freeborn (who also did the art direction to "Indiana Jones And The Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull", "Star Trek" (2009), "Angels & Demons" & the upcoming "Thor" (2011) & "Men In Black III" (2012), Matthew Gray (who also did the art direction to "Charlie And The Chocolate Factory" (2005), "The Chronicles Of Narnia: Prince Caspian" (2008) & "Sherlock Holmes"), Bill Ives, Jason Knox-Johnston (who also did the art direction to "The Descent" (2006), "The Bourne Ultimatum" (2007), "The Chronicles Of Narnia: Prince Caspian" & the upcoming "Captain America: The First Avenger" (2011), Paul Laugier (who also did the art direction to "Hellboy II: The Golden Army" (2008), Andy Thomson (who also did the art direction to "The Brothers Grimm" (2005), Bettina von den Steinen (who also did the art direction to "The Bourne Identity" (2002), Frank Walsh (who also did the art direction to "The Brothers Grimm", "The Chronicles Of Narnia: Prince Caspian" & the upcoming "Hereafter" (2010) (supervising art director) & Dean Wolcott (who also did the art direction to the upcoming "John Carter Of Mars" (2012), he was an assistant art director on "Superman Returns" & "Indiana Jones And The Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull" & set designer on "X2") is brilliant! The set decoration by Lisa Chugg (who also did the set decoration to the upcoming "Hereafter"), Paul Healy & Douglas A. Mowat (who also did the set decoration to "The Sixth Sense" (1999), "Signs" (2002), both of them directed and written by M. Night Shyamalan, "Constantine" (2005), "Fast And Furious" (2009) & the upcoming "Bridesmaids" (2011), he was also an assistant set director on "American Gangster" (2007) is brilliant! The costume design by Jeffrey Kurland (who also did the costume design to "Erin Brockovich" (2000), "Ocean's Eleven" (2001), "Hidalgo" (2004), "Collateral" (2004), "Law Abiding Citizen" (2009) & the upcoming "Captain America: The First Avenger") is brilliant!This is a brilliant and intriguing thrill-ride that keeps you on the edge of your seat and thinking at the same time, all the time. This is smart, entertaining, and fun. This is one of Christopher Nolan's best films (original concept wise), if not, the best film, to date, so far. This is one of the best films of the year, if not, the best film of the year, so far. For everyone involved on this film, its their best work to date, so far. Also an Oscar winner for Best Sound Mixing, Sound Effects Editing & Visual Effects.

reviewText: 4.3 stars[Edit, 12/22/12: Just watched Inception for the third time and must say it keeps getting better each viewing. Once all the time slips etc are clear, there are plenty of other ideas that become lucid and I realize how much serious thought Nolan put into this concept, and how well executed it is. Like Fight Club, only with multiple viewings does the whole story emerge. And for Nolan to have written and directed this, well, massive respect for that level of vision.]I love the ideas here but Nolan could have tightened it all up a bit more. There are all sorts of conceptual loose ends that a little bit more exposition would have dealt with. The way the love interest is integral yet somehow forced grated now and then, and sometimes it all felt like Nolan was so caught up in his own dream world of this movie that he could have used a "kick" or two himself to realize that shorter is sweeter.Buuuut, once I gave up expecting more cohesion and just flowed with it, warts and all, there were plenty of good concepts and CGI eye candy to keep the brain amused, and all in all it was an enjoyable viewing, especially with the fine BD picture quality. The dynamic range is as usual these days a little too much...you can barely hear them talk and then BOOM! Your walls are shaking as a train crashes into the room. But I guess the goal is visceral jolting and that is indeed accomplished.DiCaprio is solid but never stunning, ditto the rest of the cast. I can't remember one moment where I thought, "That's some fine acting", nor did I ever think it was bad. It just was, and the focus is so squarely on the dreams-in-dreams that the relationships never really gel. But once again, this is a thrill ride, so asking more might be pointless.I was on occasion reminded of Paprika, and if you like this make sure to see that, clearly an inspiration for Nolan and a truly great movie.[Edit again: One very real highlight here is Zimmer's score, which is haunting and compelling and altogether memorable. I picked up his Inception OST last year and really like it late at night driving on empty roads. The simple two note themes have a lot of power, proving that harmonic context can deeply shape any melody when put in stark relief by the simplicity of that melody. Which fits in perfectly with Nolan's overriding philosophical concept here. Now that's top notch film scoring. The more I watch this the more I love that score and see how tightly integrated it is to Nolan's ideas. Zimmer is not only insanely prolific but a genius when at his best, like here and the Dark Knight and so many others.]Worth seeing for those who like psychological thrillers, crisp effects, and considering exactly what is it that makes reality real, and not.
summary: Gets tighter and more compelling with each new viewing

reviewText: The movie is science fiction dealing with dreams being able to alter, or not alter, reality. It has a good cast of Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page, Cillian Murphy, Tom Berenger and cameos by Michael Caine. DiCaprio plays Dom Cobb, who is to pull information, through dreams, from the subconscious of their subjects. Cobb is also tortured by personal turmoil in the death of his wife & not being able to see his kids. The premise here is if he pulls off his mission successfully he will be reunited with his two children. The kids make spotty appearances throughout the movie, but Cobb can only see their backs; not their faces.Cobb's mission is to use his ability to alter the subconscious mind of his foe's son, resulting in the collapse an empire controlled by the son & ailing father.The plot is intriguing, but the screenplay kills it. The acting in the movie is good. DiCaprio plays his character well. Levitt has matured very well since his days on TV's 3rd Rock From the Sun. Michael Caine is always a grand addition to a cast. Alas, the actors can't save this movie.It's a cross between action & mind games. The result is a very confusing movie which sinks like a stone. The screenplay is awful. I gave it two stars due to the acting of the cast. Try as they may, the movie is an awful confusion. The flick is worth one star. Skip this one
summary: A Good Cast Can't Save This Movie
