reviewText: The idea for this film is very interesting, and I was quite looking forward to seeing it. Unfortunately it simply did not live up to the hype. If you are the type of person who simply wants to be entertained by pretty pictures, and an outwardly interesting story This may be quite enjoyable. However if you know something about the human psyche and have ever dreamed in detail it will likely be a huge dissapointment. There are so many holes in this film I couldn't even keep track. And the concepts were just goofy as hell. Like the idea that if you ask about a safe, the dreamer will automatically create a safe with all the information you are looking for in it, and all you have to do is break in and you will have his industrial secrets. Ok, I passsed that off as a mildly interesting bit of symbolism, but this movie just keeps going with that kind of rediculous narrow minded, unimaginative approach.A far superior rendition of the dream world was done in What Dreams May Come (whether you like the movie or not). This film (Inception) had a dream wolrd that was very closed off, square and linear. Not open of fluid at all (like actual dreams). If computers could dream, this might be how it would look - no imagination. Armies of trained profesionals coming after anything foreign. I've had a squad tracking me down in my dream. Not a pleasant feeling, but lets be honest, your conscious is a foreign entity while roaming around in your subconscious, so why does the subconscious never go after the host? No nothing ever happens in this film that is consistent with dreaming and the human subconscous. The only thing that comes close is the opening sequence. After that the film just became mired in itself, unneccesarily convaluted, and as a result of all of the plot holes and a lack of character develpment, or even any character depth (except on the part of DiCaprio). But this is appearantly Nolan's style. Creating one dimensional characters in flat lifeless worlds.Even the effects were not that great. The first dream sequence with the girl has Leonardo and Ellen's characters sitting at a cafe and the world around them starts to disintegrate. It looks like a video game. Everything comes apart in blocks, just starts exploding for no appearant reason (who cares anyway), but it just looks kind of auful. Some of the effects were good, but nothing struck me as great. It was all flat and lifeless, just like the rest of the movie.And the characters just plot about doing what they do, appearantly for no other reason than it's in the script. The girl faces the possibilty of eternal damnation in 'limbo' in order to try to protect a bunch of people she has never met, and has not attachment to, and does so with not one imodicum of emotion. They all just plot along like wind up toys. At least if they had all been androids it would have explained why everything is so flat and lifeless, and why the dream world is so increadibly dull, square, and closed off.A couple more holes: The dream within a dream. Ok, I can accept that the subconscious is faster than the consious mind, accounting for the time difference from dreams to reality; a factor of 10. But that a dream within a dream should cause time to fly by at a rate 100 times quicker? What is the reason for this discrepancy? There is none, it is just a rediculous plot device invented to create some sort of drama. And then it just goes on, 1000 times for a dream within a dream etc... And then they feel the physics of a thing happening in the primary dream while they are in the tertiary dream? What absolute nonsense! And it just keeps going like that, building nonsense on nonsense.If you can watch a two hour film without questioning anything, without taking one bit of intellectual interest in the plot, physics, psychology or physiology, then you will probobly enjoy this film. But if you have an intellect, and make the mistake of using it, there is just too much wrong with this piece of tripe. Sorry, but there it is. The only thing that makes this movie interesting is the concept and the ending. The execution is just bad. Next time I see the name Nolan attached to a film, I will just walk on past.***please excuse spelling and grammar errors***
summary: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?

reviewText: I don't review many movies, but this one blew me away, so I had to put in my 2 cents. I think this is the best reality-exploring, mind-bending, philosophical/psychological thriller since The Matrix. Fans of movies that explore themes of dreaming or alternate realities, such as Waking Life, Vanilla Sky, and the Japanese anime film Spirited Away will all love this as well. The cast was excellent, and I personally loved the ending (which I know some people complained about.) You definitely have to pay attention, but its worth it. I feel like this should have done better in the awards season - it's hard to pull something like this off in a way the audience can follow. 5 stars well-earned in my book.
summary: Blew Me Away, Best Mind-Bender Since The Matrix

reviewText: "A director makes only one movie in his life. Then he breaks it into pieces and makes it again."- Jean Renoir(SPOILERS)There's a great deal of applicability of this quote when it comes to Christopher Nolan. In Memento a man accidentally kills his wife and can't deal with the guilt so he creates a world of his own to live in in order to come to terms with what happened; in Inception basically the same thing happens but instead of telling the story backwards & from the perspective of someone who no longer has any short term memory this time the gimmick is dreams.Being the spontaneous internet forum wanderer that I am I'd heard here & there comparisons to Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey in terms of just how intensely visceral of an impact the film has on one's psyche. Now, I didn't go into my viewing with this in mind, but it lingered there back in my subconscious where the guy from Third Rock from the Sun & Bronson were trying to steal whatever secrets I have.The difference between a film like Kubrick's awe inspiring masterpiece and Nolan's film which only makes it to the level of 'just good' is that there's this sense in Nolan's film of being scared of alienating too many people from enjoying his film. "Well, I'll make it sort of complex, but only include the most base ideas and the most placid dreams imaginable. Oh, and the end will be kind of ambiguous but not too much, don't want to make anyone angry or instigate any kind of lengthy discussions."As seems to be the deal with Nolan his main actor is really cringe worthy or laugh inducing ("OH JESUS CHRIST!!!!") DiCaprio doesn't go through the film growling at people but he is still pretty bad. To be honest the only one who doesn't seem to be phoning in a performance is Tom Hardy, and that's only barely the case.The folding of Paris was pretty nice, but everything else just seemed flat and Nolan never, in 150 minutes, gets the feel of a dream quite down; not when DiCaprio is Mr. Charles in the bar, not when Joseph Gordon-Levitt is Jamiroquai-ing it up with some guys in a hall or hauling a floating bundle of his buddies into an elevator. There's nothing in this film that you can't learn about dreams from Richard Linklater's phenomenal film "Waking Life", so, Inception proves to be a fairly useless film in the end, but it is, oddly enough, worth at least one viewing.
summary: Nolan shows us how afraid he really is to make something genuinely personal
Title: N/A

reviewText: Take a thought, any thought. Now, there are many ways to take that conception and implant in other minds...speech, writing, music, movies, mimes etc. There is subliminal insertion, hypnotic insertion, even insertion on levels we never think about like smell. Pheromones can create a connection or replusion that undercuts our thinking mind. Have you ever met someone and felt that major attraction, or almost physical revulsion and could not quite understand why? Our brains and senses take in information on immeasurable levels and process that data millions of times a day. So it is with the thoughts we process.We always assume that our thoughts are our own. It is only because we are so aware of advertising, mind manipulation etc. that in this day and age the magician must go to great lengths to impress us. Even our subconscious will eventually root out any foreign mental construct that does not fit into the "one of us" concept, like antibodies seeking out an infection. How to get around our built-in swat squad? How to plant an idea at so deep a level even the subconscious is unaware of the invasion? Once acheived the possibilites are limitless!Inception, the instant an idea comes into being...the Big Bang of conscious, or subconscious creation. Think of jacking-in to someone's mind like in the Matrix. Now, conceive of going into the lower levels of subconsciousness...the dream within the dream, the other realms of lucid dreaming. Take a team of mind hi-jackers and go in to someone's super consciousness and plant the seed of an idea. That seed must be left to germinate unfettered in the subjec'ts mind, so that to all intents and purposes, the thought is their own. That person will never question their own inner reality, because no one else can penetrate the cerebral barrier, or so they believe.INCEPTION takes this concept of mind invasion and runs with it to the pit of the super consciousness. Leonardo Dicaprio plays the mind hijacker and with his team of psuedo-psychic freelancers, his character drops in on the inner world of the son of a very rich and extremely important man. The assignment...get in there...set up the scenario like controlling a lucid dream...set the pieces ever so gently in place and activate the "go" button metaphorically speaking. Easier said than done. Once inside the clutter of someone else's mind, it can be hard to hang on to our own reality. Where does the boundry go when we start to merge into cross-realities? Demons, we all have them. If those demons, those constructs of our own minds start to take form and identity of their own, how will we deal with the consequences of that?The special effects in this movie are superb, the script insightful, acting...for this type of action movie...great by all members of the cast. The concept is delicious revelry. Who does not wish they could bend reality, be full force in inside a frenetic action/adventure game with the clock ticking and terrorists and inner demons nipping at your heels? SUCH FUN!! Watching the team dive deeper and deeper into the super conscious realm is amazing.For those of us who are lucid dreamers and used to delta and theta wave interaction, this movie is an affirmation of the worlds we inhabit each night. For those who hardly remember their dreams, or swear they never dream, watch this movie carefully. When you go to sleep the next time tell yourself what you want to dream about and go for it. It takes a little practice, but you too can go any place/time you want and consciously drive the action. It's all there in the super conscious mind. ENJOY!Fantastic movie...maybe one of the best ever! Kudos to all those involved.

reviewText: Before I saw this movie this afternoon, I didn't pretend to have an interest in it.  I'm not sure why, its just no one could be very specific about what it was about, so it all sounded dull to me, the most I heard was "Its about a guy going in to people's dreams."  Other than that I didn't hear much else.  I have watched films by Christopher Nolan before, such as "Momento", and the new Batman films, but not because he did them, just because they sounded intriguing.  I learned a while ago not to pin expectations on any director, just to watch a movie and hopefully it'll be semi-enjoyable.With my mindset as it was, having never seen a preview or anything, I actually feel VERY blessed.  The truth is is that you are better off not knowing anything about it as this movie is so complex and has many mysteries in it that it is just worth experiencing it and having someone try to describe it to you is kind of a waste of time, just go see it.  I will just say that it is hands down the best action film of the year, though its much more than an action film.The thing that you should know about this movie is that it seems, from the reviews I have read and the people I have talked to whom have seen it, what will determine how much you enjoy this is a. Your expectations of the movie. b.  If you want something that makes you think as opposed to only a thrill ride.  or c.  You have an interest in dreams.  As many have said the film is slow and boring, but for me it was a very intriguing analysis of the sleeping state of the mind, but it definitely would have fared better with everyone if it had a more concise script.  The acting was pretty good, I am not particularly a fan of Dicaprio, but he did a pretty decent job as did all of the cast with what they were given, and other than Dicaprio's character and one other character, there was not a lot of character development, but there was definitely enough in his character alone to keep it interesting.  It is nice to see Joseph Gordon-Levitt in a higher profile movie, and its also nice to see Ken Watanabe and Ellen Page again as well.  The script had some glaring problems such as, at times, a lack of momentum and a lack of character development outside of the main character... but those are pretty minor since the movie quite effective and enjoyable for the most part and delved deep in to human emotions such as guilt and the long-term effects they can have on us.I want to do an analysis of the film's ideas, but I will not do that here as that's about as much as I can say without ruining anything about the film.  Although this movie is not flawless and borrows from many movies from the late 90's, it does it, for the most part, fairly successfully. Overall, I would say, in a summer (as all summers are) full of midless action films and tired comedies, this is a much welcome reprieve for many movie fans.God Bless ~Amy
summary: The LESS you know the better.

reviewText: "Inception" is a multi-layered plot based on dreams and navigating the subconscious to plant information and ideas.  The film is polished and the script must have taken a genius locked in a room for at least a decade to write.  Top notch special effects and cinematography give the viewer the feel of disorientation and being in the characters' dreamworld, fighting to climb between layers of consciousness.  The movie needs the viewer to  take great leaps of faith on what dreams and the power of suggestion can do.The hero, Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) feels lost in time and space, what is real.  Like the children's song ending - is life "But a dream"?  The movie hops between dreams and reality.  You begin to wonder what is reality, where am I in this story?Cobb had a wife that could not understand if she was in a dream or in reality.  This is the problem in his most important dream.  How can Cobb keep her from ruining his most important plan  - a plan that will return him home to his two children?Cobb says we often do not remember the beginning of a dream, do we need to?  -  and what is dream time?  Is it possible to share others' consciousness in a group dream and can time be synchronized with everyone else you are interacting with?  How do you know where you are and how long you have to finish a project?  "Inception" is adrift in time and levels of dream experience. We are never sure where Cobb or his crew is in reality.Cobb's job is to enter the minds of other men to steal ideas.  Cobb is hired by a high-level energy executive (and billionaire)  to insert an idea into a rival's mind so the rival believes completely that it is his own idea.  The rival then embraces the spirit and feeling of something that he may have fought in real life.  The energy executive is Saito (Ken Watanabe) and this "dream job" would end Cobb's forced exile from his children and father-in-law, Miles (Michael Caine).So Cobb has the money to put together a cutting-edge team of dream specialists.  He works with long-time partner, Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a new dream architect Ariadne, (Ellen Page). a couple of other helpers, as well as a chemist that puts together potions for deep, shared dreams.  They hop on a trans-Pacific jet with targeted Billionaire, Robert Fischer, Jr.(Cillian Murphy) that Saito wants him to change his mind and initiate the thought he can be his own man, he can break up his corporation and move on to make his own life.  A positive thought, instead of surrendering his corporation - just framing the idea in a good way to eliminate opposition.Adriadne, the architect, creates the labyrinths and mazes that the participants must maneuver throughout the three levels of the dream, and must be there for the "idea changers" as time, space and reality change.  She learns the art of controlling and navigating through dreams.  The films fantastic special effects are exquisitely effective with the unique and well-thought out script.  There are gunfights and car crashes as Fischer evidently has had some dream training and carries along his bodyguards to protect his subconscious. Even though there are many chase and gunfights it does not get old as you feel otherworldly along with the cast.  A different feeling overwhelms as gravity and perception change along with the characters moving from dream level to dream level still tethered in each dream's "now."Everyone is taking risks to go to such deep levels of dreaming, but Cobb is taking danger to the hilt by not moving on from his grief and deep guilt complex involving his wife Mal (Marion Cotillard).  She interferes in his dream world and sometimes overlaps in the main mission.  How this is resolved is important and white knuckled excitement.The movie grabs your gut as well as your imagination.  Well written, creative and mind-bending to the nth degree, it is an exquisite trip to subconscious worlds.
Title: N/A

reviewText: 'Reality is that which when you stop believing in it does not go away.'  Philip K Dick.Christopher Nolan's movies are among my favorite movies of the last ten years.  I remember being incredibly impressed withMemento, and own it.Batman Begins (Two-Disc Special Edition), ($373m ww) also starring Cillian Murphy, Michael Caine and Ken Watanabe), inspired me to explore and understand the idea of archetypes and mythology in movies, and presenting characters first as something else. He saved the Batman franchise and took it to a new level with Dark Knight grossing over $1 billion worldwide, and he also made The Prestige, (again with Michael Caine).  I think that after seeing Inception everyone who knows movies will appreciate who Christopher Nolan is, and his brilliance not only as a director, but also as the writer of Inception.Leonardo di Caprio, not just a talented actor, has undoubtedly become one of the most reliable barometers of movie quality with a string of outstanding movies such as The Aviator The Departed, and Shutter Island, the thrillerBody of Lies, and Blood Diamond, delivers another outstanding performance. It's also refreshing to see Marion Cotillard who won the Oscar forLa Vie en Rose (Extended Version)once again in a movie worthy of her talent.  She brings a certain richness and emotionality to what is mostly a visual spectacle.As you begin to watch, you may notice parallels between Inception and James Bond and The Matrix, although the stacking of realities seems more reminsicent mostly ofThe Jacketor Total Recall, both based on Philip K Dick stories.As the movie opens Cobb washes up on a beach.  The armed rescuers notice a a gun in his belt.  He is taken to the Overlord, an old man. He also has a spinning top.In the Matrix, Neo was a computer hacker. In Inception, Cobb, Leo DiCaprio's character is a mind hacker.In the world of Inception, some people have the technology to invade the unconscious mind of others, and take their ideas.  It is also possible to implant ideas, without people being aware. This is called Inception. You may wonder what being a spy and being a dream hacker have in common.As a hypnotist I can say Inception is a fascinating trance experience, and takes you deeper, and continually shifts scenes. Because of this, you may miss out on some details, and you may in fact, as I did, have to go see the movie again to fill in the blanks.  I understood the levels a lot better the second time.Something to watch out for is trains and Mal's talk of trains, breaking glass repeated, a ring on Cobb's finger that appears and disappears in the second scene, and seems to shift to the overlord, and later Saito's finger.  Not sure what it means.If you have not already seen it, the following may be helpful. The unconscious mind cannot distinguish between what is real and imaginary. That is a conscious distinction. The unconscious mind is the domain of memory, emotion, and imagination. Your unconscious mind repeatedly presents unresolved issues to be resolved, which is one of the main functions of dreaming. You don't always remember a dream after you have had it.There are some allusions to mythology. In Greek mythology, Ariadne constructed a maze. There is a character called Fischer, the son of Fischer, ailing ruler of an empire.  In mythology, we have the story of the Fisher King.I particularly loved the last moments in the movie, and I think you will too.'All reality is an illusion, albeit a persistent one.'  Albert Einstein.If you're like me, I think you will remember Inception long after the final credits roll.  I think a lot of people will have to see it more than once to get it. The best way to describe it I think is that it is a 'tour de force' of the imagination,and raises the bar on creativity.  Aspiring directors will look to this movie, and raise their own standards.  Well, I can dream, can't I?Having said all this,  I know this movie will not appeal to everyone. Some people may be overwhelmed by it, and others just won't get it. I think most people will love it, and it will do very well based on word of mouth.I hope this review was helpful to you.
summary: Going deeper than you can imagine

reviewText: It took me a while to digest inception. Not because the movie plays tricks on the mind but because I wanted to really think about it.There are some great things about the movie which are mostly the action and the special effects, and then there are some not so great things about the movie and that's what lost it points with me.Inception was an interesting idea but it's poorly executed. The movie feels like a lot of what might make it truly interesting is just missing and filled in with bland subject matter. For instance the movie is about persons who are go into peoples minds through the act of dreaming to steal their ideas and information.Just thinking about the plot reminds me just how little sense the movie makes. Isn't there a better way to get information out of people than this super hypnosis? What makes the movie interesting though is that it all takes place in a dream world where somehow people can connect to one anothers dreams somehow.The weird part is that this high technology just seems like a normal occurrence in their lowtech world. So much so that some persons have trained themselves to fight against such mental attacks by equipping armed personnel in their minds.What this really is.... is the MATRIX recycled. Only this time it's not in a distant future. Just like the matrix this movie is full and I mean full of those "what the hell is going on here?" moments mixed in with "gee this boring"... and lastly "oh wow! look at that!"instead of a World where people are actually sleeping but think everything is real, this is a world where people are awake but we they are pushed into a dream world where they supposed to think everything is real. Replace the Matrix guys in shades with "projections" and there you have it. Complete with special effects and all.Regardless of what anyone says this is pretty much the same movie recycled.There are too many inconsistencies with this movie to say its 4 or 5 stars just because it looks good. The story is just plain... well... not interesting. I was more interested in knowing how "jumping into peoples dreams" became a prime too for corporate espionage or just who was the Asian guy? What was his role in the company? How did the others get started into dream diving? (light spoiler)Why can't Leonardo DiCaprio(yes, the actual character names are HORRIBLE!) return home? No one saw him? There were no witnesses and his wife was in a completely different building or other side of the building when it occurred(end). So how did that come in to play as ruining his life? because his wife wrote letters? who cares take it to court and prove it! Just simple things like that seemed to just skip around all the plot holes and no one ever asked questions. Always some simple excuse was given and that was it. That's what the audience is supposed to swallow down.So much of the dreamworld doesn't make sense. If they are jumping into someone else's mind shouldn't they have 100% control. Regardless if they have an architect creating a false world shouldn't it be up to the dreamer to create or destroy what they want? It just doesn't make any sense. They need to go into Fischer's dreams which is a world that he creates to steal secrets and implant idea's? Are they confusing "dreaming" with "hypnosis?" Honestly the logic behind the movie barely works and doesn't make the least bit of sense.How about the part of feeling pain in your dream. Isn't that the point of putting people to sleep during operations so they don't feel pain. "Pain is in the mind" so that overrides physical pain now? your telling me I could poke you with a needle in your sleep but you won't feel it unless your dreaming about it? It's a bunch of bull.I can tell you first hand. When I feel pain in a dream it's because I'm experiencing it in real life. But enough about that plot hole I could go on for days. Lets get to another plot hole. How about "the kick" and the levels of dreaming which I assume are levels of sleep. First off there's only one level of sleep. If your asleep YOUR ASLEEP!. The rest are stages you experience before your actually asleep. So what's with all the kicks. If you dream your falling off a cliff don't you just wake up? and why would someone elses kick while they are in "your" dream effect them solely but not you? Your the dreamer shouldn't your world be in 1st person? If your mind isn't there present to experience your dream than why do those "projected dreams" still exists?If Fischer is unconscious in his dream or he dies why doesn't the dream just fade and send everyone into limbo like it should!  Why is limbo in this dream Cobbs limbo and not Fischer's? And I don't want to hear anyone say "oh they were in Cobbs mind" I say bull turds! to that! The movie contradicted itself when Cobb or whomever stated "they were going to have Fischer tap into his own mind or dream or whatever". Then that doesn't make sense when Fishers projections are attacking everyone but for some reason they are in Cobbs world now that I think about it minus another star this movie didn't make any sense at all!Screw this movie. It's an action flick with a poorly written script, a mediocre story (I could care less about Cobbs marital problems), that tries to trip the audience out by confusing them with the dream nonsense. The only thing that's confusing here was the screenplay the directors wrote. This movie was a "matrix" cash in that came in years later after the matrix series ended. The only thing is as Trippy as the matrix was it actually held my interest because of it's off the wall story that made you think "what if this really all was a dream"...and there we go again with the reality complex!where inception tries to do the same with its trash ending to confuse you as to what reality is.Here's the bottom line. The Matrix did the dream world better go rent and watch that instead. Pick this movie up if you just want to see the special effects because that's all this movie offers. There certainly isn't a story worth remembering here. The only thing people talk about with this movie is "Wow, it looked great!" and "what the hell happened in this movie?
summary: What this really is...is the MATRIX + Ocean's 11!

reviewText: Fantastic; simply mind-bending fun.Christopher Nolan has delivered a movie that seems as if it should be more confusing than it actually is.Inception tells the story of corporate espionage by way of stealing ideas from people's dreams.Leonardo DiCaprio headlines a stellar cast including Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ken Watanabe, Cillian Murphy and Michael Cain.Watanabe hires DiCaprio to plant an idea inside the mind of his competitor (Murphy) in order to bring about his collapse. This is called Inception.DiCaprio assembles a team to pull of the extremely tricky ploy. However, he has some personal baggage that might spell the doom for the entire project and the lives of his team as well.The logistics and implementation of this movie are things that you just have to watch. It's a case where seeing is better than explaining.Throughout the film I was on the edge of the possibility that I might go into confusion but it never happened. Writer/director Nolan kept me well informed and entirely entertained.This is a movie well worth multiple viewings. (Nevermind the ending...)

reviewText: Christopher Nolan's follow-up to 2008's megahit The Dark Knight was rumored as many different films that had been seen by no one. "This film is revolutionary!" "It sucks!" "It's dumb and pointless!" "It's amazing!"  And having finally seen Inception, without many expectations, I can tell you that if you were to see one film, for the remainder of the summer, you should make it Inception.Inception has alot going for it. Its cast works wonders, because every actor brings something fresh and new to the table. It never feels outdated, or irrelevant. It's original without being idiotic. It's intelligent without being implausible. It doesn't take its extremely layered plot too seriously, and there's one thing that really separates it from any other summer action flick: It requires a great deal of thought. You don't know where it's going next. Once it pulls you into its clutches, it takes you on a ride that is unlike anything you've seen onscreen in years. Its ending will be debated, analyzed and picked apart by many film snobs across the world, and it's a film that doesn't just deserve, but requires multiple viewings. It's a hell of alot to take in at once.Now, in any film review, a reader would like to know what the piece is about. This one's plot is better left unsaid, because the first viewing is enough to leave the audience in utter awe. However, I'll do my best to at least give you an idea.Leonardo DiCaprio outshines any of his previous works, playing Dom Cobb, a thief who is proficient in extraction (going into a subject's mind, during dreams, and stealing their ideas, and using them against them), who is embarking on one final job before he can retire, and go home for good. Instead of stealing a subjects dream, he and his team decide to do the opposite. Not to steal a dream, but to go into a person's subconscious and plant an idea.Joseph Gordon-Levitt, of (500) Days Of Summer fame, and Ellen Page, of Juno fame, Marion Cotillard, of Nine and La Vie En Rose greatness, Ken Watanabe, of The Last Samurai, Cillian Murphy, of indie film fame, and a few legends (Michael Caine and Tom Berenger) are the heart of this film. There is truly great acting all around. Everybody brings something new to the table. Each character is richly detailed, and multi-layered. Nobody is really who they say they are. Gordon-Levitt, Page and Cotillard are a few of my favorite actors of the current generation, who haven't had their "big breaks" quite yet. They've had a few parts that they're semi-well known for, and this film is a fabulous transition into mainstream cinema. That's because this is an art-house film that is financed by a major studio. That's the beauty of it. Insight, intelligence and uncanny originality are things you don't see in movies anymore. It's a breath of fresh air to see something as unique and interesting as this.But, at the end of the day, it's Christopher Nolan's genius ideas, smart script, elegant direction, and masterful artistry that make this picture what it is. This is a film that I could picture the writer-director losing his mind over. It's his story, it's his game. He invents a world that you've never seen in any type of film before. It's reminiscent of The Matrix, and the early James Bond pictures. It creates its own metropolis, and its own rules. It breaks the rules of conventional American cinema. And thank god for that. Inception is one of the best films so far in 2010.
summary: Inception: What a summer blockbuster should be.

reviewText: ...within a review within a review, and, by the implications put forward by the yarnsmiths of this wonderful(ly flawed)feature-length,so on and so on and so on times forever, deeper and deeper ad infinitum.There's a lot that can be said about a film like this...and indeed, a lot has been said. Global praise has been peppered upon all involved with this sci-fi headache, some calling it the Citizen Kane of the dream-within-a-dream genre. (albeit a market that is wide open ATM).But I, for one, am not with the majority of the planet on this one. When I first heard on Radio1 of the Conception of Inception and that it was close to Completion, I was hella excited. I've always been a fan of dreams, or 'Cranial Intertainments' as I fondly call them. They're funny, scary and unpredictable, whats not to love? Go dreams. So this film sounded very intriguing to me.But unfortunately the magic and surreality, beauty, horror and broken reality and ugliness of dreams was in no way portrayed accurately in this film, Inception.Do me one little favour. When you go to bed tonight, close your eyes. Fall asleep. Then wake up in the AM and tell me what you witnessed during your unconcious hours. Anything like the 'dreams' that occur in the movie Inception? No, obv!I'm presuming people will think I'm focusing on the wrong aspects of this film,but I just think this is way too Hollywoody an approach for such a crimson idea. They should've given it to Polanski. At least then we could have had pretty, French-looking women to enjoy looking at.Also, I found the part where they're falling off a bridge in a van into a river and the one guy ties them all up and floats about a hotel achingly dull and needlessly prolonged. Even the special effects of the buildings when they go all weird and stuff...it just failed to arouse me in any way at all!Basically, love the onion-ethic (reality being like layers of an infinite onion, you peel away layer after layer) of this motion picture, and I generally like the ideas a lot, but think this film is a miscarraige of imagination.And if anyone was wondering about the end of this film...the spinning top never stops.
summary: A review within a review within a review...

reviewText: Admittedly, I am not a big sci-fi fan to begin with, so perhaps I was doomed to dislike this movie from the start. I had high hopes for "Inception" because everyone I know who saw it absolutely loved it, but it just didn't do anything for me. It reminded me of a slightly improved "Matrix" (which I absolutely hated). "Inception" is more thought-out, with good acting, a fantastic score, and impressive visual effects. However, I thought the plot itself was kind of lame, to be quite honest. Perhaps my biggest complaint is that it is WAY too long (almost three hours). I also felt that it was somewhat predictable, because within the first 20 minutes or so, I had an idea of how the film would end, and I was totally right, so there was no big surprise for me when the final scene rolled around. Some of the dream sequences got a little too crazy, and for a while the movie turned into an action flick when everyone started shooting at each other during the snowy mountain sequence. That detracted from the rest of the film. I think I would have enjoyed it more if Marion Cotillard had a bit more screen time, because the scenes she shared with Leonardo DiCaprio were the most interesting and enjoyable for me. I appreciate the creativity behind this film, and I can understand why other people like it as much as they do, but it's just not my cup of tea.

reviewText: I was blown away by this film which has a great cast of actors!  Leonardo DiCaprio (Cobb) has mastered the art of "architecting" dreams and pulling others into the dream.  Once in, he is able to gain the other person's secrets, as people are less cautious about guarding information in their dreams.Throughout the film he has a goal of getting back to the United States to see his two children.  This may be impossible because he is somewhat responsible for the death of his wife (Mal).  He makes a deal with a powerful businessman (Saito) that if he can plant an idea for another businessman (Fisher) to break up his company, Saito will ensure that Cobb can pass through customs without a second look.Cobb uses a team to accomplish this mission including Joseph Gordon-Levitt (Arthur) and Ellen Page (Ariadne).  Ariadne has exceptional talent and learns to see and architect dreams rapidly.  The team needs to bring Fisher through three levels of a dream to put the idea in his mind that his company needs to be broken up.The movie goes on to explain that at each deeper level of dreaming time can pass very slowly (as much as decades in the lowest level) because the brain is so powerful, while very little time passes in the real world.  Cobb and his Mal had experienced and entire lifetime within a dream.  Mal seems to constantly be in Cobb's dreams and always wants to destroy the fabric of the dream.  Cobb carries a small top that he uses to let him know whether her is the dreamer or he has been brought into a dream created by Mal.I highly enjoyed this film and found it so thought provoking.  The acting was first-rate and Ellen Page is developing into one of the top actresses around.  The film is very complicated and requires several viewings to really understand everything.  For that reason I didn't give it a full five stars.

reviewText: On the surface Inception seems to be a crime caper, complete with master of disguise Eames (Tom Hardy), planner Aridane (Ellen Page), point man Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), and master thief Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio). But it's so much more than that, taking place in dreams within dreams within dreams.Inception, like Total Recall and The Matrix, is about perception.  The audience is never sure what reality is because the protagonist isn't sure what's real. There are clues providing evidence for the real/not real theories, but the best movies of this type don't come down on one side or another.  Total Recall ultimately had enough clues indicating the "right" way.  The Matrix stumbled after it made it clear that reality was fiction, thereby losing an audience who enjoyed the tantalizing mystery.  Like so many mysteries, once the truth was revealed it wasn't quite as exciting as we all hoped. Inception wisely avoids providing answers.Inception is also a thought experiment.  The central conceit of Inception is that once you put a thought in someone's head it's like a virus, incapable of being removed.  In fact, attempting to not think about the idea causes the mind to just focus on it more.  This concept, a key tenet of neuro-linguistic programming (NLP), is part of how our brains are wired.  Director Chris Nolan knows exactly what he's doing when the characters explain the premise.  It is the key argument between Cobb and his wife Mal (Marion Cotillard): is this life just a dream?Once you get it into your head as to which of them is right, Inception burrows into your psyche and you see all the evidence you need to reinforce the idea.  There are enough discrepancies to suspect that Cobb's stuck in a dream, but there are enough rules defining reality that indicate otherwise.  Unless, of course, you believe that Cobb is fooling himself by making up said rules to convince himself he's not in a dream when he actually is.  If that sounds confusing, Inception's done its job.Inception is a little too long in places, testing the viewer's patience as it delves four levels deep into the subconscious, each with different timeframes, settings, and plots. Part of the fun is watching the movie again to look for clues that reinforce what we secretly thought we knew all along.Me?  I'm convinced I know the truth.  But then maybe Inception put that idea in my head.

reviewText: Inception is one of the best sci-fi films I have seen in a long while.  It delves deeply into the idea of the subconscious mind and reality.  Inception has a pretty straight foward plot and not so complicated concept (can be explained more).  The plot and action of the movie is very intriguing, mind-bending, and keeps you interesting throughout the entire film.  I'm very satisfied with the casting.  Leonardo DiCaprio has another brilliant performance and Joseph Gordon-Levitt did a fine job as well.  At first I was skeptical about Ellen Page, but was quite impressed with her performance in this movie.  Ken Watanabe did a terrific job as Saito and made his character a lot more interesting than I thought given credit to.  Inception is a very good movie, has its Cons.Like I stated earlier, Inception has a very straight foward plot and concept, but because of that I think it could've been explained a bit more, thus I thought could've been explained thoroughly in a trilogy.  There were alot of times in the movie where I thought Nolan could have been more specific.  The totem concept is simple, but the ending made it a bit confusing (If you're the architect of the Dream, can't you control the totem, regardless of knowing the texture?).  I thought there was a bit too much action near the end of the movie to the point where it made me a bit irritated.  I think if Nolan removed some of the action at the end and added more depth with the plot I would've given a 5-star without a doubt.  The ending of the movie was obviously left hanging and ambiguous for the audience to figure out, but to this point it is still leaving my friends and I with discussions of what really happened.  I like what Nolan did, but at the same time, I want a definite answer, therefore causing me to want a trilogy, or at least a sequel.  Overall, I enjoyed the movie alot and highly recommend everyone to watch it.If you love sci-fi films, you will not be disappointed.  I recommend renting it if you aren't such a big fan of sci-fi films, but if you are, this is a good movie to keep and watch a couple times if you have the urge to understand the movie more!
summary: Great Film, could be better as a Trilogy.

reviewText: Inception is a film about hacking into a person's mind through their dreams and either extracting information from the person, or implanting a thought into their mind.  A relatively "simple" concept or idea to follow.  The complexity of the film comes from the rules of what can be done, how the mind fights back, how time reacts differently and how there can be multilevel dreams (or dreams within dreams).  You may have to actually watch the movie a couple times to track all those nuances, but they are part of what makes the move great.The main story, is a tale of corporate espionage, where an idea is going to be implanted into the mind of the head of a rival corporation.  The sub-plot, basically reveals how Leonardo Dicaprio's character discovered that inception (the idea of planting a suggestion into the mind through a dream) works, and the consequences of that action.  The story can be hard to follow at times (especially the first time you see it) because it cuts back and forth between different levels of dreams and jumps between the two story lines.The acting in the film is top notch.  You see many supporting actors from the Dark Knight movies in this one.  Christopher Nolan is one of those directors like Tim Burton who uses many of the same actors over and over.  Dicaprio, Joseph Gordon Levitt, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Ken Watanabe and Marion Cotillard are the main cast.  They all do great jobs in their respective roles.  I actually think the sub-plot involving Dicaprio's and Cotillard's characters was the most intriguing part of the story, and the scenes where it was just those two interacting were very powerful.  Many people know that the ending leaves things rather open ended.  I know some people hated that you are never given a definitive answer, but I like how the filmmakers leave it up to the viewer to imagine.The audio and visual quality of the blu ray is wonderful.  If you get the two disc edition (which is really three discs because there is a DVD copy of the movie included) you get the film and a disc of bonus features.  The bonus is a documentary that focuses on the science of dreaming, then a short animated story, some artwork, then trailers and TV spots.While there is a lot of subjectivity when it comes to enjoying movies even in general, that is definitely the case for one like this.  If you are a fan of Nolan's other movies, then I would say this is definitely worth a look.  If you are just a fan of thriller/suspense movies with some action in there as well, it is also worth a look.  There are a lot of special effects in the movie, but I don't think they took away from the quality at all.  If you love the movie, and want the most bonus material, definitely get the two disc edition and not just the single disc edition.

reviewText: "Inception" is writer/director Christopher Nolan's latest attempt convey a vague impression of profundity, through relentless CGI and explosive action, where there is nothing but cliché. Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is a mercenary who specializes in extracting information from other people's minds while they sleep, when they are in a dream state. Some mishap along these lines got him in trouble with the law in the United States, so he cannot return home to his young children. For all of his skills and taste for adrenalin, Cobb wants nothing more than to go home. So he's eager to take a job for Mr. Saito (Ken Watanabe), who promises that he can fix Cobb's legal problems in the US.Mr. Saito is in the market for corporate espionage. The owner of the world's largest energy company is on his death bed, and his son Robert Fischer (Cillian Murphy) stands to inherit. Saito wants Mr. Fischer to break up his father's company. He wants Cobb to do something dangerous and unconventional: Instead of extracting information from his victim, he will plant an idea in the man's head, disguised so that Fischer will believe it was his own. For this mission, Cobb assembles a team of specialists: Ariadne (Ellen Page), an architect who will create the environment of the dreams, Eames (Tom Hardy), who impersonates people, Yusuf (Dileep Rao), a chemist who puts people under, and Cobb's trusty assistant Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt).This is just "Mission Impossible" in a dreamscape, and those old television shows had better writers. Cobb is a crook doing one last big job that is supposed to solve all of his problems, as if we needed another cliché. And it's all about "family values"; the guy just wants to get back to his kids and shake the guilt-ridden memory of his late wife, Mal (Marion Cotillard), who keeps popping up in the dreams like some demonic whack-a-mole. The movie is 2  hours long, and it's mostly filler. The entire first hour is filler: superfluous action sequences and endless conversations whose sole purpose is to explain the technical aspects of creating and entering someone's dreams. The dialogue is so stilted that the actors can barely spit it out.As he did in "Titanic", Leonardo DiCaprio manages to bring a certain weight to his character in spite of the fact that everything he says sounds like it was written by a 12-year-old who has only primetime television dramas and Saturday morning cartoons to draw on. Ken Watanabe, on the other hand, is completely wasted here. He has nothing to do. Ellen Page is dreadfully miscast -so badly so that I wonder if it was intended as a joke. She's like a mouse dropped into the middle of an action movie. The action sequences are so boring and purposeless that you will need reading material to keep you conscious. And the whole thing is predicated on the idea that some Japanese tycoon can control the American criminal justice system, instantly, with one phone call. "Inception" is Nolan's most hollow and formulaic film to date.

reviewText: I know there has been a lot of praise for this movie, and I came in to it hoping to be entertained, but, honestly, I felt it was just "so-so."  Forgetting the special effects, one has to look at the stars, the script, and direction.  Now I am different than many here, since I am in my fifties, but I do like a number of recent films, and I have seen thousands of movies in my day, covering all parts of film history, so I have plenty of remembance of films past to draw upon in comparison.  However, "Inception", along with "Shutter Island", are two examples of recent films I just don't care enough about the people portrayed, or the stars' lacking of chemistry with the audience, and both stories left me desiring more in the way of substance over flash.  (Shutter Island, I was so far ahead of the ending that it left no surprises.)  I know the special effects in Inception are remarkable...but so what?  Where's the heart?  DiCaprio's story was supposed to deliver it, but I couldn't feel anything for him or his situation.  Too much explanation, not enough love.  As a side note, I'd really like for the actor to take some time off from the serious films he has been making.  He's just so damn intense in his performance that his own personality fails to cross the screen to the audience.  His characters of later have all been so self-involved that the actor rolls himself into a ball of deep intensity...and it doesn't leave his body to get to the audience.  That intense furrow across his brow and steely eyes just doesn't do it for me.  I miss the jocular Leonardo from Titanic.

reviewText: The movie previews gave a sense of a sort of professional psychologists embarking on an ingenious discovery of the subconscience.However, the movie narrates a scenario closer to Shutter Island with a brighter outcome. The tragic loss of a mother and wife to a psychotic disorder derailed the living spouse into a posttraumatic state of derealization and despair. In the beginning, the movie was tolerable with the stranded American citizen in a foreign land to evade the notorious cold hands of the legal authorities. A desperate man yearning to unite with the children he abandoned was something many viewers could relate to. Every time I sat to watch this movie, the theater was filled beyond the ordinary, even on evenings other than the Fridays and Saturdays.The most annoying trend in the movie was making irrational and nonsensical interpretation of the subconscience and the dream state. One could easily relate to the unreal feeling of a stressed mind and the chaotic state of perception and reasoning when deep seated pain could not be suppressed. But, assigning a crew of actors to dialogues on how to manipulate the immaterial senses into material reality is foolish. When young actors rush through artificial dialogues that insult people's intelligence, boredom and disdain grow.The portion of the movie that dealt with chaotic nightmares was too long to endure and would have done much better had the dialogue on making and sharing dreams were mature or intelligent. Though one might justify nonsense during the dream state, which the moviemakers apparently have in mind, there is evident exaggeration of the potential of the unqualified and inexperienced characters in manipulating the state of mind on such short notice. A husband influencing his wife to believe in derealization is unheard of.The short and sweat scene that save the movie was the union of the traumatized father with his stranded kids.
summary: Could have been much better had it refrained from nonsense.

reviewText: Inception is just one of those movies you won't be able to stop thinking about long after you've left the theater. In fact, if you're like me, you'll probably need to see it multiple times just to get everything straight. There is so much packed into it's 2 and 1/2 hour running time, it's hard to keep up with all the dialogue that explains what is going on. Christopher Nolan hasn't made a bad or mediocre movie yet (Insomnia being the weakest, but still good) and thankfully his career is just getting started. Not only has he directed some great films like Memento, Batman Begins, and The Dark Knight, but he is the chief writer as well. I read he invested nearly ten years in this ambitious project and it really shows. The writing and story are very clever, even becoming a little too smart for it's own good times. It seemed like some people in my theater wanted just your typical summer movie explosions, while keeping their brains in neutral. There's no getting around the fact that this film will force you to think.It's hard to say what the movie is about without giving too much away, but to put it simply, it's about a group of people who steal important information from other people while they are dreaming. In the case of an inception, they want to put an idea in someone's head which could have a huge impact on that individual and change the course of countless other lives in the process. All this is done by creating mazes and layers in the dream world to hopefully keep that person from ever knowing someone was in their mind. At one point towards the end of the film we're seeing a dream within a dream, within a dream, within a dream. Four dream layers going on at the same time, but it's so well designed I didn't have too many problems keeping up. Even so, there are a number of things I'm still confused about after my initial viewing.I can't really single out any one cast member since everyone is important to the story and they all do fantastic jobs. Like Nolan's Batman movies, the cast is filled with at least a half dozen well accomplished actors, in this case, Leornado DiCaprio, Ellen Page, Ken Watanabe, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Marion Cotillard, Cillain Murphy, Tom Berenger, and Michael Caine. Not a weak link in sight.The CGI blends in beautifully when used, though I have always liked the fact that Nolan uses practical effects whenever possible. There are some really neat visuals that are creative and unique, as well as, a few action sequences that will keep you awake if the dialogue gets a bit too heavy for your tastes, including a no gravity fight scene in a hotel hallway dreamscape. What makes it even better is that it's actually Joseph Gordon-Levitt doing all those stunts in a rotating room, as I learned from HBO's behind the scenes look.Hans Zimmer's solid music score is along the same wavelenth as The Dark Knight in mood, but there's a little more emotional weight, especially towards the end of the film.Many critics are calling Inception a masterpiece. I think it's very close and easily the best film of the year so far, which you might think isn't saying much in such a lackluster movie season, but maybe this will help clarify things. Inception is jockeying with The Dark Knight for my favorite Christopher Nolan film. Clear enough for you?
summary: My Brain Hurts (in a good way)

reviewText: Being a big fan of "mindbased" scifi and having seen on all the hype about this movie I was quite keen to see this movie. Let me clear one things first, the special effects are impressive and if that is important to the viewer they wont be disappointed.If however you like a good story line, complex characters, good acting and want to leave the theater having had your boundaries challenged this will be a let down. Leonardo di Caprio as usual delivers a solid performance but that is about what can be said about the acting. Michael Caines role is so minute that it seems he was mainly included for his 'movie poster value' and most of the others left no impression at all.Particularly Ellen Page disappoints playing the young 'super student' recommended to the project by father in law Caine. She lends no depth to her character and looks mostly like a 16 year old high school student totally misplaced in the plot.. and her character is outright damaging for the overall impression of the movie.Whether it is her character that lacks substance or it is Page who fails on delivering the intended complexity is uncertain but the end result is very damaging for the movie. In general the movie lacks characters and while the overall 'headline' plot is interesting the subplots do not fail to deliver.. they are simply not there.The action scenes are professionally done but as pointed out by others they leave the viewer shrugging their shoulders as the 'villains' are really not relevant to the plot as they are mere projections and seem to drop dead 10 to each bullet while being unable to even hit the target even when outnumbering the hero's 20 to 1.The idea of mankind at some point being able to enter people's mind through their dreams is both intriguing and likely to one day be possible and as such is a good premise for a story. The message to us all to live our lives and not 'get too preoccupied' in our most unrealistic of dreams also makes sense but that's it. It could have gone so much further but it does not. Personally it does not come close to the depth of Vanilla Sky which I found thought provoking even having to endure Tom Cruise for close to hours.Not wanting to give away any of the plot considering there is so little of it (!) I encourage only those who are into scifi and action movies for 'technical reasons' loving good stunts, special effects and action for actions sake... if you are looking for a deep story line, complex characters, good actors and something that stimulates just a bit of thought this is not the movie to visit.

reviewText: Inception is one of the more enjoyable films that I have seen in some time. It falls somewhere between the Matrix (methodology), Vanilla Sky (multi-layered realities) and the Usual Suspects (densely-plotted, begs more than one viewing.)The result is a thrill-ride that will leave most viewers pondering long after the credits have rolled. It is both provocative and at times mesmerizing, albeit a bit over-thought at times.Though the idea of "dream hacking" is hardly new, Nolan's layers to the idea make the concept seem quite fresh and the result is something unique. Instead of relying on one "plane" of consciousness or dreamscape, Nolan has included "levels", which dictate different levels of a dream and each team member has a role to serve in navigating its murky and at times unnerving landscape to accomplish their mission. Timing is critical at every level and the story is weaved together rather well, though at times it can feel a little overwhelming.In fact, the only complaint I have about the film is that at certain moments it bogs down under the weight of its own complexity and at times, unnecessarily.Part of this is because Nolan is a little unconventional in terms of how he handles exposition. Instead of laying out the rules of the world in one part of the film, he chooses to add more rules as the film progresses.In a more conventional scenario, consider the Matrix:1. First part, we are as disoriented as Neo and do not understand what is happening.2. Second part, the rules of the world are laid out by Morpheus and suddenly we understand what is happening.3. Finally, the action takes place with the audience in the full know of the established rules.With Inception, these rules unfold throughout almost the entire film, much like the plot points. The result is a double-edged sword: On one hand, it keeps the film moving swiftly and you continue to have "ah-ha" moments. On the other hand, it makes one feel like scorekeeping is in order to keep everything straight as you watch it.It's not so much that Nolan gives us TOO MUCH INFORMATION, as much as it that he gives us CRITICAL PIECES OF INFORMATION in VERY SMALL WINDOWS of screen time. This means one ill-timed bathroom break could compromise your entire understanding of the film.Even paying strict attention the entire time, there are still times when details lost because we're too busy absorbing info.Another common complaint is the "ambiguous ending", which has sparked raging debates. I personally don't mind such endings. I like coming to my own conclusions, but that's just me. Unfortunately though, I found more ambiguous moments throughout the entire film, which doesn't work as well. Again, the "rules" get fuzzy at times, which one should always be avoided when doing science fiction, especially as layered as this.That being said, you still feel like you've seen a "complete film" at the end, and it should resonate one way or another, good or bad. No one and I mean NO ONE can dispute Nolan's ambition here. It's one of the most ambitious concepts and films I've seen in years.PERFORMANCESI don't consider myself a huge DiCaprio fan. I love much of his early work but don't remember him in a memorable role since Titanic (I have not yet seen Shudder Island, which I am told he is good in.) I thought he was very strong here, with much of Nolan's script playing to his strengths.Supporting performances were exactly what I expected -- nothing Oscar worthy, but perfectly capable. Cillian Murphy is teamed up with Nolan again, and serves his character well. I feared Ellen Page would be a weak link in the film, but I was wrong. Also refreshing were the performances of lesser known talents such as Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe and Dileep Rao. Michael Caine also has a small part and it's always good to see him.My biggest disappointment was Marion Cotillard, who I thought was rather one-dimensional here. But that may have been more of a symptom of her role.CINEMATOGRAPHYIn standard Nolan fashion, Inception is generally gorgeous and well- shot. I love the fact that Nolan relies less on CGI than the average Hollywood director and still understands the value of organic action, scenes and stunts.MUSICFrankly, I was under whelmed with the score, but less because of the score itself and more so because it seems too loud and overwhelming at times. There were even times when I couldn't even hear dialogue. This is either a mixing/editing problem OR possibly because I was sitting at the back of my theater and it seemed too loud.That complaint aside, the heavy dramatic cuts that prevail in the film are effective and add to the scenes.IN CONCLUSIONI found Inception to be exciting and captivating, and easily one of the better films of 2010. Where does it rank among the all time greats? I cannot say. I do consider it a top-flight science fiction film, but I struggle to think of it as a cinematic masterpiece because I really do think it out-thought itself on too many occasions.Do I suggest you go see it? Absolutely, no questions asked. In parting I'll leave you with....RECOMMENDATION FOR FIRST TIME VIEWERS:1. The first 10-15 minutes are a little disorienting. Be patient, things will fall into place soon enough.2. As mentioned above, try and avoid bathroom breaks. It really can be the difference.3. Sit in the middle or front of the theater. As mentioned above, either by design or because of my theater, the music was too loud at times and dialogue was lost.4. Be prepared to be absorbing a lot of input. You won't have much time to process that input until the film is over.
summary: Nolan has created a provocative piece of cinema, flirting with masterpiece -- but is it?

reviewText: Watching INCEPTION very carefully and keeping track of the intertwined dreams and plot devices, I must express great respect for the obvious work that went into putting this film together.It is also an interesting concept on the idea of Dream Worlds -vs- Real Worlds.For example, if you went to sleep tonight but never woke up,  wouldn't that dream world you lived in become your real universe ?I confess, I have had some dream worlds that I have visited that I would not mind staying in and never waking up.Having said all that and giving much respect to the makers of this film for hard work and a genuine effort, I have to say as a movie, INCEPTION is painful to watch.Some movies really pull you in and make you care for what happens the the characters.At their best, you may even briefly for a few moments forget you are watching a movie.This never happened with INCEPTION.I always felt I was watching a movie with a whole crew and director sitting behind every scene.I cared nothing about the characters.I cared nothing for their assignment.For me, it was eye candy and no substance.I know it was a big success, but for me it was totally forgettable as a movie.

reviewText: This movie to me signals the end of cinema as we know it.A movie with such a ridiculous concept, that most of the beef of the movie is spent explaining it, by one-dimensional characters in a dream.The part that killed the movie for me, and where I ended up walking out, was between scenes of clunky exposition by one-dimensional characters in a dream, two one-dimensional characters float around in zero gravity. Was that supposed to be a joke?What was funny, was as watching it, I couldn't wait to see a parody, making fun of Nolan's convoluted and heartless mess. I figured it would be a Saturday Night Live skit, with all the characters taking turns explaining arbitrary concepts, with other scenes filled with mindless, over the top gunfights.Funny enough, South Park beat SNL to the punch. South Park made an entire episode making fun of Inception. My favorite quote was, "Just because something is overly complicated doesn't make it cool!" After that, another mindless gunfight starts.Great stuff. I highly recommend you skip "Inception" and seek out the South Park episode instead. Much better written and funnier.
summary: Exposition dispersed between mindless action scenes

reviewText: I loved this movie, after watching I couldn't figure out the 3 other people around me didn't like it, I finally figured it out. This movie a has at least 3 levels of premise. Not saying it complicated, its actually quite simple, but the movie carry's out as a dream within a dream within a dream. Although the movie plays deeper into these levels, they're  all connected. Imagine a house that has 3-4 basements, each one below the other. To get what you need you have to work your way through through a series of obstacles physically and mentally going down, and when you get there, getting back up to the main floor(reality/awake), will be twice as hard. Then you have to make sure your back into reality(awake) so your not stuck in a dream for eternity. Thats all I can say without giving away important story plots. So with that, if you like a good action movie with the obvious need to do some thinking to keep up, then you'll love this...if you don't like movies that you have to use your head, then this wont be for you.
summary: Excellent Movie for the real thinkers

reviewerName: Nathan Andersen "Gadget lover and author of S...
reviewText: Leonardo di Caprio (in a role and a film that bears more than a superficial resemblance to his most recent other role in Martin Scorcese'sShutter Island) plays a dream thief, hired by powerful bigwigs as a kind of corporate spy to ferret out trade secrets, not by sneaking into offices and tapping phones; rather, his job is to infiltrate the mind while the victim sleeps, and find a way to tap into his or her subconscious.  He used to be the best, but now it turns out his deep-seated guilt at a past misdeed is coming back to haunt him in his dreams even as the real life consequences of his past are catching up with him while awake.  It's a fascinating thrill ride - that is entertaining as it entertains some of the basic questions of philosophy, such as what is real, how we can know, and whether our thinking belongs to us.  It's also the latest in a long line of films that explores the implications of the fact that half our lives are spent sleeping and at least some of that time is spent wandering worlds we may not remember when we wake up.Cinema has always been fascinated by dreams, since the immersion within a film resembles nothing so much as a dream.  The lights go out and you lean back, forgetting about your worries of the day, and find yourself thrust into the midst of a situation, that somehow, almost directly, makes sense.  You find yourself meeting strangers, and yet they are almost familiar, and in moments you feel as though you know them even while you know that you have not met.  Even more, like dreams the cinema somehow caters to desires and fascinations we may not have known we possessed, obsessions we are possessed by unawares.Early filmmakers attempted to exploit this similarity between dreams and cinema, and the ease with which the audience accepts what should seem strange, once the basic logic of a situation is clear.  Experimental cinema, notably works by surrealist masterLuis Bunueland poetic filmmakerMaya Deren, explored dreams directly in their films, and even while they broke the usual rules of conventional narrative cinema, and associated images, not in accordance with the principle of continuity but in accordance with a dream (and nightmare) logic, their work somehow made emotional sense, hung together in ways that defied easy explanations.  The familiar difficulties in discerning the difference between dreams and waking life, at least when one is in the midst of a dream, caused Descartes to raise questions how we can be certain of anything; long after Descartes, the association of dreaming with doubt has been explored in a number of films, especially science fiction classics such asTotal Recall.  The tendency within such films to use dreams as a too easy resolution of plot problems by suggesting that everything we've seen may really have been a dream (usually signaled by a character waking up), has made this a cliche, that, thankfully, Nolan avoids, in part by exploring the cliche directly, and in some intriguing detail.  As his film makes clear in the opening scenes, if dreams have the impact of leading us to question our waking life, then waking up at the apparent end of a dream proves nothing.There's lots to think about here, and I imagine the Freudian philosopher Slavoj Zizek will have a field day with this one, since of course a film about dreams can't help but engage with Freud, and there are lots of Freudian elements in the film (the daddy issues, the obsession with and repression of female sexuality, the way that the repressed feminine character wields a phallic knife...).  What intrigued me most about this film, though, and makes me want to watch it again (and this is one of those rare blockbuster films that probably requires a second or third watching, but at the same time manages to make sense for the most part and be exciting to watch the first time around), is its exploration of the idea of "inception" - of what it means to put thoughts into another's head.  I'm especially intrigued by one of the examples in the film of a successful act of inception, and wonder whether it is really best described as a case of putting an idea into someone's head.  When the ancient Greek philosopher Socrates led people to question their ideas, when he inspired them to doubt, it's an interesting question whether he'd managed what in this film is called "inception."  Socrates himself claimed never to teach anyone anything, that he never put any new thoughts in their head, but claimed only to be a midwife for the ideas they already possessed.  It's worth asking whether Cobb is like Socrates in this respect.  In any case, even if this film didn't put any new ideas in my head, and I'm not sure it has anything really new to say, it still raised some intriguing questions, and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout.  Definitely fun stuff.
summary: A thrilling exploration of dream logic - with incredibly rich imagery that may overwhelm its other provocations

reviewText: We should all stand up and cheer Christopher Nolan (Memento, The Dark Knight) for a number of reasons, whether it be for making spectacular Batman movies or always willing to up the ante in terms providing something rarely seen on the silver screen.  Case in point is Inception, which finds Nolan unfolding a masterfully dizzying and ingenius thriller, in which a master thief named Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) uses technology to invade people's dreams.  Given a seemingly impossible task to pull of "an inception" for his last shot at redemption, Cobb and his crew find themselves way in over their heads as a battle of mental survival begins to unfold.  For everything that makes Inception so special, from the dazzling effects to the zero-gravity fistfight between Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), the film isn't without its flaws.  The multilayered plot can get nigh-incomprehensible, convoluted, and downright confusing, as the film's ideas come close to running away with themselves in full gear and leaving the viewer utterly clueless.  Still though, Inception is the kind of mainstream brain-teasing film that is so incredibly rare to see these days, and it's made all the better by a superbly constructed cast that also includes Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Ken Watanabe, Cillian Murphy, Michael Caine, Marion Cotillard, Dileep Rao, Tom Berenger, Pete Postlethwaite, and Lukas Haas.  All in all, you won't see many films like Inception, which is a crying shame, and here's hoping that Christopher Nolan has a few more tricks up his sleeve for the future.
summary: A masterfully dizzying and ingenius thriller

reviewText: A movie built like a labyrinth, complete with a menacing minotauric presence and a guiding Ariadne; worlds within worlds and dreams reflected onto dreams like an infinity mirror effect.Nolan takes the viewer deep, deeper than any other filmmaker in memory, and without holding your hand all the way he never lets you get lost. His vision has years compressed into hours, Paris folding onto itself, militarized minds and entire worlds built out of a single person's imagination. Yet in the end, his logic is solid and his story scintillatingly brilliant.This is bioSciFi, cyberpunk and action movie all rolled into a complex story in the near future, where not even our dreams will be safe and sharing our subconscious fears and fixations will only be an induced REM cycle away.Have you tried yourTotemyet?Then how can you be sure?

reviewText: Some directors make a big splash and then slowly fade into the background as successive works become rehashes of their early successes.  George Lucas is a great example of this.  Jumping onto the scene in the late 1970s with Star Wars and then his blockbuster collaborations with Spielberg such as Indiana Jones, he has never won a Best Director award and he now focuses on just and expanding and upgrading his Star Wars Universe.  Ditto with M. Knight Shamalayan.  Then there are the directors that get better with each successive movie, with Christopher Nolan being the best example.  Starting with Memento, then Batman Begins, followed by the Prestige, and The Dark Knight, he has made his crowning achievement with Inception.Like the original Star Wars, the first and easy sign that this is one of the greatest movies ever made is the difficulty in identifying the genre of this movie.  The movie's title, and astounding and original special effects marks this as a science-fiction movie.  But then again this is not about aliens taking over the world, or machines that rise up against man.  No, this movie is about white-collar crime, corporate crime to be exact.  So then I could say this movie should be mentioned with other classic crime thrillers that feature ensemble casts like Heat, Traffic, or more specifically, Godfather I and II.  To the point, both Inception and the Godfather movies are about a family man involved in crime for the sake of his family.  Now if we look even closer, and recount the most pivotal and important scenes in the movie, we realize this movie is really about a man trying to come to grips with the death of his wife and how he was the cause of it.  This would then make the movie a tragic romance, better than any adaptation of Romeo and Juliet.Another great feature of this movie is its ability to meld multiple forms of storytelling together.  First, there is the flashback, where the past and the present join together via glimpses of past scenes.  For Inception, the flashbacks are of the main character's time with his wife.  Second, we have the story within a story.  For some movies, this might take the form of a personal rivalry occurring within a larger conflict, such as Gandalf vs Saruman in the LOTR movies.  Here, it is the dream within a dream.  Or more specifically, 4 successive dreams within a dream.  Third, there is the concept of parallel story threads that tie together.  In Inception, we have multiple story threads that run in parallel.  There is Ariadne's exploration of Dom's past, Dom dealing with the memories of his wife, the rivalry between the two energy companies that sets the backdrop of the movie, and Dom's desire to return to his children.  All of which are threaded together seamlessly by Christopher Nolan.Throw in the everything else in the movie, and what you have is a seamless blend of thriller, drama, tragedy, comedy, science fiction, etc... everything except a western.  Add in a captivating soundtrack, great dialog, and a perfect cast, and you come away with possibly the best movie of the new century.  As for the DVD itself, we have the traditional extra features such as interviews with cast members, making-of documentaries, and trailers.  However, there are no deleted or extra scenes on either the regular DVD or Blue-Ray.  This is in keeping with other movies by Christopher Nolan; the movie version is the final and only version.  Overall, worth the buy.
