reviewText: Combine an innovative director, idea, and cast. Add to that a story that questions reality, physics defying fight scenes, and wonderful special effects. What do you get? Unfortunately, with Inception, not much.Christopher Nolan (The Dark Knight, Memento) directs this complex blockbuster about mental espionage. Using fancy technology, expert thief Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) is able to sneak into a subject's subconscious to steal information. Inception's plot involves an even more difficult, nigh impossible, assignment: planting an idea. At the behest of the shady Saito (Ken Watanabe), Cobb and his crew plan to give Saito's economic competitor Fischer (Cillian Murphy) the impulse to dissolve his company. Complicating matters is the projection of Cobb's dead wife Mal (Marion Cotillard), who violently haunts his every entry into dreamland.The film is more interested in muddled sequences reminiscent of Tomb Raider than characters. In an attempt to build suspense, scenes move from one shot to another and back ad nauseum.Nolan's measured character studies and puzzle-like plots are often superior to his action scenes. But here characters, one of Nolan's strengths, are subtle to the point of dullness. They come across as mere plot devices. This may be intentional, a metacognitive device, but it doesn't make our heroes any more interesting.Slightly unhinged and haunted by a dead wife, Cobb is distractingly reminiscent of DiCaprio's role in the movie Shutter Island. Cobb's psychosis isn't enthralling enough to emotionally anchor the plot. His right hand man Joseph Gordon-Levitt looks smashing but is lifeless. Ellen Page as Ariadne, the dream architect, looks lovely but is likewise uninteresting. Tom Hardy's Eames is the cheeky but two dimensional "forger" who can change his appearance once in a dream. Watanabe's Saito is at first mysterious, but ultimately opaque as anyone else. Dileep Rao as Yusuf, the apothecary, is intriguingly amoral - or maybe not; his character is hardly developed. In an unsatisfying part, Murphy, whose subconscious everyone enters, excels. He stands out as the only one who evokes sympathy. Cotillard as the dangerously multifaceted Mal is also excellent.None of these characters hold many, if any, surprises. In fact, there are few twists in the entire movie , which is bizarre for a Nolan flick. Also unusual for one of his films is a lack of moral exploration. Our protagonists break into someone's mind. This isn't really questioned. The cast's remarkable chemistry makes a lack of humor conspicuous. They all remained so cool, it's difficult to feel suspense.Perhaps Inception is difficult "to get." It's easy to ask, whose subconscious are they in? How did they get there? Why? What's at stake? This confusion prevents you from enjoying the film, but the real problem is not caring about the explanation.

reviewText: I was going to let this review go because I got to see INCEPTION via Amazon's Video On Demand for free as part of a promotion.  Still, as an aspiring screenwriter and basic movie fan, I've got to say something here.(If like me you hate spoilers, scroll to the bottom of this review and read the last line.  Otherwise, I proceed as if you've already seen the film.)If you think INCEPTION is simply amazing -- you've been scammed.  I know, this is a sacrilege of modern cinema to suggest the 'genius' behind DARK KNIGHT could possibly misstep, but INCEPTION only solidifies my view that Nolan has a reality distortion field around him that Steve Job's would envy.First of all, there is a thing known in screenplays known as 'exposition'.  Exposition is when the characters explain the story to YOU to make sure you understand what's going on and what it means.  The more time the story spends explaining the story, the weaker and more convoluted the story.  Too much exposition reveals a core flaw of a screenplay -- in that -- instead of having fun with the story, the story spends too much time explaining itself.INCEPTION is wall to wall exposition.  It should have been called EXPOSITION it's so bad.  It never lets up, and the reason is NOT because the film is such a 'clever engaging 'mind-bender'.  The story never stops explaining itself to you is it's poorly constructed.There are simple work-arounds to make a story present itself more clearly.  It's called a second draft.For instance, the story uses an old device known as 'explain it to the newbie'.  The Juno actress is brought in as a newbie and the entire dreaming world is explained to her.  Piece by piece.  As it's explained to her, it's explained to us.  Get it?  You've seen it a million times.  AVATAR used it too.The problem here:  we didn't need the explanation.You think I'm nuts.  The story was confusing as hell and OF COURSE we needed the 'tell it to the newbie' trick to follow what was going on.  Salami.Was the plot really that difficult to follow?  The way it was presented, absolutely, but let me prove to you how simple to plot actually was:  a team of dream re-enginners attack a sleeping son of a businessman and insert into his mind the desire to dissolve his Dad's business.  In order to implant this idea the dream re-engineers must create three dreams within a dream to pull this off, and have a matter of minutes in the first dream, hours in the second, and weeks in the third.Isn't that basically it?  Yup.  Isn't that nice and clean and simple?  Yup.  Could that have been elegantly explained in a few opening scenes.  Yup.  Did this team need to pull in a newbie device and risk their lives on a novice?  Nope.INCEPTION takes ONE HOUR to explain what I just explained in two sentences.  Not because it's cool and clever and wildly imaginative... but because it's poorly written rubbish.Oh, I know, the fans of this film just shuttered.  Rubbish?  Impossible!  "Why this was the director of DARK KNIGHT for crying out loud and INCEPTION made a fortune at the box office too!"Stop being a fanboy and ask yourself this:  was this Leonardo's best work?  When you think of what a great actor he can be, is this one of the movies you'll think of first?  I won't.I swear he spent the entire film with the same one pained look.  Downright constipated if you ask me.  I think he was supposed to be an emotionally distraught dude hiding a 'secret' that Juno girl eventually uncovered, but that doesn't explain his one note performance.The reason he looked so desperate and scared was that there no character to grab onto.  Leo's character was like all the characters in this piece:  one note comic book bad@sses.  Absolutely nothing more.  Pink Fluffernutter in dark suits.Modern cinema (I just hate putting those two words together) has this scam that's in nearly all 'big' movies these days -- and -- audiences consistently fall for it box office weekend after box office weekend.  It is:  any one of us could be a bad@ss, and when you join a team of bad@asses... wow... aren't you REALLY COOL.The scam of a movie like INCEPTION isn't that the idea of dream re-engineering is cool.  That's actually a good idea.  The scam is that you could be one of these people -- that you're smart enough and tough enough to swagger like the idiots in this film.  That each one of us is really just a James Bond in discounted jeans.  That's what you're really being sold here.Yes, I know, that all movies invite us into a character and give us a chance to be someone else.  But you know what?  In good movies -- in your best Bond movies -- you feel like there's an actual person there as well.  That, yes, you can pretend to be Bond at times, but at other times, you must face you're not Bond and James is.  This is why Bond can be amazing - because you must admit he's a bad@ss and you're not.When watching INCEPTION I merely see a room of nothings running around from dream to dream.  I didn't really buy that any of these people were real or mattered.For example, Leo cared very much about his wife.  He wanted to be with her.  Did we care about her?  Did WE want to be with her?  Nope.  Remember why?  She came off as a psychotic during most of her scenes.The movie pulls Juno girl out of nowhere.  She was in school but was -- oddly -- ready and willing to leave it at a moment's notice.  No boyfriend or family, no fear that some insane caper might destroy her mind and body.  Did they offer her money?  Did they promise her a place in a grad school?  I don't remember hearing any such offers.  Do you?INCEPTION isn't about really exploring this cool dream idea and making it real.  It's merely about inviting you along as a member of a team of bad@asses AND escorting you through a series of reasonably impressive CGI.  THAT'S ALL.  It's so that you can leave the cinema with a big swagger and feel cool.You know how some people simply HATE Apple for selling cool over anything else?  That just having a Mac is cool in and of itself?  That's all INCEPTION is.  Stop pontificating about how 'amazing' it was.It wasn't.  It was just okay at best.  Must NOT hurry to see cinema.Still not buying this?  Think about the plot again.  The motivation behind Leo's quest.  Leo has taken a job to break up a corporation so that it's competitor can make even bigger profits.  Did you catch that?  It's not that the corporation that's being broken up is 'evil'.  It wasn't.  So Leo is really working on behalf of an 'evil' corporation that's attacking another corporation for immense greed and profit.... yay?Wouldn't it simply be cheaper for the competing corporation to buy off the son instead of this completely insane and convoluted plot?  I know, I know, when you go see a fantastic movie you have to give them a little elbow room.  I did.  But INCEPTION demands a stadium of elbow room... just for starters.Did you notice how Juno girl was amazingly perceptive?  I mean she's not just an amazing 'maze' girl, or scientific mind, but she's also a perceptive psychotherapist?  All this in a youthful package which OH SO CONVENIENTLY is a voicebox for the smarter/aged screenwriter?  Yes, I know, she's as cute as hell, but I didn't let my hormones distract me from the simple fact she was a %100 unbelievable character.And speaking of hormones:  why wasn't Leo interested in this girl?  Or this girl interested in Leo?  Yes, I know, Leo was obsessed with his psychotic wife, and Juno girl was afraid that Leo might be a mental case.Still, there's something in heterosexual oriented movies known as 'the love interest' which Juno girl would have been perfect for... had she been cast as an older woman.  But poor INCEPTION was so busy explaining and reexplaining the world's most unnecessarily complex plot that ---- it has absolutely no time for a few genuinely emotional moments between Leo and Juno.(I should look up their real character names, shouldn't I?  But since they weren't really characters -- since the writer/director didn't bother to rewrite his opus -- I'll be similarly lazy.)But the special effects were awesome, you say like a trained monkey?  Okay, alright, let's discuss two of them to put this sorry movie out of it's misery.When Juno girl first discovers she's not on a street but really in a dream world, the entire street begins erupting.  Poof-pang-kapliff!  So COOL, right?  Wrong.  Tell me, why didn't it ever do this again when other characters were outright told that the world they thought was real was actually a dream?I bet you didn't notice that, did you?  Know why?  You were so captivated by the cool poof-pang-kapliff effect you forgave the story for making no sense.  That it didn't even follow its own rules.Remember when Juno girl folded the street up and over?  A really really COOL special effect... utterly wasted.  What if during one of the chase scenes she invoked it to flip the car behind them?  That would have been really SMART, right?  You know, using a skill they had to alter the situation?  The reason why they didn't do this ---- was because the story wasn't following it's own rules.  They were shifting at the whims of story and CGI. Face it:  this is yet another special effects feast that's exciting to watch once and never again.Overlong, way too much exposition, too many characters, all characters were Pink Fluffernutter, a stunningly convoluted plot, a hero (?) on an extremely selfish quest, a sidekick too smart to believe and too hot to ignore, a third act stolen frame for frame out of FOR HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE, and yet another story that invites you to 'be all you can be' so that you can leave the cinema feeling COOL with a BAD@SS swagger.INCEPTION is a scam.If you rolled your eyes at AVATAR, you'll roll them here too.

reviewText: The concept seems original at first but the more you watch the more you realize that this movie is little more than "The Matrix" meets "Vanilla Sky." Now, these were both cool movies but that's, in part, because they were both original at the time. Aside from this, "Inception" is a very complex story which end up being kind of slow. Plus, (unless I just missed something, which is possible) there seemed to be some holes in the plot. On the visual side, there were some very impressive camera tricks but that, alone, does not a good movie make. Based on people raving about this movie, I had expected something more.Not bad but not recommended.

reviewText: Underneath all the really impressive special effects and the sci-fi content, Inception offers a replay of the archetypal male fears of female sexuality. In this sense, the movie follows the conventions of Charlotte Bronte'sJane Eyre. A dark and brooding Mr. Rochester with a daunting past is here played by a blond and brooding Leonardo DiCaprio with an equally painful past. Both men are obsessed with control. What they are trying to control so desperately is the irrational sphere of emotions and dreams associated with women.Both Mr. Rochester and Leonardo DiCaprio in Inception are haunted by their wives who represent a raw, uncontrollable sexuality that threatens the obsession with control that drives these men. Both men manipulate their wives into what they see as 'insanity' and hide them either in the attic or in the basement. Both are helped in their quest to liberate themselves from the influence of their wives by a woman who embodies a completely different type of femininity: boyish, asexual, and fully dedicated to maintaining the world of logic and control at the expense of everything sexual, sensual, and irrational. The female lead in Inception is played by Ellen Page whose big head on a 10-year-old's body symbolizes her rejection of everything female.Even some small details that were presentJane Eyrereappear in Inception. A huge knife wielded by Berta Rochester is picked up by the main character's wife. A jump out of a window plays a similarly crucial role in both works.  And, of course, the feeling of male terror that comes as a response to being confronted with the threat of an uncontrollable female sexuality informs both the novel and the movie in a very similar way.What Inception teaches us is that no matter how many special effects you pile up, some things remain the same throughout history.

reviewText: Going into Inception was kind of a gamble for me as my friends and colleagues apparently know me better than I thought.  I've been hearing this is the "one to check out" since the day it arrived in theaters this past summer and while my friends have once again proven spot-on with their understanding of the kind of fiction I enjoy, it is always worrisome when so much hype comes my way.  I have to make a very conscious effort not to get swept up in it, as that is the sure-fire way to become disappointed with any project (however ambitious).That said I was able to suppress my tendency to become the ultimate Inception fan boy until its home-disc release then quickly snatched up the Blu-ray with reservations on picking up a Leo DeCaprio T-shirt and matching coffee mug.  To cut the chase, I enjoyed this film quite a bit but perhaps not quite to the levels my buddies assumed I would and the reason for this stems from the fact that some of its finest conceptual moments have been done before in various mediums.  However, we'll get to all that.  For now, let us get to the nuts and bolts of the picture.Inception tells the tale of Dom Cobb (Leonardo DeCaprio), an Extractor (a man who enters people's dreams to gather information).  With a team of dream-experts consisting of Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), Ariadne (Ellen Page), Eames (Tom Hardy), and Yusuf (Dileep Rao), Cobb is hired by Saito (Ken Watanabe) to implant an idea (a unproven process called Inception) into the brain of Robert Fischer Jr. (Cillian Murphy).If this sounds a bit muddled to you, then perhaps steering very clear of this picture will be your best bet.  For all of its intricate explanations, Inception is a venerable swirl of intense sequences that demands multiple viewings if any coherency is to be established.I liken the initial viewing experience to the first time I went though the original Matrix (another Warner Brothers piece with similar themes): The line between reality and the construct is quite hazy and the laws separating them aren't quite clearly understood despite plenty of exposition attempting to force-feed them to you.I suppose in the interest of the average viewer's sanity, Christopher Nolan was forced to integrate a technique that I personally am not too fond of here in that when the situation demands it, suddenly the rules established earlier on are said not to apply "in this situation", hence upping the level of danger to the characters involved.  Again though, given the complexity of the material here, it is far more forgivable than if used in a more-linear piece.And speaking of linearity, I will continue to summarize the plot without giving away any real spoilers.  Cobb could well be the ultimate mind thief except for one minor annoyance: The appearance of Mal (Marion Cotillard) who tends to turn up in Cobb's dreams and jobs, botching them out of spite.  Additionally we learn that Cobb is a proud daddy in the real world and that motivation to be reunited with his kids is the catalyst for his agreeing to such a risky assignment.In fact, so delicate is the act of incepting a persuasive motivation that it demands Cobb and company to enter into a dream within a dream within a dream! Each depth of the subconscious mind said to be far riskier, more unstable, and (what I found to be coolest of all) operating in its own relative speed.The film is pretty stunning, visually, right from the onset with undeniable attention paid in the merging of gritty, moody dialog sequences with larger-than-life mind-bending effects.  Direction is spectacular here as well with camera moves and angles that dazzle continually.  Hans Zimmer's score is spot-on as well.  Truly from a technical standpoint, the piece is a stunner.The 2.5-hour runtime happens quickly and efficiently thanks to roller coaster pacing and a bit of disconnected editing work.In all, if having gotten this far in my review and aren't sure exactly how I feel about the piece, that's a pretty accurate observation.  Parts of this one are brilliant but unlike 1998's The Matrix or the 2005 novel Human Interface (both of which present some very similar mind-bending concepts), portions of Inception (especially the twist at the end) leave a flavor of forced existentialism.  There is potential for greatness here in every single moment of the picture but appreciation for it all takes time to settle in much in the same way one doesn't guzzle a bottle of fine wine.I suppose in conclusion the goal of science fiction cinema is to entertain and there is little doubt that Inception delivers in this regard.  It is certainly thought provoking, unique and technically impeccable.  I will conclude this review with a quote from the film that best describes the experience as a whole:  "Dreams feel real while we're in them. It's only when we wake up that we realize how things are actually strange."

reviewText: Inception is the kind of film that you either love or hate. Just head over to any movie review website and you will see this first hand. I myself absolutely loved it. The idea of entering people's dreams is certainly not a new premise in Hollywood however, with that being said, this film take the concept to completely new heights. As the title of my review states, very few directors could have pulled this scrip off successfully. It could have easily become convoluted, confusing, and bogged down with exposition. Christopher Nolan does a remarkable job and I have no doubts that is mostly due to the control he had over this film as he wrote, produced, and directed.I don't want to give too much away in this review so ill give just the basic premise and its actually quite simple. People can enter other people's dreams and steal information. Leonardo Dicaprio's character, Dominick Cobb, is one of the best at doing just this and ultimately he winds up being hired by Ken Watanabe's character, Saito, to enter a competitors mind but this job isn't about stealing information, its about planting an idea in this persons mind, a process called Inception. Were led to believe by many characters that such a thing is not possible yet Cobb disagrees and takes the job.That's as far as I will go in regards to actual details about the film as I don't want to ruin anything for anyone. Ill simply say that it winds up being one of the most complex science fiction films I have ever seen yet Nolan never loses control with this film. Everything is masterful sewn together and the experience is second to none. Everyone gives an outstanding performance especially Leonardo Dicaprio, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Marion Cotillard, Tom Berenger, and Joseph Gordon-Levitt. Tom Hardy's performance in particular really blew me away. This film would not have been the same without him.I simply have to mention the score as it was absolutely brilliant and ultimately its one of the best scores I have ever heard. I have to admit I was surprised when I heard Hans Zimmer was the composer. Don't get me wrong Zimmer is a master but his work is usually more predictable and his scores always seem to have a similar feel to them. His work with Nolan on The Dark Knight and now Inception have really pushed Zimmer creatively and ultimately Inception is a different kind of score than I think he's ever delivered before. In all honesty if someone had come to me with this soundtrack a couple months ago, before I saw the film, and asked me to guess who the composer was, Zimmer would have been one of my last guesses. It really is one of his most original compositions.Bottom line - Inception is hands down one of the best films I have seen in years. It has an amazing story, a great cast, some outstanding special effects and one of the best scores I have ever heard. In the hands of most directors this film would most likely have been a blabbering mess but Nolan's dedication to detail makes the delivery of this film practically flawless.5 stars!!
summary: A Film Very Few Directors Could Successfully Pull Off.

reviewText: Those were the first words that came out of my mouth at the end of the movie- ingenius. I will be very brief.This is a very complex film that plays with your mind on so many levels. Nolan, has taken something very difficult and original, and open the doors for his audience to think outside of the box. Taking us on a journey, searching for the meaning or hidden meaning behind our mind. He is able to do this with such elegance, an excellent cast, superub score, beautiful & stunning filmmaking, and an awesome script.Many people these days need to be spoonfed every single thing they see, hear, and touch. If it is not going BANG BANG BANG or POW POW POW- then it is not something worth acknowledging or viewing. I feel sad for these individuals, because I am a critical thinker, you do not have to have a doctoral degree to enjoy Inception but you do have to think.For those of you who didn't get it. Or found it boring. I saw this film with my brother who is 11 years younger than me. He said it was better than Dark Knight. I said to him many people have short attention spans- and cannot deal with a movie that makes you work, challenges you to think, and makes you wait for your ending, and his answer was "I have an short attention span and this is the movie of all times!"So, there it is. The movie of all times. Nolan did something refreshing and new. Oh yes you get BANG and POWS, but the BANG and POW have meaning- and you have to actually take your brain off the gas and watch the movie.Inception is in a category all by itself.

reviewText: BLU-RAY:I just finished watching Inception for the second time. The Blu-ray is amazing. The PQ and AQ are perfect in every way. I did notice that the video was not as sharp, crisp, or clear as The Dark Knight. However it was very, very good. The audio is very bass heavy, but is up there with some of the best Blu-ray AQ I have heard. The movie was stunning all the way through and after another watch it is just as good if not better than the first time I watched it.The special features are great. Disc two is full of behind the scenes and a dream documentary by Joseph Gordon-Levitt. On the first disc there is expansion mode which takes you behind the scenes and shows you each special effects scene and all which went into creating it. It is really interesting to watch. Very little CGI special effects were used on this film. They actually did most of the stunts or build huge models. It was really cool to watch.MOVIE:I went into Inception thinking very positive and with high hopes that this will be one of my new favorite movies. I based this simply on the trailer. I was not let down in the slightest, and I was blown away by the originality and creativity of the film. The directing, acting, and cinematography were all amazing. It is a beautiful film.After seeing Inception I will have a hard time watching any other movie ever again. Anything else would seem boring and useless. I went to see The Expendables in theaters. Horrible. I couldn't understand what the interest in this film was. It was just violence and explosions; No story or plot. Just useless violence.I can see where people may think of Inception as something similar to the theme of the Matrix. It sort of has the same basic idea of people being hooked up to a machine, leaving their bodies and going somewhere else. Besides that, there wasn't much at all which reminded me of the Matrix. Each scene held its own new originality in the most creative way as possible.As far as Inception being hard to follow... well, I had no trouble following it at all. The three friends and my eleven-year-old brother had no trouble following it. I believe people who are more open minded would follow and understand it much better than people who are not willing to believe the story. Parts are incredible to believe, but you have to be open and let the story take place.The creativity and attention to each shot and scene really paid off in the end. The film was perfect in every way in my opinion. Things were done which we have never seen before and it was done so well. It has set a new standard for films, at least in my mind. The directing style is similar to The Dark Knight, however they seemed to give Christopher Nolan more creative freedom with Inception.The acting was top notch. I liked that Leo's character, Cobb, seemed a little weak minded at times. Usually he plays a strong character, but in this film his character had a weakness. Joseph Gordon-Levitt played a larger role than I expected. I was impressed with his character as well. Most of the crazy stunts, anti-gravity, jumping off walls and fighting people in mid air kind of stuff were with his character. Very cool. Ellen Page played a young architect which is hired to build cities within a person's mind. She did a great job as well. Each character was so well thought out and everyone added just the right amount to perfectly blend each character into the story.If you're a fan of films which touch on subjects which most movies dare not go, you owe it to yourself to see this film. You won't be disappointed. I am very glad I got to see it on the big screen.VideoVideo codec: VC-1Video resolution: 1080pAspect ratio: 2.40:1Original aspect ratio: 2.39:1AudioEnglish: DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1French: Dolby Digital 5.1Spanish: Dolby Digital 5.1Portuguese: Dolby Digital 5.1English: DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1French: Dolby Digital 5.1Spanish: Dolby Digital 5.1Portuguese: Dolby Digital 5.1 (less)SubtitlesEnglish SDH, French, Spanish, PortugueseEnglish SDH, French, Spanish, Portuguese (less)Discs50GB Blu-ray DiscThree-disc set (2 BDs, 1 DVD)Digital copy (on disc)DVD copyBonus View (PiP)BD-Live
summary: A Dream, Within a Dream, Within a Dream...

reviewText: Having more certainty of Christopher Nolan's originality than his film's absolute cohesion, I really wish there might have been some way to approach this material as a trilogy because there is simply TOO much to establish in a single-sitting.  So much of the dialogue is so heavily leaden with exposition that it was difficult to actually connect with the characters speaking it.  There were so many characters to introduce that there was little or no time to actually develop them.  And, most troubling, there was NEVER any explanation as to HOW one actually enters someone else's dream, and THAT was something that NEEDED to be explained!  Were the characters in someway psionic or did the little machine they carried in a briefcase do all of that for them?  Had this been a trilogy, then maybe some of these issues could have been explained as courageously as they were executed.  Inception is a good movie, but had the concept REALLY been hammered-out in advance it could have been a cornerstone in cinema history!I find myself still wondering about the true motives of Saito. The target within whom he has hired Dom Cobb's team to implant a self-destructive yet compelling notion never once showed even the faintest hint of the ruthless aggression that Saito, himself, routinely displays. One wonders if Saito's true motives were to delve deep into the psyche of Cobb rather than that of his announced target. And, to complicate matters even further, just why is Ariadne so insistent on being on Cobb's infiltration team? Was the real person she was trying to lead out of the labyrinth Saito rather than Cobb? She was, afterall, recommended by Cobb's father-in-law; what reason would HE have to believe his son-in-law innocent of his daughter's death when every authority who investigated the case believes him guilty?When I began asking myself these and other questions, I began to get the sense that Cobb's point-of-view may be no more reliable than Leonard's in Memento. I cannot help but wonder if Cobb's mind was the actual target for infiltration in order to bring HIM to justice for the death/murder of his wife.  What better way to assess his state of mind than to personally witness his very own memories of these events?In any case, if you enjoy thought-provoking art that raises more questions than it answers, then Inception is definitely a film worthy of an evening at the theater. It allows the demons that haunt the protagonist, and quite possibly other characters as well, to manifest in ways so consistent with the film medium that I wonder if this story would even work if presented in a purely written way. Subjective doesn't even begin to describe this film; there is almost no way one can spoil this story by droping a tid bit here or a tid bit unless you insist on taking said tid bit at absolute face value. The more I think about it, the more convinced I am that NOTHING in this film can be taken at face value!
summary: Could there be a more fitting title for something this original?

reviewText: I don't work for NASA, I'm not a nuclear engineer or chemical physicist...hell, I'm not even all that bright. Perhaps if I was would've enjoyed this movie. Is it a dream, you're in the dream, your in my dream, that's his dream, go into their dreams... What the hell is going on? Nolan created a slick atmosphere, but this type of story is well suited for a novel. I was so confused after keeping up I sadly said forget it. Everyone I talked to who saw it said they had to see it multiple times to understand. If I have to do homework for a movie, I pass.

reviewText: I will make this simple for you. If you think American Idol is good programming, If you give a damn who Snooki is or if you think Stephanie Myers is talented this is NOT for you. In other words, I suggest you have a brain to really enjoy this as well as an open mind and a lean towards Sci-fi couldn't hurt either. Nolan uses great visuals and techniques to tell a multi-layered story set in the world of dream-espionage. As someone who despises Leo I still managed to love the movie despite him. This movie could be difficult to follow if your not used to using your brain while be entertained but people who read for enjoyment or are used to sci-fi worlds should be able to enjoy this without spraining your brain.While their are some very forgivable flaws it was clearly one of the best movies of the year. Those who say it is not original are really looking for an excuse to attack the movie. In a world where Hollywood has done everything twice and every movie you see is a remake or blatant rip-off of something else this is as close to original as I've seen I've seen in a long while.
summary: Sleep, perchance to dream. I will make this simple for you.

reviewText: INCEPTION, I think, is a fine film to watch on a rainy day if you are looking for something twisty-complicated that's meant to make you think a bit.I though the acting was solid.  Leonardo perhaps plays it a bit low-key, but the performances of the other characters make for a good complimentary match so that it all works.The special effects were realistic without that corny over-the-top thing that Hollywood typical goes for.The storyline isn't entirely new, but it's woven in a convincing way and you don't need very much suspension of disbelief to be tugged along.SUMMARY: Great performances of a less than awe inspiring plot. reviewText: I was first introduced to Inception during a five-minute preview before the showing of Sherlock Holmes (2009) and was mildly intrigued by the snippets that were presented in the teaser trailer. Basically, I assumed the film would be another Prestige (2006) and came to the conclusion that Ken Watanabe was a 'magician' of some sort and was involved in 21st century espionage (among other things) and that Leonardo DiCaprio was assigned to hunting him down. Of course, when I heard that the film was about invading the subconscious of the dreamer and stealing or implanting ideas in the mind, I wondered how the hell that would turn out. So, on a rather spur of the moment my family and I decided to see this film and went off to the theaters.Sufficed to say, I enjoyed this movie and found it to be one of the simplest films Nolan has directed since Batman Begins (or even Insomnia) despite his efforts to confuse his audience with his ideals and opinions of how the mind works when a person is asleep and dreaming.The story, simply put is this:Inception follows the tale of Dominic Cobb and Arthur (Joseph Gordon Levitt), thieves for hire sent to steal an ideal from a man called Saito (Ken Watanabe). When their job is botched by the sudden, but not unexpected, appearance of Dominic's deceased wife, Mal (which, for whatever reason, is pronounced like "Maul"), they plan to lie low for awhile until the incoming heat from the man they were hired by blows over. Instead, Saito reappears and offers Dominic a deal he can't refuse: The chance to return to Stateside and be reunited with his children, whom he 'abandoned' when proper authorities decided to label him as his wife's killer. All he has to do is infiltrate the mind of a man who is on his way to controlling the the most powerful energy conglomerate in the world and convince him to dissolve his dying father's company via "Inception" (the ability to implant an idea into the mind of a dreamer and have them believe the idea was theirs). Despite Arthur's reservations towards the job, naturally, Dominic says yes and assembles a motley crew of former/new associates and one young college student named Ariadne (Ellen Page) who steps in to become their "architect" (a person who creates a dream scape to fool a dreamer into believing their in the real world and not dreaming) and prays the job gets done without a hitch. Naturally, it doesn't and when the group find themselves stuck in their target's mind (with one of their own mortally wounded) with no possible way of escaping, they bite the bullet and decide to go through with the plan in hopes of escaping back to reality.What follows afterward is Christopher Nolan's "How to traverse a Streamlined Subconscious 101 during a botched mission" with a combination of your typical action/adventure summer fare. And such a description is not to say that the film was terrible. On the contrary, it was a very composed film and did it's job well. However, in concerns to the dream scape universe presented in the film, I'm afraid that was far too simple and not at all like a dream. While Inception's initial (and obvious) inspiration may have come from "The Matrix (1999)" --- a film that does a superb job of playing with the themes of dreams vs. reality and bending said reality ---, it truly fails on that level to capture the same sort of surreal atmosphere. Dreams are nonsensical and jagged at best and therefore, cannot be as normal as they were presented in this film. But I suppose for the sake of coherency, it had to be. And while the idea is hinted a lot at in the film, there is never a moment in the film where the characters ever question their reality (outside of that one sequence with Ellen Page in the beginning), whether or not they are dreaming, it's just mentioned alot.That aside, a lot of people have said "You'll need to see this film a couple times to truly understand it" and that's simply not the case (at least not for me anyways). As mentioned before, this is one of Nolan's simpler films. It doesn't mean to surprise likeBatman BeginsorThe Prestigedid in 2005 and 2006, but it does test your level of patience and dedication to it's storyline with it's length, much likeThe Dark Knightdid in 2008. This film, like TDK, is a half-hour too long and really needed to be trimmed down.Another downside is that, while the performances in the film were great, a few of the characters are, perhaps, too monotone for their good. With the exceptions of Ellen Page's Ariadne (who, next to Joseph Gordon Levitt, is the highlight of the film with her everyman character), Tom Hardy's Eames (who's character can be characterized as that "smart-arse Brit with a mind for deception, 'Sherlock Holmes'-esque disguises, a taste gambling and fast women") and Cillian Murphy and Dileep Rao, who's characters are as human as they can be in a Nolan film, actors like DiCaprio, Watanabe, Levitt and Marion Cotillard (who plays Mal) have characters that could easily be exchanged between them because their devoid of any real personality outside of "serious business" (welll, maybe not Cotillard).DiCaprio's Dominic is simply defined by the loss of his wife and the need to return home to his children, outside of that there isn't much to him beyond that broodish facade. It pulls on the heartstrings to be sure, but it's not a character I became particularity attached to or concerned about. Levitt's Arthur, as smooth and likable as he is, is just another straight-faced character, brilliantly realized within the context of his ability to act with so little and one of the best action sequences I've seen in a long time (he also steals every sequence he appears in).The special effects waver between rather telling (folding the city on top of itself, the limbo level) and near seamless, action sequences are gripping and brilliantly choreographed (The Zero-Gravity fight on the second dream level). Hans Zimmer's score, while not his best in the least, takes a cue from Sherlock Holmes (with a touch of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 See: "Mombasa") and manages to be both different from his usual soundtrack and suits the atmosphere of the film as well.Overall, I loved the ideas and most of the execution presented in this film. Inception manages to be somewhat original with it's premise and will without a doubt dazzle audiences for its two and half hour stay on the Silver Screen. --- [A 4 out of 5]

reviewText: I was very disappointed with this film. I had considered going to watch this movie in the theatre because I assumed the special effects would be great and considered that the story might be one of those that takes you on a truly emotional journey. Ultimately I decided not to watch it in the theatre and now I'm glad that I didn't miss anything! Yes, the visual effects of the film are nice, but even those are less than what I thought they might be, and if you have seen the trailers for the film you've already seen the best visuals the film has to offer.The story was interesting at the outset, but even at its most convoluted times was still never dynamic. I kept waiting for the film to pull me in and give me that emotional connection resulting in that rare cinema buzz you sometimes get from that type of film that takes you on a journey that engages you, but this film never delivered, at least not for me.I suppose there was some effort to try to take you down the philosophical path of how it can sometimes be difficult to separate fantasy from reality, but even this path was barely a scratch in depth. It could simply be that the writer or director, whoever was most responsible, lacks depth themselves in order to bring this film into something more than surface-level eye candy.The film was certainly adequate enough from a visual standpoint, and Di Caprio is always great - best actor of my generation I think. The rest of the acting is adequate but nothing special. The film is little more than eye candy with nothing important to say.Blockbuster films like this one I tend to judge more harshly than I do a film that is not a blockbuster or to which I have little or no expectations of. I think most of us do that, it's simply a reality of life that when you are let down or disappointed you react more negatively than if you had little or no expectations to begin with. That said -FINAL GRADE: C-
summary: A visual film that is lacking any real depth...

reviewText: I am not exactly sure how anyone can say this movie was terrible.  Christopher Nolan is in a completely different class.  He writes and directs many of his movies himself, and the movies are completely original.  I have not seen many of the other movies up for best picture, but I don't see this one is not the clear favorite.  Social Network was good, but not best picture worthy.  This movie surpasses all the hype that went along with it and is, just like it's director, in another realm altogether.I cannot say much more about this movie that hasn't been said after it's release, but this movie had me enthralled from start to finish, and the finish is what proved to me why it was so special.The acting was amazing as well.  Leonardo Dicaprio has grown up since his days on Growing Pains, who knew the sarcatic homeless kid who outsmarted Mike Seaver would become a superstar.  Not to mention the alien kid becoming a well known actor as well.This movie made me think, just like another film by Nolan, Memento.  Both of them totally blew me away.  Those people who say they don't understand it, really must have a hard time focusing.  It's quite clear if you keep yourself immersed in the movie.  The ending is open for interpretation, but I don't think I would've liked it as much without it.  That is what separated this movie from any other.This movies ending is the best ending of any movie out there.  I challenge anyone to find one better.  I didn't think any movie could touch The Usual Suspects ending, but this one blew it out of the water.The whole dream within a dream idea in this really proved interesting, and the idea of trying to plant an idea in someone's mind by having them think of it themselves.  That is totally unique and mind-provoking.
summary: A hype movie that surpasses the hype

reviewText: I'd give it 3 1/2 stars.This film is worth going to the theater to see.***  spoilers belowWhat bothered me initially about the film was that the dreams just didn't seem very dream-like.  Most of the dreams were way too detailed and clear, and seemed too strict in following the logical patterns the film set for them.  Most of the dreams lacked the surreal touches, the dreamy fuzziness as portrayed in other much simpler films like "Dreamscape".Because of this I just couldn't completely buy-in-to the story, I never 'lost' my self in the story.  And I think for me this made some of the more complex details of how the logic behind dreams operated seem somewhat distracting and annoying... for example, Having to figure out why some of the characters seemed to easily leave the lower 'Purgatory' dream level and others apparently could not.Also some important rules followed by the 'induced' dreams of the film appear to only apply to those types of dreams and not to natural dreams...  I know this may seem obvious but I think the film unnecessarily blurred the line between the 'nature' of the  induced and natural dreams leading to some confusion.For example: If I have a 'natural' dream about having a dream, i.e. the so-called layered dreams (I've actually had dreams like this),  My brain won't operate at some hyperactive level causing me to have days, months or even years worth of experiences while only sleeping for hours (as the movie said could happen in their induced layered dreams).Another thing I had a lot of trouble buying into was that the characters involved in multi-layered dreams left some sort of 'ethereal' bodies asleep at the lower dream levels (while they are experiencing an upper level).They have one (Just one) 'real' body in the real world, that's all.e.g. I could go along with the idea that the 'Chemist' might experience the others as being in a drug induced sleep while he's driving the van during that wild chase scene.But why would the others have any connection/dependency-on the Chemist's perception of their sleeping bodies at the lower dream level?For example, If one of the character's faux asleep-body was shot in the head while in the van, why should this have any effect on them (once they've passed on to and are experiencing another dream level)?In other words, when their minds move on to another dream level I see no logical reason why they would be leaving behind some bizarre dream-sleep body(ies) at the lower levels.They might DREAM that they are waking up from one level to the next but to say that they actually leave behind some sort of sleeping dream-bodies seems silly to me.--------------- ------------Perhaps the single most dream-like scene of the film was when Cobb was trying to escape from some pursuers and he gets stuck in an alley-way which narrows to an extraordinary extent.  In a nightmare it isn't uncommon to have something inexplicably slow your progress while trying to escape from pursuers.The problem with this scene is that Cobb wasn't in a dream when this happened...  or was he? ;-)That's one aspect of the film I liked a lot, there seemed to be hints now and then that we are still actually watching a dream when the characters were supposedly awake...Didn't the Cobb character say there was a danger in composing a dream too close to your real-life because you could no longer distinguish between the two?
summary: Worth seeing. I didn't buy-in-to everything.

reviewText: Most movies these days bore me to tears because the scripts are banal.  Inception is an exception to the rule.  I can see where some people might get confused by the multilevel dream thread, but I think the editor did a good job reminding us of the original and subordinate dreams.  If you can, or better yet want, to keep up with it all then this is a fun ride.  I'll agree with the critique that it is too darn long.  A one star hit from me because I think thirty minutes should have been edited out.  That said, I can see where the filmmakers maybe cleverly wanted to pull the audience into the effect of the exponential increase in time for each dream level.  Honestly it didn't feel like 2.5 hours to me, but my wife said it did to her.  This is a very unique movie and I enjoyed it thoroughly...a rarity in these times of cookie-cutter formula movies.  Bottom line: highly recommended.

reviewText: This movie is stunning to watch.  The effects are mesmerizing, like dreams themselves.The way the movie handles dreams is wonderful (although the technique of having characters explain them is a little clunky).But there are some problems.First, the male characters are (mostly) one-dimensional.  I love Leonardo DiCaprio, but his relentless intensity gets tedious.  His sidekick's stonefaced stoicism is also a little wearisome. Cillian Murphy's unwavering astonishment is appropriate for the character, but it leaves him shallow.Much better are Eames, who has several sides, and Watanabe, who evolves interestingly as the movie progresses.(The two principal females evolve wonderfully.)But worse than this is the POINT of the whole thing.All these amazing worlds with their interesting conflicts and tensions are all created so a BIG CORPORATION CAN BE BROKEN UP?????????Puh-leeze.Yes, the whiplash world-changes are interesting in themselves, but the final resolution is a big let-down.OK, the resolution of Cobb's family problems is mildly engrossing (though predictable).  Likewise the return of the ancient Watanabe to life.But the corporate theme is simply silly.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan had a really interesting idea with Inception. It's basically an inverted heist flick with a gimmicky backdrop. Now, that would be fine, if 1, the gimmick in question made any sense, and 2, the film did not make itself out to be more complex than it is. The movie has the tagline "your mind is the scene of the crime", and reviewers have been raving about how awesomely mind-screwy it is (neither description matches Inception). Inception is straightforward, and most ways that it could have deviated from that don't work.Why should someone knowing that an idea is not theirs prevent them from pursuing the idea? The Amazon user SuperHiro put it perfectly when they said "I may not have originated the idea of me wanting to be a billionaire, but does that mean I still won't try to do it?" But why do they even need to go into Fischer's head to convince him to break up the empire? It would probably have been simpler to just manipulate the guy in real life or something. All of this makes the whole movie feel pointless.There were a lot of problems, inconsistencies, and loop-holes with the dream concept. They say that when you induce dreams, the more dreams that are within dreams, the more hyperactive your brain has to work. In the real world not much time at all would pass, but in the dreams, it could be weeks, months, and even years. But layered dreams happen in real life all the time to lots of people. How come "natural" dreams don't have this problem? Doesn't add up to me. Another thing is that when you move on to another layer of the dream, you leave behind an ever-sleeping version of yourself. I suppose this makes sense, you have to go to "sleep" while in a dream to access another layer of it, but the weird thing is, whatever happens to your sleeping body happens to the other-level you. Gravity changes, environmental changes, injuries, this affects your body in the other level. But why should the left-behind bodies have this effect? I see no reason for this to happen at all.Lot of things had me scratching my head. How does Ariadne being able to draw a maze in two minutes that takes one minute to solve (which she drew on her third try) mean that she qualifies better than experienced adult architects? How does it prepare her for the dreams? Why does Ariadne need to go on the actual mission with the team? How the heck does Eames shape-shift? Why is the limbo pocket space filled with only Cobb's ideas no matter whose dream the team is in? Why would only Cobb's mental problems affect other people's dreams? If "kicks" can affect multiple dream levels and the flight attendant is in on everything, why doesn't she just push them out of their chairs on the plane? When Cobb was stuck in limbo, why did he use inception to convince the other person to leave by suicide, thus causing the idea to stick with the person forever, ruining their life. He could have killed them just like that, they would have woken up quite fine. Why do they keep saying that inception is impossible? They say that the mind can always trace the source of an idea and that it rejects whatever it doesn't want, but that sounds really half-baked to me. After all, Cobb did an inception effortlessly by himself.Why doesn't Fischer recognize Saito? They're corporate rivals. Fischer should know who he is, he is the head of Fischer Enterprises and it's made quite clear that he has done much work for the company already. He goes on long business flights regularly and has gotten training to protect himself against extraction. So Fischer should have recognized Saito on the plane. It can be argued that he would notice him in an early dream level, but not in the later ones, because dreams cause confusion. But there are absolutely no sings of Fischer realizing Saito is on the same plane as him, or that Saito is invading his early dream levels, or that Fischer has become bewildered by later dream levels and completely accepts Saito like it's nothing. This Fischer/Saito thing is one big blatant plot-hole.On the side of characterization, Inception fails. DiCaprio's character is alright and is a reason for the viewer to be emotionally involved, but I feel like I've seen his story before. And what about everyone else? I think that Joseph Gordon-Levitt as Arthur was a very flat character. Tom Hardy and Dileep Rao were really funny to me, but they didn't have enough to do and felt underused and underdeveloped. Ken Watanabe actually plays a larger role than I expected and in my opinion was very interesting, but again, underused and underdeveloped. My biggest character problem lies with Ellen Page as Ariadne. Cobb already has an architect at the beginning, but that guy is quickly written out. How convenient. The only reason Ariadne exists is so that the movie can explain everything to the audience. Often times the other characters have to stop and communicate new aspects to her, not to very good effect on the pacing. Outside of using her to spoon-feed the viewer, Inception doesn't really have anything for Ellen Page to do. Her presence is annoying and prevents the movie from being more fast and fluent.Most of the time the action it just the heroes blasting away at gunman projections of the subconscious, and nothing ever happens to them even though they're at point blank range. The shoot-outs, or probably just the action scenes in general, tend to drag on and I lost a lot of my interest. It doesn't help that none of the dreamscapes are all that different from real life. I was honestly expecting a lot less hard physics to apply. I thought that actually going and planting an idea would be cooler. I guess I expected more adventurous/dynamic/creative things to happen. One of the reasons that the protagonists are not taking advantage of the dreams was that the mind's projections would sense an abnormality and attack the intruders. Thus it would be a bad idea to make crazy structures or materialize objects and stuff. But the projections attacked relentlessly anyway, and this strict rule prevents Inception from doing more than just several truly imaginative things. But this brings up more questions. If Ariadne is the one building the dream worlds, why doesn't she just include an area that would make projections die? She does have control over a person's psyche, so it doesn't seem like projections should really be that much of a big deal. It also has to be wondered why projections wouldn't automatically notice that they are in a constructed dream and that new comers have been placed inside with them.Inception was constantly advertised by reviewers as a big riddle that you have to figure out yourself. This made me assume it was going to a movie you can watch again to clue in on subtle hints. But there's no riddle, no complex mystery, nothing like that. Inception is simple and certainly not as smart is it wants to be. As if to somehow redeem himself, Christopher Nolan tried to pull a "twist" ending, but don't be fooled, it's nothing of any substance. To explain it I'd have to get into spoilers, so look out.SPOILER ZONE BEGINSSo at the end, Cobb gets back home and he sees his two kids doing the same thing in the same location as when he saw them last time. He's got his totem, he puts it to spin on the table, and it's wobbling, so it looks like it's going to fall soon...and then black smash cut, roll credits. What? Woo, look at us, we have an ominous ending that can be interpreted in different ways! No, fail. Look, the totem looked like it was going to fall down, and in dreams it's not even allowed to get to that point. Plus, Cobb finally gets to see the faces of his kids again, and he was always distracted from that in his dreams, so this should be reality. It also appears it's just a coincidence that Cobb's kids are in the same place doing the same thing, because in this last scene it's confirmed they're actually wearing different clothes, and the first time they appear in the movie they're played by younger kids. And how could he still be dreaming anyway? What, someone went and made a dream world for him? I don't think so. They would have to create an entire LABYRINTHINE PLANET. Lastly, even if it's all just a dream, then what the hell is the point of that? Where's the payoff from over two hours of film? A dream ending would be way too gimmicky and contrived. If it's all a dream, it's never going to be explained, thus it's a big slap in the face for the viewer.SPOILER ZONE ENDSI would not have been so disappointed with Inception if it had just capitalized on its own simplicity and made its own unique/cool parts logical. If you're looking for a generic action movie that can make you feel intelligent for following it, go ahead and check out Inception, you might be compelled to jump on the bandwagon. As for anyone else, don't waste your time.4 out of 10
summary: It shouldn't take itself so seriously.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Endlessly inventive.  Thoroughly engaging.  Fascinatingly complex.  Thought-provoking.  Very entertaining.These are the phrases I can apply to each of Christopher Nolan's films.  "Inception" is his 7th feature film, and it is a well-crafted thriller of the highest order.  It's almost impossible to describe this movie, because there really isn't a whole lot like it.  Sure, there are elements of "The Matrix" when the characters dig into their own minds, or the James Bond 007 series when the action sequences kick into the final stretch of the story.  But "Inception" cannot be reduced to those other pictures; the story is unique because of HOW it's told.Leonardo DiCaprio plays Cobb (the same name for Nolan's thief in the criminally-overlooked "Following").  Cobb is a thief of the most unusual kind: He's paid to steal the secrets of powerful men.  From the getgo, "Inception" challenges and demands you give your full attention.  Fans of "The Prestige" and "Memento" will sink into this mindset relatively quick, as Cobb's attempts to steal from Saito (Ken Watanabe) become increasingly complicated when a few characters begin to resist Cobb's mental theft.  The targets begin to shoot back.  A woman from Cobb's past sabotages his efforts.  The dream world begins to collapse.After the operation has gone sour, Saito still enlists Cobb to work for him to complete another job is by assuring him that he will be allowed to see his estranged family after being exiled for reasons I won't reveal.  The catch: Cobb and Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) must perform 'inception', meaning to insert an idea into Saito's rival for his own personal gain.Viewers may become initially lost at the outset, but like watching a Shakespearean play or sitting through a season of "The Wire", if you remain patient and just catch the jist of the scene, you'll catch the hidden subtleties as the story progresses.  "Inception" isn't an impenetrable mind-bender, but it moves at a swift pace for its 2 and 1/2 hour duration.  Thankfully, there is an early sequence where Cobb enlists a new architect (Ellen Page), where we begin to understand how this dream invasion is even remotely possible.  What are the rules?  The objectives?  The risks?  This sequence where Paris is reassembled in front of our eyes is very well-written for the viewers' convenience.As Cobb assembles a team to invade Saito's target, his inner demons and complexities reveal their ugly heads as the planning begins.  As with most action thrillers with a team of protagonists, things go horribly wrong.I don't want to reveal what exactly happens and why it happens, but I think it's fair to tell you that the first half is pretty much the setup of the Inception, while the second half is the execution of the plan while the team faces unforseen risks.  Throw in Cobb's confrontations with his dark past while immersed in the dream world, "Inception" becomes a very tricky balancing act of drama and thriller, and Christopher Nolan is equal to the task....Mostly...Before I get into my quibbles with "Inception", I want to be clear:This is a first-rate picture from a masterful filmmaker.  Audiences should see it, and audiences will certainly enjoy it.Where "Inception" is going to be nitpicked is whether this is indeed a masterpiece, and in my opinion, it isn't.  This has nothing to do with the insurmountable praise from "The Dark Knight" or the indie smash "Memento".  The flaws from "Inception" belong only to "Inception", regardless of Nolan's prior work.There is one basic element that I thought could've been better:"Inception" is simply too long.  To address Nolan's previous work, his two Batman features were lengthy pictures as well.  But in those two movies, the plot was constantly moving and evolving.  There simply wasn't any way to keep all of those storylines and make the movies shorter.  "Inception" would be just as, if not more, effective if it were trimmed a bit.  The stunning action sequences are simply too long in the final act, and even the dramatic revelations and conclusions are too long.  Considering how the story ends and where our characters end up, the film's 144-minute length isn't fully justified.Everyone will admire "Inception"'s exciting action stunts & shootouts, and the dramatic payoff of the story.But I believe most fans will love one of those elements, and simply 'LIKE' the other.  I'm not convinced that "Inception" is going to be universally praised for both of those aspects.However, with "Inception", it's biggest problem is that it has too much of a few good things.  In this case, less would've been more.  But whereas most blockbusters don't earn their lengthy running time, "Inception" is a such a terrific piece of entertainment that it's not a deal-breaker.  I once read a quote from Roger Ebert, "No good movie is too long, and no bad movie is too short."  Christopher Nolan's latest work is a very good film, and it is a bit too long.  But Nolan's enormous talent is stunning enough to tolerate the excesses of his latest acheivement.  Ellen Page's rookie becomes so drawn into the dream exploration because "It's pure creation", and so are we."Inception" is a marvelous piece of pure creation from one of the cinema's most gifted talents.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Overall, this was a good science fiction-type film, but after two viewings, I do think it's being overrated.  Once you understand the multi-layer scenarios, you also start to see a number of holes.  The film is worth watching and better than most, yet over a period of years, I do not see it making its way into the top ten of many critics' lists.  The premise is not entirely original (see Dreamscape from a few decades ago).  The film asks us to believe that if a person dies during some level of their dreaming, they will die in reality -- much in the same way that Star Trek's Hologram room could prove lethal if set to maximum -- much in the way of "Brainscan," an almost two-decades old movie -- much in the way of "The Matrix."  In all cases the notion is ludicrous.  So is the idea that someone could "live" 50 years at a deep level of sleep while in reality the subject might have been unconscious for a few hours or whatever.  The life-threatening scenes encountered by the inceptors seemed like clippings from a James Bond film.  Not only that but with their very lives in peril (within the context of this script), you'd think there would be more at risk than the success or failure of a business espionage endeavor.  Once you start to dissect some of the premises of "Inception," you'll realize a good portion of it is pure hokum.  At a first viewing, you will be kind of dazzled, perhaps confused, but, nevertheless, entertained in a way that is almost subliminal.  Discriminating viewers on a second watch will start to see the pitfalls.

reviewText: Inception is a great movie, one of the best action movies of the year. It is nothing if not a concept movie, science fiction which often seems on the brink of fantasy, but actually has some basis in reality.Fast paced from beginning to end. Inception is based on the idea of Lucid Dreaming, a difficult to master skill wherein the practitioner develops the ability to consciously recognize within their dream that they ARE dreaming and then manipulate the content of their dreams. This is a real endeavor which takes a great deal is discipline and years of practice to achieve. People do this! see "Exploring the World of Lucid Dreaming" by Stephen Laberge.  But they only can manipulate their own dreams, if that.The plot here, within giving away much you won't see in the first ten minutes, is the hero Cobb (another hard role for Leonardo DiCaprio, like Shudder Island) is trying to alter the dream not only of himself, but of someone else, an industrial magnate, Fischer (Cillian Murphy), using a team of dream architects and manipulators - Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), Eames (Tom Hardy), Ariadne (Ellen Page), and Yusuf (Dileep Rao). Sort of industrial espionage. This part is Sci-fi - it can't be done, at least not now. To borrow an information Technology concept, the magnate has nested dreams, dreams within dreams within dreams, five layers deep, like nested do-loops! Cobb and the Dream Team seek to implant an idea deep within the subconscious of the target and give him the idea he thought of it himself.Inception has fabulous special effects, as you might imagine. The actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt  (Arthur),  playing a dream manipulator, was on David Letterman's Show talking about this movie and he said the director Christopher Nolan made minimal use of the omnipresent Blue Screen CGI technology for special effects and actually had Gordon-Levitt and others suspended from wires instead, in many dream sequences, to make them weirder and less, well special-effecty than CGI. There is a spectacular special effect in Montmartre, in Paris, where a dream architect folds the whole city over on itself like a half peanut butter sandwich! This effect is certainly blue screen CGI, but others where the director turns the whole room was done with actors, wires and a turning room like the Fred Astaire movie where he dances on the ceiling!The story? Five layers deep in nested dreams the motivations get pretty murky. There's a lot of car chases, poorly motivated bad guys as we deal with Cobbs subconscious contents/demons. But is all exciting and fun anyway and a special effect tour de force. What a concept! Keeps you on the edge of your seat for two hours or so. Sci-fi and fantasy people should like this movie, IT people, younger males etc but the viewer has to pay attention.The movie poses the philosophical question: what is there underneath all the dreams?Back to reality, this movie is sci-fi, but there are places in this country where experimenters with Lucid Dreaming discovered that two lucid dreamers can, under some circumstances, have somewhat shared realities within their dreams, as fantastic as that sounds. Really! see Silva Mind Control books and Robert Monroe...
summary: concept movie - nested dreams in special effects tour de force

reviewerName: R. Attila "If honest work and justice are not...
reviewText: Not much more to add really. I managed to watch this farce for about half an hour, I desperately wanted to give it a chance, but every passing minute is such an insult to my intelligence that I cannot carry on. Then I tried again to continue, because I thought it's not fair to rate a movie without watching it to the end. But then again, I'm not a masochist.This film is the perfect example of how movie success depends hardly on movie quality, but almost solely on marketing. The same happened with the Matrix a few years back. Farcical setting, totally unrealistic story, but great marketing: Box office success.You probably already know the deal, unfortunately I was unsuspecting before I tried to watch it: Getting into other people's dreams, creating a believable world in the dream where multiple dreamers can interact with each other, and in this way, collect important information from the mark. Of course the dreams also have dreams within, and it's hard to know what is real and when your're dreaming.Whatever. No idea why anyone would WANT to watch this, other than because of the hype. But the hype has very little to do with the quality of the film. This film's whole focus is on the farcical notion of creating dreams for people, and especially, interacting with other characters in the dream who are dreaming the exact same dream. If the film were not so consumed by this outragous technicality, and it had some character and heart, some sort of purpose, I could probably let slip the ridiculousness of the whole theme. I have been known to enjoy the odd sci-fi. But this lacks any heart, all it does is try to look smart.I find it grossly unfair that this junk rates above 9 on IMDB and 4.5 stars on Amazon. However, my rating of 1 star is not because I want to bring the total down, it is rather what I think the realistic rating is.

reviewText: I just finished seeing this movie, and I absolutely enjoyed it. The concept was what I loved the most.  Yes, the picture had its share of special effects and CGI, but the reasons for them were always clear, and they served the plot so very well. The multi-layers of action going on were the driving force behind the picture and kept it going. So, if that kind of story doesn't interest you then Inception is not your kind of picture. But if you like movies that explore the mind, dreams, and the different levels of consciousness, you will enjoy this movie.  For me, the special effects were just a really cool way to show what was happening in the mind as opposed to the use of some abstract, slow, surreal, lifeless way of showing this. The acting was well done by all the players, and there were times when the tension was almost unbearable. Thanks, Christopher Nolan, for a great adventure.

reviewText: I've said that about so many movies but the euphoria passes about some time after it's done. So I figured I'd wait 24 hours to see if this euphoria has passed... looks like it hasn't. Bram Stoker's Dracula was my favorite movie, I now have to reconsider.Inception is an AMAZING movie. For one, it has one of the most interesting plots I've ever had the good fortune to witness. Look at it. Stealing/planting ideas through dreams. Entering others' dreams. Completing tasks in dreams. This stuff is what I like. The plot was very complex and multi-layered, and therefore there was so much to offer in the plot. Not a single moment went by where I wasn't interested.The visuals are AMAZING. I was blown away when Cobb was showing Ellen Page how the dream world worked, with the folding city. As well as the scenery in the Arctic. The sets looked vivid and gorgeous. They complemented the film's great plot and IMO, were very creepy and brooding too.Another reason the movie is so great is because it uses ambiguity THE RIGHT WAY. A lot of filmmakers (*ahem* Michael Haneke, I'm looking at you!!!!) think that senseless manipulation equals a great movie (to a lot of people nowadays think it does and because of it, they rave about it like it's second coming of Jesus), and this one doesn't senselessly manipulate the viewer. It challenges the viewer to piece together the puzzle and find out the answer. Yet it has plenty of exciting action and suspense to offer, and it doesn't beat you over the head with the theme. You're getting your adrenaline up during the action while simultaneously piecing the puzzle together.The ending. WOW. I'll be thinking about this one for at least a month. It uses ambiguity the right way too- I am personally leaning towards the "he's still dreaming" side, but I definitely like the ending a lot because he could be in the real world too. My friend and I both decided last night that he's lost his mind and is in limbo, but that's what makes the ending so powerful. You interpret it your own way. See this is what I wish a lot of the pretentious directors who go for the "open to interpretation" approach did more often- end it AFTER the resolution of the conflict and then leave the one element up to the viewer to decide. It can be interpreted many ways.The movie is VERY long. 2 hours 28 minutes. But it didn't feel long at all!! I seriously thought it was only 1 hour 45 minutes. That's the thing, when you're so into a movie, when your attention is drawn to it for that long, when you're trying to piece together the puzzle, time flies so fast. I didn't even get up from my seat once and mind you I'm VERY bad for having to go to the bathroom.Last night I lay wide awake in bed thinking about the movie. I tried to sleep but I couldn't. The movie was very powerful, it made me think about it. I was thinking about it on the way home from the IMAX. My friend and I were talking about it the whole way (and ruining it for people on the bus lol). It goes to show you how powerful a movie can be. It leaves you thinking, and I'm STILL thinking about it as I type this. I am really glad I saw it.As over the top as I may sound, I am not trying to sound over the top. I really loved it. WAY more than the Dark Knight. I'm seeing it again on Wednesday, and I cannot wait. This movie is the best movie I've seen this year and maybe the best I've seen in general (I do not make that up, and have seen several movies in a lifetime alone).
summary: My new favorite movie. SPOILERS INCLUDED
