reviewText: I will not criticize the score.  I will not criticize the casting, acting, or efforts of the crew.  Inception's concept has merit and potential.  It has the makings of greatness, especially in its final scene.This is the first Chris Nolan film I can say that's disappointed me.  And this is coming from someone who's studied the nonlinear cut-strategy of Memento while in film school, down to the diagram level.  That was my idea, not thrust upon me by a professor.  Though my hesitations did start some with the trailers' not-so-subtle homages (read that as: total rip off) of certain scenes from Dark City, I really did give it the benefit of the doubt going in... hoping for the best.  Yes, the trailers thrilled me in spite of my feelings that the "highest form of flattery" was using a euphemism in this case.  I wouldn't fault anyone for doubting my sincerity after admitting that, but I was excited for this film even with the aspects of the trailers I found disturbing in their derivativeness.  Come on, this was clearly an attempt to recapture the themes and visual motifs of the late 90s that were a seeming artistic lineage dead-end as an unintended consequence of the cognitive interruption that was 9/11 and 8 years of Bush The Decider.  If it was me in Nolan's place, I would likely have borrowed from GATTACA and The Matrix, too, though hopefully with more finesse.So I was thrilled at the prospects of a return to that era of transcendence and artistic progress that was then; a return out of the dark ages of the last decade.  There has undoubtedly been some stagnation during this time and I've been feeling lately that we, in the Western World, are beginning to pick up where we left off: the re-immergence of electronic music as a major  movement, the recessing of jingoistic country music and pop ideals, from passiveness to active engagement, and a social & philosophical inquiry that delves deeper into the nature of consciousness and the human experience far beyond the transient, topical issues of the day, into something with immortality to the art.And in my opinion this film unfortunately fails at that.  Perhaps it's a problem of pacing throughout.  The forced contrivances of the first act trying too hard, too quickly.  Maybe the use of a rather unethical corporate espionage plotline against someone for which we've developed no animosity for.  Then there's the possibly unavoidable here but nonetheless detrimental Deus Ex Machina of seemingly last-minute expounding upon the rules with more jargon and redefining convolutions of them to further both the plot and suspense.  There is an undoubtedly manufactured, written, unnatural quality to the film's twists, reveals, and arc that remind me of the singular clumsiness in The Prestige when we found out the diary was a ploy.  But that was one instant of the seams showing, and briefly passed.  Here, though from an audio/visual standpoint there are no overt seams, they are painfully apparent in other ways: emotional and structural.  It lacks parsimony and elegance, but not due to length.Could it be helped with not only a slightly improved cut, but a different structure or tone from many, even small, changes throughout?  It has certainly happened before, as with Blade Runner.  Is the footage available for it to be improved?  Can the pacing, call-backs, reveals, and dissemination of Inception's rules be made as organic and natural as these convincing somnambulant universes the film's characters inhabit?  Or is the film a mirror of, and as deconstruction-inducing as, the moment those sleeping realize they are in a constructed maze, meant to misdirect and manipulate their intellect and emotions?  Is the nature of this concept too disruptive to the film form?  I don't know.  I have a nagging hunch the film may have been too reliant on its aforementioned influences and lacked sufficient inspiration of its own.  But I can't help believe there's a chance it can be reshaped again, as good as any totally original concept.  Reading this review back to myself, enough of this film has obviously worked its way under my skin and into my psyche.  There is definitely something there, something at an intersection of zeitgeists that has slumbered during this last decade, waiting to get out.  There is just enough new and so much heart in the project, I dream of a better Inception.
summary: An Ambitious Disaster that (so far) Pales in Comparison to its Predecessors

reviewText: Unknown to the majority of the populous until late 2009/early 2010, Christopher Nolan was not attempting a directorial debut with Batman Begins, The Prestige, or The Dark Knight. No. He directed said films to gain experience for an idea which had been simmering in his mind for almost a decade:Inception, which was to be his breakthrough as a major feature film director. Though not as highly successful overall as The Dark Knight, which mainly received such favorable reviews because of Heath Ledger's posthumous Academy Award, Inception was a success in its own way: subtly brilliant, with a plot simple enough to comprehend but twisting enough to keep your attention.The score, composed by Hans Zimmer, is fantastic. Though perhaps not his best composition work, it definitely earns him a place among his greats. Leonardo DiCaprio is an amazing actor as always. Ken Watanabe fully captures the corporate businessman's enigmatic role. Marion Cotillard, Ellen Page, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Cillian Murphy, and Michael Caine are each persuasive in their own way, making the characters believable as well as drawing the appropriate emotion out of you.The plot is an obvious Nolan brainchild. Who else would compile such a brilliant and stunning script and successfully tie it together for one brilliant finale? Not many.Watch this movie. Find the time: it will be worth your while. Christopher Nolan is one of the greatest director's of our time, and he will be until his career has come to a close.Rated PG-13For Intense Sequences of Violence and Action throughout

reviewText: Inception is a wonderful film on several levels.  It is a fine science fiction film.  It's a great action film.  Awe inspiring special effects.  But the part of the film I was especially interested in is the questioning of reality.  Of course the cosmos is made up of matter and energy, true reality.  But what humans know of as reality is our state of consciousness. And our conscience is not merely a recording of the matter and energy we can perceive.  Our conscious can make things up.  And made up stuff is part of our reality.  What is real?  Is it just what we can perceive or does it include what we create, what we dream?  Is consciousness always a dream, even when we are awake?  The point is our whole universe is really, really in our mind.  Our consciousness is all we know, all we can know.

reviewText: Babble - nonsensical dialog - whatever you call it' this movie has more than you'll find elsewhere.  Little makes sense - dream in a dream in a dream? Sounds like an idea derived after a weekend of recreational drug use. "Dude - I had a dream I was dreaming!" "Cool - let's make a movie."Basically this was an excuse to show off special effects. The idea of being trapped in a dream - and not knowing it - is old hat. Nothing to see here. Move along. So what we have is an unoriginal plot (dream in dream) using another idea stolen from the movie "Dreamscape" (enter a dream to gather information or change the dreamer's real-life actions) with a bunch of B-list actors.Just because the end is intentionally hazy does not make this a "great" movie or a "mind bender" - it makes this a poorly executed rip-off from several other movies.

reviewText: Zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz......Oh, geez, I just woke from a dream/nightmare that I saw a really terrible movie that was like the bookend to "Shutter Island" - another movie featuring a Leonardo DiCaprio who (in his recent batch of flicks) comes across as a one-note, angst-driven actor who seems constipated and in dire need of a suppository or something .....He had more range as a teen: "This Boy's Life,"  "Gilbert Grape," even the soap opera "Titanic"...but anyway, as I was saying I....zzzzzzz.......Oh, yeah, when will acting and script writing and character development ever reclaim the throne of Hollywood from the Frankenstein Monster that is CGI???  How many explosions and bombings and crashes and shoot-outs and falling buildings will it take before the great American audience becomes punch-drunk and insensate to all of this carnage?  Maybe - scary thought - it already has.  I hope I am only dreaming that it has! Will I ever awake to a nightmare world where the word 'subtle' no longer has any meaning?????  Have I already awoken to that sensation-satiated world???Okay, dreams.  Watch "Perchance to Dream" - an episode of the original TV series "Twilight Zone" - and in less than half an hour you will see everything that is in this 2 hour and 45 minute billion buck bomb (production cost and the eventual rake-in and potential sequel)....and you will see it related poetically, imaginatively, creatively.  INCEPTION is a mad jumble not knowing what the heck it really wants to be: at times it seems like a James Bond movie with Bond wired-up to record his REM state. It also is very similar to "Shutter Island" (and Leonardo's performance in this film is just a continuation of his work in that other open-ended, non-ending, what's real/what isn't study in tedium.)  I was also reminded of the old TV series "Mission Impossible" every time the one INCEPTION character turned into Tom Berenger....reminded me of Martin Landau's ability in that old TV series to look like anybody on the planet.  The never-ending free-fall fights in the motel hallways that went on and on and on and zzzzzz....oh, sorry, where was I?  Oh, yes, those fights had me thinking the hero was Spiderman without the mask and costume - and then we come back to James Bond.  The winter assault on the mountain fortress had me wishing I were watching "On Her Majesty's Secret Service" instead - the only outing (sadly so)for George Lazenby as Bond, but a good movie - and it climaxed with a commando raid on the villain Blowfeld's snow capped mountain that was extremely similar to the snowy shoot-outs and blow-ups in this pile of film.  And I never was so lulled into a state of near coma as I was during the constant cut-backs to the slow-mo falling of the van into the water and the shots of the sleeping occupants inside with their listless arms floating about like Dr. Floyd's while he slept en route to the moon in zero gravity in a true cinematic masterpiece - "2001:  A Space Odyssey."The idea of dreams within dreams goes back to forever...and the "inception" for this film may well be a line from Edgar Allan Poe's poem "A Dream Within a Dream": "Is ALL that we see or seem...but a dream within a dream?"  As a matter-of-fact, the second stanza begins: "I stand amid the roar of a surf-tormented shore..." which also reminds me of the beginning of this film, with our hero face down on a shore with the waves rolling in.  The poem itself was written in 1849.Anyway, it is curious that this extremely over-done action packed, overblown musically scored, veritably one-note acted film dealing with Dreams....almost had me falling into one of my own, right there in the theatre! But, to be honest, I think that the most outrageous thing in the whole flick was the......zzzzzzzzzzzz

reviewText: With all those special effects, it's difficult to rate the acting ... but who cares??  With all that CGI and special effects, you don't need acting in an action-adventure film, right? To me as long as a movie takes me out of the 'everyday' world, keeps me guessing, and entertains me - that's as much as any of them can (or should) do!  :)My only problem with Amazon movies (all of them), is that my HD TV seems to not be able to allow me to hear those low-dialogue moments which some films have a lot of ... this one left me wondering what some actors said, and hoping the movie wouldn't have too many scenes like that ... it was okay, but I wish that Amazon had the audio quality of Netflix ... especially for "Hi-definition" quality films; I have no problem hearing whispers on Netflix movies on my TV, so why do the Amazon movies seem to drop the audio?  I have no idea, but I refuse to give five-stars to any Amazon film until the audio quality is enhanced!

reviewText: Director Christopher Nolan (The Dark Knight) once again proves to be one of Hollywood's finest filmmakers in the spectacular science fiction thriller Inception. In the near future, exists the technology to enter the human mind during the dream state, and international thief and spy Dom Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his team of specialists are among the very finest at extracting valuable secrets deep with a person's subconscious. When offered a chance for redemption, Cobb must perform an almost impossible task: the implantation of an original idea into a person's subconscious. Not only one of the most acclaimed and successful films of 2010, Inception is also one of the most original and well structured thrillers to hit the big screen in years. The movie is one of those rare big-budgeted summer Hollywood productions that not only delivers stunning special effects and great action but an engrossing storyline and notable performances. The cast also includes Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Marion Cotillard, Ellen Page, Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy, Dileep Rao, Tom Berenger, Ken Watanabe and Michael Caine.If you're planning to add Inception to your Blu-Ray collection, it will surely standout among your other titles. The acclaimed Sci-Fi thriller is presented in 2.4:1 widescreen format. The Blu-Ray boasts with an excellent picture and audio presentation. The picture transfer comes out almost perfect with rich colors and striking contrast. The DTS-HD Master Audio ranks as one of the engaging audio tracks of any 2010 Blu-Ray releases. Among its most interesting special feature is the Extraction Mode with Christopher Nolan, cast and crew whom provide great behind-the-scenes information. Other supplemental material include theatrical trailers, TV spots, promotional and picture galleries, and two behind-the-scenes featurettes (Dreams: Cinema of the Subconscious & Inception: The Cobol Job). The Blu-Ray release of Inception scores an "A".
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is Christopher Nolan's masterpiece. The Dark Knight is still my all-time favorite film, and I think that it is better, but this is HIS masterpiece. He managed to create his own personal intellectual property, not based on any previous work. Since Batman has thousands of comics to build a great film around, it took a lot less to bring The Dark Knight to life, than it did to create Inception. He easily outdid himself with this one. Everyone is going to talk about how smart the movie is. How it requires your full attention, and so on. I'm not going to beat a dead horse. Yes, the movie is brilliant. Yes, you do have to use your brain to enjoy it. There's not a hundred explosions and acrobatic stunts to keep today's action fans excited, but fans of every genre should find something here. The concept of entering another persons mind is such a brilliant thing to work with. The only other movie I can remember like that was The Cell. That film has absolutely nothing on this one. Ten years in the making, this is a movie that everyone and their grandmother should go to the theatre, pay whatever for the tickets, and let your minds get blown. I hate to be a fanboy, but it's so hard not to fall in love with a film that obviously, the creators took their sweet time with. The attention to detail is something of beauty. We don't get enough art in our modern films. Most blockbusters are dumb fun, and not much more. Chris Nolan consistently breaks that stigma, and defies what we've come to expect from Summer blockbusters. He always knows how to cast his films perfectly too.The acting is great, in my opinion. Not everyone was perfect, but everyone was very believable. Leo DiCaprio is creeping his way into my favorite actors list. He is today's 1970s Robert De Niro. Ellen Page is always great, and she's no different here. Joseph Gordon-Levitt...seriously. Does anyone not like him? No offense, but if you don't like Joseph Gordon-Levitt something is wrong with you. He's not an up and comer anymore. He's officially a big deal. Get used to that face, and get ready to up his paycheck Hollywood. Michael Caine is one of my favorites, so I'm not going to linger on him. I love everything he does. Tom Hardy is great as well. I only knew him from RocknRolla, but he was great there too. Ken Watanabe is still Ras Al Ghul in my eyes. I hope he keeps working with Nolan. I can go on and on about the performances. They were just all so great. Since I'm starting to sound like a broken record, talking about the "great performances", I'll just mention the last few actors, and it's understood that they were fantastic. Okay, so Cillain Murphy, Tom Berenger, Dileep Rao, and of course the beautiful Marion Cotillard...all made an impression. There so many facets to this film. The score, by Nolan favorite Hans Zimmer, was phenomenal. I love his music very much. The score is still playing in my head right now. The screenplay was unique, yet still felt very much like a Christopher Nolan story. His movies all feel almost exactly the same. His style is so predictable, yet it never gets old. I loved this movie, and . No matter how great the film is, the best part about it finally being out is that The Dark Knight Rises is right around the corner.
summary: "Your Mind is the Scene of the Crime."

reviewText: One of the most lauded films of the summer of 2010, INCEPTION is a big, bold, fascinating, gorgeous film that puts the brains of the audience to work.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really stir the heart very much.  But you'll be hard-pressed to find a more technically assured movie.  Or a movie with such an attractively diverse cast.  It's a film that isn't afraid to be rich, even dense, with plot.  It has creativity coming out of its pores.  It is pretty engrossing throughout (though I'd say it is about 10-15 minutes too long due to a few moments of slack pace).  It just didn't grab me emotionally...and it's amazing how important that is, because even though it had all the things going for it that I mention above...it didn't truly EXCITE me.In case you haven't heard, INCEPTION envisions a world in which the idea of entering the dreams of others is a reality, and in fact, is a small, lucrative industry.  In this industry, trained extractors and their teams are able to enter the dreams of their subjects to extract secrets.  It's industrial espionage to the highest degree.  It's tricky work, because it's easy to alert the dreamer to ones presence.  But for master extractor Leonardo DiCaprio, it's all in a day's work.  Along with his partner Joseph Gordon Levitt, he's the best at what he does.  Which is why he is hired by Japanese industrialist Ken Watanabe to enter the dreams of the son of a rival industrialist (Cillian Murphy) in order to plant an idea into his mind.  This is the theoretically possible, but certainly highly dangerous, concept of Inception.  Planting an idea is difficult, and the results are not always predictable...as DiCaprio knows all too well.  He had a bad outcome involving inception and his wife (Marion Cotillard)...a mistake that continues literally to haunt him and which is increasingly affecting his dream-roaming abilities.  His team knows he's the best...but they also see that he is liable to put them into great jeopardy.Because the idea of inception is so complex and involves delving into a dream within a dream within a dream; writer/director Christopher Nolan is obliged to provide us with a lot of back-story & exposition about the conundrums of wandering into and influencing the dreams of others.  To ease his efforts, he introduces a new member to DiCaprio's team, an architect who must construct the dreamworlds they will implant in Murphy.  This architect (Ellen Page) is new to all this, and so much of the early portions of the film involve DiCaprio explaining "how this all works" to Page.  It's all needed in order for the viewer to follow what comes later...but these scenes have artificiality about them.Once the inception begins, INCEPTION becomes a tightly wound thriller.  It's sci-fi, true...but the science-fiction is really just trappings for a good, old-fashioned cat-and-mouse movie.  To be honest, I can imagine Alfred Hitchcock tackling this subject matter.  Thrillers wrapped around psychological drama.  Just as James Stewart becomes undone by the memories of his wife and the appearance of her lookalike...so DiCaprio unravels at the memories and dream-appearances of his wife.Nolan likes to construct movies that are puzzles.  MEMENTO was somewhat like putting together a Rubik's cube...nearly impossible.  It was pure puzzle, with real efforts at character and emotional heft pushed way into the background.  THE PRESTIGE was like the biggest budgeted episode of THE TWILIGHT ZONE ever...with the tricks of stage magicians melding with true magic in a story full of twists.  Neither of these films really pretended to have any deeper meaning...they were meant as entertainment for audiences who didn't mind being very attentive to detail and having their minds stretched.  This made them exciting.  INCEPTION has many of the same flavors, but wants very much to be about something more.  It wants to be about the power of dreams and entering dreams.  It explores the damage the process can cause.  However, we all know that we can't really jump into the dreams of others...so all the deep psychological territory Nolan explores has no bearing on what we experience in the real world.  It only illuminates the psychological condition of man in a world in which entering dreams is possible.DiCaprio is clearly the main character and the nominal hero of the film...and he's an actor I have often admired, even as others have criticized him.  And he has excellent chemistry with the volatile Cotillard.  But much of his mental state feels like a concept and not fully integrated into a believable character.  His anguish often feels generic.  His anger feels generic.  His intensity, for the first time, feels like "oh, here is DiCaprio doing his thing again."  Fortunately, the film is packed full of other truly exceptional performances.  Cotillard is truly emerging as a force to be reckoned with.  Ellen Page, even in a thankless role, is never less than compelling:  she's clearly a fiercely intelligent person and it's so nice to see this intelligence allowed to flourish on screen.  The delightful Tom Hardy, as a team member, steals most scenes he's in through simple charisma.  Dileep Rao makes an excellent scientist.  Murphy, though sometimes a bit wooden, does a good job overall.  Gordon Levitt provides a convincing stolidity as DiCaprio's long-time extraction partner.  He's a dream-walking professional who isn't tormented by personal demons.  It's the first role I've seen him in that totally discards the "kid actor growing into a young man actor" vibe he's had for awhile now.  He is now an adult actor, who simply once was also a child star.  Tom Berenger & Pete Postlewaite are welcome in small roles...and Nolan favorite Michael Caine shows up in a two-scene role that makes us wish he was in 10 times as many scenes.  It's hardly a new observation for me to make, but Caine is truly a giant of the screen.  Does the man even know how to be anything less than the most interesting person on screen when he's in a scene?Technically, the film is a wonder.  The dreamscapes that are envisioned are marvelous, and even though they are certainly heavily reliant on CGI...the CGI is top-notch and convincing.  Watching Paris fold in on itself is something worth seeing in the theaters.  The musical score is often intrusive...but it is meant to be.  The score truly helps build the sense of dread that Nolan is going for.  And best of all is a series of scenes involving Gordon Levitt fighting some "bad guys" while the hotel hallway he is in keeps spinning around.  It feels a little like something we might have seen in a MATRIX movie...only executed about 10 times more convincingly.  Later, Gordon Levitt has to move all his companions (who are busy dreaming) into an elevator.  The method he uses to complete this, while gravity has lost its grip on HIS world, is quietly fascinating.  Simply put, the film is endlessly inventive when it comes to visuals.I highly recommend INCEPTION.  It is intellectually stimulating and is frequently quite exciting.  Most of the performances are top-notch.  (And frankly, I don't think the puzzle is all that difficult to keep up with...don't believe critics who say you have to see it twice to figure out what's going on.)  It just doesn't quite grab you in the heart.  I was always interested, always engaged, but never swept away.
summary: A treat for the mind and the eye...not so much for the heart

reviewText: Inception (Christopher Nolan, 2010)Ever since Memento hit the streets ten years ago (we'll not discuss Following, his boring first film, except to note in passing it's getting a theatrical re-release either later this year or next year), Christopher Nolan has been delivering popcorn films that have pretensions at real depth. Pretensions, yes, because while they're usually clever, looking closer reveals that there's not really much to be seen. And there's a small part of me that feels I should be castigating Nolan for this, in the same way I despise the Wachowski Brothers for the same sort of "it looks deep, but it's really not" they pulled in the Matrix movies. The difference is that, most of the time, Christopher Nolan is a filmmaker orders of magnitude better than the Wachowski Brothers, and his popcorn tastes a whole lot better. (Both of the exceptions, the aforementioned Following and the awful, awful 2002 remake of Insomnia, suffer from not pulling off the illusion of depth, rather than suffering from bad filmmaking.) Inception, both written and directed by Nolan (though I swear I heard somewhere a while ago that this is loosely based on a Philip K. Dick story; I just can't remember where I heard it, or which one), is the latest manifestation of this trend.Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio, taking a break from his longtime association with Martin Scorsese) and Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) are extractors, guys who can slip into your subconscious and, essentially, spy on your thoughts. Obviously, this has a great deal of use in the industrial espionage arena, and as we open, they're trying to get the plans for a business expansion out of Saito (Ken Watanabe, who previously worked with Nolan on Batman Begins), an industrial magnate. After Arthur, who engineered the dream scenario (more on that later), screws up a small detail, Watanabe realizes that the dream is a dream, and the whole team is in jeopardy. It doesn't help that Mal (Marion Cotillard, recently of Nine), a projection of Cobb's, shows up to throw a monkeywrench into the works at the worst possible time. After they're back in the real world, however, Saito does the one thing most captains of industry don't think to do in real life--he's impressed enough to hire them. He tasks them with inception, the impossible (by conventional wisdom) task of planting a memory in someone's mind rather than extracting one. His offer: charges that prevent Cobb from returning to the United States will be wiped clean, and he will be able to return to the children he hasn't seen in years. Thus, Cobb and Arthur start putting together a team. First, they hire an architect, Ariadne (Juno's Ellen Page), to design the dreamscape. A fellow extractor who also happens to be a mercenary, Eames (RocknRolla's Tom Hardy). And a chemist, Yusuf (Avatar's Dileep Rao), who can make the compounds that will both keep the subject, Robert Fischer (28 Days Later...'s Cillian Murphy), asleep and stimulate his dreams. It's Eames who hits on the perfect avenue for inception: make Fischer himself believe he's a part of the team and that they're trying to get secrets from Fischer's father's right-hand man, Browning (Tom Berenger, who has been gone for far too long from blockbusters). And at the last minute, Saito insists on coming along as well...First off, how is it that I've been hearing about this movie for an entire year, I've seen trailers for it at least once a week for the past six months, and I had no idea that Joseph Gordon-Levitt, one of the best actors of his generation, was in it? Way to drop the ball, publicity department. For that matter, most people seem to have only heard "DiCaprio", "Page", and "Nolan", which seems an insult to the incredible cast assembled here, which also includes Pete Postlethwaite, Michael Caine, Lukas Haas, and a handful of other folks you'll recognize. But all is forgiven once butt is actually in seat and things start blowing up, because while, as I said before, Inception isn't nearly as deep a film as it wants to believe it is (or wants us to believe it is), it is an incredibly entertaining one. Upon reflection, I think the reason for this is that Nolan is just as good with a troop of A-listers as he was with a troop of B-listers in Memento; just as he got career-best performances out of folks like Carrie-Anne Moss, Joe Pantoliano, and Guy Pearce, he whips a bunch of folks here into top form. This is (by far) Page's best performance since Hard Candy five years ago. DiCaprio and Levitt are always good, and DiCaprio has been turning in some monster performances since he finally shook off whatever slump he was in from 1997 through 2006, but this one ranks up there with What's Eating Gilbert Grape? and The Basketball Diaries. Murphy hasn't been this good since 28 Days Later.... Etc. And Nolan, of course, is a very, very good action director; there's CGI here, but it's used judiciously, and that alone in comparison to so many recent action films makes this stuff look real almost by default. Which is pretty impressive when one of your scenes involves folding Paris over like an omelet.I'm going to close out with much the same thing I said about Nolan's last film. As I write this, Inception is sitting on the IMDB Top 250 chart at #3, with a 9.1 rating. (Actually, all the top three films have a 9.1 rating; the others are The Godfather and The Shawshank Redemption. Which means it's actually tried for #1.) I think that's overstating the case, just as I thought the case was overstated with The Dark Knight (which, two years after its release, has slipped to #12, with an 8.8 rating), but not terribly much. There's no denying that Nolan is one of the best directors working today when he brings his A game, and he's arguably the best working today within the Hollywood system; anyone else I'd apply that moniker to is either working completely outside it (Kiyoshi Kurosawa, Shinya Tsukamoto, and Bela Tarr are obvious examples, though Julian Schnabel would also qualify) or make great films outside the Hollywood system and crappy films in it (Guillermo del Toro is a stunning example of this). Nolan knows how to game the system, and he's also clever enough to take a pretty basic idea and make it seem like it's a world-changing philosophy. It won't hold water when you start talking about it with your friends after you leave the theater, but does it matter? By that time, you will have been thoroughly entertained by some fantastic actors and a fantastic director, and isn't that what going to the movies is all about? ***
summary: Fun, but not nearly as deep as it thinks it is.

reviewText: I saw this movie twice at the theater and the first time I saw it I was a bit confused.  It's like Vanilla Sky in the way because it made you think is this reality or is it a dream?  The ending had be a bit confused, which I won't give away, but I think everyone comes out of watching this movie with their own thoughts or ideas.  I really like the acting as well as the visual effects in this movie and would recommend this movie to anyone who has not seen this movie.  The movie is 2 1/2 hours long but it keeps your brain thinking the whole time. I really enjoyed movies that make you think besides movies that are full of explosions and cursing that don't make any sense.

reviewText: I admire the level of detail by the several top reviews I read here, and enter this review primarily to draw those who follow my work on Phi Beta Iota the Public Intelligence Blog, to the DVD and the other reviews.This was the last of five movies I watched over the course of sixteen hours in the air, and it comes very close to making the cut toward six stars.  This is--for the intelligence and information professionals--advanced Information Operations and Cyber-Psychological Operations on steroids.  I found the movie compelling.  It is not perfect, but Leonardo DeCaprio and the totality of the production easily earn a solid five.  This is much more serious thanMinority Report (Widescreen Edition).  It is not as good as theSeventh Veil [VHS], but for a modern movie exploring levels of consciousness and how to implant, steal, and manipulate ideas inside people over the course of ten years, it is quite worthwhile.  I recommend it be watched along withWhat the Bleep Do We Know!?

reviewText: A team that is able to infiltrate someone's dreams in order to extract information is asked by a businessman to insert an idea into the mind of a competitor. The team leader undertakes this in order to return to his children, whom he has not seen since being falsely suspected of murdering his wife. This is a complex film that at first appears to have differing illogical sequences, but these are dream sequences, which cannot be fully controlled. The team has varying members of different skill sets, in order to maximize their ability to manipulate the dream environment. This is a visually stunning film, and if the viewer has patience and focus, "Inception" will payoff in the end.

reviewText: This is a delightful scifi film - it has action, fun concepts, well conceived little details that fit perfectly with the ideas, and beautiful, very good actors.  It held my interest, with the particular hard scifi pleasure of figuring out what was going on, seeking subterfuge and twists but also the fixed parameters of this future vision.  The subplot with the mysterious Cotillard character also worked extremely well for me, a bit of DiCaprio's subconscious but also a real figure; she was the most imaginative of all the constructs in the film, in my opinion.Unfortunately, I was rather disappointed with how fast the whole thing was resolved, like they had to tie if off because they had run out of time or money.  Also, I did not detect any mind-bending ambiguity that got the viewer to question everything at the end, which surely this film was made to do.  Taken together, the producers dropped the ball at the very end and turned it into a mere comicbook ending.  This is a great pity.
summary: intriguing, well acted, and suspenseful, but a bit too pat

reviewText: Movies are dreams and dreams are movies.  Both seem real while they're happening - just like life.  Christopher Nolan's layered journey into the lucid dreamscape challenges the mind and delights the eye.  What more can you ask? summary: ALL IS MIND.  AND A MOVIE, LIKE LIFE, SEEMS REAL WHEN IT'S  HAPPENING

reviewText: As of this writing, 1,046 people have reviewed this product, and most of it was positive. To me, that says you can't view this product and not feel strongly about it--strongly on the 3-5 star range, and it makes sense.There are those of us who go to movies or buy DVDs to be totally passive and entertained. Christopher Nolan's "Inception" is not one of those films. You need to pay attention. In fact, it was too demanding for one viewing, and that's okay. Sometimes I enjoy watching a film multiple times. The multiple viewings, in this case, were fine since so much of the film is just amazing to watch. The visual effects were nothing short of inspired.On the other hand, I hate feeling like I have to take notes while I watch a movie. Even if I have to really pay attention, it better be worth it, plotwise. ("Memento" is one of those films; so is "Pulp Fiction"). This one... myeh, maybe... okay, it is. There is a great deal of hesitancy (as you can tell) on my part to give this five stars. I think four is fair enough, and worth the $1.99 rental.

reviewText: Okay, while "Inception" is not Nolan's best movie ("The Dark Knight" still is though that might be my being very partial to the subject matter), it is still in that 5 star cap that I like to hand out to films that blow my mind open.  I'll go through this piecemeal to make sure I hit on all the things that go into building a good movie and why this hits so consistently.The acting is nearly flawless.  I am going to compare this movie to the other really good Leonardo DiCaprio movie out this year "Shutter Island".  Like "Inception", "Island" introduces several good actors in a clean sequence, helping to establish each their part in the overall narrative, each person plays their role with great line delivery, emotive strength, and with motivations that while not clear at the beginning, are revealed as the story progresses to give clarity and meaning to the whole of the performance.  However, I felt a deeper connection to Leo's performance in "Shutter Island", I don't know how, but I think that his performance was stronger there than here, but it is really the difference in temperature between a cup of coffee and a cup of coffee poured from the same pot 12 seconds latter.  If you have seen both movies you will be able to understand why the comparison between the two parts is so easy.  So I say near flawless because that is what it is, near flawless for the lead.The action is stellar, with subjective gravity, malleable environments, legions of soldiers battling in unique structures toward powerful ultimate goals.  If I would say one thing, at times one action sequence by Joseph Gordon Levitt completely overshadows the others so completely that it seems embarrassing, sure one guy turns into a combination of Little Nemo and James Bond, but Levitt turns into a combination of Neo and Eliot Ness, it is really good.  Also: not a lot of CGI, so the images on screen look real because they were filmed on real sets using wire movements and turning sets.The sci-fi concepts are introduced wholesale at the beginning of the movie in a way that makes you say something a long the line of "What's up with that?" and "What is going on there?"  Each part of the original illustration is then explained via the natural course of the movies narrative.  As a new character is introduced they display why they are important and in doing so explain what was present in the opening sequence.  All of this exposition is never done to the point of needless background, I don't care how the dream machine was invented, by who, or where, all I need to know is what it is and what it does, boom and boom both are explained clean, neat and concise.  It is smart and well paced in this way, using its strong visuals to make the world and dialogue become just to the left of real.  In other words: while they could use the dreamworld as an excuse to travel to different periods of history, fight monsters, and gain super powers, the movie keeps you grounded in military complexes and hotels that adequately uses the dream environment to create surreal action and adventure within a world real enough that the audience doesn't get turned off.Ambiguous in message and ending.  Watch the movie, the theme is a mind breaker, as is the chief conflict of the film, as is the major resolution.Strong and solid film throughout.  There is no major flaw that detracts from this movie.  There is no miscast person, no missed beat of action, no unnecessary conflict.  And while I have heard that some people are confused, I felt zero confusion, some people didn't get the message, I got the message entirely.  This is a superb movie that you need to go see.

reviewText: I saw this film at the theater, the first show, Midnight showing Thursday night.  From that night, I knew I HAD to purchase this film when it came out on DVD.  The people who say they fell asleep watching this film are the same ones who probably rushed out to see 'Prince of Persia' when it came out.  If you're not the kind of person who actually likes to think while they watch a movie, then no, this film isn't for you.  You will have to think.  I think it's extraordinary what Chris Nolan did with this film.  The idea of being able be inside of a dream, going deeper and deeper into the dream--essentially, a dream within a dream--is something I find absolutely fascinating.I love to see films that look like the writer/director put a little thought into what they were doing before they did it.  Many people just like to watch a movie and have the plot and everything else be self-explanatory.  They like to just be "entertained."  My idea of entertainment isn't mindless action sequences, drawn-out gunfights and unnecessary sex scenes.  I would much rather watch a film that requires the audience to actually think about what's happening and be completely involved in the film.If you don't like films like that, don't watch 'Inception.'  Also, if you do watch it, don't get up to go to the bathroom or to the kitchen for more popcorn without pausing it because you will DEFINITELY miss something.All in all, I think this was an amazing film and actually the only film that I actually like Leonardo Di Carprio in.

reviewText: I give the movie 2 stars for visual effects the rest gets zero. The whole concept was totally inane and not at all good Sci-Fi. The theme had potential. Had it depicted an experiment in mind control through manipulation of dreams etc it could have been more believable and entertaining. But the film goes way beyond this and suggests that the dreams somehow become real and that some virtual action in a dream can somehow bring about real action elsewhere. And it invokes multiple depths: 'virtual to virtual to real' etc. Don't worry if you think it is more complex than you can understand. It wasn't. It was stupid.The filming was annoying also. The action parts were excessively noisy and the dialogue parts excessively quiet. What's happened to the actor training programs? Why can't the performers speak up and enunciate their words so that we can understand what they're talking about?  Rent an old Bogart or Gary Grant or even a James Bond movie and you'll see what I mean.In this movie you have to turn the volume down during the action sequences and turn it way up in the talking sequences.Bottom line: The movie was a total dead loss.

reviewText: Finally, a mega-budget Hollywood blockbuster worth raving about!Christopher Nolan, the genius behind the last two "Batman" movies, hits new heights of creativity and imagination with "Inception," a sci-fi masterpiece about a technology that allows people to enter into the dreams of others with the express purpose of planting ideas into their subconscious. The concept is dealt with on such a complex level that, for a large portion of the movie, the characters are floating around in a dream-within-a-dream-within-a-dream. Yet, so intelligent is the writing and so meticulously thought-out the premise that the audience almost never gets confused about what's happening and, thus, can just sit back, relax and go along for the ride.And what a ride it turns out to be! Without getting too deep into the nuts-and-bolts aspects of the plotting itself, suffice it to say that the story involves a group of "dream manipulation experts" - Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, and Ellen Page, among others - who employ the technology known as Inception to enter into the pre-programmed dream of a young man (Cilliam Murphy) whose ailing father owns a giant energy firm. Their goal is to convince the son to break up the company after the old man (the late Pete Postlethwaite in one of his final performances) dies, so that a wealthy competitor (Ken Watanabe) will be able to pick up the pieces for himself. It's a tribute to Nolan's astuteness as a storyteller that he gives us this rather mundane overarching plot device rather than having the mission be about convincing someone to blow up half the civilized world or something equally over-the-top. This simpler motivation keeps the movie from sliding over into cautionary-tale territory - where most serious sci-fi works seem to eventually wind up - and allows us to concentrate more fully on the content and style of the dreams themselves.Another triumph for the genre is that the movie gives us a central character who's actually worth caring about. DiCaprio, the head of the team that goes into the dream, is a generally reformed "corporate espionage thief" who lost his wife (Marion Cotillard) as a result of a dream-traveling scenario gone awry and who has been wracked with grief and guilt over the incident ever since. As if that weren't bad enough, he's been forbidden to return to the United States, where his two small children reside, because the authorities mistakenly believe he was responsible for her death. It is only when Watanabe promises to get the murder charges dropped if DiCaprio does this one last job for him that he agrees to take on the mission. As embodied by DiCaprio, who, by the way, has never been better, Dom Cobb becomes the heart and soul of a movie that, given the genre's track record in that regard, could easily have had neither a heart nor a soul. Instead, Nolan and DiCaprio draw us into the picture with an emotional force rarely found in even the most intimate indie drama, let alone an effects-laden super-spectacular such as this one.And spectacular is certainly the word for the cornucopia of visual delights the movie offers up to its audience, as a team of FX wizards creates dream worlds of eye-popping complexity and design.Like even the best of films, "Inception" is not without its flaws. I could certainly have done without some of those skiing scenes near the end, and I'm sure there are enough holes in the plotline to keep perfection-seekers nitpicking and carping for years to come. However, I also imagine that "Inception" will be dissected and studied over by film students and film lovers alike in endless fashion, and that their efforts will lead to the discovery of themes, motifs, symbols etc., that are not readily apparent on a single viewing, when we're just dazzled by all the brilliance and ingenuity that's gone into the work.That's all the more reason for movie watchers to return to this cinematic treat regularly and often.

reviewText: ***Spoilers***It's difficult to understand how to approach this review, being that the film, itself, is so complex.. Is the linear story of a heist/inception of the Robert Fischer character really what's going on?.. Or, is their a deeper meaning?.. Consider the notion that maybe the Robert Fischer character isn't really the one the story is about, and that the "inception" is being planted elsewhere, and that the Fischer character is really a plant used to play out an elaborate psycho-therapy on the real target, Cobb himself.. This is a story about living with regret, and how it can consume us, and it's my belief the whole story is a dream that Cobb cannot wake up from.. The "inception being his kids, which of course, do not really exist (why would Moll and Dom choose to explore limbo for decades, with 2 young children?), they were only planted there (inception) by Moll, who is really still alive..This is why the ending is so powerful, cause the walking away from the still spinning totem represents Cobb's release from his despair.. A truly brilliant film..

reviewText: I've been a Christopher Nolan fan since "Following." But I'm disappointed that such an obviously smart director has so quickly allowed himself to be assimilated into the Hollywood blockbuster mentality. Granted, he does the mega-budget, computer-graphic, eye-candy movie better than most, but he could be doing less expensive & more interesting films. "Inception" is just ok (though numbingly familiar) to look at--for about an hour. Then, if you're inclined toward concise, engaging & original films that do a lot within a small space--such as classic noirs or eccentric but really fascinating art films like "Fallen Angels" or "Last Life in the Universe"--this is hard to sit through. It's much longer than it needs to be, and clumsily confusing--despite stopping the narrative every now & then to explain what's happening & whose dream we're in, which tells you there isn't total confidence in the viewer. Or in the movie itself. Finally, I didn't really care whether I was in a dream within a dream within a dream--or just dreaming I was at the movies. Nor did I particularly care about the sentimental idea of getting back to his real-life kids. (Or, hey, do they even exist? Wow!) Being a cinephile of sorts (ok, I dislike the term too), many friends I've talked with who have a similarly broad, extensive experience with film have agreed. (Read David Denby's review in "The New Yorker," which nails the pretensions & problems here.) It's a kids' film, a flashy but cheesy puzzle film, and finally a shaggy spinning-top story. Who cares if the "reality token" keeps spinning or topples? I waited this long & then Nolan won't tell me?  Not that it mattered at that point. I was just happy to have done my cultural duty & was free to return to a world that, dream or not, is far more interesting than "Inception."
summary: I know, I'm in the minority here, but...
Title: N/A

reviewText: INCEPTION could have been named INCEPTIONS or CONVOLUTIONS and a movie promo might say "Take notes or your mind will melt". For me, viewing number three was more scrutable and less frustrating; at my rate I may even get to enjoying it by, say, the fifth or sixth time. There's a plus point: you can see it again and again and be surprised.Who does the whats and hows, how consequences unfold or wrinkle every which way depends on your concentration. I refuse to take notes, so maybe new synapses are being burned in m'brain every time through. Or around and around.For some who get off on Rubik Cubes, chess and the on-line memory enhancement sites this puzzler of a picture will be embraced. Those who view movies for easy entertainment... Well, I bet Amazon has pain killers to mail to you.The number of stars I assigned relate not to the quality of the movie, action, effects or Leonardo, they're all fine; but to the percentage of people I think who can comfortably handle this maze. Other movies which are complex puzzlers, but more accessible and entertaining would beDark City (Director's Cut) [Blu-ray] orDeja Vu [Blu-ray] (I chose Blu-ray versions because their graphics are so rich and key in both).Hey, who says movies should be just things to watch while chomping popcorn? See INCEPTION a few times and you might get smarter. How much so depends on you and your patience. (Or you could end up catatonic.)
summary: THE MOST RE-SEEABLE MOVIE I'VE EVER SEEN

reviewText: Executed in fast-paced, hurrying pace, like a ticking bomb waiting for its explosive denouement, Christopher Nolan's "Inception" has that electric energy that is highly reminiscent of his previous works, especially "The Dark Knight", it's as if one is suddenly put in an already developing dire situation that calls for the survival of the fittest. Nolan has always been great in establishing chaotic, corrupt worlds, not merely as backdrops, but as centerpieces alongside his philosophical explorations of conceptional human values and struggles through his always well-developed characters. This works well, as the viewer is suddenly sucked into a particular created universe without even any hesitations or questions asked because of its extremely elaborated believable, if not heightened, chaos; immersing in it is structurally connected to watching the story unfold; in other words, being in it is the story itself.However, this relationship between ordered chaos and effective storytelling is not as organic here as it is in his previous films; this time around, the former negates the latter to some extent. The reason is mostly because the film is dealing with a heavily metaphysical concept, and it is a huge concept at that one too, of entering into one's dreams for information and secrets. Like any works in science fiction, it is a requirement to dwell into at least some form of exposition to explain the mechanism of a certain phenomena or wonder, otherwise the story lapses into a mumbo-jumbo concoction of irrational half-conceived ideas that render the populated world of the characters and themselves implausible; this might work in the fantasy genre, which even then still requires the logistics of rationality, but in science fiction, exposition is almost always a requirement. Almost.In "Inception", the characters seem secondary to the film's conceptualized dream abstractions. Indeed, its treatment of dreams is original, admirable and even awe inspiring. The layering of dreams, each paralleling another at a different time, in a different place; and the set-up of rules depending on the layer of the dream is particularly impressive. Only in this film, one could say a van falling off bridge into the river, slow-motioned for about 30 minutes, completely makes sense, not to mention thoroughly heart-pounding. And the concept of 'limbo' where one could get stuck in a dream for ten years is terrifying. But the film's heavy reliance on exposition, is both a blessing and a curse.On one hand, as soon as the mechanisms and the logistics of the act of entering dreams have been verbalized, and reiterated over and over again, the film works straight-laced in its razor sharp fluidity of action, a cause-and-effect extravaganza on the basis of the conceptualizations of dreaming, depending, of course, on its whereabouts; the farther the layer is, the deeper trouble one is in. If there's one thing that one could thoroughly admire about Nolan is that his action sequences are not rumbling, arbitrary set-pieces, design to blow up buildings to impress, but both reactions and pro-actions are on the basis of a particular tense situation, populated by struggling, deciding characters. On the other hand, this same intellectualized treatment overshadows the undercurrent emotionality of the characters. The subjectivity is there, but the root of it is missing.So while the viewer is thankfully not lost in the convolutions of the film's mechanics of dreams, even when they blossom into layers after layers of intricate and florid abstractions, as sacrifice, the undermining of the individualization of the characters makes for a rather cold intellectual cinematic experience. Mind you, "Inception" is great cinema, but in that clean-cut, deeply concise manner; thus, a rather tame realization, as it completely misses the opportunity to really delve into the primal and raw realm that is merely glanced at during its exploration of the deep burrows of the subconscious mind. In other words, like a beautiful dream, but upon waking up, one ends up losing the profoundness and mystery of it, and instead merely comes up with a technically elaborated analysis to compensate for the failed attempt at grasping the metaphysical and grotesque intangible beauty of the dream itself. The film sports a dream chemist and a dream architect. Nolan should have included a poet or a philosopher."Inception" is neither as cerebral nor deep as it should be, and it could have been, if Nolan could have only have taken the time to take the concept of dream in its actual incarnation: wholly subjective, cathartic, nightmarish, emotional, intimate. One deeply misses the haunting murkiness of memory loss and the emotional and existential discourse as its results in "Memento". This is intelligent, ambitious, occasionally brilliant filmmaking, but it is too efficient, too caught up in its exposition, perhaps even afraid to slow down for the mainstream, that it misses the mark on being a completely visionary, abstract, transcendental work. Ironically, "Inception" as a film about dreams, makes complete sense, which unfortunately seems to render dreaming pointless.

reviewText: I intentionally kept myself in the dark about most of the plot of this movie, and I am glad I did so.  Accordingly, I will not spoil the movie in this review.Anyone who has seen the trailers knows that the film involves people in dreams, and Christopher Nolan does a great job of not only providing the rules for how dreams work on the individuals in dreams, but finds very interesting ways of using those rules.The acting is very strong, and features a team of different specialists, each with a role to play in the dreams.Nolan keeps the action at the forefront, and at times, I lost track of trying to keep it all straight in my head.  Fortunately, the director sees the audience through, so just hod on and ride out the action scenes on top of action scenes.The effects are stunning.  I can't say enough about them.Most of all, in an era of moviemaking that seems to consist only of remakes and sequels, Inception brings some original ideas.  There are certainly elements of other films, notably the Matrix, Dreamscape, and the Thirteenth Floor to name a few. Nevertheless, this is a fresh and well-executed concept.There are a number of creative ideas which you will think about after leaving the theater.  I suspect that I may need to see it again to figure out exactly what intricacies I missed, but if you pay attention, this film is well worth the investment of time and energy.

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: [This is a review for the single disc DVD, which had no features, no scene selection and nothing but language changing and some trailers.  Get the dual disc edition.]First Impressions:Christopher Nolan put together a very imaginative piece, about the development of a fictitious science that can delve into other people's minds and extract information for government or corporate use - trade secrets and the like.  The story does fall down though in not always making clear to the audience what's going on.  The actors at times mumble their words and the "moody" lighting becomes dull and hard to see (although that might just be my TV set).Leonardo DiCaprio plays Cobb, the mastermind who is an expert at going into others dreams and finding secrets.  Sometimes he can go dreams within dreams.  Unfortunately the clients whose dreams he attempts to invade also have their own constructs and sometimes military force of the subconscious to take care of Cobb and his ilk.Cobb also has a major guilt complex going on.  His wife and he also explored their own inner mind except she thought the "real" world was in fact another dream layer and promptly killed herself.  She also created a scenario where he would be on the run from the law for her death -- wow, tough love!All these come together when Cobb is hired out by Saito, a corporate energy dealer who wants to plant an idea (an "inception") for Robert Fisher Jr. (Cillian Murphy) to make his own energy business, break it up and thus Saito could then deal with this competitor rather than be relegated to second rate power.To help Cobb ostensibly deal with the architect of the dreams he hires smart girl Ariadne (Ellen Page).  Though she plays her part fairly well, the character is not developed very much.  She does a lot of yelling at the guy, finds out a few of his secrets and rubs his face in his bad decision-making while on the mission (which tends to bend to his guilt), but she's not developed much.  Not a lot of romance or adventure with this character!The others of the team are similarly not well-developed.  After we get to somewhat know them, they're really throwaway characters -- vital to the plot but we don't really invest a lot of emotion into caring if they live or not.Effects:I must say the special effects were amazing.  The attention to detail, every drop of water, every piece of shattered glass, perfectly poised as in real life.  The "zero gravity" scene (my word for it) was amazing.  Did they have an actual room they were rotating or what was CGI?Not a lot of fight scenes in the film, although there were plenty of chase scenes in the streets and on the slopes.  The audience is shunted from scene to scene rather quickly, at times too much so.  I found myself rewinding the DVD to see what I just missed.Bottom Line:  Imaginative story, excellent fictitious science of the mind, where even with high technology we still have guilt, misunderstandings and in some cases some pretty blatant attempts at making others wrong to fill a book!  The special effects were great, but the editing was such as to at times confuse and startle.  The dialogue could have been clearer with a few less English accents (though Michael Caine, in the small part he played, was marvelous).Recommended, but you may have to have your finger on the rewind to fully follow what's going on.  The ending was fun, left a question in your mind.Directed byChristopher NolanWriting creditsChristopher Nolan  (written by)Cast (in credits orderLeonardo DiCaprio ...  CobbJoseph Gordon-Levitt ...  ArthurEllen Page ...  AriadneTom Hardy ...  EamesKen Watanabe ...  SaitoDileep Rao ...  YusufCillian Murphy .  Robert FischerTom Berenger ...  Peter BrowningMarion Cotillard ...  MalPete Postlethwaite ...  Maurice FischerMichael Caine ...  Miles
summary: Life is But a Dream?  Not a Bad Nolan Entry!

reviewText: Inception is an overrated MTV video for people with the attention span of celery. Anyone who finds it deep doesn't rise to the level of shallow.Specific complaints: while most modern "action" movies are guilty of this, the dynamic range of this soundtrack is wider than any I have yet heard. You have to turn the volume up to hear diCaprio's simian mumbling. Then they light off a pointless explosion or burst of useless machine gun fire which blows out your speakers. Awesome; now my neighbors love me.Who finds the stupid panning camera shots clever? Not me; they're tedious, nauseating and *boring.* They decidedly do not make up for the vapidity of the dialog, the over-explaining and telegraphing of absolutely everything and almost complete lack of plot. What is that you say? That the "multilayering" of the plot is supposed to make it clever? No, it makes it designed to appeal to the type of modern nincompoop who can't read a book without checking his cell phone or his twitter feed every two minutes. It's not clever, and it detracts from the dramatic flow in the same way that switching between TV programs to avoid commercials detracts from dramatic flow. I guess when you have enough context switches, it's harder for most people to tell how awful the plot is.The characters weren't even one dimensional characters: they are zero-dimensional characters; featureless points scattered over a landscape like bits of dandruff. Try to think of an adjective describing any one of the characters without referring to their appearance or job: you can't. The acting was horrendous; they don't act like people -they act like the human marionettes in bad TV police dramas. DiCaprio -the main character I'm supposed to sympathize with, did not change his facial expression more than a millimeter for the entire movie. The plot premise; the extremely tired, overused and moronic PKD "oooo, am I tripping out or in reality land, maaaan?" trope. Like we haven't seen that about a zillion times already in Science Fiction since the 50s, and mainstream movies since the 80s. It was dumb in the Matrix movies; it's offensively dumb done ... yet again in this stinker.The pacing is abysmal. The retardo-useless action scenes and atrocious CGI effects can't cover up the fact that it was literally a movie about a snooze fest.The worst thing about it is the fact that people actually seem to think it is something beyond a silly MTV video. Why do people use the word "cerebral" applied to this movie? Because Di Caprio was able to successfully conjugate a verb once in a while? Because of the several plot threads? Boring and useless isn't the same as cerebral.
summary: Plotless, overrated dreck: all the artistic depth of an MTV video

reviewText: I see that this film has about as many 1 star ratings as it does four star ratings.  Obviously, a lot of people didn't enjoy the film.  I'm not sure why that is.  I found it very entertaining and enjoyable.The film does start out in a confusing way, but the opening scenes where Cobb (Leonardo DiCaprio) awakes on a beach, near a Japanese castle is explained later in the film.  The subsequent scenes show a small group of people who are experts at 'extraction', stealing industrial secrets from the sleeping mind, when the brain's defenses are down.  Cobb offers his services to Saito, (Ken Watanabe), but in a different vein, to train him to protect his mind from others like Cobb who are bent on stealing his secrets.Now, they are asked to do something that is much more difficult, perhaps even impossible; not to take an idea, but to plant one into another's mind.  This time, it's rich industrialist Maurice Fischer's son, Robert, whom is sought to take his father's company into a different direction than the one his father chose.It's elaborate and complex.  In order to plant an idea, the small team led by Cobb must go not just one level down, into a dream, but beyond that, perhaps even three levels down, in other words, a dream within a dream within a dream.  In order to accomplish this, a new and perhaps dangerous sedative will be tried.  The danger, of course, is that the dreamer may die from the sedative, or more ominous, he or she may continue into the deepest level of the dream state, where hours in this world translate into years in this deepest level.  Cobb has been there before, and knows the danger.Inception is a fun romp!  There is a ton of action, as things are happening on all three levels of the dream.  There are bad guys everywhere who are manifestations of those who are trying to prevent the supposed theft of Robert's thoughts and ideas.  And then there is the wild card no one, except Cobb, expects; his dead wife, who is still very much 'alive' in his, and everyone else's, dreams.A strong recommendation for Inception.  The amount of planning that must have gone on just to write the script is fantastic.  To have it all make sense is impressive.  And, of course, the special effects are outstanding; really unbelievable.  The best effects are when Arthur (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) have to defeat the bad guys in the dreams second level.  The hotel they are in is rotating, and somehow everyone appears to float around, climb walls, and walk on the ceiling.  Fantastic job to the special effects crew!The only disappointment was the lack of interesting extras on the DVD.  There are visual explanations of making the impossible staircase and the like, but no director's commentary.
summary: A Satisfying Puzzle of a Film

reviewText: I went to see Inception in the theater, and for the second time in my life experienced the feeling of desperately wanting to get up and walk out so as to salvage at least part of the evening.  Had I been sitting on the aisle I certainly would have.  As it was, there was no choice but to sit through the whole excruciating thing, hoping beyond hope that it would end and put me out of my misery.I know others have rated the movie highly, and I respect their opinions.  At the end of the screening I went to, many of the folks leaving seemed to have really enjoyed it.  Personally, though, I think it was just awful, for three reasons: the stakes, the villains, and the writing.Comparison with The Matrix series is inevitable, because here - like in The Matrix- we have action taking place in the "real" world and a "dream" world.  Inception takes the Matrix-like concept and adds to it with multiple dream worlds, and dream worlds within dream worlds.  That idea has the potential to be interesting, so due credit there.  The first problem, though, is that the stakes in Inception are too low.  In The Matrix, success in the dream world means saving all of humanity from enslavement.  OK, that's a goal I can get invested in.  Here, success in the dream world means two things: a) the Leo DiCaprio character gets to see his kids, and b) one big energy corporation gets an advantage in the market over another big energy corporation.  Ho hum.  (Now, don't get me wrong - it's possible to make a movie where the audience gets invested in a father-child relationship, and an emotional journey comes to have high stakes.  To do that, though, the movie has to work to develop the emotional elements of the characters and the story, which Inception doesn't do.  There's so much sci-fi gimmickry, action, and special effects that there's no room left to develop a human story worth caring about.)Well, if it's not a success as a deep character study, at least it can be a good sci-fi action thriller, right?  Well, there's more hope here, but still it didn't work for me.  Here the problem is the villains.  There aren't any.  Yes, Our Heroes do a lot of fighting, but it's against random faceless gunmen who pop up and get shot down like in a videogame.  Again, compare to The Matrix: the scenes with Agent Smith talking to Morpheus, and later to Neo, give us a bad guy we can really root against, which makes the good guy more fun to root for.  Or in Die Hard, when Hans Gruber kills  the smarmy guy without qualm, it makes Hans more evil and makes it more cathartic when he loses at the end.  There isn't even a betrayal twist where one of our favorite characters turns out to be the bad guy.  Of course, the conflict here is not man-vs-man or man-vs-nature, it is man-vs-himself; but as already noted above, that takes attention to character that wasn't paid here.Finally, the writing.  There's just nothing quotable in Inception.  The closest thing to a quotable line was "well it was worth a try" - not going to become anyone's catch phrase.  No "there is no spoon."  No "I know kung fu!"  No "I'll be back."At the end of the day, Inception tries to mix an action flick with an emotional journey, and succeeds at neither.  I'd say save your time and your money, and give this one a miss.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw Inception on opening day in my town. I think that the first thing I heard as the credits started rolling sums up the experience: "what the heck?"Leonardo DiCaprio plays Dom, an expert at getting inside of peoples' minds (through dreaming) and stealing their secrets (known as extraction). He has a team who help him with this, and his clients are often leaders of some of the largest and wealthiest corporations on Earth. Ken Wanatabe plays one of those leaders. But what he wants isn't an extraction, it's an inception, in which an idea is planted in the subconscious of the targeted person. Some on the team say it can't be done, but Dom moves the team forward on this mission--despite the incredible danger it holds for them all.Inception plays with space, time and matter in ways we've never seen before. It is not science fiction in the way of spaceships and alien creatures, but of the mind and its incredible powers. The visual effects are quite amazing, especially when the world is turned upside down (or sideways). The action in the film is quite intense and some sequences had people in the theatre with me on the edge of their seats--quite literally! One toward the end especially is a real mind-blower (in more ways than one).My complaint is that the concept and the story are so complex that, even with total concentration on the screen, I found it difficult to keep up with what was going on. I know I wasn't the only one in this situation, because I heard a lot of murmuring among the packed crowd to the tune of "What just happened?" Several few people got up and left as I think they just gave up on trying to "get it." Additionally, most of the characters were not fleshed out--all the "character time" was devoted to Dom's character.If being totally dazed and confused sounds like mad fun to you, then this is definitely your film. If it all sounds like too much work, then you may want to pick another movie. If you're in between, definitely give it a shot on DVD.I liked it...I really enjoyed the effects, the action and most of the puzzle...but didn't LOVE it. 4 1/2 stars.
summary: Whoa...incredible movie but very different and creative!

reviewText: I won't go over the plot because it is already well covered in many other places, but will just give an overall review of the tone and pace of the movie. The storying is very intriguing, and, like a lot of complex movies these days, it can be difficult to follow unless you are ready, willing, and able to follow the plot very carefully. It is a good dinner movie to watch with good friends, but not necessarily a movie to watch with people who are used to a slower-paced movie or a movie with fewer intricate ideas. Watch with sci-fi friends or friends who like complex plots, and then you are guaranteed to have fun. Good filming, great acting, great plot for those who like complexity!

reviewText: This movie will deffinately make you think. It is not a passive story that you will absorb just by being in the room.The acting is fantastic. The story is a great trip that really leaves you questioning what was real and what wasn't. (Sort of like The Matrix, but with less "bullet time" and crazy sunglasses)This movie will tire you out just watching it trying to figure out what's going on.The thing I appreciated most about this movie is that they never tried to explain the science behind the dream control machine. They just said "this is it, it works, accept it" rather than spending a half hour of the film showing how it works with some impossible explanation that made no sense. They just asked you to suspend disbelief for the length of the film and it works great!As for the quality of the Blu Ray print, it's incredible. This film was made with a great combination of strong set design a limited (but well done) use of CGI. So the look of the film is fantastic and the Blu Ray print really picks it up masterfully.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan has done it again. He continues to prove that he's the master of creating beautiful, layered and imaginative films. With "Inception" we follow Mr.Cobb(DiCaprio)and his associate Arthur(Gordon-Levitt), a duo of specially trained thieves who enter peoples minds and steal their secrets and ideas. After the film's first mission the duo is offered a job by their original target,Mr.Santio. He wants them to implant an idea into his business competitor's mind(Fischer). He wants them to make Mr.Fischer think that it's in his best interest to break up his father's business empire after his father dies. A procedure known as "Inception". At first Cobb and Arthur turn down the project because it's too complex and dangerous but Santio has an offer that Cobb can't refuse. If he completes this mission, Santio can pull some strings so Cobb can see his children again. Cobb, heartbroken and desperate to his children(you have to see the film as to why) agrees to take Santio's offer. Cobb and Aurthur then set out to assemble a team of other specialist to complete their mission. A mission that will prove to be more dangerous than any of them ever imagined. Without a doubt "Inception" is one of the most stunning and imaginative films I've ever seen. Nolan really shows that he can turn on the special effects with the best of them. People run up walls, water floats,and cities turn upside down on to themselves. As enjoyable as "Inception" is, it's easy to get a little lost. Seeing as the method of inception is to create multiple "dream realms" or dreams within dreams, you can find yourself forgetting which one you're watching. Even the characters in the movie seem to confuse themselves. In one scene that I found amusing, Ellen Page's character Aliadne chimes in "Okay..So who's subconscious are we entering again?". "Inception" is a thinking man's action film and the best film I've seen all summer. I can't help thinking how cool some of the effects would of been in 3-D(they're making a Step Up 3-D! I say why not make a good film in 3-D?) but I digress. If you're looking for a movie that is fun and intelligently made then "Inception" is it. The best film of the summer by far.
summary: a dream within a dream within a dream
Title: N/A

reviewText: Do you feel like I do? Was Inception a very (long) good, modern day episode ofThe Twilight Zone? Was it overly hyped as a complex, thinking man's movie? Granted, you do indeed need to think more about what's happening in Inception than, say for example,The Expendables(the other movie I watched this week). But at least I didn't fall asleep during my first watch through of The Expendables like I did in my first attempt at Inception.Granted, I probably started Inception a little too late on a Friday night after a couple (okay, more than a couple) of beers, but the next night I did the same with The Expendables and stayed wide awake. And this is not because I got lost in Inception's plot. It's because I got literally tired of the actors explaining what they were doing or about to do versus just doing it. "It" mainly being entering a person's dream, then in that dream jumping to the person's simultaneous dream, then repeating this to a third dream in the person's subconscious where time moves the slowest giving the "jumpers" the most amount of time to change the host's mind about an issue without the host realizing that his change of heart was inspired by outside parties (the jumpers). Yes, that was a mouthful, and not as easy to say as, "The Expendables was an action star studded bang bang shoot 'em up flick about a bunch mercenaries that attempt to overthrow a South American dictator."But was Inception really so complex that Director Christopher Nolan had to spend almost the first 90 minutes of the movie walking me / us through what was about to happen and how it would happen without missing a detail? Would I have gotten "it" without the explanations? Maybe I give myself too much credit, but I think that I would have.All that said, please don't get me wrong...it was a great movie...regardless of the ultimate length of the movie and the time Nolan spent explaining it along the way. I liked it. The special effects were out of this world. The visuals overlaying all of the explaining made the movie fun to watch (on my second attempt anyway), and when there was action it was tight, exciting and extremely well done.The cast was interesting. Leo DiCaprio is excellent as always. Ellen Page was an interesting pick; she's cute in herJunokinda way, but seemed a little out of place on the action front. Cillian Murphy was good and DiCaprio's "dream team" were well cast. They all made it very believable...and it would have been just as believable without all of the verbalizing they did about how and what they were doing.Bottom line: Inception is a really cool and unique movie. See it. But I'd make it a Netflix pick and buy it in later 2011 when the DVD will be even cheaper.
summary: Must Have Been A Dream; I Can't Believe Where I've Been. C'mon, Let's Do It Again!
