reviewText: Inception is the type of movie that asks a lot right out of the gate. It's a bit like having a friend who owes you a ton of money promising to pay the debt with golden turds his dog started dropping after he switched puppy-chow brands. The natural temptation to respond by slapping him in his lying face is pushed aside when he presses that first, shiny, golden butt-burrito into your hands before he runs off to feed his dog again. I'm sure I could have picked a better analogy, but that one is quite accurate, and it also lets me use funny euphemisms like "butt-burrito".With Inception, just as with the magical "Golden" dog, if you stop to think about it long enough you soon realize that, not only does the story not make any sense, but you've been given a finely polished deuce in place of actual money. And it takes a lot of polishing to keep you slack-jawed and incapable of incredulity for the 2.5 hour run-time of this film. The fact that they pull it off is actually quite impressive, although having a boat-load of money certainly made it easier for them. I'm no expert and more importantly, I'm too lazy to look it up, but I'm going to go ahead and claim that the studio budget for this movie rivals the GDP of many small island nations. A-list actors, impressive sets, complex action sequences...all are tossed about with the carefree air of a Saudi Sheik who just discovered his oil fields are sitting atop vast deposits of pure heroin.Of course, all the spectacular scenery is meant to keep your eyes on the magician while his lovely assistant drops your trousers and rifles around in your body cavities. Inception is just a trick - smoke and mirrors and the occasional albino tiger wrapped in layer after layer of misdirection and executed with practiced slight-of-hand. The central plot is about as thin as soviet soup - Leo and his team of "extractors" specialize in dream burglary, essentially hijacking their mark's subconscious to get him/her to divulge industrial secrets, PIN numbers, their grandma's secret velvet cake recipe...whatever. How this is done is glossed over entirely - everyone hooks themselves up to a silver briefcase and it just works, ok? Now stop asking silly questions and relax your colon, because we're just getting started.See, Inception is not just another dream movie. Apparently, a single dream world where anything is possible was simply too limiting, and to break out of the straightjacket of infinite possibilities you need to go into a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream within a dream.....you get the idea. The only thing necessary to pull this off is another silver briefcase for each successive dream, an easy matter given that you can essentially drop whatever you want to into these dreams. You've just been handed the golden, impossible deuce: the mechanics of this concept are never adequately explained yet the consequences of traveling through multiple dream "levels" are central to the story.That's not to say it's a bad movie. Oh, I'm sorry...did the previous paragraphs deceive you into thinking this movie was a big pile of suck? Well, it depends on whether or not you decide to take the golden deuce to the bank or not. If you're willing to accept that gold is gold then it does not matter what shape it's in or even what orifice it was excreted from. You deposit the deposit (snicker) and go about your business. You can do the same thing with Inception: take the story at face value and ignore that little part of you that scoffs in disbelief and you'll have no problem enjoying this film. If you can't help but see through the smoke and mirrors it will only become more ridiculous with each passing minute.I recommend you give this movie a shot, mainly because it is a massively ambitious story to tell in this format and, despite its short comings, manages to be riveting and original. The third act is a masterful display of tight pacing, tying together multiple timelines with fluid precision while never letting up the suspense. I found myself unable to stop watching, even when the ending became more or less predictable, and I respect the ambition of the story enough to jettison my complaints about its execution. I don't think it will ever become the instant classic, genre-inventing film that it was hyped up to be, but it explores interesting territory (albeit superficially), and makes for an excellent viewing experience. Given what hollywood serves up as typical fare these days I'd say a golden deuce is about the best you can hope for.

reviewText: `Inception' is one of those films that surprises you by being a whole lot better than you anticipated. I knew the basic premise of the film from the trailer, but this had so much more going for it than I had hoped to imagine.This follows a team who usually enter dreams to steal information from the dreamer (extraction), but in this case go into a dream to plant information (inception). This is the basic premise, but the levels of detail and philosophy behind the idea make this something more than your run of the mill Hollywood extravaganza. I won't ruin it by going into much more detail here, suffice to say there is more to the film than just that basic idea.Everyone in this film is acting at the top of their game and the special effects (whilst reminiscent of `The Matrix' in places) are simply excellent. This manages to come up with quite a complex storyline, but you are never left feeling lost or unsure of where you are, apart from the deliberately ambiguous ending which leaves things open to your open interpretation after leaving the main bulk of the story tied up in a highly satisfying way.This managed to hold my attention for the whole duration (without my mind wandering once) and I was often on the edge of my seat or emotionally involved with the characters. Ken Watanabe is as great as we have come to expect and DiCaprio also turns out a stellar performance. At the end of the day this was an accomplished bit of film making, that delivered a suspenseful, original premise in an authentic and gripping way. Well worth a viewing.Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

reviewText: This movie has it's pros and cons. Here's what my wife and I think.Pros:1. There's a lot of action. Lots of excitement and unexpected surprises.2. The acting was top notch. DiCaprio is a genius and the rest of the cast was fantastic.3. The special effects were mind bending, imaginative and well done.4. The concept of conscious dreaming and invading someone else's dreams to manipulate them is both fascinating and frightening. The story was deep and intricate. It was a great scifi concept with plenty of creativity.Cons:1. This movie is very challenging to follow. To give you an idea so you can judge for yourself - We're both college grads with post graduate courses. If you look back at my previous movie reviews you'll see that when others find a movie hard to follow, I usually have no problem with it. Yet with this movie I think I'd have to watch it several times to really comprehend all of what was going on. Both my wife and I were lost a lot. In the end, I think we figured out the overall story, but there were long periods of just feeling lost and confused. This was frustrating. I see that the featured reviewer on the Amazon page mentions that she and her 11 year old brother understood it, but I think they must be Mensa geniuses.2. The manipulative nature of what the main characters were trying to accomplish made it harder to root for DiCaprio and his team. (Kind of a SPOILER: They were to make a decent man dismantle the company that was his inheritance by planting ideas in his subconscious.) Though the client hiring them to do this said it was to prevent a monopoly, it didn't seem completely right. They were risking this guys life for their own profit.Final recommendation: I'm a huge sci-fi fan, and this is not one of my favorite sci-fi movies. However it's still worth seeing for the Pros up above, especially if you like sci-fi or special effects movies. I'd recommend seeing it on DVD so you can rewind and rewatch it to get the story straight.
summary: Creative, full of action, but hard to follow

reviewText: Like others, I went to this with zero advertising exposure. My only decision point was that it's a Chris Nolan movie. I'm also one of those people who like Batman Begins much better than The Dark Knight.Having seen Inception, I agree absolutely on 3 points: 1) The less you know going in the first time, the better off you are. 2) You must see it at least 2 times. 3) It is far, far better the 2nd time you see it.Here's my advice: See it once. Read the interviews with Nolan and Dicaprio, read about what was their primary creative goal. Wait a week or two. Then see it a second time, and be prepared to be knocked on your ass.I have to confess, another reason I saw Inception was that Avatar utterly blew me away. I saw Avatar twice, and I found it mind-boggling. It wasn't just the technology, even more, it was the character of Neytiri. I still think that Zoe Saldana caused a brain-fry in the Academy Award nominating process. Yet great as the acting is in Avatar, I think the acting in Inception is even better, because that's Inception's focus. If you get inside this movie, you will be on a first-name basis with every character that has a name. They are all etched in a living flame.I wanted Inception to convince me that Avatar had not rendered "conventional" movie making obsolete. Mission accomplished. How? I believe the characters of Inception are even stronger than the characters of Avatar, because Inception is based in a world everyone already knows. Nolan and the actors and actresses were able to devote themselves to making the best characters they possibly could. Inception may be the greatest ensemble movie ever made, and I include The Magnificent Seven.I will also say that I see a certain ethos within Inception. Again, I don't want to give it away. Everyone deserves a chance to see the movie and interpret it for themselves. But for me, I rank Inception as equal among the greatest movies I have ever seen. Dom and Mal, and all these people, will live inside me so long as I live.
summary: Inception Creates People, Avatar Creates a World: You Choose

reviewText: Every year, Hollywood shells out products that serve no other purpose than to bore audiences into a state of stupidity. This has been a problem for years, since the birth of the blockbuster. In the late sixties and early seventies, mainstream audiences frequently enjoyed intellectually stimulating films, such as MIDNIGHT COWBOY, A CLOCKWORK ORANGE, and TAXI DRIVER. That was until STAR WARS was unleashed upon the world, and everyone threw their brains out the window and settled for pure spectacle. Not much has changed. Audiences still crave style over substance. If you don't believe me, check out the box office results for AVATAR, and then get back to me. A Hollywood film with a brain is a rare thing these days.But every now and again, I have to insert my foot into my mouth. INCEPTION is one of the most intelligent, completely involving mainstream films since THE MATRIX took the world by storm in 1999. INCEPTION will blow you away. I've already seen this film twice, and I will see it again.Where to begin. INCEPTION is one of those extraordinary films that is inherently hard to describe, yet easy to comprehend whilst you are in the theatre experiencing it firsthand. It deals with one of my favorite subjects: dreams. We not only deal with dreams, but dreams within dreams within dreams. With all of the complex layering going on, it could be easy to lose yourself - which is why I'm going to give you the most simple synopsis that I can muster in this review. It will be short, sweet, and to the point.The film deals with a man named Dom Cobb, an experienced thief who utilizes the best of modern technology to enter the subconscious dreamworlds of others, and steal their most precious secrets and ideas. This process is known as "extraction". Because of this, Cobb is one of the most sought after fugitives in the business. When his latest assignment goes awry, he is offered a chance to redeem himself by pulling off a seemingly impossible "inception" - a process by which an idea is planted into an individuals mind. In order to do this, Cobb must put together a team of experts and race against the clock in order to successfully execute the mission.This is just the tip of the iceberg. Much more goes on within the two and a half hour running time. To say anything else would only spoil the film for you, and rob you of the pure rush that comes from watching such cinematic genius.Christopher Nolan is at the top of his game here. His direction is flawless, and his confidence in his cast and crew is visible on screen. This is his best film since MEMENTO, and it's just as puzzling. Yes, there are special effects in this film, but they do not take precedence over the story or performances. They are merely a part of the world that Christopher Nolan has so expertly crafted. After seeing INCEPTION, I have officially forgiven Nolan for those overrated Batman films.The performances from the entire cast are amazing. Leonardo DiCaprio, Ellen Page, and Marion Cotillard shine. Everyone else is just as good. There is even a cameo from Michael Caine, as well. Hans Zimmer's score may as well be counted as another character in the film, as it is that powerful. It's one of those scores that audiences will recognize whenever they hear it play for years to come.INCEPTION is a gift. Do yourself a favor and see it as soon as possible.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a movie that grew on me as I watched it. The first part was slow and almost incomprehensible to me; I seriously thought of walking out of the theater. But as the sponsor of the "dream team," Saito, began to make clear what he really wanted--the breakup of a competitor's business empire, the movie gains clarity and focus and begins to move ahead with great energy.The first issue is keeping the cast members in mind. The "team" developed by protagonist Cobb (played by Leonardo DiCaprio) includes an array of professionals--an architect (Ariadne, played by Ellen Page), Eames (played by Tom Hardy), Yusuf (a chemist who develops sedatives to facilitate the dream process--especially if there are dreams within dreams [the movie, at one point, goes four dreams deep]), and Arthur. The normal goal of Cobb and his partners is "extraction," getting information through entering dreams--and even manipulating dreams. In this case, Saito wants "inception," introducing an idea into the mind of his competitor, Robert Fischer, son of Maurice, who had developed a business empire that threatens to overwhelm Saito's concerns. The idea would lead Robert to dismantle his father's empire and allow greater competitive room for Saito (at the beginning, needless to say, this and other threads are hard to keep in mind).Then, they build the scheme--to function at three levels. The top dream involves a chase; the next layer occurs in a hotel room; the third layer in a winter wilderness. Violence occurs at each level as "projections" from Fischer's mind emerge in the dreams. And, making the schemes developed by Cobb's team more difficult, his wife, Mal, who had killed herself believing that she was still in a dream, shows up as a projection in his "capers." No different in this effort, and she adds an element of unpredictability and danger.As the movie begins to gather momentum after a slow start, the characters make this plot "work." The action is nonstop. Some suggest that this is a cerebral, deep movie. I'm not sure that I agree. It is an action movie, based on an interesting concept about dreams. One other plus: an appearance by the redoubtable Michael Caine as Ariadne's college teacher and Cobb's father-in-law.If one can be patient until things begin to clarify, this will be a worthwhile movie to attend and reflect upon.
summary: The movie grew on me as it progressed

reviewText: I remember watching this movie in the theater. Most movies I watch based on friends recommendations or other people turn out to be total crap. The point of the movie is defeated.I will give credit to the soundtrack though that was good.The video quality is ok.The environments in the dream world have little imagination. reviewText: About 15 years ago, maybe more, I wrote a short story called "Language Surfing." It was about a gang of semi-criminals and cyber-punks who engage in language surfing. I'm not even really sure what language surfing is, but it's a bit like entering the Matrix and seeing what's going to happen. I wrote it to be a preposterous as possible and I wrapped it up neat and nice, even if not everything made sense.The film Inception uses the same logic, and I think that the director is taking the piss out of all of us with a preposterous tale of entering people's dreams and influencing their thinking. I thought that this was one of the stupidest films I've ever seen, and the plot was so totally preposterous I simply could not suspend my disbelief any longer. Architects who create dream worlds! Dreamers who go under for 50 years! Car chases inside a man's brain! Executives that can buy off justice! Ambushes in Tangiers! Cities that fold like slices of pizza! Wowee!!The way it was all neatly wrapped up in a happy ending in the last two minutes, with the ironic twist of the spinning top thingy, was also hard to take. What did we just sit through for two hours? People take this film really seriously and think about what it means. I guess they're a lot deeper than me...

reviewText: Like Hitchcock and Kubrick, Nolan has the tendency to work out every last detail of his characters as if they were algebraic equations, to be worked out but without the existential heart or mystery.In the factory of dreams that is film, Nolan has developed an idea with such breath-taking virtuousity,planned action sequences of great splendour,that we are apt to overlook his inability to create believable characters that move you.Still you know this film could only get made using Nolan's expertise and DiCaprio's star power.The beating heart of the film comes from Mal(Cotillard) locked up in the subconscious of Cobb(diCaprio).Elaine Page(Ariadne)is an androgynous figure, explaining to the audience via questions or to provide exposition on her own terms,eg when Cobb lays down the rules of shared dreaming to us through Ariadne.Since The Dark Knight,Nolan has been handed the keys to Hollywood to open up a Pandara's box of special efx,making a Faustian pact with the machinery of film, emphasising tendencies already latent in The Prestige and Memento to use trickery to hide a hollowness in his story-telling,a lack of soul,hidden by trap-doors,symbols,hidden secrets. The striking visualization comes from poverty rather than wealth.The plot needs explaining as it proceeds, disengaging you emotionally. Nolan has learned all the techniques of direction at the expense of emotion. Everything is done by sleight-of-hand as in previous films.His staging of dream-within-dream and dream-within-dream-within-dream,are cleverly conceived,highly-wrought constructions,with the conscious levels realized at the expense of the subconscious levels,affecting the latter dreamscape with meticulous,crafted logicality. Most breathtaking are the implosion of a Parisian boulevard, a runaway train careening down a Los Angeles thoroughfare, and a midair tussle in a hotel corridor.The team members break off in rear-guards,defending one level so the rest can continue on in dreams-within-dreams. Nolan cross-cuts between each stage as synchronized alarm clocks tick toward zero, while surface actions send rippling reactions along the chain.On each level time runs at a different rate.There are hard-and-fast rules in this psychological pinball-in-a-dreamscape.The dreamworlds are carefully constructed by imaginative architects like Ariadne.Mess with the physics of the dreamworlds too much, and peoples' minds that are being heisted by extraction or inception,rebel against the unreality. The main characters are trapped four levels deep within a dream, racing against time, unable to tell real from fake and trying to escape up the chain of dreams before it all collapses into mind-melting nothingness.At the lowest level there is a James Bondian assault on a snowbound fortress,that seemed a cliché. Extractors are skilled in the art of inducing a dream in their target, creating an imaginary world in their mind, occupying that world, and using that imagination against them to find and steal their secrets.Nolan plays around with the idea that reality is a construct in our heads,how real is the `real' world?He has no distinction between waking feelings and dream thoughts and feelings. There are derivations from other films: 2001, eXistenz,Cocteau's Orpheus,Last Year at Marienbad and The Matrix.Cobb is similar to the character DiCaprio played in Shutter Island,driven by memories of a dead wife. "The catharsis" at the center of Inception is based on Cobb's choice: whether to go on permanent vacation with his dream-memory of Mal, or to return to real life. It's deciding between eternity with a bitchy wraith, presumably sexless, like all of Inception's subconscious, or . . . that recurring sentimental snapshot-memory of his children?Nolan needs to just deal with ordinary people in the real world,bringing in more real world topics and concerns.Pare down,cut back.Become like Beckett to Joyce.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
summary: "So whose subconscious are we hacking into now?"(Ariadne)

reviewText: You have just directed a masterpiece with The Dark Knight, what do you do for another follow-up?  Create another masterpiece with a little film called Inception.  The plot is a little hard to describe but I'll try.  Inception tells the story of Dom Cobb (played by Leonard Dicaprio in an oscar-worthy performance).  Cobb is a professional theif but not in a conventional way.  He uses a piece of technology that was originally developed by the military to allow its soldiers to injury and kill each other without actually doing it to each other.  He uses it to enter people's dreams and steal their secrets.  He's also on the run from the police for something they believed he did.  After failing his last job. he is offered another one from the same person he was trying to steal secrets from but this job will be his hardest one yet.  The client wants him to perform Inception.  Its basically the reverse of what Cobb does.  Instead of stealing something from a person's mind, the client wants Cobb to put an idea into his competition's mind.  It is described at being very hard and the film does a very good job at explaining why.  In fact, it not only does a very good job at explaining this technology but it also explains dreams, ideas and a bunch of other things that you would not expect.  Even though it explains everything, it doesn't insult the audience's intelligence.  You might think that might just be a standard heist movie but with Christopher Nolan as writer and director, it is far from standard.  It has depth, intelligence and creativity.  I don't think there has ever been a movie like this.  It is part heist movie, part action adventure and part character study.  There is nothing bad that you can say about this movie.  The performances, script, direction, music, editing, visual effects, etc, were all top notch.  It is a crying shame that for as many Oscars this film was nominated for, Leonard Dicaprio did not receive a Best Actor nomination and an abomination that Christopher Nolan was not nominated for Best Director yet again for creating another masterpiece.  Films don't direct themselves.  If you are interested in a compelling, character driven, mind-bending film, I highly recommend this one and I'm surely that a lot of other people would too.

reviewText: I had heard good things about this movie. I wanted to like it, but in the end, it just didn't do much for me.It's not that it was a bad movie. It just seemed a little overblown, overcomplicated, and overdramatic for what was actually going on.You know the plot. Good ol' Leo enters people's minds, sneaks around there, and steals (or perhaps plants) information. Sounds like a decent enough sci-fi yarn, doesn't it? I love themes like that, in themselves. Sort of a Dreamscape meets The Matrix, all focusing on the question: "What is real?"But the movie bogs down. Mainly it gets so caught up in "rules" that it loses itself. For example:1. You need an "architect" to create the dream.2. Subconscious people will try to kill you.3. Time flows slower the deeper you go, /10, /100, /1000.4. The feeling of falling is one of the few things that will wake you up.5. Getting killed while in a regular dream will wake you up, UNLESS...6. You are killed while sedated, in which case you will go into "Limbo".7. And etc, etc, etc... until you don't even care anymore.I mean really. I understand the need to have some consistency in a made-up movie universe. But since when do dreams follow ANY rules? The obsession the film creators had here in sticking to a bunch of arbitrary "rules" bordered on OCD.And apparently you can't just wake up from a dream. You have to be "kicked". And if you are having a dream within a dream, you have to wake up in the deeper dream before you will wake up in the upper dream. Or else you may fall into a deeper dream and from which you cannot wake up, and- uh... something. Sorry, lost track there. If any of that seems overly complicated to you, let's just say that you are far more intelligent than the all-too-clever people who produced this movie. That or you and are both too dumb to "appreciate" it, fanboys will charge, no doubt.And that's another gripe I have about this movie. The subject - dreams. It lends itself to such awesome writing, really limited only by the imagination. But the dreams in this movie were so unimaginative. They were flat, boring, downright lifeless! How could that be? Why should dreams be limited only to city streets and urban apartments? I guess by those standards, the snow base is considered imaginative. How about a city in the sky, instead? And I think my subconscious would be defended by dragons and monsters, not chicago-esque gangsters with machine guns, thank you very much! Really, for a movie about dreams, what you see here is completely underwhelming.I also disliked the special effects thrown in for no reason. Wow. A city block exploding in slow motion. And this is profound? Why? I kept getting the feeling the filmmakers were trying to plant their own idea in my head. "Be impressed! Be very impressed NOW!" Only I wasn't. If I wanted to watch random stuff being blown up for no reason, I'd watch something by Michael Bay. (I'm talking to YOU, Transformers!)The movie also featured a bunch of action sequences I didn't much care about. Where the Matrix was stylish and cool in this regard, Inception takes the route of "gritty realism", and falls completely flat. Gritty realism in a dream? Why? Of course, it never made any sense to me why so many people were required to be in the dream in the first place, so I never really cared one way or another when any of them were in danger.The action is nonstop, but ultimately "much ado about nothing". We cut back and forth between dreams, with non-existent drama in each one. (I mean, repeated slow motion scenes of people falling a van? Really?) It seems silly to me the way the movie tried to get you to care what happens in one of the upper dreams, when you already know good and well that it won't have any impact whatsoever until they finish doing what they came to do in the lower dreams.And I really wanted to care about the characters too, but they just seemed kind of soulless. Just gun-wielding morons, really. As an actor I especially like Tom Hardy, bless him. But there just wasn't much for him to do here except shoot a bunch of people. Leo gets most of the character building. And that's okay; he does a convincing enough job. It just left me wanting more. I think the movie would have done a lot better with 75% less characters and 75% less gunfights.Something else that was really irritating was the ridiculous, overdramatic music. Music in movies is essential. But this just kept droning on and on. The seriousness just never let up! After a while, the dramatic music just starts weighing on you. By the end, I just felt like saying, "Enough already! Sheesh!"There are two things I didn't get. ***SPOILERS AHEAD***So if you spin a top in the dream world, it spins forever. But if you spin it in the real world, it falls down. This is how you know you are in the real world or not. But what about if you dream that it falls down? I mean, why couldn't you? For a movie that cares so much about logic, they sure skipped over that one.I didn't understand the ending with the father on the deathbed. So he opens the safe, and finds the pinwheel. And his father says some kind words. Only in real life, he never really opened anything, did he? And his father didn't say anything nice. And above all that, who actually did any "Incepting"? I thought Leo was supposed to put the idea in the guy's head. Only he did that stuff on his own, apparently. So the whole idea of the movie crumbles and falls flat right there! I thought the point was for the guy to get an idea. Not for him to hallucinate events that completely did not happen at all. It just didn't make any sense."Inception". They kept repeating the word throughout, as if it carried profound meaning. Well, how about we look that up in a dictionary? It just means "beginning". That's it. Any meaning beyond that is just invented by this movie. And that's about as deep a thought as this movie will bring you, unfortunately.

reviewText: Popped this in my DVD player the other night.Well,first off - just as Shutter Island was similar to another film called 'the ninth configuration', Inception is rather similar to a film called 'Dreamscape'.The principal character can enter people's dreams and steal their secrets or perhaps even alter their thinking.As usual, Christopher Nolan's direction is rock solid and there are some really beautifully acted scenes that also look fantastic.The one problem with Inception is that it drags on a little too much and makes its nifty little idea into a great big overly complex film.If, as others suggest, this film is taking a lot from the matrix, then perhaps the makers should have considered the simplicity of the plot to the original matrix.A great film, and very entertaining, but the idea is overdone a little too much for my taste.
summary: Very good, but overstays its welcome

reviewText: If you didn't like the Matrix, you might skip this one. Dicaprio is man who is an expert at entering dreams and extracting information for corporate espionage. He has a problem in that there is a price on his head. He is a wanted man. A Japanese business man wants Dicaprio to enter the mind of a competitor and place an idea in his head to break up his empire. In exchange Dicaprio (Dom Cobb) would be allowed to go home to his family. Cobb first gets an architect (Ellen Page) who can design a complex location, such as a dungeon master creating the stage. He then must assemble a team of people with different skills to navigate through the dream world.The beginning of the movie is a bit confusing as you don't know what is real and what is a dream. However this shortly clears up. Dom Cobb has a lot of issues concerning his past life and dreamworld which jeopardizes the mission. His dead wife keeps showing up to foil his plans and he just hasn't the heart to kill her. The dreamworld works like a narcotic. Once you go into it, reality becomes boring. This movie is more brilliant in its complexity and script than it is in entertainment, but it worked for me.

reviewText: Christopher Nolan has done it again, he has made a movie that will be remembered many years from now. When I saw this in theaters, I, a lot like you, was confused to the plot and what was going on. Then watching it again on dvd, the movie made perfect sense. I understood the whole diamic of the movie, the characters and more importantly the story.This film has done something rarely seen in movies today...done something original. The special affects are stunning, the acting almost as good and the story (after watching a 2nd time) great. Its near flawless...the problem...You need to watch it a second time to fully understand everything. If only it wasnt confusing the first time around. But I still think this is a must own dvd even though the special features arent as good as they should be.Basically its one feature split into 4 subjects:Four Focus Points-*The Inception of Inception: Christopher Nolan shapes his unusual concepts for Inception*The Japanese Castle: The Dream Is Collapsing: Creating and destroying the castle set*Constructing Paradoxical Architecture: Designing the staircase to nowhere*The Freight Train: Constructing the street-faring freight trainThey could have had thrown in maybe deleted scenes and commentary but beggers cant be choosers.Pros:-Stunning visual affects-Great storyline-Great actingCons:-You need to watch this a second time to fully understand the story-Lack of special features
summary: One of my 5 favorite movies of the year

reviewText: I am a movie collector.  It's getting harder to find movies to add to my collection that are not boring, predictable, disgusting or offensive.  This great movie is none of these.  Complex, multi-layered plot (no spoilers here) intense action, beautiful cinematography.  Plot is at times a bit hard to follow, but this is a good thing.  But not a movie to have on when you're walking around the room, catching up on your e-mail, or talking on the phone.What I liked:  mind-bending plot is a refreshing change from same-old, same-old, dumbed-down movie fare these days.  Cinematography is fantastic (opening Chinese castle scene is my favorite).  Action is very intense, but nary a car being blown up (for once).  DiCaprio is very good, and good supporting cast.  Could name lots more.What I didn't like:  I can't think of much, my rating is that this film is definitely a cut above the usual fare.  But the multi-layered plot-within-a-plot-within-a-plot could be too involved for some viewers to follow, especially if they just want to relax with some predictable action fare, that doesn't make you pay too close attention to enjoy it.  And if dreams have bad associations for you, rather than good, you might find some of the themes in this movie disturbing.  None of these factors were a detraction for me, but just trying to be balanced.Smart, cool, intense, original, great to look at.  Give me more movies like this.
summary: complex and interesting, for once . . . . thank you hollywood!

reviewText: What can I add that others haven't already said? Do you like Sci-Fi? Do you like action? Do you like to figure things out during a movie?A while back, a friend of mine pooh-poohed this movie after seeing it in the theatre yet a couple days ago, had a much more positive opinion when I said we watched it. I bought it with some skepticism after what she had told me originally (without her spoiling it in advance).So I told my wife what our friend had said....before we watched it...Then we watched it and wondered if our friend had her head up her butt when she saw it.I can't give it an A+....but it is better than just an A. This movie is almost fantastic. The cast is great. The story is great. The action is fun. There are some things that were a little predictable, BUT since you're so busy keeping up with the movie, you don't mind it one bit, in fact you kind of enjoy the fact you've figured some of it out just a little beforehand so you can enjoy the action.and near the end....when you get there....you're busy thinking ok...where in the heck were we....and then whoomp you're there just before you recall....which is nice...and there you are...and you finally BREATHE....because you were holding your breath.and the best part is that question left in your mind at the end....Is it Live or is it Memorex? which you'll understand after you see it.Definitely glad I bought this one as it's definitely worth seeing more than once to pick up what you missed before thanks to the fast pace at times.Buy it, you'll like it.which reminds me....yet another movie with Michael Caine that doesn't disappoint. I simply can't recall him ever being in a bad movie and he was actually the deciding factor for me buying this.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***Before Leonardo DiCaprio agreed to play the lead part in 'Inception', he spent months with Christopher Nolan trying to improve the script. It was at DiCaprio's insistence that the part he was playing, Cobb, the corporate dream extractor, had to have a more beefed up internal arc. Otherwise, Inception would turn out to be another shallow, action adventure thriller. Despite Cobb's triumph over his internal demons (particularly the way in which he expunges his dead wife, who has been haunting him in his subconscious), Inception is much more an exploration of the mechanics of dreaming than a chronicle of emotional catharsis.At the basic level, Inception can be divided into four distinct parts: Intro, Exposition, Journey and Resolution. The Intro consists of the initial scene, a flashback where Cobb must save his employer, a sleazy Japanese businessman, Saito, now far advanced in years, who has been stuck in a limbo-like purgatory for decades, unaware that he was mortally wounded in someone else's dream. It's a nice, little compact scene where we see a near-dead Cobb, washed up on a beach and dragged into Saito's fortress compound. A gun is left on the table in front of Saito and we're trying to figure out whether Saito is going to kill Cobb or himself.Cut to the next scene where Cobb and his associate are involved in a trying to extract information from a much younger Saito inside one of his dreams, as they all sleep on a bullet train somewhere in Japan. Apparently, Saito was expecting the dream extractors and informs them that this is their 'audition'; the extractors' 'architect', the guy in charge of designing the dreamworld, somehow lets things get out of control when a mob of men invade the room where they're all staying, and Saito later has his thugs toss the architect off the roof of a heliport. Despite the botched job, Saito is impressed that Cobb and his partner are able to move through different 'levels' in the dreamworld. Cobb's 'audition' could have been compressed into one or two minutes but Nolan insists on illustrating every aspect of his convoluted plot. We finally arrive at the film's inciting incident: Saito's proposal to Cobb that he enter the dream world of his business rival, Fischer, and plant a suggestion in his subconscious, leading to the dissolution of the rival's entire business empire. 'Inception' is the reverse of what Cobb and his team have been trained to do--extracting information and Cobb has doubts about successfully carrying out Saito's proposal. But when Saito promises to pull some strings, enabling Cobb to return to the United States, despite murder charges hanging over his head, Cobb can't resist jumping at the chance to see his two children again.The next part of 'Inception', the 'exposition', takes about an hour. This is where Cobb assembles his new carefully selected "Mission Impossible" superstar team who will penetrate Fischer's mind and plant the suggestion to break up his dying father's business empire. Nolan's explanation of the mechanics of the dreamworld is so complicated, that he has Cobb explain it to his new architect, a naive graduate student who manages to acquit herself rather well despite facing major obstacles inside multiple dreamworlds. Nolan manages to violate a major tenet of screen writing technique: Show don't tell. Unfortunately, during these expository sequences, there's a lot more 'tell' than 'show'. Yes, there is a rather neat scene (reminiscent of an M. C. Escher illustration), where one Paris landscape folds on top of another but most of the visuals are much more mundane: for example, a speeding locomotive appears out of nowhere during a car chase on a Paris street.Much has been written about the 'journey' aspect of 'Inception'. Critics seem to be impressed by the three dreamworlds the 'dream team' penetrates, coupled with the way in which they're able to return to reality--the so-called 'kicks', where a huge sound or explosion propels them through the different levels back up to the surface. Nolan, however, serves up some of the dullest and derivative landscapes that our 'heroes' must navigate through--in fact, these so-called dreams don't look like dreams at all. Take Level 1--just a typical shoot em up with faceless bad guys chasing the 'good guys'. As for level 2--I felt I was watching a parody of Space Odyssey, with our dreamers floating through a hotel without the benefit of gravity. Finally, I have heard 'Level 3', compared to 'Ice Station Zebra', the schlocky 60s action film set in the Arctic.Inception's Resolution is as unsatisfying as the earlier parts of the film. What are we to make of Cobb? Just because he has made this deal with Saito and it enables him to see his children, does not mitigate the fact that the whole plan to literally change Fischer's mind, is reprehensible. After all, shouldn't have Cobb walked away when Saito had his men murder the first architect? Cobb, by and large, remains a tainted and unsympathetic character, precisely because he looks the other way when he's quite aware that Saito has committed murder.We're also told (by Saito) that the breakup of Fischer's empire is a good thing but should we take his word for it? He's a thug and Nolan has provided us nothing to go on to evaluate the nature of the Fischer empire. Finally, why does Fischer cry at his father's deathbed? He's just learned that his father put his mother in a mental institution so shouldn't he be angry? Or are those tears of joy so that he can be now 'his own man'?The bulk of 'Inception' is merely a pastiche of mediocre action adventure espionage thrillers dating back to the 60s when the genre was in full bloom. The long-winded 'B' story, Cobb's tortured machinations in trying to literally kick his dead wife out of his subconscious mind, merely serves to distract us from the hollowness of the overall plot.

reviewText: Suppose you lived in a world that possessed the technology to invade others dreams? What if that power allowed you to dive into the deepest depths of the human mind? From Christopher Nolan's mind comes Inception.This is the story of a man whose job is to invade people's dreams in order to plant ideas into others minds and take them for the purposes of business. Yet, his history of his work is much deeper than what people know. He now has to take on one final task with a new recruit and his best team to find one of the most important ideas that can change the modern world.This film is probably one of the most well put together that came out this year. The actors chosen all played their roles beautifully. Joseph Gordon Levitt was probably the best of the bunch as he always seems to astound me with all his recent work. What can be said about DiCaprio that hasn't these past few years? Ellen Page always brings her "A" game and this time it is no different. Still, this movie is not going to appeal to everyone. This movie really makes you think, and unless you pay close attention you are surly to get lost. I would realistically give Inception 3 stars just because it doesn't appeal to a mass audience. Still, the movie is well acted and well executed and it is definitely worth seeing

reviewText: Inception is a film that needs to be watched again and again to truly appreciate it. Not that the first viewing is any less intense or superb, but you notice much more the second time around. Inception may seem confusing but it in fact has a very simple premise: Attempt to steal vital information out of a person's subconscious, while dreaming. I have no idea why some people were perplexed about this film. If you pay attention from beginning to end, there should be no confusion and very little questions. It really isn't that hard to follow which surprised me. It may seem disoriented at first but as long as you keep watching and stay focused, you should have no problems. And the ending, though made to clearly aggrivate alot of people, was a no-brainer. And for people still disputing it, Christopher Nolan has come out and explained it and it is precisely what I originally thought happened.This film is a team effort and everyone does a phenomenal job. DiCaprio is spot-on, as usual but it is actually Joseph Gordon-Levitt who has some of the film's more exciting scenes. Inception is non-stop from the first scene and truly is one of those edge-of-your-seat type films. The editing is superb, the visual effects, cinematography and musical score is near perfection. Again, to say much more about the film would be to ruin it, and no doubt in my mind it was the most exhilerating and just plain awesome cinematic experience of 2010.

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Chris Nolan's "Inception" is like a giant puzzle and, as such, those that are interested in puzzles will probably enjoy this movie more than those who hate puzzles.Chris Nolan tackles some dark and stormy themes as part of his exceptional science fiction thriller "Inception" reminding us why he's one of the most talented and challenging mainstream film directors. Cobb (DeCaprio) leads a team involved in corporate espionage invading the minds of others taking their ideas for his employers. After one deal goes bad he gets an unusual offer from Saito (Watanabe); Saito wants Cobb and his team to plant an idea in the mind of Robert Fischer (Murphy) that will give Saito's company an advantage in the marketplace. Cobb knows the risks though as Inception can rarely be done and pulled off but he has his own motive pushing him to succeed; Cobb wants to be able to come home to America and see his children again after being on the run for years. ***Anchored by a strong, complex performance by DeCaprio and his supporting cast, "Inception" would seem doomed to failure simply because of the mulitple plot strands that weave around each other in the film. Nolan has accomplished a rare and unique feat (that he's managed to pull off before but not with such a complex narrative); he has created a summer blockbuster film with a brain and a heart that also has all the muscles of an action thriller. He may occasionally almost miss catching one of the many balls that he is juggling but the deft exposition of the film in the first half (and using the clever plot device of having Page play a novice to the team allowing us to learn at the same time about how the team operates) and action packed second half more than make up for any slip in the storytelling illusion that Nolan pulls off here. ***As a thriller "Inception" has more in common with "Insomnia", "Memento" and "The Prestige" than it does with "Batman Begins", "The Dark Knight" or even Nolan's first film "Following". He takes all the lessons he's learned from those films and puts them to excellent use here crafting a film that constantly keeps the audience on its toes even in the conclusion of the film which leaves the resolution open to interpretation.As with all of Nolan's films, "Inception" looks marvelous with a distinct look to each "layer" of the film. It's pretty amazing what Nolan creates visually in collaboration with his director of photography considering that he is color blind. The Blu-ray receives an equally strong presentation here as it did in theaters. Colors pop with a distinct visual style for each level of the dream a challenge for both audiences and the production team. The transfer looks amazingly sharp with a crisp, detailed transfer that has very good depth. I didn't see any hint of edge enhancement nor did I see any other digital flaws aside from occasional digital noise that cropped up and that was relatively minor. ***The audio is equally impressive with a lossless audio transfer, nice use of the surround speakers to create the environment of the film.Watching the extras in the "Extraction Mode" is probably the best way to experience the extras included on the Blu-ray. The option allows one to watch the film while watching the various extras like Nolan who appears in a picture-in-picture special feature providing a nice companion piece to the film itself. I wouldn't watch it this way the very first time of course. You can watch the special features separately as well. There are long periods where the "Extraction Mode" doesn't have anything though so be prepared--you might find yourself drawn back into the movie only to be extracted again by having it pop up. Nolan doesn't explain the meaning (he leaves that up the individual viewer much as we interpret our own dreams) but does discuss the techniques about HOW he acheived many of the impressive effects of the movie (yes, Nolan uses CGI but he doesn't use it as his MAIN tool like a lot of directors might but as one of many preferring where possible to use onset physical effects where possible. ***We get one documentary on the making of the film that veer off into interesting, different and sometimes challenging directions much like the film itself. "Dreams: Cinema of the Subconscious" features actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt as host of a sometimes trippy examination of the subject bringing in a variety of folks from experts on dreaming to Nolan tying it back into the film itself. It runs just under 45 minutes. ***We also get a prequel that explains why Cobb is on the run with "The Cobol Job" running just under 15 minutes. This motion comic is a nice background piece for those who must know everything and can't take it on faith as to why Cobb was on the run from Cobol and how it forced him into Saito's waiting arms. ***BD-Live material is represented by Project Somnacin: The Confidential Files and we get a generous amount of pre-production artwork and promotional artwork. The extras are rounded out by the trailers and TV ads. All of these special features are presented in HD. -Whether or not you like "Inception" will depend on what you select a movie for--entertainment, a puzzle that challenges you, enlightenment and how you determine whether or not films like "Inception" play a role in all of that. Having said that, "Inception" will not be to everyone's taste. I like the movie quite a bit although I still feel it is flawed but even with those flaws it is better than the most of the summer swill that Hollywood usually has fed us in the past.Chris Nolan has often been accused (like Stanley Kubrick) of creating films that have no heart, no soul and that focuses on the intellect only but if you dig beneath the surface you will find that the film does have a heart and soul. Nolan manages to plant a smart, stylish thriller in theaters just as it looked as if we would be facing a limbo of dry, empty thrillers without no heart and no soul.
summary: "Inception" - a giant puzzle of a movie

reviewText: Inception is such a profound, imaginative, complex movie that it is difficult to describe.  I'm sure this very complexity is off-putting to some, but those of you are serious sci-fi buffs, Inception is a must-see.  It is just one brilliant piece of movie-making that grabs you and takes you on a very complex ride until the end and then leaves you still wondering.  Beautifully written, wonderfully acted, perfectly cast, everyone does their job well.  If you haven't seen it, then get it and take the ride.  It will be worth it.

reviewText: Right from the start, the plot was very hard to follow (with sub-plots between Di Caprio and his wife that were equally, if not more so, hard to follow/swallow), and although there are a lot of cool special effects, and lots of action, this movie is devoid of a believable premise.  The dreamworld in Inception - which consisted of a series dreams within dreams scene's - was way over-the-top, leaving the movie watcher wondering at any particular moment during the movie, "where was the scene was taking place: is it reality, or a dream, or a dream within a dream, or a dream within a dream within a dream?"  This movie ends up being nothing more than a poorly conceived twist of the Matrix, or more specifically, a "Matrix Wannabe" type movie -- it attempts to do with dreams what Matrix did with a virtual world created by computers, but fell sadly short.  I couldn't wait for the embedded dream events (dreams within-dreams) to unwind, and for the movie to be over.  Ironically, this movie puts forth the idea that five minutes in reality is about an hour in dream-time, and although this movie is approx. 2.5 hours long, it felt like well over 10-hrs to me .... and when done, it then left me wondering, whose dreams are they anyway?

reviewText: I found this movie a confused jumble.  It was one of those "huh?" movies.  It was often unclear who the good guys and bad guys were or what exactly was happening.  This was one of the rare sci-fi movies that we watched, then tossed.  The effects were very good, but I found this movie to be all effects with little substance.  That can be okay with even a predictable, rudimentary story, as long as the story is clear and can be followed.  Unfortunately, the elements of good storytelling were largely missing from this movie, and the effects, good as they were, couldn't carry it.  I'm a lifelong sci-fi can, and if you want real sci-fi, get Alien or Terminator and skip this one.

reviewText: I went into this movie expecting more than it delivered.  It is not a horrible film, and director Nolan certainly deserves much credit for the inventive, creative and artistic elements.  However, my problem with the movie boils down to not enough special effects and too many scenes where the characters are standing around talking, not doing anything.  At over 2 & 1/2 hours long, there ARE several SFX scenes within Inception, but not nearly as many as the trailer leads you to believe (the street cafe and crumbling-cliff-skyscraper scenes previewed in the trailer are the two main ones), and in between SFX are long passages of talking.  The blurb description of "Bond meets The Matrix" has some relevance, as this film has several things in common with those two series.  For example, the "snow fortress" scene has seemingly endless shots of guys on snowmobiles shooting machines guns, a la Bond, and one of the "Dream Team" morphs into another character a la The Matrix.  (Just two examples of many similarities I could list.)  However, I didn't enjoy Inception nearly as much as either The Matrix movies at their best, or the best Bond flicks.  The strongest section of Inception was the final 15 minutes or so, where the multiple layers of dreams have to pull together for the good guys to survive, but even THAT was interrupted by a too-long, talky parting scene between the DiCaprio character and his wife, where they seem to be just repeating the same lines for about 10 minutes!  I once read a critic's guideline that you could tell how good a movie is by how many times you checked your watch.  The fewer times, the better.  (No watch-checking at all means a really engrossing move.)  I must have checked my watch at least a dozen times during Inception.  I also saw a few people get up and walk out of the movie, not returning.  I predict this flick will have some negative word of mouth from people like me expecting a big summer sci-fi movie but getting a drawn-out head trip instead.
summary: Mind-bending, but too long & too talky

reviewText: If you thought parts II and III of "Back to the Future" were hard to follow (I didn't), wait until you try to wrap your mind around "Inception". It's an extremely entertaining film, if only because it keeps your brain on the edge of its seat (so to speak), but it doesn't stand up to close scrutiny.The principal difficulty is that, in wanting to make a film about dream states, and moving from his initial horror-film approach to one of straight drama, Christopher Nolan painted himself into a corner. The central dramatic conflict is between Cobb and his guilty memories of his dead wife, whom he accidentally influenced to commit suicide by convincing her of the unreality of their shared experience during an extended dream sequence they were trapped in. When she's finally convinced and "commits suicide" (along with Cobb) so they can exit, she's become /so/ thoroughly convinced of the "unreality" of everything, that she later kills herself in the real world.This points to the film's major problem -- Nolan has to /arbitrarily/ define those dream-state conditions and actions needed to make the story unfold as he wishes. The /drama/ is legitimate, but the mechanisms that ultimately incite it are tautologies, not extrapolations from what's known about dreaming -- and therefore unconvincing. (The script sometimes resembles Rick Berman dialog.)The worst of these problems involves lucid dreaming. Lucid dreamers (I'm one), can control most of their dreams. If someone shoots a gun, the bullet is unlikely to cause pain or damage. Yet Saito -- who knows he's in a dream -- is shot and bleeds. Similarly, the laws of physics cannot apply to someone during a lucid dream. We see the characters changing their environments simply by thinking about it -- but they don't walk through walls, teleport, or leap tall buildings in a single bound. If one impossible thing is possible (such as "mentally materializing" a potent weapon, when needed), then /every/ impossible thing should be possible. There can't be exceptions.I'm reminded of Gene Roddenberry reminding "Star Trek" writers that "Marshall Dillon doesn't stop to explain how a gun works." Christopher Nolan makes a heroic effort to minimize explanations, but "Inception" suffers from having to have almost everything explained to the viewer. The result is that much of "Inception" looks like a concoction.If you're wondering why the young woman is named Ariadne -- look it up. And the "totem" that Cobb carries is a "teetotum". Versions with numbers around the edge were used in games during the 19th century (possibly earlier).Still, "Inception" is entertaining (though I wouldn't call it "fun"), and you're likely to watch it at least twice, if only to try to figure out the things that didn't make sense the first time around. Some of the special effects are mind-boggling. The supplemental material on a second disk is good, but doesn't give an extremely detailed description of the film's -- uh -- inception and development.

reviewText: This movie works in more ways than I can even think to name. Start with the start power: Leonardo DiCaprio in the lead role, Ellen Page playing the most mature part I've seen so far, an under-used Michael Caine, Ken Watanabe, and more.The action plays out in the dreams of the heir to an industrial empire. The goal: to get him to shut it down. Despite the obvious risk of degenerating into psychobabble, this stays true to its action theme, even when levels of reality start to layer like pastrami on rye. The victim, it turns out, has unexpected defenses. The attacker, it turns out, has unexpected weaknesses. And Page's character, Ariadne, takes on the role of her mythic namesake in unwinding the labyrinths of architecture and mind - not that this movie makes clear distinction.This could have become an effects-flick, as shown in Ariadne's intro to the dreamworld - possibly the most dramatic urban dreamscape sinceDark City. That setpiece really just served to show the effectmeister's general restraint, except on the few scenes where the enhancement really mattered. Instead, the movie relies on plot, action, and acting - a refreshing change from so many summer films of recent years.The multi-reality backdrop worked well, on the whole, but might become clearer on a second viewing. No matter. "Inception" works well as a summer popcorn movie, but works well at other levels too. For once, it's a summer movie I'll remember even when summer is gone.-- wiredweird

reviewText: Chris Nolan's "Inception" has been reviewed here endlessly so I'll just make a few points:It's good, and actually enjoyable on the second viewing - it's just too much of a headache trying to keep up on the first watch. It's not just the multiple layers of action involving the same characters on seperate planes that is tough, but somewhere I began losing my grip on why the characters were doing what they were doing.There are some things that require suspension of disbelief, like why Arthur would go back into a dream scenario with Cobb after a peice of Cobb's subconscience assaults him in the form of his dead wife by shooting Arthur in the leg within the dream. The very end was not actually disappointing as it was slightly annoying - kind of gimmicky and very Hollywood in terms of "twist endings". I suppose if Nolan hadn't edited it the way he did fans might have said he should have. I never really cared enough about the characters to have an opinion on that, DiCaprio is good but never really likeable.But the only thing I found more than a little disappointing is that for a film using dreams as a battleground there isn't the slightest shred of the surreal. Other top 500 reviewers claim this is on par with films by David Lynch  - not by the slightest stretch of the imagination can this opinion be sustained. The film is a straight out action flick, there isn't a trace of the surreal in it. Fans of Lynch will not be impressed; I know this because I have been a great fan of Lynch since "Eraserhead" was first released in 1977, as well as other surreal films like the great "The Devil and Daniel Webster" and Bergman's "Hour of the Wolf". Flat out plot weirdness does not make a film surreal (many of Lynch's later films I also do not find surreal, so much as just weird), that is attained by a particularly sensitive kind of filmmaking."Inception" is a good solid action film with some weird sci-fi graphic elements that are reminiscent of "Dark City" (which is more surreal, by far), and though it places continuous demands on the viewer's attention span, it is well made. I can't say it was 'fun', but it's a good trip and worth checking out if you have time to watch it twice.

reviewText: INCEPTION--a pretty good film at first viewing, but it needs a few screenings in order to figure out all the nuances, twists, and clever script. Then, with each viewing, the film gets better and greater. Christopher Nolan does [it] again. Whereas he brought the "real world" to superhero movies with THE DARK KNIGHT he brings it to this Science-Fiction/Heist/Thriller/Corporate Espionage film through his cinematography, production, and script. As in all great "heist"-type films, the key is a great ensemble cast. Leonardo DiCaprio is the lead, but he is backed with the likes of Ellen Page, Ken Watanabe, Tom Hardy, Dileep Rao, Cillian Murphy and an actor who has grown so much since his days from the tv series THIRD ROCK FROM THE SUN, Joseph Gordon-Levitt (who looks uncannily like the late Heath Ledger, that, should Chris Nolan decide to do more Batman-sequels, should cast Levitt as "The Joker" for a re-match as the antagonist/villian). Also in the cast, Lukas Haas, Michael Caine, Pete Postlewaite, and good to see veteran Tom Berenger in the mix.  INCEPTION loosley resembles a forgotten 1984 Dennis Quaid thriller DREAMSCAPE with nods to TOTAL RECALL and THE MATRIX, with an ensemble-type atmosphere resembling the films of HEAT and RONIN. The pseudo-science, suspense, and special effects of dream worlds all blend well together for a great sci-fi thriller. Once again, DiCaprio turns in another intense performance (one of his best since THE DEPARTED), and Christopher Nolan is just an amazing filmmaker.

reviewText: Christopher nolan uses foreshadowing to play with viewers expectations. Leonardo Dicapro deserves this. Inception keeps a balance of good acting and cgi. Both the acting and the cgi steal the show. If you are really into the art of filmaking, Inception is not something you want to miss out on. As I explain Inception to you, and what it expresses and how it may appeal to your senses. SPOILERS BELOW!!!!!STORYThis movie is sort of an IQ test. Inception's story may be the most complex story you'll ever have to go on. Many things are thrown at you. You will be trying to focus on one thing, and you'll think you understand everything, well no. There is so many things you have to look into when watching this film, and trying to understand its flow. Former dream architect Dominic "Dom" Cobb and business partner Arthur perform corporate espionage using an experimental military-developed machine to infiltrate the subconscious of their targets and extract information while dreaming, their latest target being Japanese businessman Saito. Tiered dream within a dream strategies are used and dreamers awaken by a "kick" such as falling or by dying in the dream. If the dreamer is the one who awakens, the dream "collapses". Each extractor carries a totem, a small object the behavior of which is only predictable to its owner, used to determine whether a dreamer is in someone else's dream. Cobb's totem is a spinning top that perpetually spins in the dream state. The extraction fails due to Mallorie "Mal" Cobb, Cobb's deceased wife, whose memory projection sabotages the mission. Saito reveals, after Cobb's and Arthur's associate sells them out, that he was actually auditioning the team to perform the difficult act of inception: implanting an idea into a person's subconscious while they sleep.Saito wishes to break up the energy conglomerate of his ailing competitor Maurice Fischer, by planting the idea in his son and heir Robert Fischer to disintegrate his father's company. Should Cobb succeed, Saito would use his influence to clear a murder charge against Cobb, so he can return to the United States and his children. Cobb accepts the offer and assembles his team: Eames, a conman and identity forger; Yusuf, a chemist who concocts the powerful sedative for a stable dream within a dream strategy; Ariadne, an architecture student tasked with designing the labyrinth of the dream landscapes; and Arthur. Saito accompanies so that he knows whether or not Cobb and his team succeeded.When the elder Fischer dies in Sydney and his body is flown back to Los Angeles, the team share the flight with Robert Fischer and Cobb sedates him, bringing him into the shared dream. At each stage, the member of the team generating the dream stays behind to initiate the "kick", while the other members sleep within the dream to travel a level deeper. In the first level, Yusuf's rainy downtown dream, the team abducts Fischer. However Fischer's trained subconscious projections attack and severely wound Saito. Eames temporarily takes the appearance of Fischer's godfather, Peter Browning, to suggest Fischer reconsider his father's will. Yusuf drives the team in a van as they are sedated into Arthur's dream, a hotel, where the team recruit Fischer, convincing him his kidnapping was orchestrated by Browning. In the third dream level, a snowy mountain fortress dreamed by Eames, Fischer is told they are in Browning's subconscious, but they are really going deeper into Fischer's. Yusuf, under assault by trained projections, initiates his kick too soon by driving off a bridge, sending Arthur's dream world into zero-gravity and causing an avalanche in Eames' dream. Arthur improvises a new kick using an elevator that will be synchronized with the van hitting the water, while the team in Eames' dream races to finish the job before the new round of kicks.Due to the effects of heavy sedation and multi-layered dreaming, death during this mission will result in entering Limbo, dream space of unknown content where the dreamer could be trapped. Elapsed time in each dream level is roughly twenty times greater than in the level above it; in Limbo, the deepest level of all, 24 hours of outer-world time would be experienced as about half a century. Cobb reveals to Ariadne that he spent "fifty years" with Mal in Limbo constructing a world from their shared memories whilst seemingly growing old together. After returning to the waking world, Mal remained convinced she was still dreaming and committed suicide, trying to persuade Cobb to do so by retroactively incriminating him in her death. He fled the U.S. and left his children behind, ostensibly in the care of his father-in-law.Saito succumbs to his wounds, and Cobb's projection of Mal sabotages the plan by killing Fischer, sending them both into Limbo. Cobb and Ariadne enter Limbo to find Fischer and Saito, while Eames remains on his dream level to set up a kick by rigging the fortress with explosives. Cobb confronts his projection of Mal, who tries convincing him to stay in Limbo. Cobb refuses and confesses that he was responsible for Mal's suicide: having convinced her to leave Limbo by using inception to plant the idea in her mind that the world they had been living in for fifty years was not real, and hence the need to kill themselves in order to return to the real world, once back in the real world she continued to believe dying would wake her. Mal attacks Cobb but Ariadne shoots her. Through his confession, Cobb attains catharsis and chooses to remain in Limbo to search for Saito. Ariadne pushes Fischer off a balcony, bringing him back up to the mountain fortress, where he enters a safe room to discover and accept the planted idea: that his father wishes him to be his "own man", and that splitting up the conglomerate might not be a radical notion.All of the team members except Cobb and Saito ride the synchronized kicks back to reality: Ariadne jumps off a balcony in Limbo, Eames detonates the explosives in the fortress, Arthur blasts an elevator containing the team's sleeping bodies up an elevator shaft, and the van in Yusuf's dream hits the water. Cobb eventually finds an aged Saito and the two remember their arrangement, presumably killing themselves and awakening to outer-world reality on the airplane. Saito honors the arrangement and Cobb passes through U.S. customs once the plane lands in Los Angeles. Before reuniting with his children, Cobb tests reality with his spinning top, but he turns away to greet them before observing the results. As I stated earlier, this is a lot to go on, so you can't miss a single second of this film, or you will not understand its climax. Inception's story is something you won't understand the first time around.ACTINGWhy Dicaprio hasn't won an oscar for this fantastic performance? I will never understand. I mean how much better is he supposed to be? There aren't many actors out there like him these days who can become the character by putting so much expression and heart into his role. Joseph Gordon-Levitt makes the film even better. He, as an actor, supports leo's character in every way, he gives off a believable performance in support of leo. Ellen page is a fresh new actress who does her best to capture the role as the film's second protagonist. Tom hardy, I say this a lot but, Tom hardy is a great character actor who chooses the right roles. If you are looking for a persona film, Inception has multiple persona performances by each character, and is most desirable! Michael caine, same old same old.CHARACTER DEVELOPMENTThere is so much character development in the entire film. Good thing the film is long enough for you to understand the characters in the film, and what their purpose is. I can't stress this enough, PAY ATTENTION TO THE FILM!SPECIAL EFFECTS AND SETSThe cgi is one of the main aspaects that captures this film. The sets and effects are visual striking. I would imagine this film making a beautiful blu ray, unfortunatley I didn't purchase the blu ray, but the dvd. It feels as if you are in this illusionary world (No pun intended). It doesn't look fake at all, not one little bit. Of course christopher nolan had to hire the best cgi workers in the world.DVD QUALITYI purchased the dvd at a small store. I note that the dvd says "Inception", then it says "Origine". I am not sure what origine means or what language that is, but if someone could tell me I would appreciate that. Overall, the picture quality of this dvd is great, very clear, good sound, no fuss or sound issues. The film is presented in widescreen.SPECIAL FEATURES-The inception of inception- Christopher nolan shapes his unusual concept for the movie.-The japanese castle: The dream is collapsing- Creating and destroying the castle sets.-Constructing paradoxical architecture- Designing the staircase to nowhere.The freight train- Constructing the street faring express train.LANGUAGESThe languages are in english, french, and in espanol, dolby surround 5.1. Also has english subtitles for hearing impaired.SOUNDTRACKThe music is really nice in this film, it has an epic sound. A great orchestra was hired to make this film. Love the trailer music, ending music, I'm gonna see if I can find the tracks on cd anywhere.FINAL WORDInception is a film that is testing your IQ. Therefore, this film may not be for everyone if you don't like to think that hard when watching a film. However, you will be spending almost 3 hours of your time contemplating what is going on in terms of events, but in the end, it all leaves you with an inscrutable climax that will begin to make piece together all that has happened. Many people had questions in the end, because the film is like rocket science, but it's so exciting. Inception is one of those films you have to watch over and over again. Christopher nolan's vision of filmaking is pure solid geniusness! You can't miss out on a film like this, and if you have any unanswered questions, simply dig deep into the film's presence, find what you found passionate about the film, and slowly piece everything together. I will be reviewing the departed soon, so stay in touch.

reviewText: This film features one of the most innovative concepts of all-time, that of "dreams within dreams" and similar fare.  But is it a classic?  Not quite, due to some "can't quite put my finger on it" lack of overall execution.For a basic plot summary, "Inception" deals in the world of shared dreams, in which individuals (while asleep) can enter the dream of another and insert/extract information.  When an "inception" team (led by Leonardo DiCaprio) is put together for an especially difficult assignment, they must go deeper into the mark's head than ever before.In terms of grandiose ideas, "Inception" is truly a mind-boggling concept that will intrigue you right from the get-go.  The visual effects are spectacular and innovative, while the whole scope of the movie is often staggering.Here's the "problem", though: This isn't a movie that will stick with me for any prolonged period of time (and thus makes me unable to give it five stars).  The plot execution and character development just left a little too much to be desired in sacrifice to the ideas.  I can't quite put my finger on it, but (besides the incredible science fiction", "Inception" just isn't an all-time classic.Thus, while an entertaining watch, I rank "Inception" well below "The Matrix" (very similar concepts) and about on par with "Shutter Island".  Enjoy it far what it is, but don't expect it to be the greatest movie you've ever seen.

reviewText: Every time a Christopher Nolan film is released, it is hailed, en masse, to be the second coming of Christ in the form of a film. Christopher Nolan doesn't really make films though, he makes rollercoasters. Inception isn't something where anything is learned or truly examined as much as it is a brain twister. It doesn't engage the heart and mind and soul in any way very mature as much as it , more often than not, dazzles every human's reptilian hindbrain and excites it with shiny fancy gimmicks and contrived chases and little riddles to keep you busy while he pulls another trick out of his sleeve to make sure the next flash blinds you enough to not notice the lack of weight. While it was a pretty good rollercoaster or lateral thinking puzzle or at times both at once, as a film it was very little to say much about. The single emotional, as opposed to intellectual, string it tries to pull is pulled so sappily and so much like some kind of soap opera it got a bit sickening and tiring after a while (while it still "kept you guessing"). Better than The Dark Knight and Memento , not as good as Following and The Prestige.On a brighter note it did in a way rekindle a certain interest in videogames and architecture and installation art (and all three together). The music and sound design were quite nice and added effective and affecting accents to many parts; many of Zimmer's eerie drones helped create a dreamy vertigo effect. The acting was competent and the overall idea is smart even if emotionless and empty on any deeper level. The special effects were done quite well with some very striking things-- the spinning hallway being the simplest but also most interesting-- and I like that Nolan, as much as possible, wanted to avoid computer effects so that things could be done just in-camera with tricks that way, which ultimately look more "real" than just about any computer graphics can even today. Even if Nolan is nothing but a Juggler, he's one of the better jugglers.
summary: Smart and exciting, but heartless and meaningless

reviewText: I found this film to be very confusing and tedious to watch.  It requires you to use too much of your brain power and it doesn't really offer you an escape from the world. It only makes you over-analyze existance and ruins the whole experience of dreaming, which should remain a mystery.  To make matters worse, Inception morphs into a brainless action movie towards the end, with car chases, explosions and rapid gun fire.  Not my cup of tea.
